Title: French troupe of poetry whisperers comes to Bengaluru
Content: Do you think that whispering sweet nothings in your loved one’s ears is mundane? Picture this: You suddenly meet someone on the road, who murmurs poetry in your ears. Curious as it may sound, Les Souffleurs — Commandos Poétiques (the whisperers) are coming to Bengaluru for the first time with their poetic secrets and surprise interventions. Nine artistes from the French collective are currently touring four cities in India with their unique project, called Jaan.So, what do they whisper? They will slowly recite select verses of poetry by Indian poets. Interestingly, the group comprises comedians, writers, dancers, theatrepersons and musicians. They usually pop up in public spaces and act through poetry and quiet choreographies. In India, they are enacting in four languages — English, Hindi, Urdu and Bengali. The artistes have previously performed in Spanish, Italian, Arabic, Hebrew, Portuguese, Turkish, Romanian and Japanese. The Bengaluru chapter is presented by Chennai-based arts collective, Prakriti Foundation, in collaboration with the Institut français India.Describing it as a flash mob of poetry, Meera Krishnan, of Prakriti, says, “It is a unique project that intends to make poetry more accessible in public places. This is mainly for common citizens who either do not have access to a library or are too confined in their day-to-day activities and can barely manage time to pick up a book to read.” The whisperers mainly perform via gestures, installations and writings. The artistes murmur poetic, philosophical and literary secrets in the passers-by’s ears with the intention “to create slowdowns into the beating heart of cities, restore the meaning behind each poetry verse and adopt a tender, benevolent and furtive gesture in common public spaces”.“People tend to find opening poetry books much more difficult compared to novels or political texts. This allows the audience to discover a therapeutic literature through poetry. They can expect curiosity, discovery and lots of love. We whisper beyond castes and distinctions,” say the artistes, adding, “Through our silence and slow pace, along with the tumult of contemporary Indian society, we try to create a poetic counterpoint — the blaring horns vs the whispers. And somewhere the point between these horns and our whispers is where we find harmony, jaan.”In Bengaluru, they will perform at Cubbon Park, alternative art hubs, as well as co-working spaces from February 2 to 4.

Title: When Kudla celebrated the spirit of Kambala
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Karavali thrives in celebrating its unique culture and traditions, and Kambala holds a prime spot in this scheme of things. One such race was recently held on the outskirts of Mangaluru . The annual Rama Laxmana Jodukere Kambala is usually held at night, and it goes on till the wee hours of the following day. The race is divided in six categories – Naegilu Hiriya, Naegilu Kiriya, Hagga Hiriya, Hagga Kiriya, Kane Halage and Adda Halage.

Onlookers cheered and rooted for their favourites. The highlight of the event, though, were the tassels representing the tricolour that graced the horns of the participating bulls.

Title: Kirik Keerthi, Sparsha Rekha and Pawan Kumar to judge new Kannada comedy show
Content: There is no denying that comedy is a genre that works on all platforms, so, it is no wonder that Kannada television has a fair share with shows like Majaa Bharatha and Comedy Khiladigalu, among others. Joining the list is Nagso Challenge, a show hosted by Taneesha, which will have Kirik Keerthi Sparsha Rekha and Pawan Kumar as judges.Speaking about the show, director Bhuvan Shastry says, “Nagso Challenge is not only limited to standup comedy, skits, mimicry or mono acting, which are currently seen on television. Contestants can do whatever act they want, according to their creatviity, but they have to do it in four minutes, without resorting to double entendre. The idea is to present comedy in its purest form, so that people of all age groups can enjoy it. In total, we have selected 26 contestants between the age groups of nine to 60 years across Karnataka, who will progress to the next round based on the judges’ opinion.”As for having Keerthi, Rekha and Pawan as judges, Bhuvan adds, “Pawan is known for his comedy in Kannada movies, while Rekha has carved a niche for herself as a versatile actor. She can guide talented contestants in the right way. Keerthi is a creative guy known for his spontaneous humour, so we zeroed on him,” he says.

Title: Flashback: Meet television’s original Ram and Sita
Content: “If life gives you many things at one point, there is always a balance that it strikes at another point. You have to take life as it comes,” says actor Arun Govil , who is best known as television’s original Lord Ram. It’s been three decades since Ramanand Sagar’s 'Ramayan' aired, and the last few years have seen many versions of the epic on the small screen, but even today, his level of popularity remains unmatched. However, as Govil admits, along with the highs, he has also experienced lows. In an exclusive chat with BT, the actor opens up about how he could never return to the world of films and TV after playing Lord Ram , the lure of politics and why he prefers to keep away from showbiz now. Excerpts:The fact that someone is asking me about my role 31 years after the show ended, proves that people still consider me the best version of Ram on screen. (Writer-director Ramanand) Sagar sir’s 'Ramayan' had an impressive cast, the script was outstanding, the performances were good and above all, his belief in 'Ramayan' made all the difference. After our show ended, many others, including Sagar sir’s sons, made shows on the epic. However, I felt that their casting was not as good. I could be termed old-school, but I believe that the content of a mythological or historical show should not be tampered with. Technologically, we are more advanced today, but our show was supreme in terms of content.That’s true. I had started my career as a Hindi film hero and post Ramayan, when I wanted to return to Bollywood, the producers said, ‘Your image as Ram is so strong, we cannot cast you as anyone else or give you a supporting role.’ They felt that I was not suited for commercial movies anymore. That became the biggest minus point of my career, and I realised that I could never return to showbiz the way I wanted to. I took up a few TV shows, but every time I did something, people rejected me saying, ‘Arre, Ramji kya kar rahe hain’. I was disappointed and there was a question mark on my career. On one hand, a single show had earned me immense love and admiration, but on the other, my career came to a standstill. I worked for a few more years before putting a full stop to my career in showbiz. For the last 14 years, I have not done anything, except maybe make a few special appearances. I have not given up on acting completely, but I will do something only if it is good.I turned towards my guru, who evoked my interest in spirituality and the study of mantras. It’s not that I have turned cynical because I got a raw deal. One has to take life as it comes. If life gives you many things at one point, there is always a balance that it strikes at another point. I am not jobless now; it’s just that it was not important to continue acting. There has never been a situation where I had to worry about running the family. I have always had the faith that I can support myself. I remember, after the audition for 'Ramayan', I had requested Sagar sir for Ram’s role, but they had already chosen someone else. They asked me if I was ready to play Lakshman or Bharat, but I declined. Then suddenly, one day, they told me that I was playing Ram. If you are sure about yourself and what you want, you will succeed.I have been receiving offers to join politics since 1988. In the last elections, too, I received a tempting offer. Anybody who aspired for a career in politics would have grabbed it. I was also a bit inclined towards it, but somehow, it did not materialise. Also, I am too straightforward for politics. If I don’t like something, I will say it openly and that does not work in politics. I realised that I would not be able to sustain a political career and so, I opted out. Many people advised me to capitalise on my image as Ram and join politics, but that’s not me. I don’t believe in trading. I also believe that there is no limit to what people want in life. Even if I accepted the offer, then what? I would have wanted to move on to something else and the cycle would continue. I have reached this point after understanding the importance of life. The lesser I get involved, the lesser the stress and complications.I don’t socialise much. I can sit idle and alone for four-five hours, and still enjoy it. I watch films and read fiction and non-fiction books. In fact, I have started reading Hindi literature again. People still fall at my feet and it is very embarrassing when they have tears in their eyes on seeing me.I don’t understand the content on TV now, though technically, they have grown by leaps and bounds. The actors are good and hard-working, but there is no story or logic in the shows. People ask why TV shows are dragging, it is because viewers continue to watch them. We need finite shows. I was offered many roles to play the father, but they were not meaningful at all.It is not necessary that two co-actors have to be friends. Dipika and I would talk only about work and that was fine.She was literally worshipped across the country when she played Sita in 'Ramayan'. And then, she entered politics as a Member of Parliament (from 1991 to 1996). Dipika Chikhlia Topiwala says that she had received “everything on a platter”. But post her marriage to industrialist Hemant Topiwala, she preferred to focus on her personal life and disappeared from the limelight. Now, as she gears up for her second innings in showbiz, Dipika talks to BT about how the image of Sita worked against her, why she quit politics and her future plans. Excerpts...There were pros and cons of portraying Sita. I became a household name, but the image of Sita went against me because after that, I was offered similar roles on TV. I wasn’t glamourous like Zeenat Aman or Hema Malini, and maybe that’s why I was not approached for big roles in films. After a long time, I took up a role in a historical show because it gave me a chance to do something different. I also moved to regional cinema, but it wasn’t easy, as I could not speak South Indian languages. After a point, I gave up.I can easily say that I am destiny’s child. Fame, TV shows and even a career in politics came on a platter, but the day I got married, my dreams changed and my other ambitions took a backseat. I wanted to be a hands-on mom. Being a politician would not have allowed me to be at home when my daughters needed me. I was also working with my husband at that time and he suggested that I stick to one thing. So, after I finished my term in the Parliament, I gave up my seat. I did win the election, but I had developed cold feet and got nervous about becoming a politician. However, exiting politics did not bother me as much as lack of quality roles did. Also, the urge to be at home and play the role of a wife and mother was so strong that I felt it was best to give it all up.When we did a show in those days, we never took up any other work. So, it never clashed with my image and that’s why perhaps, our roles are still remembered. The actresses are good now, but they look like heroines and not the characters that they are playing. The glamour element is stronger than looking the part. In those days, I refrained from even wearing nail polish and lipstick and I used to chop my nails whenever I was on set. I remember Hema Maliniji calling the Sagars and telling them to ask me not to wear any lipstick, as that would make my character look more real. I don’t enjoy watching TV shows now and my attention span is less. I may watch a crime-based show, but nothing really holds my attention for long.My children are grown up now and though I don’t mind playing mother on TV, I should not just be a part of the décor in the show. The supernatural genre is dominant right now and people are watching those shows, so there is no way you can stop making them, but I will never become a naagin (laughs!). Having said I would love to do a costume drama like a mythological or historical show, and also, films.I met Arun (Govil) after 25 years at a function, and we were cordial. Sunil (Lahiri, who played Lakshman) has kept in touch and I also speak to Arvind (Trivedi, who played Ravan) sometimes. I am focussing on getting back to acting full-time since I am free now. I also enjoy doing my yoga, meditation and my regular chores.

Title: Kaanadante Maayavadanu: Kaanadante Maayavadanu is a ghost story with a twist
Content: Kaanadante Maayavadanu, which has Vikas and Sindhu Loknath in the lead, along with Achyuth Kumar, late Raghava Uday, Bhajarangi Loki, Suchendra Prasad, Dharmanna, Seetha Kote, and Siddha the dog, among others, releases across the state in over 100 theatres, today. The film, which has been produced by Back Benchers Motion Picture, including producers Chandrashekar Naidu, Som Singh, and Pushpa Som Singh, has a fantasy narrative, and features elaborate sets, CGI sequences, picturesque locales, and more, share the makers. “The one line story that Vikas and Raj Pathipati narrated is what got me hooked and made me back this film. This movie's protagonist is a ghost who is not terrifying, but funny and well-intentioned — his antics are sure to leave you laughing. The content is refreshing and the fact that there haven’t been too many Kannada films in the recent past in the fantasy genre, makes it markedly different from conventional narratives,” explains Som Singh, adding, “This movie is tailor-made for family audiences. At no point will viewers feel uncomfortable with the humour or the dialogues. It is truly for all age-groups.”

Title: Chennai Times 20 Most Desirable Men on TV 2019
Content:
Rank 2019 HOTTIES GAINERS/LOSERS IN 2019 Rank 2018 1 Kavin New Entrant - 2 Mugen Rao New Entrant - 3 Vijay Down 1 4 Tharshan Thiyagarajah New Entrant - 5 Kathirravan K Down 4 6 Prajin Padmanabhan Down 3 7 Rahul Ravi Down 5 8 Rakesh Down 7 9 Kumaran Thangarajan

New Entrant - 10 Viraat New Entrant - 11 Karthik Raj Up 15 12 Puvi Arasu Muthusamy - 12 13 Rio Raj - 13 14 Sidhu New Entrant - 15 R Shyam New Entrant - 16 Sibbu Suryan New Entrant - 17 Akshay Kamal New Entrant- 18 Arun Prasath New Entrant - 19 Rakshan - 8 20 Sanjeev Karthick - 6

Here are the guys who have made it to Chennai Times 20 Most Desirable Men on Television 2019. With an overload of talent and a huge fan following, these hot-bods ruled the television scenario, and how!Though he didn’t win the Bigg Boss Tamil 3 title, Kavin managed to win the hearts of many. The audience despised him initially, but started liking him slowly, and by the end of the show, they were, in fact, rooting for him. With a massive fan following, no wonder Kavin has been chosen as the Chennai Times Most Desirable Man On Television 2019. When we informed him of his win, he asked us whether we were playing a prank on him. “Ennoda collar-ah thooki vittutu, naan veetla Chennai Times paper-oda nadakka poren,” he laughed.This Malaysian-Tamil paiyyan was already winning hearts on Instagram with his singing skills. And he became a household name here after winning the third season of Bigg Boss Tamil. His song Enna Marantha became so popular that it has many cover versions. The young lad is quite busy with several projects in the pipeline.He has a ‘sparkling relationship with Malaysian actor Yasmin Nadiah.His soulful voice, charming smile... Okay, we’ll stop now!He charms audiences with his witty anchoring in shows like Dance Vs Dance and Singing Stars. He also dabbles as a lyricist and his Takkunu Takkunu from Mr Local is among the chartbusters he has penned.He married his best friend Monika Thangaraj last year.He was our Chennai Times Most Desirable Man On Television last year. Do we need to say more?This Sri Lankan-born started off his career here as a model. But it was his stint in Bigg Boss Tamil 3 that catapulted him to fame. Even though he didn’t win the title, Tharshan managed to sign a three-film deal with Kamal Haasan’s production house!Seems like he’s going strong with Sanam Shetty.Tall, suave and handsome — he’s that guy you just can’t stop drooling over!Kathirravan has been rocking the TV space for a while now and there’s no stopping him. His funny style of anchoring in shows like Hit List and Super Sister has found him many fans.He says that he’s single. Hard to believe, no?That smile, that charm and that beard... ooh la la!The actor won the hearts of many with his lively performance in Chinnathambi, which ended last year. He also played a pivotal role in the Malayalam film, Love Action Drama. And now, he’s busy with his next show, Anbudan Kushi.He is happily married to his sweetheart, Sandra Amy.Gaandha kannazhaga, look-u vittu-u kick-u ethum... phew!This Thrissur-based actor wowed Tamil audiences when he starred in the multilingual Nandini. He is now playing the lead in Chocolate, a remake of the Malayalam serial by the same name.Listen up, ladies, he’s apparently single!His dapper looks and his sense of style make him quite a star!It is only been a while since he made his TV debut, but this youngster has already found his way into the hearts of the viewers. He’s currently hosting Sun Singer and will also make his acting debut soon.We hear that he’s in a steady relationship. Who’s the mystery girl, we wonder.Unconventional good looks and that soft smile have got the hot-o-metre ringing!He made a big entry in TV as a dance choreographer. And then he hit it out of the park with Pandian Stores, which has made him namma veetu paiyyan in Tamil Nadu.He’s married to Suhasini, who is also an actor.This man can dance his way into your heart.This handsome hunk from Bengaluru made his Tamil television debut with Perazhagi last year. His performance has been getting a thumbs up from the audiences.: Go for him girls, he’s single.His rugged looks make women go weak in the knees.Karthik Raj has had an interesting journey in TV. His Sembaruthi is still rocking the TRPs and his performance as Adithya has helped him amass a sizeable fanbase.He’s fiercely private about his personal life.Tall, dark and handsome. Enough said!Starting off as a reality dance show contestant and then taking the plunge as an actor, Puvi Arasu has become quite the TV star already. He’s currently got the ladies impressed with his portrayal as Iniyan in Oru Oorla Oru Rajakumari.He might be single, but the love he gets from his fans makes him glow.Tamil paiyyan, daaaaaw!Rio Raj has had an eventful year, what with making his film debut with Nenjamundu Nermaiyundu Odu Raja. Even though he’s busy with films like Badri Venkatesh’s Plan Panni Pannanum, Rio continues to host TV reality shows like Dancing Super Stars.He and his wife Shruti Ravi give us some major relationship goals.Who doesn’t fall for a man who can make you laugh?Sidhu is slowly but steadily making an impression on Tamil audiences with his performance as Santhosh in Thirumanam.He’s rumoured to be dating his co-star Shreya Anchan.His boy-next-door looks and impish charm work like magic!Shyam is quite the television biggie, what with the actor starring in a host of television shows and serials. Right now, he’s busy with Eeramaana Rojaave and is also working in a couple of Tamil films.His marriage with Sandhya Nambiar is what fairy tales are made of.He’s a jolly paiyyan and sexy to boot!He’s yet another Bengaluru boy who’s made it big in Tamil television with his debut serial, Roja. Being quite the charmer, he’s bagged some awards, too, for his performance.He aces the romantic scenes, but says that he’s single.Those laugh lines. Uff!He’s new to the list, but not to the audiences. He’s been climbing up the ladder of people’s hearts steadily and is now raring to go in Rettai Roja, in which he plays the lead.Rumour is that he’s single. But you never know...Well, we can’t go past those arresting eyes...Arun takes his acting career quite seriously and has been part of several short films. He even did an important role in Meyaadha Maan. And last year, he made his TV debut in the serial, Bharathi Kannamma.That’s quite a mystery.There is something striking about him, no?Rakshan never fails to impress us with his wit. Busy with a couple of shows, including Cooku With Comali, Rakshan is also gearing up for the release of Kannum Kannum Kollaiyadithal, in which he plays an important role.He’s single, at least that’s what we think so!He has got a down-to-earth demeanour and an affable personality!Sanjeev is quite the darling of television audiences. After wrapping up Raja Rani last year, he’s back with a new serial, Kaatrin Mozhi.He tied the knot with his papu Alya Manasa last year and they are expecting their first child.A well-groomed man always gets our thumbs up!

Title: Love Mocktail: The emotions in Love Mocktail are relatable: Krishna
Content: For just over a year, actor Krishna has been busy focused on just one thing — making his dream directorial debut, which, incidentally, he has also produced along with his co-star Milana Nagaraj . Produced under his home banner, Krishna Talkies, the film, Love Mocktail, releases today and Krishna couldn’t be happier to have audiences see what he brings to the table, given that he has also written it. As the title suggests, Love Mocktail is a youthful romantic drama that follows Krishna’s character from teenage to his mid 30s and the women — three of them — in his life at various stages. While Milana is one of the heroines, the film also has Amrutha Iyengar and newbie Rachana. “I have written the script based on some of my own experiences as well as stuff I have seen and heard, so, a lot of the sequences, especially the emotions, in the film will seem relatable to audiences,” says Krishna. The story and his execution apart, the actor-director says that the music by Raghu Dixit and cinematography by Sri Crazymindz will also be highlights.

Title: Planning to go vegan? Make sure your body gets these essential nutrients
Content: Although still relatively new, veganism is fast becoming a popular dietary practice. With stores selling a variety of organic products and supermarkets offering plant-based mock meat and milk, as well as other healthy substitutes, options seem to be plenty for those who follow this ‘ethical’ trend. However, many would also agree that maintaining a vegan diet is quite challenging. People often find themselves at crossroads during the transition to opting for a wholesome vegan meal plan. Here are a few things to keep in mind before taking the plunge…“Don’t switch to veganism just because your favourite celebs are following this diet. While veganism is a healthy dietary practice, it is important to understand its ethos before opting for it,” says Kavita Devgan, a Delhi-based nutritionist, adding, “Figure out whether or not it will agree with your body. You should also be willing to spend the required time, effort, energy and money to ensure that you are maintaining the protein and nutrient levels in your vegan diet.”Once you have turned vegan, it is important to plan your diet carefully. If you relied on dairy products for calcium, you can now choose from alternatives such as ragi, soybeans, leafy greens, sesame seeds and almonds, says Sheela Krishnaswamy, a dietician and wellness consultant. “Proteins help repair your body’s tissues, muscles, hormones and enzymes. In a vegan diet, toor dal, moong, chia seeds and almonds can provide adequate amount of protein for your body. Almonds also make a great snack option, particularly when you have those between-meal hunger pangs,” she suggests, adding, “It is about ensuring that all your dietary requirements are met adequately.”“Vitamin B12 is the only nutrient that is not found in plant foods. Its deficiency in the body may cause anaemia or even lead to neurological problems. So, if you decide to turn vegan, get your Vitamin B12 levels assessed regularly and take B12 supplements, if required,” says Sheela. It is advisable to evaluate your goals before taking the plunge. Many also partially follow the diet before turning full-time vegan. “Going vegan suddenly may take a toll on your body. So, start your transition by being a part-time vegan. It’s better to take help from health experts to understand the diet better,” she suggests.

Title: Udaipur boy Nakuul Mehta marks ninth anniversary in Bikaner
Content: Be it any occasion, Rajasthan remains among the top choices of celebrities wishing for a quick getaway. Hailing from Udaipur, Nakuul Mehta, who recently celebrated his ninth wedding anniversary, decided to enjoy the occasion with his wife in Bikaner Nakuul Mehta with wife Jankee Parekh in Bikaner “Rajasthan being my home state, I don’t miss any opportunity to be back here. Moreover, it has been pretty long since I came here as I am based in Mumbai. Bikaner is a small city and has its own unique charm. The city is known for its bhujiya and I am a big bhujiya fan. I have already got packets of bhujiya and fini (sweet) packed for Mumbai,” says Nakuul.Nakuul reslishing kachori in BikanerMehta and his wife, singer Jankee Parekh, went to Bikaner to ring in the anniversary celebrations. They visited the famous Junagarh fort and explored the local markets before marking their anniversary in the evening. Nakuul shares, “It was a simple candle light dinner date. We relished the daal-bati-churma, while enjoying the magnificent view of the Gajner lake. At this time of the year, the lake becomes home to thousands of migratory birds and looks all the more beautiful. It was all we wanted. We also watched kalbelia dance performance.”Nakuul was last seen in the TV show Ishqbaaaz. Talking about his upcoming projects, he says, “Currently, I am in talks with some daily soap makers. What is important for me is that the role has to be creatively different and also something that does not give me mental fatigue. Though I have been lucky enough to be a part of shows that gave me name and fame with meaty roles, it is very difficult to reinvent yourself with daily soaps.”

Title: French troupe of poetry whisperers comes to Bengaluru
Content:
Jaan

jaan

Title: Raai Laxmi’s film will have an animated tiger for 40 minutes
Content: Cinematographer MV Panneerselvam’s debut film as a script writer, Mirugaa , which stars Raai Laxmi and Srikanth, is in its final stages. He had told us earlier that a tiger will be seen in a crucial role in the film, which is directed by J Parthiban.Now, the team has created an animated tiger which will be seen in the film for almost 40 minutes. “Usually, in our films, the portions that actually have visual effects will be for say, about five to 10 minutes. But in our film, the tiger’s footage lasts approximately 40 minutes,” says Panneerselvam, who has also shot Mirugaa.The team took several references and made dummies of the tiger, which formed the blueprint for the animated version. “Many filmmakers go to Thailand to shoot with tigers for real, or use rubber or thermocol dummies when shooting scenes with tigers, but we did not resort to any such acts. We have created the tiger in our film entirely digitally. I wanted to do this with an animation studio here rather than go abroad or Mumbai for the visual effects work,” he states.The studio that he went with was behind the recent film, Thumbaa, which also had a tiger in the central role. Quiz him as to whether the footage created for that film has also been used here, and he says, “You cannot use VFX that was done for a different film because in every shot the lighting will be different, especially when the animated tiger is a character. Work on the visual effects in this film has been going on since March 2019.” He informs that the animal will appear in three sequences in the film — in the opening sequence, the interval portion and the 40-minute climax. “The climax will have very little dialogues and will feature just four characters — the hero, the heroine, a child, and the tiger,” he says.

Title: Most Desirable Man On Television 2019: Kavin
Content:
Take three with Kavin



Rank 2019 HOTTIES GAINERS/LOSERS IN 2019 Rank 2018 1 Kavin New Entrant - 2 Mugen Rao New Entrant - 3 Vijay Down 1 4 Tharshan Thiyagarajah New Entrant - 5 Kathirravan K Down 4 6 Prajin Padmanabhan Down 3 7 Rahul Ravi Down 5 8 Rakesh Down 7 9 Kumaran Thangarajan

With a massive fan following, no wonder Kavin has been chosen as the Chennai Times Most Desirable Man On Television 2019 . When we informed him of his win, he asked us whether we were playing a prank on him. “Ennoda collar-ah thooki vittutu, naan veetla Chennai Times paper-oda nadakka poren,” he laughed. In his first interview after the reality show, Kavin tells us his experience on the show, his concept of love, and more…I have been keeping a track of the desirable coverage for the last couple of years. Last year, my friend Vijay had won and I’d wished him, too. In the main list, namma thala Anirudh had won. This time, I am surprised to see my name on the list. It makes me happy that I am part of something that boasts big names. See, when you are in the media, you would always want to be a part of such lists or award nominations, right? In that sense, I felt like I made it. But when you told me that I’ve been chosen as the Most Desirable Man on Television 2019, I honestly thought you were playing a prank. But I am glad that I’ve been chosen for the top slot. This is more like a reminder to push myself more and work hard consistently... to be responsible and sincere with my work.The idea of being desirable changes from person to person. If you’ve seen me in the show, I mostly stuck to wearing shorts and veshti. I think people could relate to me. But I should say that I felt intimidated doing this shoot (laughs). I don’t wear a suit even for a friend’s marriage. Namakku veshti dhaan… I am a quintessential Tamil paiyyan.I think so. They like my humour and I guess they admire my boy-next-door appeal. Naan paaka yaaro anniyama theriyala. I’ve become active on social media only now, but most of the comments I get for the posts are heartwarming. They call me anna or thambi. They don’t see me as an artiste.Who doesn’t enjoy such attention? We are in the acting business and it only warms your heart when you have a huge fan following. I do get a lot of comments from women for my social media posts. When I am out, some of them take pictures and selfies with me. It’s nice.Well, yes. To be a part of the show was an experience of a lifetime.You get to meet 15 or 16 people and lead your life without phone or books. Even if you plan this, it won’t happen. As humans, you usually live within a boundary… a comfort zone. I wanted to break that shell and see what happens. Though I was reclusive initially, I became my usual self over time. I learnt many things, met new people and made friends, too. I didn’t care about what was happening outside. This is not a dance or music reality show, where one needs to plan. Just like how I cry, laugh, fight with my friends and family outside, I lived my life in the same manner inside the house. I felt as if I was back in college.The first thing I did once I got back from the show was to ask my athai ponnunga about my behaviour. They said that I behaved the same way inside the house, as I do outside with them. I wanted to entertain and keep all those 15 people happy. It became a problem because it was shown on TV. But audiences took it too seriously… They liked me while playing Saravanan (in Saravanan Meenatchi) a flirty, fun guy, but not when I did it as Kavin. I usually don’t regret any of my decisions, but, if there is something at all, it is perhaps my behaviour in the house.That I didn’t change myself for anything or anyone. Like I mentioned in the show, I didn’t want to win the title. I used this more like a platform to recharge myself. I thought I went offline as I had no releases for a while and wanted people to remember me. But I am glad to hear from my friends that I remained myself and didn’t put up an act in any situation.I am single.Hmm… a lot has changed. The kind of love that I believed in when I was in school and college is different from what I think of it now. Back then, I simply wanted to settle down with a nice Trichy girl. But now, it’s different. Usually, we say that a relationship without expectations is friendship. I think that applies to love as well. Love thrives if we can accept someone the way they are and don’t expect anything in return. It should be unconditional, honest and trustworthy.I am a die-hard romantic! If I love someone, I will go any extreme to make her happy. I will look out for those small things that she would have liked as a child and forgotten. I will ask her friends or family about those tiny details and surprise her at unexpected moments. It is filmy, but I am like that.Eyes. That’s perhaps the first thing I notice in a woman. I also like women, who are simple and independent.Lack of trust!I really don’t know. Marriage is a part of our culture. I know couples who are happily married for over a decade, and those who’ve gotten divorced in six months. Married or not, all that matters is love.I am a big Thala fan. He is extremely good looking and rocks the salt-and-pepper look like nobody else. In Viswasam, he went all out with grey. He presented himself just the way he is and sported the look with confidence. Among female stars, I am an all-time Trisha fan. In Bigg Boss, there was a task that involved us taking up the role of a cinema character. Now, Trisha had shared an Insta story of a contestant’s (Losliya) 96 Jaanu’s portrayal. I appear for a nanosecond in that video. My friends told me about this and saved the video for me. My happiness knew no bounds. I am certain that Trisha doesn’t know me, but amazingly, I got be a part of that video.Well, I am doing a film now. The official announcement will be made soon. I got some film offers before I went inside the house. I made a list of people who I wanted to work with. Once I got out, I went to those same people for films. I want to do films that are entertaining.I think it’s my laugh. People would have seen on TV… I laugh wholeheartedly.Once I got back from the BB house, I saw this video about how I live. Apparently, I live in a bungalow, earn rupees 2lakh per month, am married and settled with two kids. I wanted this to be true. My life would be set, no?Nobody should come in between two people who are in love. Just listen to them when they are going through tough times — and do that without judging them. That’s the biggest gift you can give them.

Title: Noorin Shereef: Every film set scares me first, and I slowly get on track
Content: She’s just 20 years old and is still in college, but Noorin Shereef has made a name for herself within a short time. Alongside her acting profile, people also love her unconventional golden curly locks, her smile and even her mean moves on the dance floor. Noorin, who has a bunch of interesting projects in her kitty tells us about her films, her plans and more.The youngster is just done with Praveen Raj ’s Velleppam, in which she plays an artist named Kalina . “The movie is set in Velleppam Angadi of Thrissur, and revolves around the problems and lives of people in this area. My character is a Christian girl who is an outsider, and lands there to paint the famous Veliyapalli of the area. A few issues crop up around her in the church in the story,” says Noorin.The actress says that unlike the role in her first film Oru Adaar Love, this is a matured character. “In Oru Adaar Love, I mostly just had to be myself, as she too was a student my age. However, though Kalina is a playful extrovert, she is also a mature, capable person. She also has to be a lot more romantic and emotional, which was challenging for me at first. However, director Praveen chettan and the film’s team helped me immensely to handle it well,” explains Noorin.As we talk, she is gearing up to start the shoot of her next film Maradu, starring Anoop Menon and directed by Kannan Thamarakkulam. “It is based on the recent flat demolition episode in Kochi. I play someone who used to live in one of the apartments there and the movie shows what the people went through, where they go and more,” says the artiste, who had also debuted in Telugu recently. Her movie Ullala Ullala had veteran actor Satya Prakash’s son Nataraj as part of the cast. “I was scared at first, but slowly adapted to it. I guess it got easier as the production team of the film is the same as that of Oru Adaar Love’s Telugu version Lovers Day. While the experience in Malayalam is quite homely, they were all about being professional and that was quite new to me. Sometimes one would even wonder why it’s so different!” says the Kollam native. She confesses that tension grips her initially on every set. “But, I try my best to be myself and slowly, things fall in place.”Alongside her films, Noorin is also a third year BBA student at MSN College, Chavara. “I joined the college even before I turned a celebrity so it’s a comfortable space. However, it’s interesting when juniors inquire ‘Isn’t this Noorin’s college?’ (laughs).” Apparently, she has no plans to side-line education for movies. Noorin explains, “I love dance and will definitely continue with that. I also want to do good movies, but don’t want to take undue pressure on it on my head – if I get good opportunities well and good and if not, that’s cool too. I want to continue studies and find a job as well. It’s not that my life is all about movies,” says Noorin. She says that her supportive family gives her occasional motivational talks! “That’s something that keeps me going and strong,” says Noorin.The social media enthusiast often discusses her looks, especially her corkscrew locks that she boldly wears in different colours. “I don’t consider myself very pretty,” says Noorin, explaining, “But, I like to be inventive with fashion within my own limitations and go for variety make up and different hair colours. I have tried many different shades like gold, brown, mixed shades and even red – I’m crazy about it. But now, I can’t do it as much as I used to, as one has to also take it account the film that I am shooting for. I do want to try a lot more different colours and probably carry them during a promotion or so,” says the youngster, who adds she takes good care of the coloured hair. “I don’t go for permanent hair colouring, ever and always take into account whether it will affect my hair texture, etc.” Interestingly, people often ask her why not try the straight hair look. “I have tried it a few times and those who have seen me know that I look the best in my natural curls. I don’t look myself when I straighten my hair and it’s in my curls that I am the most confident,” says Noorin, who also has two movies – Meppadiyan and Chocolate 2 with Unni Mukundan , coming up.

Title: Chinmayi files nomination for the post of president of Dubbing Union
Content: The election for various posts at the South Indian Cine, Television Artistes and Dubbing Artistes Union, popularly known as the dubbing union , will be held on February 15. While Radha Ravi, whose tenure will come to an end in March, is contesting for the president’s post again, taking him head-on this time around will be Chinmayi . The singer-dubbing artiste filed her nomination yesterday.For those who’re not clued in, the dubbing union had terminated Chinmayi’s membership in 2018, alleging that she hadn’t paid her subscription fee. However, those in the know claim that the singer was banned from the union only after she started sharing stories of #MeToo victims who accused Radha Ravi and lyricist Vairamuthu. Though she was active in Tollwyood, she hadn’t done much work as a voice artiste in the last couple of years. Chinmayi soon moved court and was granted an interim stay order in 2019. Post that, she managed to dub for Hero, which released in December. And now, she has filed her nomination to contest in the election. The dubbing union has also been embroiled in other controversies, including funds misappropriation, as alleged by a few members.Speaking to us a few minutes after filing her nomination, Chinmayi said, “The union has appointed retired justice Mr Ravi as the election officer. I’ve dropped my nomination in the dropbox kept at the dubbing union office. My nomination will be scrutinised and the status will be out in a few days.”She will be contesting for the post of president on behalf of Ramarajiyam Team. “In the last election, in 2018, the team had secured 45 per cent of vote. They have been fighting for the members who have faced problems,” she noted. Interestingly, a few members had opposed her contesting the election, saying she was not a member of the union. Her name was also removed from the voters list a few days ago. “The order copy of the ad interim injunction says that I have all the rights of a member, which means I have the rights to vote and also to contest. What they are saying is a violation of the order,” she told us.

Title: Hardik Pandya steals the limelight at Khasdar Krida Mahotsav
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Content:

Act of bravery!

Displaying courage

Displaying courage

Preeti Grover

Demonstrating acts of bravery and courage, the youth of Bareilly took out to streets and showcased their bravery skills on the occasion of Prakash Parv of Guru Gobind Singh.The highlight of the road procession , which was carried from Koharapeer area of Bara bazaar till Civil Lines, was act of dare by devotees amidst chants and prayers, who demonstrated their physical skills in a road show displaying courage, bravery, confidence-all with grit. The added highlight of the procession was a 'dhol band' who performed foot-tapping beats amidst loud and cheer that was thoroughly enjoyed by Bareillywallahs., one of the on-lookers of the show, said, "We were amazed to see the daring acts and stunts performed by young devotees, and their presentation left each one of us watching the act, spellbound."In Video: Bareilly youth demonstrates act of bravery and courage on the streets of Bareilly

Title: Restaurant Review: Biryani Guru
Content: It was exciting. And exacting. And exhausting. I was on a Navi Mumbai exploratory round. And I ended up in the delicious value for money Biryani Guru. All thanks to my other set of gurus — my #foodieblinddates. In this case, it was the vivacious, Zulekha Jabeel, who’s been running her small business for 27 years in Navi Mumbai. She loves cooking and entertaining at home and also eating out. I drove in from South Mumbai and met my #foodieblinddate directly in the restaurant and spent an amazing afternoon.Cheerful. Well-lit. Decorated with photos of musicians, from Bhimsen Joshi to Mick Jagger. A warm, happy vibe infused the ground-floored restaurant.Of course, you must opt for the biryanis (choice of 15) but before that, ask for the plump, well-marinated, boldly flavoured fish tikka with hammering notes of garlic, the velvety soft paneer delightful with black pepper. Richly succulent with cheese, chicken kebab and fleshy, tasty bhatti kumbh. Sounds strange but the ‘Istanbul Pardah Biryani’ came up tops. Cut through the sphere, with it’s thick coating into the moist, flavoursome mutton biryani. Also must-try the ‘Bombay Matka Biryani’ for its long-grained rice, vibrant with masala. End with the silken, sweet delicious caramel custard. Plenty of choices for vegetarians.I met Alok Sharma who drove all the way from Vashi and was waiting to pick up biryani as a takeaway, since it’s the best here.Some of the dishes were over-spiced and even oversweet, like the butter chicken. Leathery garlic naan.Details: Piquant homemade capsicum chutney, tangy, silken beetroot chutney and, of course, robustly spiced, tasty biryanis and kababs make this a must visit if you happen to be in the vicinity. It’s moderately priced and it’s open throughout the day. It sure is a biryani lovers mecca, which lives up to its name — Biryani Guru.Mermaid 1, Opposite Indian Naval Canteen, Sector 11,CBD-Belapur, Navi MumbaiTimings: 10 am to 11 pmMeal for two: Rs.1,000

Title: Nitin Kakkar: The reality is, people prefer to watch movies that feature stars, and producers back films that have stars in it
Content: He enjoys his share of indie space, what with winning a National Award for a film in a similar zone — Filmistaan (2012). However, director Nitin Kakkar reasons that in a country where films are dominated by stars, it is hard to survive in that space alone. With his upcoming film Jawaani Jaaneman , he tried his hand at directing a star, Saif Ali Khan . In a conversation with BT, he shares his experience of working on a typical commercial masala entertainer, discovering Bollywood debutante Alaya F and Sara Ali Khan’s exit from the project. Excerpts…I made Filmistaan in 2012, and it did the rounds of various festivals where it was received really well, but it hit the theatres only in 2014. It was almost funny, as festivals were going gaga about it, but the local producers and distributors were not even looking at it. Winning the National Award did something good, as we finally got buyers. That gave me the push to make one more indie film, Ramsingh Charlie (2015-16). It starred Kumud Mishra and Divya Dutta, but it never released as we couldn’t find buyers for it. We are a star-led industry. People prefer to watch movies that feature stars, and producers back films that have stars in it. This is the reality. Today, the digital medium has opened up, and it has led to a big demarcation. Big films are set for theatrical release, whereas indie films are pushed towards OTT platforms. I got that opportunity too, but hello, I want my indie film to release in a theatre and not on any OTT platform.I got a firsthand experience of working with stars when I assisted director Siddharth Malhotra on We Are Family (2010). Films starring big actors give you better budget to justify your vision. Talking about Saif, I must say that he is a witty, well-read and intelligent man. He is never scared to experiment. As artistes, we are meant to experiment and push ourselves towards uncomfortable zones. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't, but the point is to keep trying. Tabu is a very honest person. In this industry, you can make out who’s fake and who’s not. I found her to be an honest soul.The best thing about Alaya is that she is well prepared. In fact, she has been prepping for this moment for years now. She is one of the most confident 21-year-olds I have ever seen. I never felt that she was a debutante. We did a few reading sessions before we began the shoot. So, it wasn’t like directing a debutant and a senior actor, but a fresh, well-prepared ‘actor’ and a senior ‘actor’. So, their duet scenes went really smooth.Yes, Sara was there, but one fine day, I was told that she was not doing the film. I don’t know what happened between Saif, who was producing the film, the rest of the team and Sara. However, I looked at it very positively. Alaya was a fresh face. There was no baggage to her, while Sara’s Kedarnath (2018) was set for release. She was also shooting for Simmba (2018). I am glad that we discovered Alaya. I was shooting for Notebook in Srinagar, when I asked her to join the team. I spent an entire day with her, and I could see my character in her personality. There are a lot of similarities between the two — for example, the way they look at relationships. In our society, divorces and separations are taboo even now, but Alaya has dealt with it in real life in a mature way (her parents, actress Pooja Bedi and businessman Farhan Furniturewala,are divorced). Alaya totally fit the bill for me. It is because of this change in casting that the film got pushed; otherwise, I was supposed to work on it before Notebook.Currently, I am developing a story which I want to direct. I always wanted to make my directorial debut with a black-and-white film. I had even written the script and was on the lookout for a producer. I am going to take that project ahead now, seriously. It is going to be my next. It is based on the Partition, and I will set it in a black humour zone.

Title: The art of composting: Turn your organic waste into natural fertilisers
Content: As people get increasingly eco-conscious and seek to eat organic, here's how you can make compost at home for your organic kitchen gardenEco-consciousness among people has been on the rise, especially when it comes to making informed choices about the food they consume. This in turn has lead to a boom in organic farming, and now, many city folks have switched to organic kitchen gardening in their lawns or balconies to ensure that their food is free from chemicals such as fertilisers and pesticides. And even those who do not grow food, want to keep their house plants healthy, so they’re switching to organic fertilisers and composting. If you are also planning to turn a new leaf and try composting, here are a few things you should keep in mind when you are getting started.Compost is decayed organic matter, which includes food waste, dry leaves, twigs among other things. When they are put together in a composter or a pit, they break down naturally into a nutrient-rich fertiliser.You don't need a large space to compost – your balcony is good enough. Simply buy a composter, preferably a terracotta one, and start layering it with wet organic matter, dry leaves and twigs. Once full, cover it and let it sit in an airy place. Keep mixing the matter every other day, to ensure proper aeration and moisture content. In about 45 days, your compost will be ready.Tip: Place a plate or a container at the base of your composter to collect the liquid that comes out. This liquid, called leachate, is extremely strong and is an excellent fertiliser. However, it should be used diluted, otherwise, it can burn the plants.Contrary to what many think, composting at home is quite easy. "Home composting is a simple process based on two basic principles: adequate air and water. It's like taking care of a potted plant while understanding the science behind composting," says Smita Ahuja, a working professional and an eco-warrior, who has been composting at home since 2016.Sangeeta Nayyar, a Gurgaon resident, began composting 30 years ago. "The MCD people would simply burn the leaves. So, I dug a pit and asked them to put the leaves in it. It turned to compost, and I asked my maali to use it for our plants," she tells us. Smita adds that composting "has reduced her household waste by almost 50%".Both Smita Ahuja and Sangeeta Nayyar, who do home composting, replicated their composting models as a society in their condominiums in Gurgaon. While Sangeeta was successful, Smita's society didn't continue with community composting. Sangeeta tells us that her condominium has about 25 bins for composting. "We do not use machines. We have employed two people to rake the compost bin and ensure there is adequate water and air. Since we fill one bin at a time, we have compost ready by the time we fill up the last bin," she shares.Not just in your homes, you can also compost as a community. Societies have community composters where residents can deposit their organic waste. The waste is then raked every other day till the compost is readyRahul Khera, the founder of a company that helps provide waste management and community composting solutions, tells us that for successful community composting, 90-95% people should be composting. "Community composting requires space, and that’s the first question municipal corporations ask us, that how will we procure the space required for composting," he adds. Rahul currently runs projects in 15 societies across NCR.Priya Mehrish, another Gurgaon resident, adds, "In our society, we use machines to crush the food waste, which is then squeezed to remove moisture. This is mixed with leaves and put in large bins. Lime carbonate is added to maintain pH levels, and the compost is ready in three weeks."In both Sangeeta Nayyar and Priya’s condominiums, the residents are provided with compost for free. "12kg/year is free for the residents; for any excess, residents can buy it at a nominal price. Also, any remaining compost we have is sold to the Municipal Corporation of Gurugram for about Rs 5/kg," Priya tells us.

Title: Bonding over theatre at the French Embassy
Content:
Catching up: (L-R) Beatrice, Pinky Anand, with Brazilian Ambassador André Aranha Corrêa do Lago

Catching up: (L-R)

Beatrice

, Pinky Anand, with Brazilian Ambassador André Aranha Corrêa do Lago

'Theatre is a family affair for Sanjna':

French Ambassador Emannuel Lenain

French Ambassador

Emannuel

Lenain

'Art is for everybody, and not just the elite':

Probir Gupta

Probir Gupta

Guests list:

Chinese whispers?

Chinese whispers?

Chinese whispers?

Jatin Das

Jatin Das

Rajeev Sethi

Rajeev Sethi

Raghu Rai

Raghu Rai

Romila Thapar

Romila Thapar

Valmik Thapar

Valmik Thapar

Kunal Kapoor

Kunal Kapoor

German Ambassador Walter J Lindner

German Ambassador Walter J Lindner

Tara Gandhi Bhattacharjee

Tara Gandhi Bhattacharjee

VN Dalmia

VN Dalmia

Yashodhara Dalmia

Rahul Mishra

Rahul Mishra

The city's swish set, including artists, historians, photographers and ambassadors, among others, gathered at the French Embassy on Tuesday evening to raise a toast to theatre personality Sanjna Kapoor, who received French honour of Chevalier dans l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres (Knight of the Order of Arts and Letters) for "her outstanding contribution to theatre". The insignia was conferred by the French Minister of Culture Franck Riester , who was in India on an official visit.Highlighting Sanjna's passion for theatre, Franck said, "Whether on stage, in front of the camera, or at the helm of the organisation she runs, she shows the same infectious enthusiasm for championing the place of art in our societies." He added, "For Sanjna, theatre is a family affair. Her parents, Jennifer Kandal and Shashi Kapoor , met in Calcutta, where the tours of their respective parents' theatre companies had taken them. Her maternal grandparents, Geoffrey and Laura Kendal, were touring with their company Shakespeareana from Great Britain , crisscrossing India and falling in love with it. Her paternal grandfather, the great actor Prithviraj Kapoor, had decided to travel across India with Prithvi Theatre, which he had established. It was at the intersection of these two theatrical universes that her family was founded, so naturally, theatre has accompanied her since her very first steps."Thanking the audience, an elated Sanjna, said, "This is another possibility and opportunity to embark and learn from each other. There is a lot that we can learn from France about how it manages its cultures and its policies. I hope this ignites more policymakers and thinkers in our country to think about what role they can play in promoting arts and culture in the country." She added, "France has done some amazing things, especially in the field of circus, something that I am passionate about. It believes that a circus is an art form that belongs to everybody. I believe strongly, too, that art is for everybody, and not just for the elite or some section of the society. You ask Indian children if they have seen circus and they have probably seen it on television. It is a dying art form in India, and we need to revive that. France went out and put systems in place to enable that. I hope we can learn something from them."Accompanying Sanjna were husband and conservationist Valmik Thapar , son Hamir Thapar and brother Kunal Kapoor. Catching up with old friends over some French champagne and soufflé were Raghu Rai, Romila Thapar, Jatin Das, Alka Pande, Aruna Vasudev, Rahul Mishra and several others.A group of nine Frenchwomen and men (a part of French collective Les Souffleurs Commandos Poetiques or The Whisperers, Poetic Commandos), dressed in all-black arrived at the venue holding vintage umbrellas and a black hollow tube, which they called a "nightingale" to whisper poetry into the ears of the attendees. "The whole idea is to slow the world, and whispering poetry to people is just one of our gestures to promote that idea," said Olivier Comte, the founder of the group.Yashodhara Dalmia

He added, "For Sanjna, theatre is a family affair. Her parents, Jennifer Kandal and Shashi Kapoor , met in Calcutta, where the tours of their respective parents' theatre companies had taken them. Her maternal grandparents, Geoffrey and Laura Kendal, were touring with their company Shakespeareana from Great Britain , crisscrossing India and falling in love with it. Her paternal grandfather, the great actor Prithviraj Kapoor, had decided to travel across India with Prithvi Theatre, which he had established. It was at the intersection of these two theatrical universes that her family was founded, so naturally, theatre has accompanied her since her very first steps."French Ambassador Emannuel LenainThanking the audience, an elated Sanjna, said, "This is another possibility and opportunity to embark and learn from each other. There is a lot that we can learn from France about how it manages its cultures and its policies. I hope this ignites more policymakers and thinkers in our country to think about what role they can play in promoting arts and culture in the country." She added, "France has done some amazing things, especially in the field of circus, something that I am passionate about. It believes that a circus is an art form that belongs to everybody. I believe strongly, too, that art is for everybody, and not just for the elite or some section of the society. You ask Indian children if they have seen circus and they have probably seen it on television. It is a dying art form in India, and we need to revive that. France went out and put systems in place to enable that. I hope we can learn something from them."Probir GuptaAccompanying Sanjna were husband and conservationist Valmik Thapar , son Hamir Thapar and brother Kunal Kapoor. Catching up with old friends over some French champagne and soufflé were Raghu Rai, Romila Thapar, Jatin Das, Alka Pande, Aruna Vasudev, Rahul Mishra and several others.Chinese whispers?A group of nine Frenchwomen and men (a part of French collective Les Souffleurs Commandos Poetiques or The Whisperers, Poetic Commandos), dressed in all-black arrived at the venue holding vintage umbrellas and a black hollow tube, which they called a "nightingale" to whisper poetry into the ears of the attendees. "The whole idea is to slow the world, and whispering poetry to people is just one of our gestures to promote that idea," said Olivier Comte, the founder of the group.Jatin DasRajeev SethiRaghu RaiRomila ThaparValmik ThaparKunal KapoorGerman Ambassador Walter J LindnerTara Gandhi BhattacharjeeVN DalmiaYashodhara DalmiaRahul Mishra

Title: On Martyrs Day, 17-year-old fires at anti-CAA march in presence of cops
Content:
The Class 12 student, who’s just short of 18, abused protesters and shouted ‘Aake le lo azadi (come and take y... Read More

‘Come and take your freedom', screams shooter as cops watch

NEW DELHI: A peaceful protest by students of Jamia Millia University against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on Thursday afternoon was disrupted by a shocking act of firing by a gunman in front of a police contingent and cameras telecasting the event live. As a student tried to reason with him, the gunman fired, injuring the student’s left hand, before he was taken into custody by the cops.The shooter, according to police, is a juvenile and his age is being verified. He was using a countrymade weapon which has a short range. Police have come under fire from many eyewitnesses and observers for not making any effort to rein in the youth when he was walking backwards towards them, waving the gun and shouting slogans. The cops were seen watching nonchalantly and one of them intervened quite late, after the man had fired. He handed over the gun to them and was taken away. A case of attempt to murder has been filed against him.The incident came after days of intense campaigning for the Delhi assembly elections when rhetoric on Shaheen Bagh has taken centrestage.It was around 1.40pm when the 17-year-old shooter, wearing white trousers and a black jacket, entered the protest site by climbing over the roadside grilles near Gate No. 4 of the university on Okhla Marg. The students — about 400 — were planning to march to Rajghat where they would have formed a human chain.Instead of joining the protesters , the youth started walking ahead of them, hurling abuses. One of the protesters, Shadab Farooq , along with some volunteers, approached the man and asked him to fall back in line so that they could begin the protest. However, the man hurled abuses at Farooq, whipped out a countrymade pistol and started threatening to shoot the protesters.In videos that went viral on social media, the youth is seen waving the pistol in the air and walking ahead of the protest while media persons and volunteers try to persuade him to drop the weapon. “He kept shouting at the protesters. ‘Aake le lo Azadi,’ he screamed. Before opening fire, he shouted, ‘Hindustan mein rehna hoga to Vande Mataram kehna hoga’,” said TOI photographer Tarun Rawat, who was at the scene when the incident unfolded.“We had thought he was among the protesters at first, but when he started waving the gun, we were taken aback and tried to convince him to drop the weapon. He walked with his back towards the police for a few metres and then suddenly opened fire at Farooq,” said one of Farooq’s batchmates. “The police were at a distance and had slowly started moving despite being alerted about the man carrying a gun,” she said.Witnesses say that after hearing the gunshot, they saw Farooq and his woman friend crouching on the road with blood oozing out of Farooq’s left hand. By this time, the policeman who had started walking towards the shooter took away the pistol and led him away.DCP (Southeast) Chinmoy Biswal said that since no permission was given to the protesters to hold a march, a barricade had been put up near Holy Family Hospital to stop them. The entire force was deployed behind the barricades, except for a few officers. “The incident happened within the few seconds during which the officers got alerted and the suspect opened fire. We immediately apprehended him,” he said.During the initial interrogation, the youth claimed that he had travelled to Delhi from a village near Jewar in UP with the intent of teaching the protesters a lesson. He claimed he was not affiliated with any organisation.Meanwhile, Farooq’s classmates rushed him to the barricades, asking the cops to remove them. “We requested the police to allow us to go through since Farooq was shot but they asked him to climb over the barricade. We had to haul him up over the barricade and go to the other side before walking to the hospital,” said one of his classmates. Farooq was then referred to AIIMS trauma centre.The police have registered a case of attempt to murder under Section 307 IPC and under Arms Act. They are in the process of verifying the age of the accused since he has produced his Aadhaar card and certificates that mention his age to be 17 years and nine months. However, the date of birth mentioned in his Class X CBSE marksheet, which TOI has accessed, is April 8, 2002, which makes him older. It was found that he had procured the weapon from an arms dealer in UP. Police have informed his family and will produce him before the juvenile justice board.Meanwhile, Election Commission has sought a report regarding the law and order situation from the police commissioner after the incident. Two senior police officers met the injured student at the trauma centre on Thursday evening.In Video: Shaheen Bagh: 'Khel Khatam, Le Lo Azaadi', says youth

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: India’s 1st coronavirus case reported in Kerala
Content:
A man wearing a surgical mask makes a child wear one outside the government general hospital where a student w... Read More

Coronavirus scare: 15 put in isolation wards in Kerala

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The first case of the new strain of a coronavirus (nCoV) in the country was reported from Thrissur, Kerala , on Thursday. A young woman studying medicine at a university in the Chinese city of Wuhan , the epicentre of the nCoV outbreak, has tested positive for the virus that has killed 170 people in China and has spread to other countries, including the US.State health minister K K Shailaja said the student was hospitalised after she developed symptoms of fever and a sore throat. She was quarantined, along with four others, in the isolation ward of the general hospital in Thrissur. “The student who has tested positive for the virus is stable; there is nothing to worry,” she said. The five students, who had returned from Wuhan, had come to the hospital of their own volition. Three of them were shifted to Thrissur Medical College Hospital by Thursday afternoon. Swabs and blood taken from them have been sent for tests.Meanwhile, at a high-level review meeting in Delhi, cabinet secretary Rajiv Gauba decided that all those who have come from China after January 15, 2020 will be tested as the virus has an incubation period. Apart from China, 15 other countries have reported a total of 68 confirmed cases so far.In Kerala, the medical college principal, Dr M A Andrews, said the three had been shifted to the hospital’s specially prepared isolation ward. Two more patients, including the student who tested positive, remain in the isolation ward. A final decision on shifting them will be taken later. The health minister, principal secretary (health) Rajan N Khobragade and other officials are expected to reach Thrissur late Thursday night. Khobragade was informed about the case in Thrissur in a video conference with the Union cabinet secretary, the health secretary and health secretaries of all states on Thursday. “The Union health ministry confirmed that one out of the six blood samples sent for tests to NIV Pune has tested positive. However, a gene identification test result is pending. This will reaffirm the status of the case,” Khobragade said.Meanwhile, 1,053 people who have returned from virus-hit regions are under observation in the state. Of these, 15 have been admitted to isolation wards of various hospitals in the state. Of the total 24 samples sent for tests to date, only one among them has tested positive.

Title: MEA starts its biggest internal rejig in 50 years
Content:
Foreign minister S Jaishankar is putting his plans of redrawing the MEA structure to work (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The foreign ministry is undertaking its biggest restructuring exercise in almost half a century, making it the Centre’s first ministry to undertake ‘root-branch’ structural reform.The ministry’s management and functioning structure remains hidebound and out of sync with modern practices and demands of India’s foreign policy, which is becoming more complex and diverse.With foreign secretary Harsh Shringla taking charge this week, foreign minister S Jaishankar is putting his plans of redrawing the MEA structure to work. It helps that Shringla and Jaishankar are on the same page regarding the overhaul, and getting it out early in the government’s tenure means they will have ample time to put the plans into action.The new structure will be more corporate in nature. MEA will build a series of ‘verticals’ like economic and trade diplomacy, development partnership, consular, emerging areas like technology etc. Each of these verticals will be headed by the equivalent of “political directors” at the additional secretary level. The idea is to decentralise the present pyramid-like structure, to separate routine foreign policy work from strategic projects. This will leave the secretaries to handle the big-ticket issues.On Thursday, MEA created the first verticals. Akhilesh Mishra, the current head of ICCR (Indian Council for Cultural Relations) will oversee all the four development partnership divisions. These are key to India’s overseas aid and development projects, particularly in the neighbourhood and Africa. Dinesh Patnaik will take over ICCR and handle the entire cultural diplomacy portfolio. P Harish will oversee the economic diplomacy initiative, leading the multilateral economic diplomacy and states division. Nagma Mallik will have three Africa divisions reporting to her. She will relinquish her current job as joint secretary, policy planning to Anupam Ray, who has just returned from Houston. Vikram Doraiswami will take charge of all multilateral work, overseeing political, economic and conferences and summits. He will give up his charge as head of Indo-Pacific to Neena Malhotra, who will oversee Indian Ocean, Indo-Pacific, and south-east Asia, with Smita Pant taking over as joint secretary ( Bangladesh and Myanmar ).Consular issues, an increasingly important area, emerging strategic technologies, cyber will be the future areas of expertise to be woven into the MEA structure. MEA recently set up the NEST (new and emerging strategic technologies) division. India wants to be part of the global rule-making order in these areas, so stands to reason that MEA should build policy expertise here.Currently, the system puts enormous pressure on joint secretaries as well as the four secretaries, making running the ministry and India’s foreign policy a continuous fire-fighting exercise, leaving little or no space for strategic planning, initiatives, etc. The new system is designed to break some of the silos that MEA currently functions under, align the Indian system with global powers, which will answer a perennial problem MEA faces when organising official dialogues with their international counterparts – of a mismatch in designations.With a reputation of having one of the smallest foreign services in the world, MEA will need to get creative about staffing. At present they take in officials from other services, but soon that pool will be expanded from the private sector, think tanks, etc. In addition, MEA plans to deploy its people in other key ministries like commerce, defence, finance, science & technology, etc. There are two reasons for this – international cooperation is increasingly being used for domestic development goals and India’s internal decisions have a foreign policy impact. This cross-pollination is intended to synergise the two goals.The exercise has just started, and it will take a few months, perhaps even a year to straighten out the knots at the operational level. But MEA may become a trailblazer in the Indian government.

Title: Hindus from Pakistan ‘visiting’ Punjab worry agencies
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

he arrival of over 200 Hindu families from Pakistan via the Attari border after the new citizenship law was pa... Read More

Title: Nirbhaya: SC rejects another curative plea
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Supreme Court of India

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Thursday dismissed the curative petition of Akshay Thakur, one of the four death row convicts in the Nirbhaya gang rape-and-murder case . It had earlier dismissed the curative pleas of two other convicts, Vinay Sharma and Mukesh Singh . Only Pawan Gupta has so far not filed a similar plea.

“We have gone through the curative petitions and the relevant documents. In our opinion, no case is made out within the parameters indicated in the decision of this court in Rupa Ashok Hurra vs Ashok Hurra & Another, reported in 2002 (4) SCC 388. Hence, the curative petitions are dismissed,” a bench of Justices N V Ramana, Arun Mishra, R F Nariman, R Banumathi and Ashok Bhushan said.

The court dismissed Thakur’s plea seeking open court hearing on his petition and passed the order after examining the plea in chamber.

The court had on Wednesday rejected Singh’s plea challenging the President’s declining his mercy plea and said there was no illegality in the decision. With the dismissal of his plea, Singh has now exhausted all legal remedies to avoid execution of his death sentence.

The trial court on January 17 issued death warrants for the second time for the execution of all four convicts in the case — Singh (32), Gupta (25), Sharma (26) and Thakur (31) — in Tihar Jail at 6 am on February 1. Earlier, on January 7, the court had fixed January 22 as the hanging date.

Title: Farrukhabad news: 9-hour Uttar Pradesh hostage crisis ends, captor shot dead, 22 kids rescued
Content:
Commandos of the UP police stormed into the house of a murder convict, who had held 23 children captive

LUCKNOW/AGRA: The nine-hour hostage crisis at a village in UP’s Farrukhabad district finally came to an end hours after midnight after crack commandos of the UP police stormed into the house of a murder convict, who had held 23 children captive since Thursday afternoon. Hostage-taker Subhash Batham was shot dead by the police and all 22 children were rescued. One girl held hostage was earlier released.A huge cache of arms and ammunition was also seized from his house godown where he had held the children hostage. The operation was spearheaded by IG, Kanpur Range, Mohit Agarwal, with support from the quick response team, special operation group and Anti-Terrorism Squad of the UP police. During the hostage crisis, Subhash hurled a crude bomb and fired shots from a country-made pistol at villagers and police personnel, injuring three of them.Hostage-taker's wife, who was thrashed by locals, succumbed to her injuries on Friday morning, IG Kanpur Mohit Agarwal said.He even threw out a letter of demands for the district magistrate, in which, he accused state officials of not providing his family with a house under the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana or even a toilet under the Swachh Mission.The incident took place in Kathariya village under Mohammadabad police jurisdiction, where Subhash invited children to his house for a party and then locked them in. According to locals, Subhash appeared to be heavily drunk. He was accused in four criminal cases other than a murder case in which he was convicted and given a life term. NSG commandos were kept on standby.Earlier in the day, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath convened a high-level meeting on the hostage incident. The meeting was attended by the chief secretary, principal secretary (home), DGP and the ADGP (law and order). Farrukhabad MLA Sunil Dutt Dwivedi told TOI, “When some local residents tried to get the door opened, Subhash started firing. He even hurled a low-intensity bomb from the window, injuring Mohammadabad SHO.”In Video: UP Police rescue all 23 kids kept hostage in Farrukhabad, suspect shot down

Title: After cold December, India’s wettest January in 15 years
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: This winter season continues to make news. December saw record-breaking cold in the north and now January is the wettest India has experienced in 15 years. Met records show countrywide rainfall during this month has been 67% above normal (till January 30), with north, and east and northeast regions receiving almost 80% surplus rains.Experts said the wet conditions and cold conditions in January, particularly over north India, have been ideal for rabi crops such as wheat, which is heading for a bumper harvest.All-India average rainfall in January so far has been 27.9mm, highest since 2005, when 28.1mm was recorded, met records reveal. Winter rainfall is mainly regulated by western disturbances (WDs) — pulses of moist winds travelling from regions close to the Mediterranean, which bring wet weather to north and, at times, central India.“Normally, there are five to seven WDs in January. This month, we got 10. Not just that, many of these WDs came in through a more southerly path which brought rainfall to the northern plains in addition to the western Himalayan states,” said Mrutyunjay Mohapatra, head of India Meteorological Department .An additional factor brought rain to many parts of central India as well. “This month, we saw several of the WDs being supported by easterly winds from Bay of Bengal . The confluence of the two systems increased the geographical spread of the rainfall, with Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Odisha too getting wet weather,” Mohapatra said.The weather in January was quite a contrast to December, when there were no WDs for a 16-17 day period — except for a single, weak disturbance — during which day temperatures remained way below normal in north India, leading to the longest “cold day” spell over the region since 1901.In January, a WD has hit north India every three days on average, not only bringing frequent rain spells but also preventing a sharp fall in temperatures. So, while January remained cold, there were no extreme temperature events.“Weather conditions this month, at least over north India, have been very good for rabi crops, particularly wheat. We have got rain every few days while there has hardly been any heavy rain or just a few hail spells. Also, fog episodes have been few and crops have received sufficient sunshine,” said M L Jat, a senior agriculture scientist with the non-profit International Wheat and Maize Improvement Centre, better known by its Spanish acronym, Cimmyt.In line with the weather conditions so far, among other factors, several agencies have forecast a record wheat production this year, which could bring some cheer to the rural economy that has seen a slowdown in recent months.

Title: bank strike: Two-day strike may hit operation of PSU banks
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: Bank unions have decided to go on a two-day nationwide strike from Friday as talks with the management of public sector lenders on wage revision have failed to reach a consensus.

Many banks, including the State Bank of India ( SBI ), have informed customers that operations may be impacted to some extent due to the strike.

The strike will coincide with the presentation of the Union Budget 2020 on Saturday.

Title: Ready to discuss all issues, PM tells combative opposition
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PM Narendra Modi at an all-party meet ahead of the Budget Session in New Delhi on Thursday (PTI)

NEW DELHI: The opposition drew the Centre’s attention to the anti-CAA protests and communal statements from BJP functionaries in Delhi elections even as Prime Minister Narendra Modi said the government was ready to discuss all issues in Parliament , exposing the political fault-lines which may make the budget session a stormy affair.
