At the all-party meeting on the eve of the parliament session on Thursday, the government and the opposition laid out their priorities. It was attended by 26 parties and included seniors like Ghulam Nabi Azad , Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury and Anand Sharma of Congress, T R Baalu of DMK, Sudip Bandyopadhyay of TMC, Navaneethakrishnan of AIADMK and Pinaki Misra of BJD among others.

The opposition, led by Congress, was emphatic that greater focus was required on the economic situation, rising unemployment and anti-CAA protests even as they pointed to controversies arising from non-stop communal remarks from BJP in the Delhi campaign. They also demanded the release of political detainees in Jammu and Kashmir .

Interestingly, while the opposition focused on economic distress, the PM displayed optimism on the issue.

According to an official statement, Modi said, “Most of the members have asked for discussion on the economic situation concerning the country. I welcome this and we need to discuss the economic issues as suggested by you all. We should focus on how we can turn the global scenario in favour of India.”

However, CAA continues to be the flashpoint which may mar the budget session.

Azad accused the government of focussing merely on passage of its bills and spoke about the nation-wide protests against CAA. “We brought the government's attention to these protests. The government has displayed arrogance by not reaching out to protesters to hear their concerns,” he told reporters.

In contrast, parliamentary affairs minister Prahlad Joshi said the bill was passed by Parliament following a long discussion and asked rival parties to introspect their role in the protests.

Some participants raised the “incendiary” statements made by BJP functionaries during the Delhi poll campaign and asked Modi to intervene.

Urging parties to help increase business transacted in the House, Modi said, “In the last two sessions, we saw increased productivity and the great public response in favour of it. As people's representatives, it is our responsibility to increase productivity of the House while we discuss all issues with an open mind.”

He added, “In this budget session and in the beginning of the new year, if we can give a proper direction to the country's economy, it would be in the best interest of the country.

Title: Bodo pact ‘historic’, says PM
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PM Narendra Modi (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Terming the Bodo agreement a historic chapter for peace, development and unity in Assam , Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday said the accord sent a clear message that non-violence and adherence to democracy and the Constitution could help resolve issues.

“Bodo friends joining us on the path of peace sends a clear message that solution to issues is possible when we leave the path of violence and repose faith in democracy and Constitution. I welcome my Bodo friends to the mainstream. We are committed to ensuring the development of Bodo areas," the PM said in a series of tweets.

“As India remembers pujya Bapu on his punya tithi, Assam is witnessing a historic chapter for peace and development. After a wait of 50 years, agreement with our Bodo friends heralds a new beginning. It will strengthen Assam's unity, bring development and usher in a bright future," Modi said, adding, “I welcome the decision of my Bodo friends for leaving violence and reposing faith in democracy and Constitution.”

As per the agreement, all Bodo outfits have decided to give up their militant campaign for creation of a separate homeland. This was the second time in a week when the PM emphasised that peaceful means were better suited for resolution of problems. On Sunday, he had stressed on the importance of non-violence in his ‘Mann ki Baat’ address on Sunday.

His return to the theme on Mahatma Gandhi ’s martyrdom day was seen in the context of anti-CAA protests. The stir, which has seen protesters invoking Gandhiji, has also sparked violence in many places.

“Nation's development can be given momentum only in an environment free of violence and fear. Happy that entire energy of our Bodo friends will further strengthen Assam's development,” Modi said, stressing that the agreement was inspired by the mantra of 'Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas and Sabka Vishwas ' and the spirit of 'Ek Bharat, Shresth Bharat '.

“This is a victory for all. It's a victory for humanity," he added.

Modi said after signing the historic agreement with Bodo organisations, the foremost priority of the government was the development of Bodo areas and work had begun on a comprehensive Rs 1,500 crore package.

Title: Indians will fly out today if China allows
Content:
People wear masks at a hospital in Thrissur as Kerala reported first coronavirus case (AP)

NEW DELHI: After India reported the first case of coronavirus from Kerala , China said it was paying close attention to the case and that it was going to jointly work with India to strengthen efforts to prevent and control the epidemic which originated in Wuhan , the capital of Hubei’s province. While Beijing was yet to approve India’s request to operate two aircraft to fly back Indian nationals, the Indian side was hoping evacuation will finally begin Friday evening."Indian nationals have been alerted about evacuation plans for Friday evening. It will materialise though only if Chinese authorities approve it," said a source here late on Thursday evening.The China embassy here expressed hope in a statement that the Indian government will show understanding and support for China’s efforts to deal with coronavirus. It said the virus was controllable and curable and that Wuhan was stocked with enough daily necessity supplies.The Indian government said Thursday that it had contacted more than 600 Indian nationals in the Hubei province to ascertain their willingness to be repatriated. MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said India was hoping approval to evacuate Indian nationals who want to return will be granted very soon.“Our Mission in Beijing is working round-the-clock on the ground to work out the necessary logistics. Arrangements are being put in place for people to travel to the airport. We appreciate the support extended by the Government of China and other ministries in the government of India in putting this process together,’’ said the official.He also said that India had not put any restriction on movement of tourists from China to India.The Chinese embassy said here that it had maintained close communication with the Indian government, timely briefed Indian officials on the development of the epidemic and China’s efforts in epidemic prevention and control.``The Chinese government attaches great importance to safeguarding the safety and health of every foreign national in China, including the Indian people. We are willing to continue to maintain close communication with the Indian side, provide necessary assistance and convenience to ensure the health and safety of Indian citizens in China, and address their legitimate concerns timely,’’ it said.It further said that China believed the international community would assess the epidemic situation in an objective, just, calm and reasonable way, and will continue to strengthen international cooperation to jointly tackle the epidemic and safeguard regional and global public health security.“The epidemic is generally preventable, controllable and curable. At present, there are sufficient supplies of daily necessities in Wuhan, and the commodity prices are also generally stable. The Chinese government has mobilised all the national resources to ensure the supply of medical equipment and living materials in Wuhan. We have full capability, confidence and resources to win the battle against the epidemic at an early date,’’ it added.The Chinese claimed they had acted with openness, transparency and “a high sense of responsibility’’ and that the Chinese government had shared information of the epidemic with WHO and “relevant nations and regions’’ in a timely manner.

Title: VTR tour package: All slots booked till March
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PATNA: Nature lovers are making the most of the recently launched ecotourism package for the Valmiki Tiger Reserve (VTR) in West Champaran as all its slots have been booked till March.

According to VTR officials, the ecotourism package, which can be availed by 16 people simultaneously, has been in demand since its launch by the forest department on December 21 last year.

“The two-day package worth Rs 1,500 each includes transportation from Patna to the VTR, accommodation and food for 16 tourists. They can also enjoy jungle safari and canopy walk on Kauleshwar Jhoola and visit the Gandak riverfront,” VTR’s deputy director Gourav Ojha told this newspaper on Thursday.

Located 289 kilometres in the north of Patna in Tarai region of the Himalayas, the VTR comprises eight forest ranges with two divisions — Govardhana, Rangia, and Manguraha ranges in division I and Harnapand, Chiutaha, Madanpur, Valmiki Nagar, and Ganauli in division II.

The Bihar State Tourism Development Corporation (BSTDC) has been running a number of buses for tourists travelling to the VTR. “More than 60% of the bookings are made during the winter season, from mid-November to February. We offer special packages that include a visit to the eco park, elephant shed and the Jatashankar Temple. We also have a special nightlife package that is available on full moon nights,” a BSTDC official said.

People, who have availed the VTR package, recalled their amazing experiences. One of them, Rakesh Sharma, said, “My friends and I had gone to the VTR in the first week of January and had a lot of fun. The facilities were great too.”

Exhibition Road resident, Manoj Srivastava, enjoyed the jungle safari on a 14-seater open air vehicle. “We were taken to the Gandak pathway, but the best part was the Kauleshwar Jhoola,” he said.

Kadamkuan resident, Uma Shankar Prasad, is excited to visit the VTR in February. He said, “We were planning to go in January. However, all the slots were full and we had to extend the date.”

Monitoring of tigers through camera traps till February 15: The ongoing exercise of monitoring tigers using camera traps at the VTR is likely to continue till February 15. The photographs taken through the 500 pairs of camera traps will be sent to the Wildlife Institute of India (WWI) and processed before the annual tiger census is released.

The census work began in November-end last year with installation of 500 pairs of camera traps in division-II of the tiger reserve. Its divisional forest officer (DFO) Gourav Ojha said, “After monitoring the movement of tigers and other species for more than a month, the camera traps were removed from division II in the first week of January and placed in division- I.”

“Monitoring will continue till February 15. Thereafter, the recorded data will be submitted to the WWI for final processing,” Ojha added.

Title: Need national board to promote GI-tagged products, says expert
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Varanasi: Ahead of the Union budget on February 1, Geographical Indication expert Padma Shri Dr Rajni Kant urged Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman for a budgetary allocation for National GI (Geographical Indication) Board to promote GI-tagged handicrafts on global level. Kant also urged for an enhanced allocation of fund for handloom sector.

“We are expecting something good for handloom and handicraft sectors in the Union budget for weavers and artisans and also to promote these goods globally,” Kant told reporters on Thursday.

He said that the handloom sector should be given an increased share in the budget. There is a need to establish a National GI Board so that exclusive GI certified products of the country could be promoted in international markets, he said.

The artisans should also be given facilities of solar subsidy, handicraft credit card on the lines of kisan credit card, and inclusion of all handicraft goods in a single GST slab of 5%, he said. A budgetary allocation is also needed for special training of artisans, packaging and marketing of goods. There should be a separate budget for woman weavers and artisans, and for the marketing of the goods produced by them.

Kant further said that there should be a special provision of GI tourist circuit and craft tourism for the interest of Indian crafts and craftsmen. “We also urge for a provision of special raw material depot and common facility centres for handicraft and handloom sectors,” he said adding that there should also be provision of promotional activities and marketing of Indian handicraft and handloom in foreign countries through the respective Indian embassies.

Title: Amreli police nabs 26 absconding criminals
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Rajkot: Parole and furlough squad of Amreli police has caught up with as many as 26 absconding criminals who had either evaded arrest or jumped parole, furlough or interim bail.

“On the instructions of Amreli superintendent of police Nirlipt Rai, we had formed four teams to hunt for the absconders and dispatched them to Uttar Pradesh, Delhi and Haryana,” said a senior official from Amreli police.

Those arrested were involved in the crimes ranging from attempt to murder, rape, kidnapping, cheating, physical assault, chain snatching, bootlegging, gambling, threatening and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act.

The teams had effected most of the arrests in Nuh (Mewat) district of Haryana, said a release issued by the police.

Title: GST evasion of Rs 20.34 crore unearthed
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Surat: The Directorate of GST Intelligence (DGGI) has unearthed tax evasion to the tune of Rs 20.34 crore of the Vadodara and Ahmedabad-based firms engaged in security services and event management services on Thursday.

According to the DGGI, an inquiry was initiated against Vadodara’s Checkmate Services Private Limited, providing security services, including manned guarding and cash management services to various firms across the country. During the preliminary scrutiny of the documents recovered from their premises, it was found that they have not paid GST to the tune of Rs 17 crore.

The tax evasion was found for the services provided to their clients across the country. The company admitted their liabilities and paid Rs 9 crore and that further investigations are on.

In the second case, the DGGI officers gathered information on the evasion of service tax and GST by Ahmedabad-based Expositions and Conventions, engaged in providing event management services and business exhibition services to various state government departments.

The DGGI officials carried out search at the premises of the firm located in Ahmedabad and found incriminating documents were seized. On the preliminary scrutiny, it was revealed that they have evaded tax to the tune of Rs 3.24 crore by way of short declaration of taxable income in tax returns and agreed to pay the same. The firm paid service tax of Rs 1.45 crore and GST of Rs 700 lakh immediately.

Title: Gujarat: Attempt to kidnap minor girl foiled, 3 booked
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PALANPUR: Three people were booked for attempting to kidnap a 14-year-old girl in Meghraj. A police complaint was lodged in this regard on Wednesday evening and cops booked Sadhahai Damor, Narsinhbhai Damor and Sanabhai Damor , all in the age group of 18 to 20 years and residents of Raywada village, 7 km from Meghraj , for the crime.

The girl studying in Class IX told the police that the incident took place on Monday at about 10 pm when she and four other girls were coming home from a religious function. Three youths waylaid the girls and Sadhabhai Damor allegedly caught her hand and forced her to sit on his bike. “He said he wanted to marry me and make me his wife,” the girl told the police. Cops said that she began shouting for helpwhen the bike reached near Mohanbhai Damor’s farm and the latter rushed to her rescue.

The kidnapper allegedly threatened Mohanbhai too saying that “he shouldn’t have interfered in their internal matter and that the girl will not be spared”.

Police sub inspector KS Sishodiya said the trio have been booked under several sections including 363, 366, 311 of IPC and relevant sections of POCSO Act. Police are hunting for the absconding accused.

Title: Surat: Death warrant issued for minor girl’s rapist, killer
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

A file photo of accused Anil Yadav in Surat police custody

Title: Kolkata: Bus, auto routes around Tallah realigned to ease commute
Content: KOLKATA: Learning from the initial commuting chaos in the aftermath of the Majerhat bridge collapse, the transport department has drawn up a detailed plan to be implemented in Tallah from February 1, when the Tallah Bridge will be closed for razing. Additionally, pedestrian movement and safety will be on top of the police agenda as they prepare to divert vehicles into narrower roads from midnight on Friday. The emphasis came after back-to-back fatal accidents in the area over the past two days. Senior traffic officers led by joint CP (traffic) Santosh Kumar spent several hours in and around Tallah Bridge on Thursday as the top brass took stock of the possible challenges that may come up.The state has realigned more than 100 bus routes and engaged 1,766 buses for passengers travelling from the northern suburbs beyond Tallah Bridge to the city. “The idea is to reduce reliance on private vehicles so as to decongest the roads. In case of Majerhat, the sudden surge of private cars — which occupy a huge amount of road space but carry a lower number of commuters — left traffic unmanageable and the transport department needed to deploy buses to ease the issue,” said a transport department official.West Bengal Transport Corporation, a state transport undertaking, has realigned 26 routes and plans to deploy 148 buses to serve these routes. The movement of goods vehicles will be planned in consultation with Kolkata Police.“We will be coordinating with private operators so we can avoid overlapping buses. We have to make sure buses will be available throughout the day,” said a WBTC official.The Railways has introduced five trains between Barrackpore and BBD Bag and one train from Barrackpore to Sealdah . Metro has also increased frequency of services between Noapara and New Garia. The transport department will also provide connectivity between Noapara and Dum Dum Metro station from the nearest points.In October 2019, the transport department started ferry services from Kuthighat to Fairlie Place via Bagbazar Ghat. “It was a success and we are planning to strengthen the services. We also plan to extend operations till Alam Bazar Ghat so we can reduce congestion in Baranagar and Cossipore .Pedestrian safety will be prioritized once the traffic movement is realigned. Several key roads in the area, including Cossipore Road, which is expected to bear a large chunk of traffic once Tallah Bridge is shut, do not even have proper pavements. The scene is similar on Khagen Chatterjee Road. The police said they have recommended the redevelopment of pavements and installation of lights, especially near schools and important crossings.Lalbazar said the proposed pedestrian walkway connecting Tallah Park with Tallah station will ease pedestrian movement at both ends of Tallah Bridge. Cops have been asked to clearly demarcate bus stops and ensure that a case is lodged if construction material is dumped on the road. “But this is one road where we cannot control crossovers and chances of accidents cannot be ruled out,” an officer said.“Neither Khagen Chatterjee Road nor Cossipore Road has a pavement. We have to walk down the road even though it is risky,” said Shakti Singh, a Cossipore resident.Cops said they also held a meeting with bus owners and auto operators on Thursday to apprise them of the situation. “It was not a meeting on the Tallah issue. It was a stock taking meeting, and the Tallah issue came up,” said an officer.

Title: Ganga riverfront: Three more ghats to come up by June
Content:
The 6.6km-long promenade on the banks of the Ganga, officially known as Patna (RFD) project, is likely to get ... Read More

PATNA: The 6.6km-long promenade on the banks of the Ganga, officially known as Patna Ganga Riverfront Development (RFD) project, is likely to get extra grandeur with the introduction of laser shows from June this year.Apart from laser show, the Bihar Urban Infrastructure Development Corporation (BUIDCO), an agency of the state urban development and housing department (UDHD), has also decided to develop three more ghats – Bhadra Ghat, Mahavir Ghat and Nauzar Ghat – by June this year. Work on setting up infrastructure for laser shows would begin next month.A senior BUIDCO official said the UDHD has been urged to sanction Rs180 crore for construction of pathway on the three proposed ghats and introduction of other facilities, including laser shows.Chandrashekhar Singh, managing director of BUIDCO, said the proposed amenities would be developed at the three ghats by the end of June. “Of the 20 ghats in the first phase of Ganga RFD project, 16 have already been developed. Bhadra Ghat, Mahavir Ghat and Nauzar Ghat will now be taken up under phase 1 of the project. Laser shows will also be introduced to make the riverfront more attractive,” Singh said.Food kiosks, water pumps, landscaping, electric crematorium, high mast lights, sitting kiosks, benches, watchtowers and urinals are some of the facilities proposed to be developed in the remaining three ghats.Chandrashekhar said there will be 16 approach roads to reach 19 ghats between Collectorate Ghat and Nauzar Ghat.Meanwhile, promenades or pathways along the 16 ghats in the city between Collectorate Ghat and Rani Ghat have become a major attraction for residents. People visit the ghats from early in the morning. Fitness enthusiasts visit the place for morning walk, exercise and performing yoga.Students from various schools, colleges and universities also spend time with their friends and study in groups. It has become a picnic hotspot for families, while lovebirds also spend time in the sitting kiosks.Some major attractions are decorative lights, Madhubani painting on walls, decorated sitting kiosks, landscape, boat ride, 50-seater ship – MV Kautilya – which is run by the Bihar State Tourism Development Corporation and Ganga aarti in the evening.BUIDCO has also developed an eco-centre at Collectorate Ghat and an audio-visual theatre centre at Baharwa Ghat, which would soon be handed over to Patna Municipal Corporation .Visitors can see the artworks related to the Ganga, get information of its origin, river- course and its tributaries at the eco-centre. At audio-visual theatre, a short film based on Ganga will be shown to visitors.

Title: India clocks over 5.5 billion hours on TikTok in ’19
Content:
(File photo)

BENGALURU: Indians clocked 5.5 billion hours on TikTok, the mobile application used to post 15-second short videos. This is an increase of over six times from the 900 million hours spent in 2018, according to data of Android users assessed by mobile and data analytics firm App Annie. TikTok outstripped growth of rival Facebook in the key battleground market for global user domination.The number of monthly active users (MAUs) on TikTok increased by 90% to 81 million as of December 2019, as compared to the same period in the previous year, as India emerged as the largest market outside the home base China. At the same time, Facebook saw total hours spent on the platform increase by 15% to 25.5 billion hours, while its MAUs as of December also increased by 15% to 224 million. Facebook-owned photosharing platform Instagram grew its MAUs much faster at 40% to 137 million as of December on Android, which is the dominant operating system with over 90% market share in India.While TikTok — owned by the world’s most valued startup ByteDance at $75 billion — remains behind global rival Facebook in terms of users and time spent, it is catching up fast. TikTok launched in India in September 2017, about 28 months ago, while Facebook, for whom the country is the largest market in terms of users, has been available since September 2006.The TikTok app was also downloaded 323 million times across both Apple’s App Store and Android devices in India in 2019 — over twice the 156 million times Facebook was, according to Sensor Tower data.“In December 2019, the total time spent on Tiktok in India was more than the next 11 countries combined. It is not only that there are more people engaging with TikTok, but there is deeper engagement per person,” said Lexi Sydow, senior market insights manager, App Annie. She added that what works for TikTok is that it is blurring the line between a social network and entertainment.TikTok’s India numbers have outstripped its global growth numbers — where time spent on the app grew over two times, while MAUs went 70% to 717 million, with a large majority in China, according to App Annie. Facebook is not operational in China.The numbers come at a time when TikTok is increasingly looking to monetise its fast-growing user base in the country as it has hired a top management team. TikTok is also eyeing Rs 100 crore in revenue for the July-September quarter, according to a report on Entrackr, up from Rs 23-25 crore in the December quarter.According to investors tracking the space, TikTok’s ability to create stars early in the life of the social network has attracted more users and content-creators on the platform, giving it the “viral loop”. “Their content format in full screen is also very engaging, as with one swipe you are on the next one, unlike other platforms where buffering takes time. In both their video-streaming technology and the application of artificial intelligence, they have truly pushed boundaries,” said Pratik Poddar , principal at Nexus Venture Partners , a VC firm. “And they are genuinely aggressive and not shied away from spending money.”

Title: Coronavirus threat: Thermal scanners to be installed at Gaya airport today
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose (Photo: AP)

PATNA: Passengers arriving at Gaya international airport by international flights will have to undergo thermal screening in view of coronavirus threat . According to officials, thermal scanners will be installed at the airport by Friday.Flights from Gaya international airport connect Yangoon in Myanmar, Paro in Bhutan and Hanoi in Vietnam. Unlike other international airports in the country, Gaya airport does not have Airport Health Organization (APHO) counter.“Thermal screening equipment reached Patna on Thursday and we expect that it would be installed at Gaya airport by Friday evening,” said ministry of health and family welfare senior regional director (Bihar and Jharkhand) Dr Kailash Kumar.Gaya airport director Dillip Kumar said thermal screening cameras would be installed near the immigration counter, for which an area has been identified. “Announcement regarding thermal screening at the airport will be made in the flight. Directorate General of Civil Aviation has already issued guidelines in this regard,” he said.As of now, passengers are manually checked at the airport and they have to submit a self-declaration form regarding their health and symptoms.State surveillance officer Dr Ragini Mishra, who has been made nodal officer for novel coronavirus, said the health department was monitoring Gaya airport and the border areas. “Areas bordering Nepal are the biggest challenge as the neighbouring country has already witnessed one confirmed case of coronavirus,” she added.As India's first case of coronavirus of a student from Wuhan University was reported in Kerala, the Bihar health department is on its toes. “We will keep an eye on the flights coming to Bihar from Kerala,” she added.

Title: Stones pelted on JMC councillor’s house; six booked
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Six persons were booked for allegedly pelting stones at the house of Jamnagar Municipal Corporation’s (JMC) councillor Umar Chamadia in Bedi locality over an old enmity on Wednesday night.

In his complaint, Chamadia, a BJP corporator of JMC ward number 1, alleged that the accused, identified as Hanif Bhokal, Mohsin Bhokal, Qadar Bhokal, Hasan Bhokal , Akhtar Gazia and Ayub Gazia, pelted stones at his house while he and his family members were sleeping on Wednesday night.

“After window glasses were shattered by stones, Chamadia came out of the house and the accused allegedly threatened to kill him. However, the accused fled after Chamadia’s neighbours gathered at the spot,” said K C Vaghela, sub-inspector with Jamnagar B division police station.

Chamadia alleged that the animosity had been brewing ever since he got elected as a councillor. “The Bhokals and the Gazias did not like the way I carried out development works in my ward. They had picked up fights with me in the past, and they resorted to stone pelting on Wednesday,” said Chamadia.

Title: Bihar: Kanhaiya Kumar starts yatra amid arrest rumours
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

CPI leader Kanhaiya Kumar addresses a rally at Motihari on Thursday

BETTIAH/MOTIHARI: Amid high drama, CPI leader Kanhaiya Kumar set off on his ‘Save Constitution, Save Citizenship Satyagraha yatra’ from Mahatma Gandhi’s Bhitiharwa ashram in West Champaran on Thursday.

The former JNUSU president’s yatra on the Mahatma’s martyrdom anniversary was marked by cancellation of his scheduled public meeting at Bettiah, rumours of his arrest or detention and a flood of fake news.

He addressed a large crowd outside the Bhitiharwa ashram before being escorted beyond the boundaries of West Champaran via a circuitous route that dodged the waiting crowds near Bettiah. Greeting another large crowd at the Sports Club in Motihari later in the afternoon, Kanhaiya alleged that he was stopped at Bhitiharwa in a conspiracy that was thwarted by people’s support.

Kanhaiya’s Champaran yatra was preceded by clashes at Bettiah’s Meena Bazar on Wednesday when Bharat bandh supporters protesting against CAA-NRC clashed with shopkeepers. An ugly situation was saved by the prompt action by an alert district administration. “The permission for his public meeting (at the Aerodrome grounds) here was cancelled as meeting grounded was not adequately barricaded,” West Champaran DM Nilesh Ramchandra Deore told TOI.

The Bettiah meeting cancelled, a crowd began assembling at Kudiya Kothi, site of a Raj-era indigo factory, six km from Bettiah as word-of-mouth and Whatsap messages said Kanhaiya would hold a meeting here on his way back from Bhitiharwa. Police kept vigil at Kudiya Kothi. Meanwhile, Kanhaiya — after spending the night at his CPI comrade Om Prash Kranti’s house in Chanpatia— was stopped from leaving Kranti’s residence at 8 am. Allowed an hour later, as he drove out towards Bhitiharwa, a handful of BJP supporters shouted “go back Kanhaiya’ slogans near the Sikrahana bridge near Chanpatia.

A massive crowd greeted Kanhaiya, accompanied by his fellow JNUite and Congress MLA from Kadwa ( Katihar) Shakeel Ahmad Khan, as he entered the ashram gate to pay obeisance to the Mahatma on his martyrdom day. A CPM press release claimed that he was arrested, but Kanhaiya’s statement later at Motihari said, “I was stopped.”

Thanking the Bhitiharwa crowd for coming in such large numbers on Gandhiji’s day of martyrdom, Kanhaiya said, “The Mahatma was murdered because of his adherence to ishwar-allah tero naam, sabko sanmati de bhagwan” hymn and credo. “Today, we are in a situation where hatred is being fanned, a Hindu-Muslim divide is being deepened....people in their own country are being considered second class citizens.”

He added, “I was supposed to go to Motihari from here after a programme in Bettiah. But police, administration say: aapka permission cancel kar diya gaya hai.” Kanhaiya’s statement evoked a “Modi ji ka police hai” reaction from the crowd. A commotion erupted, only to be calmed by Kanhaiya. “He had the permission (to address people at Bhitiharwa),” DM Deore said, adding, the circulation of fake news (on the contrary) was unfortunate.

Meanwhile, at Kudiya Kothi, the ‘Kanhaiya arrested’ rumours and fake news were negated by ‘FaceBook live’ streaming that encaptured the assembled crowd huddled in groups glued to Kanhaiya’s Bhitiharwa speech on smart phones. An hour later, the crowd at the erstwhile indigo factory grounds began to disperse as news filtered in that Kanhaiya had been whisked out of the district through a diversionary route via the Triveni canal to Mainatar- Ghogha- Sariswa- Piparpainti bridge onto to the NH 28 B on the Sugauli- Raxaul road enroute Motihari.

At Motihari, describing the CAA-NRC as ‘black law’, Kanhaiya said, “ We do not acknowledge a government that does not consider us as citizens.” He appealed that people assemble at Patna ’s Gandhi Maidan on February 29 at the culmination of his yatra that he has set out from Champaran to cover Bihar.

Bettiah SP Nitasha Gudiya refuted claims of Kanhaiya’s arrest. “He was not arrested,” she categorically said.

Talking to TOI over phone, Kanhaiya said, “The administration is under pressure and officials were intentionally creating trouble to stop me from holding public meet. This is undemocratic.”

Even Shakeel alleged there was nothing wrong with the protest site at Bettiah and they had followed all instructions given by the administration. “The district administration officials inspected the site with me on Wednesday and first demanded the Tricolour to be removed from the stage. In late evening, they cancelled our permission to hold a public gathering there citing security reasons, but the fact is they are working on instruction of a particular political party.

(With inputs from Sheezan Nezami in Patna)

Title: Tendulkar, Dhoni to bat for mutual funds
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Mumbai: Association of Mutual Funds in India (Amfi) has brought in cricketing icons Sachin Tendulkar and M S Dhoni as brand ambassadors for the ‘ Mutual Fund Sahi Hai’ campaign. Tendulkar, one of the best batsmen ever and Dhoni, a world-cup winning captain for India, have been roped in to help create awareness about mutual funds being the preferred investment option among retail investors, Amfi said. Markets regulator Sebi doesn’t allow individual fund houses to have brand ambassadors, but in 2017 it had allowed the industry as a whole to go for celebrity endorsements. The Tendulkar-Dhoni combine is the first such endorsement for the fund industry.

According to Amfi chairman Nilesh Shah , Tendulkar and Dhoni “evoke unstinted trust and high dependability.” Shah feels the long careers of the two cricketers could be compared to retail investors having a long-term approach towards their investments. “Longer term approach, be it in cricketing career or in mutual fund investments, can deliver rich dividends for cricketers and investors alike,” Shah said.

The hugely successful ‘Mutual Funds Sahi Hai’ campaign was launched three years ago when Aditya Birla MF MD A Balasubramanian was Amfi president. Amfi CEO N S Venkatesh feels that with three years of refinement behind the campaign, the industry trade body felt that the time was right to take the conversation with the retail investors across the country to the next level and hence the cricketing icons were brought on board.

Tendulkar, after signing the deal with Amfi, said that discipline and longer term approach were the cornerstones in achieving success, “be it in any sport and likewise in personal investing.” According to Dhoni, having a goal-based approach, starting early, staying disciplined and not being fazed by volatility are the four mantras that the wicketkeeper-batsman always followed, be it in his cricketing career or in personal money management.

Title: Hyundai to export EVs from India; targets 190,000 units in exports in 2020
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Chennai: Hyundai Motor India, which rolled out it’s 3 millionth export vehicle on Thursday, will make India an export hub for electric vehicles and parts once the local sourcing takes off. The company, which saw over 13% rise in exports in calendar 2019, is developing a new mass market electric UV for India which will have high local content, said SS Kim, MD &CEO Hyundai Motor India. “HMI’s Chennai plant is the only other Hyundai export hub apart from Korea and is responsible for 100 markets,” he said. “Any electric vehicle that's competitive in India is a candidate for export,” he said. HMI, will follow the same long-term strategy with electric vehicles that it does with gasoline or diesel ones. “We are developing a mass market electric UV for India and we will localise its parts aggressively,” said Kim. “It’s still early stages but once the localisation production and procurement is in place, we will export to other countries. We will export both vehicles and components/parts just like internal combustion engine vehicles. Hyundai exported 1,81,200 units in 2019, the highest in 5 years and has a 26% share of all passenger vehicle exports. India’s overall passenger vehicle exports went up in CY2019 at 7,06,000 units from 7 lakh units in CY2018. Hyundai is targeting upto 1,90,000 units in calendar 2020.

HMI’s exports dipped in 2016 and 2017 due to civil war, political and financial turmoil in a number of Latin American and African markets.

“Things are stable now and there is growing demand from markets like Saudi Arabia, South Africa and Mexico and the growing preference is for mid-size vehicles and SUVs rather than small cars,” said Kim. And while its BS4 stock for India is “under control” it will continue to make BS4 vehicles for export markets. Many export markets have regulations that are less stringent than India. South Africa currently has Euro 3 regulations.

Title: SMC begins spot surveys in textile markets to assess fire risk
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

About 100 textile markets on both sides of Ring Road from Udhna Darwaja to Sahara Darwaja will be covered unde... Read More

Surat: Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) is undertaking spot surveys in textile markets located on Ring Road from Thursday. These surveys aim at identifying extra elevations in textile structures and encroachments that block entry of fire vehicles into market premises. About 100 textile markets on both sides of Ring Road from Udhna Darwaja to Sahara Darwaja will be covered under the surveys and spot notices to remove obstructions within seven days will be issued to people concerned.

Municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani had issued instructions in this regard on Wednesday.

“In the old textile market area of Ring Road, the issue of elevation and adornment of the structure from outside with combustible material is not a major problem. But narrow roads and encroachments are,” said a civic officer from central zone.

Begumwadi area in old Surat houses at least 50 small and big-sized textile markets with about 30,000 shops. The same number of shops exists in Limbayat zone on Ring Road. Approximately 23 market surveys were carried out in these areas on Thursday.

A SMC executive engineer said, “We surveyed 23 markets today. The issue is no space for entry of fire vehicles due to encroachments of different types. In their attempt to give unique identification to the buildings, people go for outer decoration which blocks release of smoke. In an emergency situation, firefighters are unable to work efficiently because of the smoke.”

SMC teams are likely to complete the surveys in three days and then clear entry and exit gates of encroachments.

Banchhanidhi Pani said, “We will clear all obstructions in the textile markets from a fire point of view. We can’t let some people play with the lives of others. If firefighters are unable to reach a spot on fire, how can you expect them to save lives and properties?”

Title: Uday Kotak gets reprieve from RBI, can hold 26% in bank
Content:
Uday Kotak, MD & CEO, Kotak Mahindra Bank (File photo)

MUMBAI: Kotak Mahindra Bank has settled its dispute with the Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) over dilution of promoter holding. The settlement between the bank and the regulator envisages the promoters getting six months to dilute their holding to 26%, but losing voting rights beyond 15% with effect from April 2020.In a statement to the stock exchanges, Kotak Mahindra Bank said that the RBI had written to the bank on Wednesday, conveying acceptance of a proposal whereby the bank’s promoter Uday Kotak and family, who hold almost 30%, will cap promoter voting rights at 20% of paid-up voting equity share capital until March 31, 2020. From April 1, 2020 onwards, the promoters’ voting rights in the bank will be capped at 15% of equity share capital.Also, once the agreement with the RBI is approved, the promoters will bring down their shareholding to 26% within six months. Given the bank’s current market capitalisation of Rs 3.11 lakh crore, the promoters will have to sell shares worth Rs 12,500 crore. Alternatively, they can issue fresh shares or dilute equity through an acquisition with the resulting share-swap bringing about the dilution.Kotak Bank had filed a writ petition in the Bombay high court opposing RBI’s directive to dilute the promoter stake when it was required to bring down promoter holding from around 30% to 20% by December 2018 and 15% by 2020. Kotak Bank had responded to this directive by issuing Perpetual Non-Convertible Preference (PNCP) shares in August 2019, which brought down the promoter’s holding to 19.7%. The central bank, however, did not approve this, leading to the bank filing a petition against the RBI.As part of the deal with the central bank, the promoters have agreed not to purchase any further ‘paid-up voting equity shares’ of the bank till the percentage of promoters’ shareholding reaches 15%, or such higher percentage as may be permitted by the RBI from time to time.If the laws in future allow it, the promoters will be entitled to purchase paid-up voting equity shares of the bank up to 15% of the equity shares capital or a higher percentage.The bank’s board of directors have resolved to abide by the conditions set by the RBI. In June 2019, the RBI had penalised Kotak Mahindra Bank Rs 2 crore for its failure to adhere to the regulator’ diktat on promoter shareholding.In September 2018, the RBI had frozen the salary of Bandhan Bank CEO C S Ghosh and barred the lender from opening new branches for not adhering to the central bank’s guidelines on diluting promoter stake. According to banking sources, the petition filed by Kotak Bank might have prevented the RBI from imposing similar restrictions on it.Industry sources pointed out that this was the best deal that Kotak Bank could have expected. Had the court judgment gone in favour of the lender, earlier court orders had reaffirmed RBI’s powers to come out with new guidelines.

Title: Lalu Prasad's aide calls Prashant Kishor sewer water, Tej Pratap welcomes him to RJD
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Tej Pratap Yadav at Patna University campus on Thursday.

PATNA: A day after he was expelled from JD (U), poll strategist Prashant Kishor on Thursday found himself caught in a spat between Tej Pratap , Lalu Prasad’s elder son, and RJD’s state president Jagadanand Singh .

It all began when Singh, while speaking to the media, compared Kishor with sewer water. The RJD leader said, “Sewer water is not used at home or in the kitchen.”

Soon after, Tej, who recently posted pictures of him milking a cow, said Kishor welcome to join RJD if he wished to do so. He also cautioned Singh against unparliamentarily language against the former JD (U) leader. He remarked, “He (Jagdanand) is my uncle and a fatherly figure. Hence, I will advise him to work towards strengthening the party rather than publicly abusing someone. This is against Lalu ji’s ideology.”

Asked if his party is divided over Kishor, Tej said, “Jagdanand’s thinking cannot be compared to mine. One thing is certain that my thoughts are similar to those of Lalu ji’s. I follow Lalu ji’s ideology.”

Tej used the occasion to lash out at chief minister Nitish Kumar for “misusing and dumping Kishor”. He said, “He (Nitish) is in the habit of using people and then throwing them out. This is his policy.”

Bihar Congress chief Madan Mohan Jha indicated that his party was not averse to associating with Kishor. This can happen if the party high command wishes, he added.

On the other hand, Kishor said he would make his future plans public in Patna on February 11. Earlier in 2015, Kishor’s political advocacy group, I-PAC, had handled Mahagathbandhan’s campaign in Bihar. At that time, Congress, RJD and JD (U) were part of the alliance. Currently, I-PAC has a fully functional office in Patna.

Title: Unilever to review global tea business
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Unilever said it has initiated a strategic review of its global tea business. Industry analysts, however, do not expect the Indian subsidiary Hindustan Unilever ( HUL ) to evaluate selling its tea business in India.Tea is part of HUL’s food and refreshments (F&R) portfolio, which contributed about 19% to the company’s 2018-19 revenues (see graphic) of around Rs 38,000 crore. Brooke Bond , a key tea brand of HUL, is an over Rs 2,000-crore brand, and is one of the leading players in India’s beverage category.Other brands include the iconic ‘ Taj Mahal ’ tea under Brooke Bond, which is marketed as a brand closely linked to the heritage culture, while Lipton focuses on emerging consumer tastes such as green tea .With tea in its portfolio, HUL’s connect with consumers goes beyond personal products, opening new opportunities in foods and refreshments in addition to growth in the out-of-home channel. In a statement on Unilever’s fourth quarter and full year performance, CEO Alan Jope said, “We are continuing to evaluate our portfolio and have initiated a strategic review of our global tea business.”Unlike in India, where tea drinking is well entrenched, in the developed markets, black tea is seeing a decline as consumers are said to be moving to other alternatives.Edelweiss Securities said it does not expect HUL to evaluate selling its tea business in India, given that HUL is a market leader and has gained market share over the past few years. “We continue to see HUL being on acquisition mode in India (acquired Indulekha hair oils, Aaditya ice cream, GSK Consumer). In our view, this strategic review of global tea business by Unilever could be possibly for Unilever’s business in some mature markets and for brands like PG Tips,” said Edelweiss Securities research analyst Abneesh Roy.In reply to TOI’s query on the outcome of Unilever’s decision to review its global tea business on India, an HUL spokesperson said, “We have no additional comments to offer since we are in our closed period.” HUL is slated to announce its third quarter results (October-December 2019) on Friday.“We expect HUL to see volume growth of approximately 3% YoY on a high base of 10% YoY (Q2FY20 saw volume growth of 5% YoY on a similar base of 10% YoY),” said Roy. For calendar year 2019, Unilever delivered an underlying sales growth of about 3%, and witnessed growth from emerging markets and its home care unit. Overall growth was lower than the guided range due to the slowdown in the December quarter.While Unilever said India performed well in a slowing market, it added that in the fourth quarter (October-December 2019), price growth decelerated, driven by price reductions in India.

Title: Patna: Buy dresses, ‘papads’ at 5-day Mahila Udyog Mela
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Women select sari at Mahila Udyog Mela in Patna on Thursday.

PATNA: Animal and fisheries resources department secretary N Vijayalakshmi on Thursday encouraged women entrepreneurs in rural areas to learn skills like cattle rearing and fish, poultry and dairy farming.

Addressing the inaugural ceremony of Bihar Mahila Udyog Mela organized by the Bihar Mahila Udyog Sangh (BMUS) at the Planetarium on Thursday, Vijayalakshmi, who is also the managing director of Women Development Corporation (WDC), said the department would soon provide skill development classes on fisheries, poultry and cattle under the Bihar Skill Development Mission.

“The animal husbandry sector is also focusing on generating employment opportunities for women. We can train rural women in such skills and generate employment. As far as the funding is concerned, the WDC will help women get loan for start-ups,” Vijayalakshmi said.

Altogether 70 stalls, including four food stalls, have been put up by women entrepreneurs at Udyog Mela. Many of them have come all the way from Madhya Pradesh, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat and other districts of Bihar.

BMUS president Usha Jha said, “Despite the inclement weather in Patna , the footfall of customers was good on Day 1 of the five-day fair. This time, we have two customized stalls of shoes and cakes.”

The items on sale include embroidered suits, ‘Anarkali’ suits, Madhubani paintings, handmade wall hangings, artificial flowers, block-printed garments, ‘papads’, pickle, ‘sattu’, potato chips, sweets, jewellery and other home decor items.

A Patna-based entrepreneur, Shazia Qaiser, is selling customized footwear for occasions like weddings and parties. “I use materials like leather, fabric, foam and rubber. Party sandals are made using ‘resham’ and ‘zari’ embroidery, stones, crystals and pearls,” she said.

Another entrepreneur, Anita, has displayed Madhubani paintings as well as stone and marble sculptures in the range of Rs 1,200 to Rs 3,500.

Poonam Kumari, a resident of Bank Road, bought a sari, mango pickles and some home decor items on Day 1.

Title: Muzaffarpur records poorest AQI in country
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Patna’s AQI, on the other hand, was ranked the fourth worst.

PATNA: Muzaffarpur recorded the poorest air quality in the country on Thursday as the air quality index (AQI) stood at 418. Patna’s AQI, on the other hand, was ranked the fourth worst.

According to a bulletin issued by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the overall AQI of Patna deteriorated from 276 on Wednesday to 305 on Thursday. The AQIs of Muzaffarpur and Gaya were at 418 and 250, respectively.

Track the pollution level in your city

Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) officials claimed that Patna’s overall AQI was the average of the AQIs near the planetarium (404), BIT-Patna (337), Eco Park (280), and S K Memorial Hall (194). The air quality oscillated between 301 and 309 throughout the day as per the data available on ‘Sameer’, a mobile appl that provides hourly updates on the national AQI published by the CPCB.

BSPCB chairman Ashok Ghosh told this newspaper that suspended pollutants from various sources were trapped in the atmosphere due to thermal inversion. “This has lowered vertical wind movement, causing very low dispersion of the pollutants. Hence, the moisture level in the atmosphere has increased. This will continue until the prevailing meteorological condition changes,” he said.

He added, “The AQI can improve only if there is good sunlight and high wind velocity. Light rainfall can, however, further deteriorate the air quality of Patna.”

The Air Quality Early Warning System of the Ministry of Earth Sciences has predicted that the overall AQI of Patna will witness a sharp decline due to climatic conditions.

Ghosh said, “The newly installed continuous ambient air quality-monitoring station at the DRM’s office in Khagaul, which became operational on January 13, is yet to be connected to the CPCB’s server. Two more monitoring stations in Hajipur and Patna City will be operational by the first week of February.”

Title: IMFL worth Rs 21 lakh seized; two arrested
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A total of 6 ,960 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 21 lakh were seized from a truck near Halvad in Morbi district on Wednesday night. Cops also arrested two bootleggers identified as Dinesh Bishnoi (30), the truck driver , and Balwantsinh Zala (29), who had come to collect the IMFL supply.

“During interrogation, Bishnoi revealed that one Kalu Bishnoi had uploaded the liquor cache on to the truck from Barmer in Rajasthan and had asked him to contact Pradeepsinh Zala, who sent Balwantsinh to take delivery of the consignment. We have booked Pradeepsinh who is yet to be arrested,” said V V Jadeja, inspector with Morbi local crime branch.

Title: Met: Rise in temperature likely after February 7 in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Fog envelops Patna on Thursday

PATNA: The winter season does not seem to be in a hurry to depart from Bihar as a fresh spell of cloudy and windy weather along with light showers was witnessed at a few places on Thursday. Although weathermen have ruled out the possibility of continuation of showers, mercury is set to plunge from Saturday, following the departure of clouds.

The daily weather bulletin issued by the Patna Meteorological Centre on Thursday evening stated that light rainfall occurred at some places over southwest and south central parts of Bihar like Dehri (1mm), Gaya (0.8mm), Patna (0.3mm) and Muzaffarpur (0.2mm). Besides, moderate to dense fog was observed at few places in the state during the last 24 hours.

The bulletin also stated that the night temperature was likely to fall by two to four notches during the next 48 hours.

“As per the extended weather outlook prepared by the India Meteorological Department (IMD), a rising trend in temperature is expected in Bihar from February 7,” Patna Meteorological Centre director Vivek Sinha told TOI on Thursday.

Asked about the prevailing inclement weather, Sinha said the cloud cover formed due to a western disturbance passing through the region and the skies were likely to be cleared by Saturday.

“Moisture incursion due to the western disturbance and an anti-cyclonic circulation over Jharkhand led to cloudy conditions and showers at a few places. However, the weather system is likely to subside over the next 24 hours. Accordingly, clear skies are expected from Saturday,” he added.

High performance computing facility at CUSB: A high-performance computing (HPC) facility has been set up at the Centre for Environmental Sciences of Central University of South Bihar (CUSB).

“The facility, which has been installed as part of the Climate Modelling Network Programme of the Department of Science and Technology, will be used for weather and climate change research and complex mathematical models,” said CUSB’s public relations officer (PRO) Md Mudassir Alam.

The project at CUSB is being looked after by Pradhan Parth Sarthi, professor of environmental sciences department.

Title: Clouds plunge city into darkness, push temp up
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Boatmen on the Hooghly anchor their vessels to the shore as darkness approaches on Thursday afternoon

KOLKATA: A low cumulonimbus cloud plunged the city into near darkness shortly after noon as an upper air trough loomed over Kolkata for several hours on Thursday. Street lights had to be switched on and cars ran with headlights on as visibility dropped.

The darkness persisted for about 10 minutes till the sky opened up and a sharp shower followed. While some parts of Kolkata received a steady drizzle, some areas in Howrah and Hooghly were lashed by a short hailstorm. The Alipore Met office recorded 5.7mm of rain till 5.30pm.

An upper air trough stretching from Haryana to Bangladesh through Uttar Pradesh , Bihar and Gangetic Bengal generated a stream of low clouds that floated into Kolkata around 12.30pm. “They hung low over the city, which led to the darkness. But the rain was light, barring a few places outside the city,” said Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC) director G K Das.

Other than the thick, low cloud cover, small cloud cells gathered in the sky and moisture kept flowing into south Bengal from the Bay of Bengal. It kept the entire day cloudy. “Cloud convections from Jharkhand hovered above Kolkata, keeping the sunlight blocked for most of the time. This, along with the wind, made the maximum temperature plunge to 22.8°C — four degrees below normal,” said Das. According to him, the maximum temperature will start crawling up from Friday. However, even though Kolkata could be cloudy in the first half of Friday, chances of rain were low.

The cloud cover since Wednesday pulled the mercury up, with the minimum temperature touching 18.8°C on Thursday, four degrees above normal. It could drop by a couple of degrees on Friday and slide further to 13°C-14°C this weekend. “While the minimum temperature could plunge to 16°C on Friday, it could fall by another couple of notches on Saturday. The chill will return once the trough moves away and the cloud cover goes,” said Das.

Title: Surat airport finally gets SMC’s fire NOC
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The airport had been operating without fire NOC since 2005

SURAT: Finally , the Surat international airport has been given no-objection certificate (NOC) by the Surat Municipal Corporation ’s (SMC) fire and emergency department after the Airports Authority of India (AAI) had applied for the NOC.

Since 2005, the Surat airport had been operating without taking the mandatory NOC from the SMC’s fire and emergency department. The issue had come up during the inspection of the warehouse at the domestic cargo terminal by the fire authorities in the first week of December-2019. A diesel pump installed inside the warehouse was found to be in the non-working condition.

The fire department had issued notice to the Surat airport authorities asking them to take the NOC within 15 days. On checking the records, it was found that the airport authorities had not applied for the NOC since 2005.

According to the national fire safety manual, every airport has to take fire NOC from the local civic authorities. However, the Surat airport authorities failed to take the NOC.

Official sources in the SMC’s fire and emergency department said that the fire systems installed at the airport were inspected on January 6, 2020 and that they were found in the working condition. The systems including fire hydrant with hose box and hose reel, fire extinguisher, main fire pump with diesel pump, smoke detector with fire alarm system, sprinkler, under ground water tank and exit were all checked.

SMC chief fire officer Basant Pareek told TOI: “After conducting inspection at the airport, we found all the fire fighting systems in the working condition. Hence, the fire NOC was issued to the Surat airport. The NOC is valid for a period of one year and that the authorities will have to renew it every year.”

Pareek added, “The AAI has its own fire fighting system to deal in the emergency situation. They have got trained staff, equipment, a fire station etc., but the fire NOC is mandatory from the SMC’s fire department. We came to know after checking the records that the airport had not taken NOC since 2005.”

Title: Two women arrested for trying to extort Rs 25 lakh from businessman
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: Rander police arrested two women , including a reporter of a local news channel , for honey trapping a businessman and attempting to extort Rs 25 lakh from him on Wednesday. Ashmita Dodiya and Priya Kanojiya were arrested by police from the spot when they were trying to extort money from the complainant. Third accused Ashok Raval of Mahadev News channel has been booked, but is yet to be arrested.

According to the complaint, a 43-year-old carting agent contacted Dodiya after collecting her contact details from a friend. Kanojiya made a video when the two were enjoying their private moments. After the video was made, Dodiya demanded Rs25 lakh from the complainant. Kanojiya introduced herself as a reporter to the complainant and threatened to telecast the video on Mahadev News channel if the money was not paid to them.

The victim contacted his friend who had provided him Dodiya’s contact details and informed him about the extortion bid. The victim’s friend then called police who immediately arrived at the spot and arrested the women.

Police have seized the mobile phone with which the intimate moments were shot. The mobile phone is being sent to Forensic Science Laboratory for examination by police, who will also investigate if the accused had extorted money in a similar way from other victims.

Title: Sports meet kicks off at city college
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PATNA: A four-day annual sports meet, christened ‘Aagaaz’, kicked off at St Xavier’s College of Management and Technology (SXCMT) on Thursday. Students of more than 25 city schools and colleges are participating in soccer, volleyball, basketball and carom competitions at the meet that will conclude on February 2.

In volleyball, BIT-Patna and NIFT students defeated May Flower School (25-13, 15-25, 25-21) and Chanakya National Law University (25-21, 22- 25, 25-15), respectively. In carom, Ashu Aman of SXCMT entered the finals of boys’ singles. A N College, St Michael’s High School and IIT-P qualified the semi-finals of basketball in the boys’ category while Patna Women’s College and S B College won the basketball girls’ category against CNLU and Magadh Mahila College, respectively.

SXCMT principal Fr T Nishaant SJ was also present on the occasion.

NIT-P: Students of National Institute of Technology (NIT) participated in events like doodling, T-shirt painting, parliamentary debate, track relay and robot war on Day 6 of ‘Corona and Melange’, a techno-cultural fest.

Arjun, Abhimantu and Rishab of NIT-P won the robot war in which 20 teams from various colleges and institutes participated. Shivang Sharma bagged the first prize in T-shirt painting whereas Meenal and Aastha stood second and third, respectively. In doodling, Vaishali, Punendru Priyadarshi and Garima stood first, second and third, respectively.

Title: Yellow all the way as Patnaites worship Goddess of knowledge
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PATNA: Clad in traditional yellow dresses, Patnaites celebrated Saraswati Puja with enthusiasm on Thursday. Many youngsters played with ‘abir’ on the occasion.

Pandals were also set up on the campus of several schools, colleges, hostels, and coaching institutes in the city. While Magadh Mahila College girls worshipped Goddess Saraswati and recited hymns, students of Sri Arvind Mahila College organized a cultural programme.

Hostellers did not lag behind and celebrated the festival with their friends. Shreya Sinha, who lives in a hostel on Jagdeo Path, told this newspaper, “We enacted a small play on the importance of Saraswati Puja last evening. After worshipping the Goddess, we distributed ‘prasad’ among the poor.”

Puja pandals with idols of Goddess Saraswati were also erected in residential colonies. Gola Road resident Sarita Sharma, who visited a pandal on Jagdeo Path with her kids, said, “Saraswati Puja has a lot of significance in my life. I prayed to the Goddess and offered flowers and sweets to her today.”

Another devotee, Komal Kumari of Danapur, said, “Every year, I visit at least five pandals for worshipping the Goddess. This has always been fruitful to me and my family.”

Meanwhile, city-based priest, Shiv Shankar Bhatt, pointed out that students, musicians, scholars, and artists worship Goddess Saraswati, who is an epitome of art, music, knowledge, and wisdom.

Kathak dancer Hansika said, “I make sure that I celebrate the day in the best possible way. This year, my students surprised me with a special dance performance dedicated to Goddess Saraswati.”

CM prays for prosperity of state: Chief minister Nitish Kumar attended a Saraswati Puja function at the residence of development commissioner A K Singh in IAS Colony and worshipped the Goddess. He prayed for the happiness, peace and prosperity of the state. Several dignitaries, including state assembly Speaker Vijay Kumar Chaudhary were also present on the occasion.

Title: Tight security for immersion of idols
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PATNA: Patna police personnel and paramilitary forces conducted flag marches across the city to avoid any untoward incident during Saraswati puja festivities on Thursday.

Flag marches were conducted on Bailey Road, Samanpura, areas under the Airport police station, Phulwarisharif and Pirbahore. Patna DM (incharge) Suharsha Bhagat said the festival passed off peacefully.

“The administration has fixed February 1 as the deadline for immersion of Saraswati idols. Magistrates and security forces will remain deployed till then,” he said. Bhagat said the idols would be immersed in artificial ponds near the banks of the Ganga. “Unlike previous years, people will not be allowed to immerse idols in the river,” he added.

District administration sources said at least 30 static magistrates have been deployed in areas which are prone to clashes, including hostels of Patna University.

Title: PU to develop herbal garden soon
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PATNA: In order to develop 102-year-old Patna University (PU) as a green campus, the authorities have decided to set up a herbal garden at its Saidpur complex and plant saplings of medicinal plants and spices in and around the main campus.

The Internal Quality Assurance Cell (IQAC) of PU, at its meeting held here recently under the chairmanship of vice-chancellor Rash Bihari Prasad Singh, also decided to construct a green house as well as a glass house on the campus for developing floriculture on the campus. “The state government has already sanctioned necessary funds for the purpose,” the VC said.

PU is already engaged in preparing a comprehensive directory of plants found on the campus right from Patna Law College to Patna Women’s College soon. This colourful directory would be a souvenir of the university’s centenary celebrations held with much fanfare a couple of years back

PU botany department senior teacher and editor of the directory, Birendra Prasad, told the newspaper that more than 200 varieties of different types of plants are found on the campus. Each of these plants would figure in the directory along with its botanical details, economic importance and medicinal value, if any, and its photograph.

Referring to the proposed herbal garden Prasad said that work of earth filling would be taken up well before the development of garden as Saidpur happens to be low lying area, always obsessed with the acute problem of water logging. After the land filling work is completed, all types of medicinal plants and spices would be transplanted here for the benefit of students as well as research scholars of life sciences, he said.

Medicinal plants available on the campus include ambala (Phyllanththus emblica), arjun (terminalia arjuna), ashok (polyathia longifolia), bael ( age marmelos), bahera (terminalia balerica), laung or clove ( syzygium aromaticum), chandan ( pterocarpus santalinum), dalchini ( cinnamomum cassia), hare ( terminalia chebula), jamun ( syzygium cumin), lasura (cordia myxa), neem ( azadirachta indica), rudraksha ( elaeocarpus granitrus), saptparnee and (alastonia scholaris).

It may be mentioned here that the city of Patna, which once used to be the home for a rich variety of trees, is fast losing its floral wealth, thanks to its unplanned growth in recent years. A good number of rare and beautiful species of plants have either become extinct or are facing extinction in the city.

Even ‘Patli’ trees, after which the city had derived its ancient name ‘Patliputra’, are on the verge of extinction. Only a few species of this tree can be found in the city today, one of them at Patna Museum complex. At least four other plant species, namely Hyphaene Indica, Madhuca Longifalia, Didymocarpus Ladelicate and Tectona Grandis, have already vanished, according to botanists.

Retired professor of botany and old resident of Patna Ajay Kishore Sharan said the city had a rich variety of trees, both long and small, in some cases extending more than 100 feet in height. Most of them were of the flowering kind. But, in recent times, most of them have vanished. The most common trees found in the city today are neem, peepal, mango, bel, red cotton and lebendrum which form over 60% of the total tree population, he said.

Title: Minister: 2 new bridges to be ready by March
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PATNA: Several key bridge and road projects are likely to be inaugurated or launched before the state assembly elections to be held around October-November this year.

Road construction minister Nand Kishore Yadav told TOI that a bridge is being constructed by National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) as a part of Patna-Ara-Buxar four-lane project and another four-lane bridge connecting Kesariya in East Champaran and Chhapra in Saran district is expected to be thrown open for vehicular movement in two months. He said the bridge in north Bihar is being constructed with an estimated outlay of over Rs200 crore.

The 1.53km-long bridge parallel to Koilwar bridge over Sone river connecting Patna with Bhojpur is also being constructed with an estimated outlay of over Rs200 crore. “Work on three lanes of the new bridge is in the final stages and is likely to be thrown open for vehicular movement by the end of March,” the minister said.

Koilwar apart, bidding process is also under way for construction of a four-lane bridge parallel to Mahatma Gandhi Setu across the Ganga. The minister said altogether seven big firms have submitted bids for construction of the bridge, which is part of PM Narendra Modi’s special package for Bihar he had announced before the 2015 assembly elections in the state. Its total length from Zero Mile in Patna to Ramashish Chowk in Hajipur is 5.63km and the overall length comprising the approach roads on either side is 14.5km. The bidding process for the project was initiated by the ministry of road, transport and highways in August last year.

“The bidding process is to be completed by March this year, following which at least two months will be given to the selected firm for mobilization of equipment and manpower. Thus, actual construction is likely to commence around June,” Nand Kishore said.

Sources said the new bridge west of Mahatma Gandhi Setu will be constructed with an outlay of Rs2926.42 crore, with civil cost amounting to Rs2411.50 crore.

Works are also under way for rehabilitation of 38 years’ old Mahatma Gandhi Setu. The rehabilitation work on its western flank is targeted to be completed by March this year. The rehabilitation work on its eastern flank will commence thereafter.

The minister said Digha-AIIMS elevated road in Patna is likely to be ready by March this year. The first 2km from AIIMS-Patna is a two-lane semi-elevated road and the remaining stretch is a four-lane elevated structure.

Title: All-women sit-in against CAA/NRC at Ballarpur today
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Chandrapur: Muslim women under the banner of Women Against NRC and Muslim Ekta Manch have geared up for a massive agitation against the controversial Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and the proposed National Register for Citizens (NRC).

A grand all-women agitation has been planned at Ballarpur SDO office on Friday where protesters will stage daylong sit-in to oppose the allegedly tyrant laws of the central government.

Shakila Parveen, district president of Jamaat-e-Islami’s women’s wing, alleged that the CAA has been brought to “rectify” the failure of NRC in Assam. “There are many burning issues like poverty, unemployment, health and education in the country. At a time when the Centre has failed on all these fronts and country’s GDP has dropped to a record low of 4.7%, the government is busy in pitting one community against other,” said Parveen.

“It is a well-planned conspiracy and the ruling party is sowing seeds of discord among communities for its political gains,” she charged. Parveen also accused the ruling BJP of being inclined to fascism and using Hitler’s tactics to persecute Muslims in India.

Humera Khan from Muslim Ekta Mach informed that over 3,000 women from all major towns in Chandrapur and Gadchiroli districts will gather at Ballarpur and stage the daylong sit-in to oppose the CAA, National Population Register (NRP) and NRC on Friday.

Leaders from various organizations including Bharatiya Muslim Parishad, Jijau Brigade, Shramik Yalgar, Tipu Sultan Foundation, Shaheed Ashfaqulla Khan Foundation and various organizations including Jamat-e-Islami Hind etc have declared their support to the agitation and will address the gathering.

Title: Leopard attacks old woman in Ankleshwar
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Surat: A 71-year-old woman was attacked by a leopard at Bharan village in Ankleshwar taluka of Bharuch district in the wee hours of Thursday. Forest officials said the woman received serious injuries on head and other parts of the body and was referred to civil hospital in Vadodara for treatment. She was first taken to civil hospital in Bharuch.

Fuli Vasava was attacked by the leopard inside her kutcha house without a door. The leopard escaped after the woman screamed for help.

Bhavna Desai, deputy conservator of forest (DCF), Bharuch range, said, “This is second leopard attack at Bharan village this month. In the first incident, a five-year-old boy died after he was attacked by a leopard in a sugarcane field where he was playing in the morning hours.” Kishan Valvi, 5, succumbed to serious injuries that he suffered in the leopard attack that took place on January 5.

Desai said the old woman was a farm labourer and lived with her son, who was also sleeping in the house when the leopard attacked the former. Their kutcha house constructed with woods and mud had no door. The woman was sleeping near the house entrance.

“We have placed cages in and around the village to capture the leopard. The camera tracking of the leopard is being done in the entire area. We found pug marks at a lake near the village. Also, villagers, especially those living close to sugarcane fields, have been sensitized and asked to take precautions” Desai added.

Title: JLR chief to retire in Sept, will take up non-exec role
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Reeba Zachariah | TNN

Mumbai: After serving as CEO of Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) for a decade, Ralf Speth will retire from his current role this September as he turns 65. According to the company’s HR policy, executive directors retire at the age of 65. However, Speth will continue to be on the board of JLR in a non-executive capacity. He will be redesignated as the vice-chairman of the company that accounts for the bulk of parent Tata Motors ’ revenue. According to the company’s HR norms, a non-executive director can remain on the board until the age of 70.

Tata Motors had acquired JLR from Ford Motor Company for $2.3 billion in June 2008 and brought Speth, a German engineer, on board to steer JLR in February 2010. Besides JLR, Speth is a director on the board of Tata Motors and Tata Sons, the promoter of the Indian automotive giant. A search committee has been formed to find the next CEO for JLR, Tata Motors said in a statement.

The Financial Times reported that Denmark national Hanne Sorensen, independent director of Tata Motors, could be a replacement for Speth. This, however, could not be confirmed. Speth, one of the highest paid executives in the Tata Group , has developed JLR from a “niche UK-centric manufacturer to a technological leading, global premium company”.

Title: Bajaj Auto posts 15% hike in Q3 profit
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Pune: Despite a fall in motorcycle sales in the domestic market by about 16% to 5.4 lakh units, Bajaj Auto said its standalone net profit grew 15% to Rs 1,262 crore.

The automakers 16% fall was in comparison to the industry’s 14% fall during the quarter. The company’s revenue grew 3% to Rs 7,436 crore. The company was largely helped by lower taxes during the quarter, where it paid only Rs 410 crore against Rs 457 crore, a year ago.

The export markets also somewhat cushioned the steep fall in the domestic market for the Pune-based motorcycle maker. Export of motorcycles grew 11% to 4.8 lakh units, while it also got more bang in rupee for each dollar of exports.

Including the commercial vehicles, the total sale of the company fell 5%, compared to the year-ago period. The company added that its cash and cash equivalents stood at Rs 17,407 crore, against Rs 15,986 crore, a year ago.

Title: Four killed in two different accidents
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Rajkot: Four persons were killed in two different accidents reported from Gondal of Rajkot district and Lalpur of Jamnagar district early on Thursday morning.

Two persons were killed in Gondal and 16 injured when a tractor collided with a truck on Rajkot-Gondal Highway.

“The truck rammed into the rear of the tractor’s trolley in which labourers were seated. After ramming the trolley, the driver lost control of the truck which turned turtle. Then the truck fell on the cabin of a roadside tea stall,” said Ajaysinh Jadeja, sub-inspector with Gondal taluka police station.

Those killed in the accident were identified as Govind Patel (20) and Chhotubha Jadeja (52). While Patel was a labourer sitting in the trolley, Jadeja was the owner of the kiosk.

The truck driver, identified as Rajkumar Punjabi (40), was caught by local people when he was trying to flee the spot. They tied him to a pole till police arrived at the spot. Cops booked the driver for negligence causing a fatal accident and arrested him.

In Lalpur, two persons including a woman were killed when the mini-truck they were travelling in overturned by the roadside on Lalpur-Bhanwad Road.

“The victims, identified as Madhu Ahir (52) and Jivi Bantawa (65), were declared brought dead at Lalpur Civil Hospital. The accident left six persons injured who were shifted to GG Hospital in Jamnagar. The victims were going to attend an engagement ceremony in Jamnagar from their native, Varvala village of Jamjodhpur taluka in Jamnagar district,” said V A Parmar, sub-inspector with Lalpur police station.

Title: Brain-dead accident victim’s organs save three lives
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

cap

Rajkot: Overriding their personal grief , the family members of an accident victim of Rajkot decided to donate his organs after doctors declared him brain dead. The family’s noble gesture managed to save three other precious lives.

Virendra Bosamia (64) met with an accident while he was on his way to Jasdan on his bike on January 25. Bosamia was admitted to Wockhardt Hospital in Rajkot where his condition deteriorated and doctors declared brain dead.

Dr Vijay Maniyar of Wockhardt Hospital said that he along with another physician convinced deceased’s son, Chintan, to donate his father’s organs.

“Chintan convinced his grieving family comprising his mother Jyotsana, brother Paras and sister Asha for organ donation.
