When they agreed, the body was shifted to the Kidney Hospital in Ahmedabad where State Organ and Tissue Transplant Organization (SOTTO) regional transplant co-ordinator, Dr Divyesh Viroja and Dr Pranjal Modi, completed the transplant procedure,” said Dr Maniyar.

A team of seven doctors carried out the transplant procedures on Bosamia. The deceased’s two kidneys were donated to a 31-year-old woman and a 29-year-old man, while the liver was donated to a 41-year-old man.

“In his death, Bosamia ensured that three others can lead a happy life,” Dr Maniyar added.

Title: Jamia firing: Suddenness gave us no time to react, say police
Content:
Students protesting the firing at Jamia

NEW DELHI: Police action , or inaction rather, allowed a man to open fire at the protest site in Jamia Millia Islamia and injure a university student. Cameras have caught the cops on Thursday standing idly even as the shooter animatedly waved the pistol and threatened to shoot, some policemen in fact capturing the scene on their mobile phones. Later they were seen making the injured student, Shadab Farooq , jump over the metal barricade when taking him to hospital.Police could have moved swiftly to prevent the youth from firing because he was threatening to do so for over a minute. Instead, the cops stood idly by, their officer in the forefront. Even after the firing, only one policeman stepped forward to nab the shooter, though others joined him later.Police pleaded the suddenness gave them little time to react. “Around 1.30pm, while the protesters were marching, a person burst out of the crowd brandishing a small firearm-like object and within a split second, before anyone could assess or react, fired at the marching students,” said Anil Mittal, Delhi Police additional PRO.Senior officers who have served abroad and have had training exchanges with their western counterparts explained that in incidents like this, the shooter is either tasered or shot in the leg or hand. “If the gunman does not respond to a warning or two, policemen are well within their rights to shoot at him,” a retired officer said. “The videos in circulation show the policemen had ample time to react and grab the youth.”Later, the injured student had to negotiate police barriers when being taken to hospital. Mittal claimed Farooq was lifted over the barricades to save time in accessing medical aid. He added that special commissioners of police Satish Golchha and Praveer Ranjan had met Farooq at the AIIMS Trauma Centre and assured him of all help in recovering from the gunshot.A case for attempt to murder under Section 307 of the IPC has been registered. The Arms Act has also been invoked against the shooter. The Crime Branch is investigating.On several occasions in the past year, Delhi Police has failed to act like a professional police force. The lack of training and discipline was evident in the incident of June 2019 involving tempo driver Sarabjeet Singh, who had taken out a sword to confront the cops. Five policemen responded by hitting the tempo driver and his son with sticks and pistol butts, a few even landing kicks on Singh’s head. On December 15, during the protests at Jamia, a video showed a group of cops dragging a man by his arms even as two women tried to stop them. There was also criticism of excessive police action to quell the protests that day.These incidents have highlighted how the capital’s police force not only lacks non-lethal devices like tasers, but also lacking training in control rogue elements. Plans to procure non-lethal riot control equipment are stuck in paperwork since 2015.

Title: Surat: Man who killed his lover’s husband in Pandesara nabbed
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Cops at the crime spot

SURAT: The man involved in the murder of a vegetable vendor in Pandesara was nabbed by police while trying to escape to his native village in Uttar Pradesh on Thursday.

Santosh Prajapati was nabbed when he was on way to his native village near Chitrakoot district. The accused had escaped from the city during early hours of Wednesday after murdering his employer. Cops are likely to arrive in the city with him on Friday. The accused had allegedly killed Premchand Sonkar along with the victim’s wife Sudha. Prajapati and Sudha, who were in an illicit relationship , killed Premchand since he came to know about their affair, police investigation revealed.

Sonkar had employed Prajapati for helping him at his vegetable cart. Prajapati, who lived in neighbouring house, used to visit Premchand’s house frequently and became close to Sudha. There used to be frequent fights between Premchand and his wife over her affair. Prajapati and Sudha planned to murder Premchand and on Wednesday at 1am she opened the door for her paramour to enter the house. Prajapati first strangled Premchand using a rope while Sudha held his hands. Later Prajapati slit the victim’s throat with a knife and also hammered his head to ensure death. The murder was executed in the presence of Premchand and Sudha’s four children aged 11, 8, 5 and 2 years.

Sudha locked her house and went to Prajapati’s with the children. They spent the night there before Prajapati left for his hometown. Sudha returned to her house and sought neighbours’ help to open the door. She told neighbours that robbers had entered her house and killed Sonkar. She told the same thing to police, but her children revealed the truth.

Title: Coronavirus: ‘Safe’ Chhapra girl discharged from PMCH
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: A 29-year-old woman from Chhapra, who was kept in the isolation ward of Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH), was discharged from the hospital on Thursday after test reports showed that she was not suffering from the Novel coronavirus (nCoV).The researcher, who had arrived from China recently, was brought to PMCH on Monday after reporting symptoms of cold and breathlessness — signs associated with the deadly virus which has China in its grips and is spreading fast across Southeast Asia.Her nose, throat swabs and blood sample were sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune for nCoV test as well as to Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences, Patna for influenza A and B tests, both of which came negative.State surveillance officer Ragini Mishra, who is the nodal officer for nCoV, said, “We received the report from NIV this morning. The report states that the girl’s pathological samples have tested negative for CoV. A copy was been mailed to the PMCH superintendent to release her. Even the report from RMRI, which we got earlier, was negative, which means she was suffering from a common viral infection.”The woman, a research scholar at Tianjin in China, had reached Kolkata on January 22 and the next day she arrived at her native place in Chhapra. She was kept overnight at the district hospital on Sunday, after one of her family members informed the state health society about symptoms similar to those of nCoV. Next day she was brought to PMCH.“I had been saying since the beginning that I was completely fine, however, the officials were doing their duty and I will cooperate with them,” she told TOI on Thursday.The health department was also keeping a tab on a 22-year-old Sitamarhi resident who had reached Danapur in Patna via Kolkata on January 19 from Wuhan in China. On Tuesday he left for Sitamarhi.

Title: Gold demand at 8-year low in October-December: WGC
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

(Representative image)

CHENNAI: High gold prices during October-December quarter of 2019 pushed gold demand to a 8-year-low, when consumption was 194.3 tonnes, data from World Gold Council (WGC) showed.

Traditionally a high-demand period, the quarter which included Diwali and the start of the wedding season, witnessed gold lose its sheen owing to 20% higher prices compared to the previous year.

Jewellery demand stood at 149 tonnes, down 17% from 180 tonnes and the demand for investment dropped by 20%. The data from the council showed that gold demand for calendar year 2019 also fell 9% by volume, because of subdued demand in the second half of the year.

“By volume, India’s annual gold demand was at 690 tonnes — lower than our outlook of 700-800 tonnes — primarily because of a sharp surge in prices of over 20% in H2. Growth in H1 was followed by a sharp drop in Q3. Diwali and Dhanteras revived hopes but the volatility coupled with a higher price bar impacted demand, in the lower and middle price bands,” said PR Somadundaram, managing director India, World Gold Council.

Jewellers witnessed up to a 30% drop in demand on an average in Q4 and was restricted to necessary purchases for weddings and other occasions.

“The demand in the first half was good and since June, when the prices began to shoot up, it dropped and on average in the second half, we saw a 25%-30% drop in demand,” said Anantha Padmanabhan, MD, NAC Jewellers and chairman, All India Gems and Jewellers domestic council.

Looking forward, jewellers are expecting the upcoming budget to reduce import duty on gold from the current 12.5% to at least 10% which would inturn help salvage the demand situation.

“As policy measures unfold, broader economic growth accelerates and local prices of the past 6 months become more acceptable among households, India’s gold demand will be in the range of 700-800 tonnes in 2020,” said Somasundaram.

Title: Brexit will oust 73 members, many of them anti-CAA, from Euro parliament
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Brexit kicks in on Friday, with the EU having ratified the UK divorce (AFP)

NEW DELHI: When the European parliament meets again at the end of March to vote on India’s CAA legislation, the 73 British MEPs, many of whom are believed to be behind the numerous resolutions against India, won’t be present. With Brexit kicking in on Friday, all 73 British MEPs would have left. To that extent, the deferment of the vote in the European parliament was a last hurrah that was aborted.

Gaitri Kumar, India’s envoy to Brussels, has met all the groups who have sponsored the drafts in the past couple of days to explain the Indian perspective. Some of the groups have already been convinced of the Indian argument. The resolutions, sources here believe, have been sponsored by Pakistan via some of the British Labour and Liberal Democrat MEPs who belong to groups like S&D and Renew Europe which have sponsored these resolutions.

Foreign minister S Jaishankar will be visiting Brussels in mid-February in preparation for Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s visit there for the India-EU summit on March 13. Some of the European lawmakers said they would wait to get answers from him before voting on the resolution. In addition, Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla also wrote to the president of the European Parliament, David Maria Sassoli: "As members of Inter Parliamentary Union , we should respect sovereign processes of fellow legislatures, especially in democracies."

However, the issue has not died, merely been kicked down the road. For Pakistan, this exercise keeps the issues in play, particularly because they have been portrayed as being infringement on human rights and Islamophobia.

The Indian defence centered around the argument that the CAA process is internal to India. In addition, it is being debated hotly on the streets, in the states and in the courts. There are 60 petitions pending in Supreme Court against this amendment. The government’s view has been that the entire process would be allowed to run the course of popular and judicial scrutiny. For the European parliament to be passing resolutions on something that is undergoing scrutiny in India, would be disingenuous.

But within the Indian government, certain quarters say the commission and member states should do their bit with their own MEPs, given the extensive briefings etc. that their diplomats have been accorded by the Indian government. Sources said, “As fellow democracies, the EU Parliament should not take actions that call into question the rights and authority of democratically elected legislatures in other regions of the world.” In addition, India said the European countries themselves have set up their own conditions for naturalisation that is dependent on their own context, with their own criteria. India’s context is unique, given the circumstances of its partition and the politico-religious context that exists in this subcontinent. “Every society that fashions a pathway to naturalisation, contemplates both a context and criteria. This is not discrimination. In fact, European societies have followed the same approach.”

Title: Partial operations at Porvorim water treatment plant by March
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: By March 2020, the new 15MLD water treatment plant at Porvorim will be made partly operational, PWD chief engineer Uttam Parsekar told TOI. Porvorim is presently on the tail-end of the Assonora water treatment plant’s distribution network and suffers water shortages quite often. The new plant will cater exclusively to the drinking water requirement of Porvorim, which is witnessing a rapid rise in population density.

“At least part of the new15MLD plant will be ready and operational by March 2020,” Parsekar said.

The plant is being constructed near the cricket stadium in Porvorim.

The water resources department has already laid the raw water supply pipeline up to Porvorim. It means that once work on the plant is completed, increased water supply to Porvorim can begin immediately.

It is expected that at least 5MLD of treated water from the plant will be ready for supply by March 2020, as per instructions given to the contractor.

PWD officials said that areas like Calangute and Candolim also fall at the tail-end of Assonora plant’s distribution line, and thus, supply to these locations is affected.

Once at least 5MLD of the plant becomes operational and supply from the new plant to Porvorim begins, it will reduce pressure on the Assonora plant. This will then enable the Assnora water treatment plant to cater to other stressed areas of Bardez taluka.

After the new 27MLD plant at Opa was commissioned last week, water supply to Panaji, Santa Cruz and parts of Cumbarjua and St Andre constituencies has been enhanced, Parsekar said. The residents of Kadamba Plateau also will receive piped water supply for the first time.

“Water tanks and the pipeline network for Kadamba Plateau are ready. Now, the residents have to apply for water supply connections. We have also issued a public notice to residents across the state asking all those who do not have a water connection to apply for one,” said Parsekar.

Title: Drug racketeer wanted by Gujarat ATS held in Italy
Content:
Simranjit Singh Sandhu

AHMEDABAD: Simranjit Singh Sandhu, of Amritsar, allegedly one of the biggest drug mafiosi of the country, has been detained in Italy, based on the red-corner notice (RCN) issued at the behest of the Gujarat Anti-Terrorist Squad ( ATS ).Sandhu was wanted in the drug trafficking case in which 300kg of heroin, worth Rs 1,500 crore, was allegedly smuggled from Pakistan to the Mandvi coast of Gujarat.Smuggling of such huge quantity of heroin was unearthed when five kilos of that consignment was seized by Gujarat ATS in Jam Salaya.The heroin was found in possession of Rafiq Sumra and Abdul Aziz Baghad, in August 2018. “Based on their interrogation, three others, namely Manjur Ahmed Mir and Nazir Thakkar of Kashmir, who were in touch with Sumra and Baghad, and one Shahid Sumra, were arrested by the Gujarat ATS. It is suspected that money from sale of the heroin was part of a larger narco-terrorism racket for funding terror attacks in India,” a senior ATS official said.Investigators said the part of the syndicate that sent heroin consignment from Pakistan is suspected to be associated with the terror outfit Jaish-e-Mohammed. “Once Sandhu is extradited to India, the hawala links through which money was transferred will become clear,” an investigator said.ATS officials said it was unearthed that the 5kg of heroin seized in Salaya was part of a 300kg consignment that had been smuggled into India earlier, and parts of which were sent to Punjab and other north Indian states camouflaged as cumin stocks in trucks.Gujarat ATS officials said they have initiated the procedure to get Sandhu back to India through the ministry of home affairs and the ministry of external affairs.

Title: Festivities mark BHU Foundation Day
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Varanasi: The Banaras Hindu University was abuzz with celebrations and festivities as the university celebrated its foundation day on the occasion of Basant Panchami on Thursday.

The celebrations commenced with BHU vice-chancellor Prof Rakesh Bhatnagar taking part in the puja and hawan at site where foundation of the university was laid in 1916. BHU officials and professors including registrar Dr Neeraj Tripathi, Prof VK Shukla, Prof MK Singh, Prof RK Jain and deans and heads of the departments also took part in the puja. It was followed by puja at various girls hostels.

After the puja, the VC flagged-off the colourful procession of tableaux presented by different faculties and units of BHU. As many as 29 tableaux presenting different themes like Ek Bharat, Shrestha Bharat, Sarvadharma Sambhav, and others related to environment conservation, medical, schience and technology, ancient Indian medicine system, tradition of knowledge and farming were taken out on the occasion.

Meanwhile, city also witnessed puja events held by different organisations to worship Goddess Saraswati, the goddess of learning on the occasion of Basant Panchami.

Title: Single-window & 50-day deemed nod for land reclassification for industries in TN
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Chennai: Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Thursday announced a raft of schemes, including single-window clearance for land use reclassification in non-plan areas with 50-day deemed approval and ‘Direct CTO Scheme’ (consent to operate) for green industries, to promote industrial growth in the state.

Nearly 90% of land in the state falls under the non-plan category, while under reclassification, non-industrial lands are reclassified for industrial use from time to time.

Speaking at the Confederation of Indian Industry’s (CII) 125 years of service to the nation, the CM said approval under single-window clearance for land use reclassification in non-plan areas will be provided within 50 days from the date of submission of applications online. If the approval is not received within the time limit, industries can consider them as ‘deemed approval’ and can go ahead with their project.

Under the scheme, certification of the agricultural department will be done in 30 days, and reclassification of land will be completed within 50 days, the CM said.

The process normally takes six months to two years to be completed.

Typically, planned areas are non-CMDA areas for which the Department of Town and Country Planning has prepared a master plan duly approved by the government. Non-planned areas do not have approved master plan.

In the case of green industries, the CM said, “they can directly pay and apply for ‘consent to establish’ without the need to wait for formal approval and can go ahead with construction of buildings with self-certification.”

Already, white category industries don’t need any approval from the state pollution control board. Now, 63 types of industries coming under the green category, too, will also benefit from the new initiative.

Mostly micro, small and medium scale industries come under the green category.

“These initiatives will give big advantage to industries, with the overall project time line coming down to one year from 2 to 2.5 years, besides risk mitigation and cash flow advantages,” Srinivas Anikipatti, senior director, TN and Kerala, of Knight Frank India (property consultants).

Speaking on how small scale industries and ancillary units of large manufacturing companies will benefit, he said, “In recent times, SIDCO and SIPCOT have not acquired new land parcels to establish industrial parks. So, the ancillary units had to find land in the suburban areas of the city which will mostly be non-planned areas where the conversion (from farm land to industrial land) could take a long time.”

Stressing on the immediate need to play a participative role in shaping the next generation, governor Banwarilal Purohit urged business leaders to sign more MoUs with universities in the state like Anna University. “Even the syllabus must be revised to meet the current demand of skill sets for which business leaders must suggest revision of syllabus,” the governor said.

Title: Couple designs wedding card with anti-NRC, CAA message
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

MIDNAPORE: A couple from Keshpur in West Midnapore have voiced their protest against the National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) on their wedding card . They plan to theme their wedding around the anti-NRC/CAA movement and spread a message of peace and harmony.

The groom — Md Alif, a graduate in English and a resident of Mugbasan in Keshpur — runs a dealership of kerosene. He will get married to Hasina Mumtaz who is from a neighbouring village on February 27. When they started distributing their wedding cards last week, the one thing that stood out was the message — ‘No NRC, No CAA’ — printed above their names.

“We are getting married at a time when the entire country is protesting against NRC and CAA. I believe that as an Indian, I should also protest against the same. Hence, I designed the wedding card, voicing my protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act. This is my humble contribution to the movement,” said Alif.

Alif said, when he told his parents — Sheikh Yusuf Ali and Marhum Nehura Begum — about his plans for the card, they readily agreed.

“Many of my relatives are unaware of NRC and CAA. So I decided to share the message on the card so that it remains a topic of discussion at the wedding,” he said.

Title: Gwalior hospital tells coronavirus suspect to go home
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: A 30-year-old patient, who returned from China a week ago and turned up at Gwalior district hospital on Thursday with coronavirus-like symptoms, was told to go back home. This, only a day after health minister Tulsiram Silawat ordered a statewide alert on the virus that has killed 170 people in China.The administration is frantically looking for the patient. Chief medical and health officer Dr Mridul Saxena has sought explanations from the civil surgeon B K Gupta and the doctor who treated him.Sources say the patient turned up at the hospital on his own after reading news reports of the viral outbreak. At the OPD, the doctors prescribed some medicines and asked him to come after two days. Still anxious, the patient went to another government hospital, Jai Arogya, and then returned home.“The patient arrived at the district hospital OPD in the morning with symptoms of cold and cough. If he was suspected (of coronavirus infection), then why wasn’t protocol followed? We have asked for clarifications from the civil surgeon and doctor who attended to him. Instructions have been issued to trace the patient and ensure that treatment protocols are followed,” Saxena said.Dr Gupta said, “We have traced the patient. He had gone to Jai Arogya Hospital after visiting our OPD but he went away there. We have sought his report from the doctors who treated him at JAH and are contacting the patient so that his samples can be taken. Appropriate protocol will be followed. We have got his address and are sending a team of doctors to his residence”.

Title: Drug racketeer wanted by Gujarat ATS held in Italy
Content:
Simranjit Singh Sandhu

AHMEDABAD: Simranjit Singh Sandhu, of Amritsar, allegedly one of the biggest drug mafiosi of the country, has been detained in Italy, based on the red-corner notice (RCN) issued at the behest of the Gujarat Anti-Terrorist Squad ( ATS ).Sandhu was wanted in the drug trafficking case in which 300kg of heroin, worth Rs 1,500 crore, was allegedly smuggled from Pakistan to the Mandvi coast of Gujarat.Smuggling of such huge quantity of heroin was unearthed when five kilos of that consignment was seized by Gujarat ATS in Jam Salaya.The heroin was found in possession of Rafiq Sumra and Abdul Aziz Baghad, in August 2018. “Based on their interrogation, three others, namely Manjur Ahmed Mir and Nazir Thakkar of Kashmir, who were in touch with Sumra and Baghad, and one Shahid Sumra, were arrested by the Gujarat ATS. It is suspected that money from sale of the heroin was part of a larger narco-terrorism racket for funding terror attacks in India,” a senior ATS official said.Investigators said the part of the syndicate that sent heroin consignment from Pakistan is suspected to be associated with the terror outfit Jaish-e-Mohammed. “Once Sandhu is extradited to India, the hawala links through which money was transferred will become clear,” an investigator said.ATS officials said it was unearthed that the 5kg of heroin seized in Salaya was part of a 300kg consignment that had been smuggled into India earlier, and parts of which were sent to Punjab and other north Indian states camouflaged as cumin stocks in trucks.Gujarat ATS officials said they have initiated the procedure to get Sandhu back to India through the ministry of home affairs and the ministry of external affairs.

Title: HC issues notice to CIC for reviewing own orders
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court , comprising justices Atul Chandurkar and Vinay Joshi has issued notices to the state chief information commissioner (CIC) and three other information commissioners at Mumbai, Konkan and Amravati, while hearing a writ petition filed by Khaparkheda resident Shriram Satpute.

The bench directed the CIC and three other commissioners to file affidavits on or before February 14, indicating the source of powers to constitute a bench of information commissioners and powers to review its own orders.

The petitioner had sought information regarding a work order issued to private persons for the “excavation of forest land” in Mukutban, Yavatmal on May 20, 2013. He did not get any information within 30 days, as per the provision of Section 7(1) of the RTI Act 2005.

After the authorities failed to reply, Satpute filed his first appeal before the appellate authority on October 7, 2013.

The appellate authority did not conduct the hearing within the stipulated time of 30 days and hence, the appellant filed second appeal under Section 19(3) on October 8, 2013 before the state information commissioner (SIC), Nagpur, which was decided on January 16, 2014.

The SIC directed the appellate authority to conduct the hearing and decide the first appeal. The first appellate authority, by its order dated Feb 14, 2014, directed the public information officer (PIO) to furnish the complete information.

The PIO told the petitioner that “no such information is available with him” on February 20, 2014.

Aggrieved by the conduct of the PIO, the petitioner filed another appeal under Section 19(3) before SIC Amravati on March 10, 2014.

The Amravati SIC found that the PIO had violated Section 7(1) and the appellate authority had breached section 19(6) of the Act by failing to give information to the applicant, for which a show-cause notice was issued to them asking “why action should not be initiated against them under Sections 20 (1), 20 (2) of the Act”.

The Amravati SIC found appellate authority PA Dongre guilty of violating the Act, and directed the chief conservator of forests to conduct a departmental enquiry against the appellate authority.

Meanwhile, it was found that the Mumbai CIC had suo moto constituted a division bench of Ajitkumar Jain (SIC at Mumbai) and Thanksi Francis Thekekara (SIC at Konkan), and directed them to review certain decisions.

The petitioner submitted that this division bench arbitrarily reviewed 19 decisions, including that of SIC Amravati, dated October 30, 2015.

The original applicant wasn’t given any hearing opportunity before the order was reviewed on December 17, 2016.

Petitioner’s counsel Tushar Mandlekar argued that SICs do not have any powers under Section 18 to review their own orders and “review” of such decisions of SIC by forming another division bench at Mumbai is absolutely illegal.

Mandlekar told the court the conduct of SIC is arbitrary, illegal, and violative of RTI Act. The constitution of division bench only for the purpose of “review” of a decision of any SIC amounts to action without jurisdiction, he added.

Mandlekar was assisted by Rohan Malviya, while counsel Ambarish Joshi represented the forest department.

Title: ‘Confident will win all ZP seats in North’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Saligao: North Goa BJP block has expressed confidence in winning all 25 zilla panchayat seats in the north. BJP’s North Goa mandal’s spokesperson Premanand Mhambrey told reporters BJP will put up candidates who have shown willingness to work at the grassroots. “BJP governments at the Centre and state are determined to solve the issue of unemployment and we will provide facilities to solve it,” he said. On CAA, Mhambrey said the act was to give citizenship and not take away. “In Kashmir, when the Hindu pandits were removed, there was no hue and cry,” he said. “Whatever is going on in the country, is only to misguide and fool people,” Mhambrey added. tnn

Title: Three years after note ban, ‘deposits’ continue in temple hundis
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

MYSURU: Three years after demonetisation , scrapped currency notes of 500 and 1,000 denomination continue to pour into temple donation boxes, including at Chamundeshwari and Srikanteshwara in Nanjangud , some 26km from Mysuru .

Temple functionaries said the hundis are opened once a month and they continue to find bundles of demonetised notes offered by devotees. All the demonetised notes received through hundis are being preserved and government authorities have been informed, they said.

The Srikanteshwara temple received 55 notes of 500 denomination and about eight notes of 1,000 denomination early this week. The Chamundeshwari temple hundi has accumulated invalid notes with a face value of Rs 12,000. Officials said though the notes were scrapped in December 2016, there has been no let-up in the flow to hundis since.

“We have sought the government’s directions on how to dispose of these notes since there is no specific protocol so far,” said Muzrai tahsildar Yathiraj.

“There are 19 hundis in Chamundeshwari temple alone and we continue to receive demonetised notes from all these boxes. Notes with a face value of Rs 15,000 were retrieved earlier,” said Govindraju , an official.

Venkatachalpathy, lead bank manager of Mysuru district, said the notes could be destroyed as they are just bits of paper now. “It is an offence to possess more than two demonetised notes. Banks won’t take the notes either since they are worthless so they can be destroyed,” he said.

Title: Breakfast scheme for over 2,400 pourakarmikas to be scrapped
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Mysuru city corporation

MYSURU: The Mysuru City Corporation (MCC) has decided to cancel the tender of the breakfast scheme for over 2,400 pourakarmikas.

A decision to this effect was taken in the monthly meeting of the MCC held on Thursday evening.

The breakfast scheme for the pourakarmikas was launched in November 2019. A few members raised the issue saying that the quality of breakfast provided to pourakarmikas is very poor. They alleged that it is adversely affecting the health of the civic workers. They urged the MCC to pay the amount in the form of cash directly to all.

Health officer Dr MS Jayanth informed that the food is tested before serving to the pourakarmikas. MCC commissioner Gurudutt Hegde stated that the scheme is implemented as per the directions of the state government and cash cannot be given directly.

After an hour-long discussion mayor Tasleem announced the cancellation of the breakfast scheme. She informed that the matter will be referred to the MCC standing committee on health.

The meeting also approved incentive to the pourakarmikas who worked extra hours as part of the Swatch Sarvekshan 2020.

The meeting also witnessed fierce debate over naming the auditorium inside Subbarao Garden in Nivedita Nagar after KS Rangappa, former VC of the University of Mysore (UoM) and the Karnataka State Open University (KSOU). Congress and BJP members raised objections citing pending FIR and investigations against Rangappa. JD(S) members supported the proposal. Finally it was decided to refer the matter to the mayor.

In the meeting it was announced that former mayor Ayub Khan has been selected as the leader of Congress group while MU Subbaiah selected as the opposition leader in the council.

Title: Hundreds join rally to Park Circus
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

KOLKATA: It started as a small protest on Bondel Road on Thursday afternoon. By the time it reached Park Circus, the motley group of protesters, including students and homemakers, had swelled to hundreds. The Jamia incident weighed heavily on their minds. The protesters held hands, while raising ‘Azaadi’ slogans and demanded immediate repeal of CAA , NPR and NRC .

Shahzeb Khan, a UPSC aspirant, who was among the protesters, said, “There are so many issues in our country right now such as falling GDP and poor state of economy. Instead of attending to those, the government is busy with something as arbitrary as the NRC and CAA.” “Protests have been going on for almost two months, but the government refuses to listen. And now, they are failing to protect the citizens,” he said, referring to the Jamia Millia shooting incident on Thursday.

International Human Rights Organization working president Wajda Enam Ansari said, “We are not here because we belong to a particular religion. We are here because this is our country. We would have protested even if the discrimination had been against any other religion.” Noorjahan Begum, a third-year commerce student of KK Das College , said there was nothing good about NRC and CAA and the voicer are growing louder.

Title: Police to step in to identify Chinese tourists
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Jaipur: Amid scare of coronavirus, all hotels of the city and other parts of the state will be searched for people who have reached from China for keeping a watch on their health. For the purpose, the health department has decided to engage the police department. The police will help the health department in identifying tourists from China who are staying in hotels, guest houses and also at residences. TNN

Title: Amaravati rail still a pipe dream as Centre is unlikely to give nod
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Amaravati: The proposed rail project to connect Amaravati is likely to remain a pipe dream thanks to the state government’s decision to set up three capital cities.

The railway board had cleared the project almost two years ago and it is in the final lap of getting the green signal from the Union finance ministry. Now with the state government not keen on achieving the new railway line to Amaravati, the Centre might junk the proposal.

Senior officials in South Central Railway (SCR) are waiting for the outcome of the Union budget to see whether Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman would make any allocation for the project. The FM is slated to present the budget in Parliament on Saturday. The SCR has submitted the first Detailed Project Report (DPR) with an estimate of Rs.2,700 crore for double-line track between Errupalem and Nambur and new tracks between Sattenapalle-Narasaraopet and Amaravati-Pedakurapadu in 2016. The line between Narasaraopet and Sattenapalle would provide direct connectivity to Amaravati with Bangalore. Similarly, Amaravati-Pedakurapadu would connect the capital city with Hyderabad without touching the busiest junctions in Vijayawada and Guntur.

After intense lobbying by the then state government, the Union railway ministry had promised to clear the project, provided the state came forward to share 50% of the project cost. However, the TDP government had refused to take the burden and insisted that the project be sanctioned as the new capital city should have railway connectivity. Instead, the state government promised to provide land free of cost within the capital city area.

Subsequently, the railway board directed the SCR engineering wing to revise estimations to cut down project cost. The SCR readied the second DPR in 2017 which brought down the cost to Rs.1700 crore. Further trimming the project, the railway board gave the nod for laying the new line connecting Amaravati from Guntur and Vijayawada. The new stretch will begin from Errupalem on Vijayawada-Hyderabad section and culminate at Nambur on Guntur-Vijayawada section.

Sources said that Union ministers had promised BJP leaders from the state to clear the new railway line to Amaravati in the upcoming budget. However, the state government’s plan for setting up three capital cities has changed the situation. “It is an open secret that such projects are cleared only under political compulsions. It is doubtful to get the go-ahead from the Centre in the current situation as the state government is not so keen,” said a senior railway official on condition of anonymity.

Interestingly, YSRC parliamentary party leader V Vijayasai Reddy had not mentioned the Amaravati rail project in the wish-list he submitted to the Centre at an all-party meeting held ahead of Parliament session in New Delhi on Thursday.

Title: No-violence plea from demonstration platforms
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

KOLKATA: CAA protesters in Kolkata condemned Wednesday’s violence in Murshidabad where two people died in a clash and appealed not to identify the widespread protests against the citizenship law with any community or political outfit.

There have been attempts from both sides of the political spectrum to either discredit the protests.

On Wednesday, two groups both of whom oppose CAA but differed on forcing a bandh clashed, killing two persons. “We condemn use of violence in any form. The protests and the movement is not Islamic in nature. Let us unite and rise above communal divide,” said Arshad Parvez Khan, an organizer of a demonstration at Nawab Ali Park in Ekbalpore.

Nousheen Baba Khan, a PhD scholar who is a familiar face at anti CAA protests in the city, too, cautioned against people trying to brand the civil and secular movement as a Muslim one. “CAA and NRC are anti-poor. It cannot be associated with any one community. In Assam, more Hindus are suffering than Muslims,” Khan said. “I condemn those trying to spread Islamophobia under the garb of nationalism. I also want to caution some Muslims who are putting out statements that are making the community a target for bigots. Both are fringe groups and have no space in our secular movement,” he said.

People from all communities, including Sikhs, Christians and Hindus, have also staged series of protests against CAA in the city. “The anti-CAA protests have brought together all the citizens who feel the secular fabric of the country is under threat and the rights guaranteed by the Constitution are being violated. It will be unfair to identify it with any particular community,” said Sneha Sarkar , a college student who is a regular at the demonstrations at Park Circus and Hogg Street.

Religious figures have also urged people to protest peacefully and co-operate with law enforcing agencies.

“The two deaths in Murshidabad is very sad. We are protesting against an authoritarian and barbaric regime. The protesters must be united and not walk into traps of those wanting to derail the movement,” said Mohammad Yaqub, a cleric in central Kolkata.

Title: Robbery in Gujarat: 3kg gold jewellery looted in broad daylight in Gujarat
Content:
The perpetrators snatched a bag containing 3kg gold jewellery worth Rs 1.02 crore from a salesman in Nikol on ... Read More

CCTV grab of the salesman (in white shirt)

AHMEDABAD: In what seems a well-planned operation, two persons on a bike snatched a bag containing 3kg gold jewellery worth Rs 1.02 crore from a salesman near Khodiyar Mandir in Nikol on Thursday, at about 4pm. Police said four salesmen from Vikas Jewellers, CG Road had come to display their ware to Kalpesh Modi, the owner of Vaibhav Laxmi Gold in Nikol.When the salesmen were exiting the shop and about to sit in their car, a bike came speeding from the direction of the highway. Within seconds, the bike-borne men snatched the bag of jewellery and sped away towards Canal Road.Deputy commissioner of police, Ravi Teja, said they have barricaded the entry and exit points of the city and put barricades on different roads in Nikol area. “The robbers wore helmets and came on a black bike. We have alerted adjoining police stations about the incident. We have CCTV footage of the crime and will identify the bike from its registration number,” Teja said.“We will take into consideration all angles. An insider could have tipped off the robbers. A crime branch team is also working to identify the accused,” Teja added.Police sources said Vikas Jewellers, located on CG Road, is a wholesale trader of gold jewellery and sells its products to other jewellers in the city.“The salesmen had been in the shop for about half an hour to display jewellery to Modi. Then they left and went to their car. However, just as the salesman on the right side was about to put the bag in the car, a bike with two helmet-borne men came speeding in and snatched the bag away,” said a police source.As soon as the news came in, senior police officials including additional commissioner of police, Sector -2, Nirja Gotru, DCP Ravi Teja, ACP N L Desai and the inspector of Nikol police station rushed to the spot.In Video: Ahmedabad: Bike borne men loot 3kg gold jewellery in broad daylight

Title: Goa: Rs 40 crore pending VAT refunds take toll on small businesses
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Two-and-a-half years after the goods and services tax ( GST ) system was rolled out across the country and value added tax (VAT) was phased out, refunds of the previous tax regime to the tune of Rs 40-50 crore remain pending with the commercial taxes department, sources said.

Small businesses are facing a liquidity crunch at a time when they are looking for working capital. With sectoral credit drying up and GST refunds also delayed by 30-45 days, industrial units want the state government to clear the backlog.

“VAT refund for 2016-17 are piled up, for some companies it is around Rs 5 crore,” said a local industrialist, who chose to remain anonymous.

Some industrial units are also facing an issue in getting a refund for the input tax credit for the financial year 2017-18. During the transition from VAT to GST, input tax credit was allowed to be utilised as input tax credit under GST transition provisions. Tax payers with excess input VAT credit over output credit for previous financial years were supposed to apply for VAT refund.

“VAT refunds for various assesses are still pending with the department due to delay in assessment or clearance of refund voucher. This creates undue hardships and needs to be resolved immediately,” said Confederation of Indian Industry–Goa chairman Lalit Saraswat.

Officials with the department of commercial taxes said that the pending dues will be cleared before March 31, by when the limitation period for dues ends.

“The claims have to be verified minutely. There are multiple stages of assessment and verification,” commissioner of commercial taxes Deepak Bandekar said.

President Goa Chamber of Commerce and Industry Manoj Caculo said a scheme to settle pending cases under the Goa VAT Act would reduce litigation, bring revenue to the state, and allow authorities to focus on GST implementation.

Micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) and traders find themselves squeezed from all sides as banks refuse to lend and GST payments are delayed, industrialists said.

“As the payments are blocked for more than six months, the MSMEs go in red and default on repayments and are classified as defaulters,” chairman, MSME at Assocham National Council, Manguirish Pai Raikar said.

Title: Lawyer jumps off 9th floor, lekhpal hangs self in office
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: A lawyer- Prashant Singh (39) committed suicide by jumping from 9th floor of an underconstruction building in district court premises in Varanasi on Thursday morning. In another incident, a lekhpal hanged himself from the ceiling of consolidation office in Ghazipur.

SSP Varanasi Prabhakar Chawdhary said, “CCTV footage showed that lawyer Prashant Singh entered the building alone and later his body was found lying on ground floor. Police are investigating the matter.” Motive behind the suicide could not become clear, he said.

According to Singh’s family, on Thursday morning, he took his 5-year-old son to UP College ground to play. He left the ground leaving his son there who later returned with neighbours. After sometime, the family received the information about the suicide. The lawyer was upset for some time, said his family.

In Ghazipur, lekhpal Indresh Yadav (35) committed suicide by hanging himself in a consolidation office in Sadar Kotwali area. According to reports, Yadav, a resident of Azamgarh district, reached the office at around 8am and asked the peon for office keys as he had some urgent work.

The peon left the office for some personal work and when he returned he found Yadav’s body hanging with the ceiling. He raised alarm after which police reached the spot. Kotwali inspector Dhananjay Mishra said that during initial investigation it appeared to be case of suicide and the matter is being investigated. Yadav’s family members were informed and the body was sent for post mortem.

Title: EFLU students protest academic reforms
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: A section of students from English and Foreign Languages University ( EFLU ), Hyderabad, boycotted classes on Wednesday against recent reforms on admission, intake and evaluation introduced by the academic council.

The academic council recently approved several rules pertaining to PhD admission, intake for master of arts courses, bell-curve grading and sit-in examination as evaluation methods for various courses. This irked the students community at large who not only boycotted classes, but also held a massive protest within the campus.

Students argued that as per the statues, the academic council did not have two student representatives and that such rules cannot be imposed after the commencement of the semester. “The rules cannot be implemented if they are not mentioned in the prospectus,” stated a statement issued by the EFLU students union 2019-20 against the circular issued by the in-charge registrar.

Before boycotting the classes, the students held an emergency meeting on Tuesday late night to discuss possible plans of action regarding the circular. The students continued the protest till late Wednesday evening.

Even University of Hyderabad students’ union called for a protest over ban on public talks/gatherings and various other academic issues related to reservation policy, clauses regarding backlogs in CIS among others on January 30, which also happens to be Rohith Vemula’s birthday. Members of Students Federation of India, UoH unit, burnt the circular banning public gatherings, posters and graffiti on the university walls.

Title: 3 held for posing as cops, abducting, assaulting 2 youths
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Ghatlodia police on Thursday arrested three men, all aged around 25, who allegedly posed as crime branch cops and abducted two 19-year-old men, accusing them of being drug addicts and extorting money from them.

It later turned out that the accusers were themselves were addicted to ganja and were trying to get money to get their fix of the drug.

The accused were identified as Sahil Rabari, Harsh Barot and Sahil Rathod, all residents of Sola.

In his FIR at Ghatlodia police station, Naitik Arya, who works for a private firm, said that he and his friend Urvish Chunawala were sitting at the Sola Road AMTS bus stand late on Monday evening.

At around 5.50pm on Monday, two men, later identified as Rabari and Barot, arrived in a car and asked them why they were sitting there. “They rushed to us and asked us if we were smoking and selling ganja. They began assaulting us and pushed into the car,” Arya stated in his FIR.

The duo took Arya and Chunawala to a place nearby, where one of them said that some senior crime branch officials were coming to see them and they would decide whether a complaint would be filed against them.

After a while, the third accused arrived and that he was a crime branch official, but Arya identified the third man as Rathod, who he knew. On hearing this, the three began beating Arya and Chunawala and began demanding Rs 50,000. When they were being beaten, Rathod said he had some work at the jail and left.

Rabari and Barot then took Arya and Chunawala to another place in their car and started beating them with sticks. Rabari and Barot then snatched Arya and Chunawala’s mobile phones and took Rs 500 from them.

Arya and Chunawala managed to get away from their attackers and get home. They later filed a complaint with Ghatlodia police and the accused were arrested on Thursday evening.

Inspector Pushpa Gamit of Ghatlodia police said the accused are addicted to ganja and that was why they abducted and robbed the two men.

Title: Fate of 2 IPL ties subject to PIL outcome, says HC
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A division bench of Rajasthan High Court on Thursday said that fixing the venue of matches of Rajasthan Royals outside Jaipur is subject to the outcome of writ petition. The court has also granted time to Board of Cricket Control in India (BCCI), Rajasthan Royals, Rajasthan Sports Council and Rajasthan Cricket Association to file a reply within a week. The court has fixed February 13 to be the next date of hearing.

The bench comprising Chief Justice Indrajit Mahanty and Justice Ashok Gaur gave these orders while hearing a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) in the high court challenging the decision of BCCI to shift to IPL matches of Rajasthan Royals from Jaipur to Guwahati.

“We have said in the court that IPL matches benefit the state at large as the state collects big revenue. These matches in Jaipur also generate employment and most importantly benefit the local cricketing talent. Thus, there is no point in shifting the matches from Jaipur to Guwahati,” said Vimal Chaudhary , counsel for the petitioner.

During the hearing, it was further said that by additional advocate general (AAG), Satendra Raghav that the government is ready to provide all the facilities for conducting IPL matches in the state. “Apart from SMS Stadium, matches can also be held at Jodhpur and Udaipur Stadium,” he added. While the Sports Council said that on every IPL match played at the SMS Stadium, the council gets 20 lakh rupees per match, which will is utilized for the benefit of the budding young crickets.

Prateek Kasliwal, counsel for RCA, said, “We are well-prepared to organize these matches. We get Rs 60 lakh per match including Rs 30 lakh from BCCI and Rs 30 lakh from Rajasthan Royals. There is no point in shifting these two matches elsewhere in the country.”

On the other hand, BCCI said that under the 2019 IPL rules, three matches of a home team can be organised away from the home ground.

Rajasthan Royals informed the court that they will get extra earning if the matches are organised away from Jaipur. Responding to this the court said the extra earning makes no difference. “Matches are not just to earn money. Since Rajasthan and Royals are the names associated with Rajasthan and Jaipur, it is not appropriate to take two matches away as people’s sentiments are also associated,” the court said in verbal remarks.

Title: ‘There’s the constant fear of getting infected, nobody knows what to do’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Few Indian students stuck in China after Coronavirus struck the country

For Indian and foreign students in China’s Wuhan city, the Chinese New Year is one of the most anticipated annual events. This is the time when they come home for vacation.

But this year, with Wuhan, the capital of Hubei province, becoming the epicentre of the deadly coronavirus outbreak, the over 500-strong Indian student community, most of them studying medicine, in various universities are facing an unprecedented crisis.

While those who are stuck in Wuhan are living in fear of contracting the deadly virus and are confined to their rooms with no contact with other students, the many who have come home are clueless of when they can return to China.

I was among the few fortunate Indians who left Wuhan and reached home in Jaipur just before the mortalities from the outbreak began to mount and the news hit international headlines.

The news of some ‘virus’ causing cold, cough, sneezing and breathing problems had started circulating among local residents in Wuhan and in the media during the last days of December. Nobody had then anticipated that it would be so deadly, and that life would come to standstill in a few weeks.

In the first week of January, people wearing masks could be seen visible on the streets. However, I didn’t observe any major concerns and normal crowds were seen on the streets and malls.

Since January 25 is the New Year (Spring Festival), the biggest festival for Chinese, streets were decked up with traditional festival lanterns and paintings. The excitement was palpable in the air. The situation started to look grim from the second week of January as more number of infected cases were confirmed with coronavirus.

Soon, Thailand and Singapore reported cases from among travellers arriving from China. That was when I came to fully ‘understand’ the deadly virus. The news was enough to alarm local residents, expats as well as international students.

While those who could started leaving the city, foreign students, who had planned to go home in mid-January, preponed their journeys. Those who had planned to stay back during the vacation, began preparing to leave as early as possible. On January 7, a few days before the outbreak became a full-fledged crisis, I left Wuhan for India.

It was later reported in the media that one of the sources of coronavirus was believed to be a local seafood market, which is about 30 minutes from where I live in Wuhan. Looking back, I can only count my blessings.

Since then, I have been in constant touch with both my Indian and foreign friends who are still stuck there. The epidemic has resulted in the virtual lock-down of the city. All transportation systems have been suspended from January 23.

The shutdown has created panic among the student community. Students have been asked to stay inside their room sand instructed to avoid any physical contact or visiting rooms of fellow students. An Indian PhD student from my university described the situation as unprecedented and said that staying inside the rooms was taking a toll on the mental health of students.

“I have not gone outside for the past one week. Physically it is tiring and psychologically I am exhausted. There’s the constant fear of getting infected and nobody has any idea of what to do in this situation. In addition, family members are also worried, and my mother starts crying whenever I call her,” he said.

Most of the complaints that are being shared in various WeChat groups revolve around unavailability of food, face masks and sanitisers and disinfectants. Stores open for a few hours and run out of goods. One classmate said that the situation was “so grim that food and other grocery are almost over. I am surviving on packed noodles and even that will soon run out of stock”.

While the university has deployed staff to calm down and direct students on taking proper care and sending regular updates on where they can avail grocery, a sense of confusion still prevails.

Meanwhile, the whole of Wuhan city with a population of nearly 10 million has turned into a ghost town. Amidst the chaos, the Indian embassy in China has created a coordination group on WeChat and is working on finalising the dates and logistics for evacuating Indian nationals from the province.

As per latest information posted by officials on the group, they have asked students to confirm their willingness in writing to be evacuated. The embassy will then inform them about the dates and process of evacuation. Almost all are waiting to be airlifted to home quickly.

(The writer is currently doing his PhD in management from Wuhan University of Technology. He was a reporter with Times of India, Jaipur, from 2011 to 2017)

Title: B Pharm 2nd yearstudent ends life
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vijayawada: A second year student at a private-run B Pharmacy college committed suicide by hanging herself at her hostel in Nuzvid on Thursday.

According to Nuzvid police, fellow students found the 20-year-old girl found dead in the morning.

The police said that the girl is from Vijayawada and left a suicide note behind requesting her parents not to demand an inquiry into her suicide.

The police suspect that a failed love affair might be the trigger for the suicide. In her suicide letter, the girl sought forgiveness from her parents, her younger and elder sisters.

The suicide note said she was battling depression. “Please don’t inquire into my death. Both my parents took care of me very well. I miss you all,” the letter read. The police registered a case under Section 174 of CrPC (death due to hanging) at Nuzvid police station. The police have sent the body to a local government hospital for post-mortem.

Title: Fate of 2 IPL ties subject to PIL outcome, says HC
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

Title: 2 held for cheating bank executive
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Ahmedabad: Navrangpura police on Wednesday arrested two men, 23 and 32, for cheating an employee of a private bank by showing him a bundle of Rs 500 notes, which actually contained waste paper, and taking away his mobile phone and tablet, worth Rs 15,000.

The accused, identified as Mahesh Salat, 23, and Kishor Salat, 32, had allegedly cheated the bank employee, Abdulkalam Shaikh, 21, a resident of Shahibaug on January 9, states the FIR filed with Navrangpura police.

In his FIR, Shaikh states that he was travelling by a shared autorickshaw from Laldarwaja to Law Garden on the afternoon of January 9. Two other passengers—Mahesh and Kishor — were already in the autorickshaw.

Then, Mahesh told Shaikh that he was hungry and had not eaten for three days as his employer had sacked him. Mahesh showed Shaikh a bag saying that he had stolen its contents from his employer’s home and offered him to Shaikh.

Kishor then snatched the bag, pulled out the purported bundle of banknotes and told Shaikh that they would divide the money equally and would not tell Mahesh about it. He told Shaikh they would together fool Mahesh, states the FIR. “On Kishor’s instructions, Shaikh got off from the autorickshaw at Mithakhali Crossroads. Kishor told him to deposit his valuables with him as a guarantee, and count the money where nobody would see him doing it. He told Shaikh that he would wait from him,” the FIR states.

Shaikh took the bag to Law Garden and opened the bundle, but found it contained just waste papers with Rs 500 notes at the top and bottom.

Title: Man gets life imprisonment for murdering nephew’s wife
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vijayawada: The Mahila Sessions Court on Thursday sentenced a 49-year-old man to life imprisonment and imposed a Rs 500 fine for killing his nephew’s wife over a family dispute.

The incident happened on May 2, 2015.

The convict, M Nagaraju, a resident of Yerram Vari street in Machavaram, stabbed his nephew J Rama Rao’s wife to death. Nagaraju was a frequent visitor and was accused by his second wife of having an affair with Rama Rao’s wife. A few months later, he barged into their house when Rama Rao was at his shoe shop. He found that Rao’s wife was cooking at their neighbour’s house. He dragged her out and stabbed her with a knife after an argument. TNN

Title: Road safety: Police urge depts to finish works on time
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: It appears that the meeting conducted by state police chief Loknath Behera in November last year to address road traffic-related concerns of city residents was not merely a publicity stunt. It has been learned that the police have taken serious note of the problems highlighted by the residents and have even forwarded these complaints to officials of departments concerned to rectify the problems related to road infrastructure.

The police authorities have also served them notices stating that the failure to carry out the works in a time-bound manner will result in legal action. This move came after the tragic death of a 23-year-old two-wheeler rider, who fell into a pothole and was run over by a truck near Palarivattom metro station in Kochi recently.

A senior official of the state road fund board confirmed receiving the notice early this month and said that they have already begun relaying works of pothole filled roads in the city.

“Around 15km of roads in the city are full of potholes and had failed miserably in the bump integrator (BI) test to measure the unevenness of road surfaces,” said an official.

Even if the police had not served the notices, we would have carried out the works anyway. The department was waiting for the rains to end. It was just coincidence that the launch of works happened at the same time the police served the notice, the officer said adding that the ongoing relaying works will be completed by March. Then, they will commence the works on road signs and markings, the lack of which was causing numerous accidents at busy junctions as highlighted by the city residents.

Besides the KRFB, notices were also served to the public works department and Thiruvananthapuram road development company ltd. Keltron was also served a notice to look into the faulty traffic signal lights in the city. On January 17, the works were reviewed in a meeting of the traffic advisory committee chaired by the city corporation mayor in which senior officials of the city traffic police and other departments attended.

Assistant commissioner (city traffic, south) M K Zulfiquer said that the police had prepared a list of spots that needed maintenance, categorized them according to the agencies or departments responsible and then handed out the lists accordingly. A deadline of three months was given, which ends on March 30. So far, only KRFB has replied to the notice on record, agreeing to finish the works in the allotted time.

State police chief Loknath Behera had convened a meeting with the city residents after long traffic snarls became a regular affair on various roads in the city. Besides this, the city also has a high accident rate. Recently, National Road Transport Planning and Research Centre (NATPAC) too had released the results of a survey conducted based on accident data for the year 2018, which revealed that the capital city had the highest number of high-priority accident-prone stretches in the state.

Title: Traffic cop suspended for misconduct and indiscipline
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar on Thursday suspended a traffic police inspector , posted at Traffic Training Institute (TTI), Begumpet, for “misconduct and indiscipline”.

According to a senior officer, traffic inspector Ch Nagender Rao was reportedly not attending duties properly and was given a warning. The officer was also attached to CAR Headquarters by the Hyderabad police chief almost five months ago.

However, it was found that he did not report to his new posting. After higher-ups noticed it, the CP on Thursday issued orders suspending the officer. “City police is committed for good conduct and perfect discipline among all officers,” a statement from Hyderabad police said. TNN

Title: Cops to be roped in to spot Chinese tourists
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Jaipur: Amid scare of coronavirus, all hotels of the city and other parts of the state will be searched for people who have reached from China for keeping a watch on their health. For the purpose, the health department has decided to engage the police department.

The police will help the health department in identifying tourists from China who are staying in hotels, guest houses and also at residences.

The health department is not taking any chance in its efforts to keep monitoring the health of the people who came from China which has reported an outbreak of coronavirus. Two persons who have returned from China have already been quarantined at Sawai Man Singh Hospital after being suspected to have coronavirus. Their samples have already been sent to National Institute of Virology, Pune.

Additional chief secretary (health) Rohit Kumar Singh said, “We gave appealed to the people who have reached here in Rajasthan from China after January 15 to remain indoor to stay at their homes for at least 14 days and also to get screened for coronavirus. We have appealed them not to come in contact with other people.”

Moreover, the health department is taking measure to start the diagnostic facilities for coronavirus in the state soon. As of now, no hospital in the state has the facility to conduct diagnostic test of coronavirus and in the absence of that the health department has to send the samples to National Institute of Virology, Pune.

For the convenience of people, the health department has issued helpline numbers 01123978046 and 01412225624 and toll free number 104 and 108 to get information regarding coronavirus.

Title: Model accuses husband of cruelty
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Ahmedabad: Laxmi Dusane, 25, a model and a resident of Sujal Apartments in Ramdevnagar, lodged a complaint with the Mahila police station on Tuesday, accusing her husband Sanjit Dhuri, and his parents Geeta and Sunil Dhuri, all residents of Golden Villa, Vasai (West) of cruelty and demanding a dowry of Rs 25 lakh from her parents.

She also alleged that her husband, an actor-producer, threatened to publish private pictures of her on social media if she did not give in to their demands.

She married Sanjit in February 2017. Geeta and Sunil did not accept their union and then went to live separately. “Dusane’s in-laws told her that her family would have to organize a function in Mumbai and pay them a dowry of Rs 25 lakh. Dusane’s family arranged the function in Mumbai and the couple began living with Sanjit’s parents,” said a police official. Dusane alleged that ten days later, her in-laws and husband started torturing her.

Title: Traditional rituals, prayers mark Vasantha Panchami celebrations
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vijayawada: Vasantha Panchami was observed with religious fervor across the city on Thursday.

Goddess Kanakadurga was adorned as Maha Saraswathi as a part of the celebrations. Many school and college-going students flocked to Sri Durga Malleswara Swamy Varla Devastanams atop Indrakeeladri shrine in the city to offer special prayers.

Endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas participated in Vasanth Panchami celebrations at Kanaka Durga temple and offered special prayers seeking prosperity of the state.

Temple executive officer MV Suresh Babu accorded a ceremonial welcome to the minister. Srinivas participated in Sri Saraswathi Maha Yagam held at the Yaaga Shaala of the temple.

Temple authorities adorned the festive deity at Maha Mandapam of the temple as goddess Maha Saraswathi and performed Ganapathi pooja, Saraswathi pooja, Swaraswathi Maha Havanam and other vedic rituals.

The temple management provided free darshan for students from 7 am to 6 pm on Thursday and vedic scholars blessed the students. The temple management distributed free pens, kumkuma, and Kankanam, pocket-size photographs of goddess Kanaka Durga wishing great success to students appearing for the forthcoming examinations.

A huge turnout of devotees was noted at Kali Mandir at Thrisakthi Peetham in the city. Around 300 children got Aksharabhyasam on Vasantha Panchami day.

“Vasantha Panchami is a very auspicious day. It is considered a prominent day for worshipping Saraswathi, the goddess of knowledge and wisdom. It is believed that children who got Aksharabhyasam on Vasantha Panchami will shine in studies,” said K Lakshminatha Sharma, a vedic scholar.

A few private schools in the city conducted Saraswathi pooja wishing best for their students in the forthcoming board examinations.

Title: Event organisers stage protest outside Gyanvapi entry point
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Organisers of Sri Ramcharit Manas Navahan Parayan Gyan Yajna staged a sit-in after being denied entry by secur... Read More

Varanasi: A high drama was created at Gyanvapi entry point of Kashi Vishwanath Dham (corridor) when the organisers of annual Sri Ramcharit Manas Navahan Parayan Gyan Yajna staged a sit in after the security personnel denied entry to the articles sent for the event to Kashi Vishwanath-Gyanvapi complex on Thursday morning.

They even threatened to hold the event on road. The event is commencing from Saturday.

The issue was settled after the KV temples chief executive officer Vishal Singh proposed to hold the event at Nandi Hall this year. The organisers agreed to it and called off the stir.

The organisers had sent tent and other decoration items for nine-day Ramcharit Manas recital and discourse on Wednesday night. However, the security personnel at Gyanvapi entry point of the corridor stopped the articles outside Gyanvapi entry point.

On Thursday morning, officer bearers of the organising committee, including Suryalal Vyas, reached there and informed the security personnel that they had permission for the event but the security officials denied having any such information.

Vyas accused the temple administration of creating hurdles in the six-decade old traditional event from past many years and warned to hold the event outside Gyanvapi entry point if they were not allowed to enter the premises.

Later, temple CEO reached there and proposed Nandi Hall as the venue for holding their annual event this year as the the one they sought was not available due to disturbance caused by the ongoing construction work of KV Dham project.

Title: SI, two constables suspended for harassing woman and mother
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vijayawada: Based on the recommendations of Guntur urban SP PHD Ramakrishna, inspector general of police of south coastal zone (Guntur range) Vineet Brijlal suspended three cops for allegedly misbehaving with a woman complainant and her mother on Thursday.

The cops were identified as G Bala Krishna, sub-inspector of Arundalpet police station and constables - Ch Ramu and B Hanumantha Rao. According to an official press release from Guntur Urban Police, suspension orders were handed over to both of them based on a preliminary inquiry report submitted by the SP.

Police sources said that the incident happened on Wednesday when both the officials did not respond to the woman’s harassment complaint. In her complaint, the woman claimed that her boyfriend David cheated her by promising to marry her.

Instead of taking action, both the cops sought sexual favours from the woman and Balakrishna asked her to come to his house. The constable too allegedly harassed the complainant’s mother by asking her to come to a lodge. The complaint was first handed over to a constable B Hanumantha Rao who neglected the plaint. The women approached Guntur urban SP Ch Vijaya Rao who ordered a preliminary inquiry.

Title: Court denies pre-arrest bail to Hardik Patel
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hardik Patel

AHMEDABAD: A city sessions court on Thursday denied anticipatory bail to Hardik Patel , the Congress leader and former convener of the Patidar Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS), in connection with the FIR registered by Vastrapur police for violence at the GMDC ground on August 25, 2015 evening.

Additional sessions judge P M Unadkat refused to grant any legal protection to Patel with the observation that his custodial interrogation is required to elicit information regarding the arrangement of the mammoth rally, to find out who other accused are in the offence etc., said public prosecutor Sudhir Brahmbhatt , who had vehemently opposed the anticipatory bail plea.

The Vastrapur police lodged an FIR for the violence that broke out in the evening after Patel addressed the Patidar rally and then sat on fast to push the demand for reservation for the community. The FIR was filed for rioting, unlawful assembly, deterring cops from performing their duty and causing damage to property. The government objected to Patel’s plea by stating that Patel and others violated the police commissioner’s notification by continuing their programme even after 5pm on August 25, 2015, when they were supposed to finish their meeting.

Patel sought anticipatory bail in the 2015 case after non-bailable warrants were issued against him by various courts and he was arrested in three different cases for bail condition violation. The courts had issued warrants on complaints made by the government.

Title: Drunk man throttles wife to death
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: A man in an inebriated condition allegedly killed his wife at Langar Houz on Wednesday afternoon. The police said that 40-year-old K Yellappa, who worked as a labourer, consumed alcohol in the afternoon and came home.

After reaching home, Yellappa picked up an argument with his 35-year-old wife Amruthamma. During the argument, Yellappa hit his wife on the head with a mini-cylinder and later throttled her to death.

Police said that Yellappa used to frequently demand money from Amruthamma to purchase liquor and they always fought over this issue. Police registered a case under Section 302 ( murder ) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) against Yellappa and he has been taken into custody.

Title: Cold wave makes a comeback, Churu coldest at 5.7°C
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Jaipur: Cold wave conditions revived in the state on Thursday when majority of places witnessed a dip in its minimum and maximum temperatures across the state. Churu remained coldest in the state where a minimum temperature of 5.7°C was recorded.

Attributing the dip in the mercury to the active northerly winds and vanishing of the factors like upper air cyclonic circulation and western disturbances, the Jaipur Met office said that similar conditions will prevail in the state for the next couple of days. Many places in western Rajasthan are likely to record a minimum temperature of or below 5.0°C.

People in Jaipur woke up to a chilly morning with a minimum temperature of 9.1°C, almost 1 degree below the normal notch. Despite a sunny afternoon, windy cold conditions prevailed in the afternoon with a maximum temperature of 21.6°C recorded, almost 2 degrees below the normal notch. With a sudden dip in the mercury, the roads wore an empty look especially during early morning and late evening with people mostly confined to their homes. Ground frost was also witnessed during morning hours in villages under Jaipur district including Bassi, Bagru, Phagi, Hathoj and others.

Many places in the state also witnessed showers early this week which is beneficial for the crops especially during the last week.

Churu was followed by Udaipur with a minimum temperature of 6.6°C, Kota at 8.2°C, Ajmer 8.3°C, Bikaner 8.4°C, Jaisalmer 9.1°C, Jodhpur 9.3°C and Sriganganagar at 9.4°C.

Title: USFDA warns Aurobindo of action against Unit VII
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: City-based pharma major Aurobindo Pharma on Thursday said the US drug watchdog US Food & Drug Administration (USFDA) has warned that it may initiate regulatory action against its oral solids formulations manufacturing facility, Unit VII, in Telangana.

The company said USFDA has written to the company stating that its inspection of the unit, located on the city’s outskirts in Medak district, has been classified as Official Action Indicated (OAI). As per USFDA’s website, OAI means regulatory and/or administrative actions will be recommended.

“Further to our intimations dated 7th & 11th October, 2019 with regard to the USFDA inspection of Unit VII, an oral solids formulation manufacturing facility of the company, we inform you that the company has received a letter from the USFDA classifying the inspection conducted at the aforesaid facility as Official Action Indicated (OAI),” Aurobindo Pharma said in a regulatory filing to the bourses.

The company said the OAI classification is not expected to have any impact on revenues. “The company believes that this OAI classification will not have any material impact on the existing revenues or the supplies to our US business at this juncture,” the company said in the filing,

Aurobindo Pharma also said it will work closely with the regulator to comprehensively address the issues.

News of the OAI classification for Unit VII sent the company scrip falling 8% to a low of Rs 466.75 before closing 5.32% down at Rs 480.30 as compared to Wednesday’s closing price of Rs 507.30 a share.

Title: Focus now to make farming a profitable venture: Expert
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Guntur: Renowned agriculture scientist Dr Maruthi Prasanna said a new variety of maize seed which could withstand both drought conditions and natural calamities would reach farmers shortly.

He said the development of the new seed was in an advanced stage and they were planning to release it for farm experiments shortly. Dr Prasanna, director of CIMMYT at International Maize and Wheat Improvement Centre at Kenya, said scientists have set their focus on making cultivation a profitable venture.

Addressing a national seminar at Bapatla Agriculture College in the district on Thursday, Prasanna, who was an alumni of the college, said that their focus has shifted from increasing yields to making agriculture profitable after witnessing agrarian crisis across the globe.

He said that agriculture researchers should take Norman Borlaug who was a pioneer of green revolution as inspiration to make the farmers happy. “Any research should help the farmer come out of the crisis. Students should keep in mind that the purpose of their studies will be served only when the farmer is happy,” said Dr Prasanna. TNN

Title: Rajasthan: 3 Barmer students stuck in Wuhan hospital
Content:
Students from Barmer quarantined at a hospital in Wuhan
