Kho Nagoriyan is a dark zone area where ground water has dried down and people have been demanding water supply for a long time. In 2012, government approved water pipeline for areas of JDA approved colonies in Kho Nagoriyan and now as the work is completed the connections are being given.

Shubhanshu Dixit, superintendent engineer at public health and engineering department (PHED) said, “We have started camps to give connections to people of Kho Nagoriyan and the last date for the same is January 31. The connections will be given immediately after residents apply for a connection either at the camps or by coming to the department.”

When asked about the remaining residents of the Kho Nagoriyan, Dixit said that another pipeline sanctioned in 2018 is under construction and will be completed soon. “The remaining people will get water connectivity by the end of the year as a pipeline is sanctioned which is also known as Bisalpur phase 2 project. The construction of the pipeline will be finished by October 2020 which will benefit remaining people. In all, around 1 lakh people are expected to get water supply,” said Dixit.

Mass movements have been organised by the residents of the areas many times for the supply of water. Tankers are usually provided in the area that pours water in the community water tank in the locality from where people can take water for their household work.

Title: Maharashtra: Cops detain 40 for attempt to disrupt anti-CAA programme
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

A group of people stages a demonstration in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act at Gandhi Bhavan on Thurs... Read More

PUNE: There was some commotion outside the city’s Gandhi Bhavan where a programme was organised by the Maharashtra Gandhi Smarak Nidhi (MGSN) on Thursday against the Citizenship Amendment Act, National Register of Citizens and National Population Register.

Some unidentified people assembled outside the venue and started raising slogans in support of CAA. Police swung into action and detained them.

The programme was attended by Actress Urmila Matondkar , Pune Bishop Thomas Dabre, MGSN's Kumar Saptarshi and civil rights activists Teesta Setalvad.

Pratibha Joshi, senior inspector, Kothrud police, told TOI that 40 people were detained for attempting to disrupt the programme at Gandhi Bhavan. "Initially, 15 men raised slogans outside the Gandhi Bhavan. We immediately detained them. We also detained further 25 men who reached the venue and started raising slogans," Joshi said.

She said the police will take action against MGSN as it did not take prior permission. "Our probe is on," Joshi said.

The programme, organised to mark the death anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi, later continued without any disturbance following police intervention. While addressing the gathering, Matondkar condemned the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), terming it as a “black act”.

"The country is united to protect the secular fabric. CAA has come as a hurdle to communal harmony and secularism. The Britishers had drafted a similar law about 100 years ago,” she said.

Pune Bishop Thomas Dabre said the country has been following the principles of social harmony. Division in the society on the basis of religions and caste cannot be accepted, he said.

Saptarshi said that CAA will impact over 40 crore people in the country. “The act is not against the Muslim community. It will also impact the poor people from other religions and castes,” he said.

Title: Garbage at Vellalore dumpyard poisons air, groundwater & life
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Coimbatore: With the total dissolved solids (TDS), total hardness and chlorine values exceeding the permissible limits, underground water in and around the Vellalore dumpyard is highly polluted, says a Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) report.

TNPCB had collected water samples from 15 places and tested air quality at five places in and around the yard last November. According to the experts, water in the area has not just become unfit for drinking but also for domestic purposes.

While the permissible limit of TDS that measures the dissolved content of both organic and inorganic substances in drinking water is less than 500ppm for fresh water, the level at most of the areas around the yard is between 880ppm and 3,936ppm, according to the report. The TDS level inside the dumpyard was found to be 18,108ppm.

According to the Indian standard specification, the maximum permissible TDS limit for drinking water is 600mg/l. But the report says that the samples have exceeded it. The same is the case with biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and chemical oxygen demand (COD). The respirable suspended particulate matter (PM10), which is supposed to be 100 as per the board’s standard, was found to be between 38 and 129. Pollutants including SO2 and NO2 were found in the air.

“The quality of air and water in the region is degrading with every passing day. The more the city corporation delays to take effective steps, the more would be the consequences. The civic body has been giving assurance to reduce the inflow of waste to the dumpyard, but nothing was implemented,” said K S Mohan of the Kurichi and Vellalore Pollution Prevent Action Committee, who obtained the TNPCB report using the right to information (RTI) Act.

Pointing out that the foul smell emanating from the dumpyard had drastically increased in the last couple of months, Mohan said that local residents are suffering from frequent headache and throat pain, apart from respiratory problems.

Daniel Jesudass, a resident and activist, blamed the corporation. “The pollution level increased only because the corporation failed to follow any of the measures required to be followed while handling waste,” he said.

When contacted, a corporation official said that the civic body will soon float a tender to scientifically dispose the waste through biomining.

Title: Learn from chefs and mixologists at food festival
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

PUNE: Visitors to the Times Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest , to be held at the Vrindavan Garden in Baner on February 1 and 2, will not only get to taste some of the best vegetarian food in the city, but also learn from the best chefs and mixologists .

Pune-based Sufi Bollywood band Malang will perform at the festival ground on both the days. Renowned restaurants in the city will put up several stalls, offering an array of lip-smacking fares. Moreover, there will be some well-known food trucks too.

The festival will offer exclusive vegetarian fare from across the world — from Mughlai to Mexican to middle-eastern, Chinese and Indian street food. There will be keto diet options too.

Some of the top multi-cuisine restaurants like Baan Taao from Hyatt as well as Marrakesh, which serves some of the best Lebanese shawarma and Middle-Eastern cuisine in the city, will put up stalls at the food fest.

Chef Steven D’Souza of Hyatt Pune, Kalyani Nagar, will host a workshop on the opening day from 3pm to 5pm. He will demonstrate preparation for various kinds of dimsums and vegetarian salads.

As part of the workshop, Poptates will demonstrate the art of mixology, a skill that requires intimate knowledge of taste and aroma.

Radisson Blu will also hold a workshop to teach “quick cooking” to kids. Another workshop will be held by executive chef Ilandhirai Vadivel, where the basics of bakery, including preparation of pastries, will be demonstrated.

The Times of India Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest is powered by VTP Realty and curated by Pune Eat Outs. Girikand Travels and Ranka Jewellers are the associate sponsors.

Title: Coronavirus threat: Thermal screening at Goa airport, says Vishwajit Rane
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose. (Photo: AP)

PANAJI: Thermal screening will be introduced at the Goa International Airport at Dabolim as a precautionary measure against coronavirus.

Health minister Vishwajit Rane said signage and a help desk have been set up at the airport on Thursday evening.

Confirming the measure, state epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar told TOI on Thursday evening that thermal screening will be introduced at Goa airport to check international travellers.

The Goa government had requested the Centre to set up thermal screening at the state’s lone airport.

Till Thursday, Goa had one suspected case of coronavirus and five persons under observations.

Rane said the test report of the suspected case is awaited. The other five patients are asymptomatic and being monitored daily, he said.

All five had been to China in recent past.

Title: UP: 29 arrested in a day for anti-CAA stir
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: As many as 29 persons have been arrested by Pratapgarh police in a day on charges of rioting and obstructing highway in connection with Wednesday’s road blockade incident in Kunda.

A large group of anti-CAA protesters had on Wednesday blocked the Allahabad-Lucknow state highway for more than half an hour.

Following the incident, Kunda police lodged an FIR against 150 protesters on charges of obstructing highway and rioting under Sections 147, 148 and 149 of IPC and 7 CLA.

Pratapgarh SP Abhishek Singh told TOI claimed that police had identified 50 more persons involved in the incident.

during the road blockade on Wednesday, police reached the spot and tried to pursue protesters to withdraw. This resulted in a heated argument between the protesters and the police personnel. Police resorted to lathi charge when a group of protesters started pelting stones on them and the passing vehicles.

Title: JDA seeks HC nod for extension of parking lot
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) has sought permission from the Rajasthan High Court for construction of underground parking at Ramniwas Bagh which will be an extension of existing one.

As the court has banned any kind of construction in the Bagh, the civic body has requested a permission to be granted to avoid future hassle. To reduce snarls in Walled City, the JDA has recently proposed extension of the underground parking at Ramniwas Bagh.

As per the preliminary design, most of the construction will be below the Union Football Ground at the park. The parking will be constructed in L-shape.

An official said the JDA proposed to extend the underground parking till Jaipur Traffic Police office towards Ajmeri Gate end. However, the authorities are apprehensive about constructing a parking space beneath Sawan Bhado Park as it might violate high court directives, which prohibited construction of any kind in that area.

Title: DMK MLA flays bus stand plan
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Coimbatore: Singanallur DMK MLA N Karthik on Thursday requested the government to develop roads before constructing the integrated bus stand at Vellalore.

Speaking to reporters, Karthik said that the bus stand does not have proper accessible roads from most parts of the district, including Neelambur, Singanallur and Mettupalayam. “It is high time that the corporation develop access roads before constructing the bus stand. Without roads, the facility will remain unusable to the public,” he said.

“Travelling to the bus stand itself will become tedious as the location selected for it is not suitable. Based on the location, the entire bus routes and schedule will have to be revised,” the MLA added.

Title: Behmai case verdict adjourned till February 12
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: The designated dacoity affected area court Kanpur Dehat on Friday once again adjourned the delivery of judgment in Behmai massacre case and fixed February 12 as the next date for order.

According to district government counsel Rajeev Porwal , the date was adjourned due to strike of advocates against an order of district judiciary. The court had earlier fixed January 24 for hearing of the case and further order but due to strike of advocates, no hearing could take place. The presiding officer had fixed January 30 as next date.

Talking to TOI, Porwal stated that advocates of Kanpur Dehat court have no chambers in the court campus and they have to sit in corridor or verandah for legal work. The judgeship had asked them to vacate the corridor and verandah and court staff had seized chairs and tables of some advocates.

The advocates were protesting against that move, and they were not allowing anyone to enter the courtroom. As a result, no hearing could take place, DGC said.

Though the case was lodged against about three dozen dacoits including Phoolan Devi but at present case is being heard against four dacoits and they are Posa, Bheekha, Vishwanath alias Krishna Kumar alias Putani and Shyam Sundar. Four dacoits are absconding and remaining including Phoolan devi died or killed in police encounters.

Title: Jaipur: Fee hike for PRN to benefit land mafia, alleges ex-minister
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

A file photograph of Prithvi Raj Nagar in the city

JAIPUR: A day after Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) increased the regularisation and development fee for the Prithvi Raj Nagar, former urban development and housing (UDH) minister Rajpal Singh accused the government of benefiting the land mafia. He alleged that JDA is imposing heavy fee on poor and regularising plots more than 1,000 square yards is unjustified and exploitation of poor plot owners.

“Our government has devised the revenue model to acquire land of bigger plots and provide relief to poor. The ruling party in connivance with land mafia has tweaked the rules to fill their coffers,” said Singh.

He said, JDA has not developed facilities in PRN area with Rs 1,250 crore, collected after regularisation of plots in their tenure. “An integrated plan was prepared to develop facilities in PRN scheme. However, no such attempt has been made to provide facilities to plot owners. The JDA intentions is to earn revenue from poor residents for its own survival,” he added. The (JDA) on Wednesday increased the regularisation and development charges for (PRN) Scheme. For a 100 square yard plot, the JDA will now charge Rs 300 regularisation charge (per square yard), which will include allotment rates. Similarly, for plot size between 101 to 300 square yard, the JDA would charge Rs 480 regularisation charge (per square yard) including allotment rates.

Owners having a plot more than 1,000 square yard will have to give 1.5 times regularisation charges. For regularising the marriage garden in the scheme which are developed on the plot size above 2,000 square yard, the JDA has fixed Rs 1,500 (per square yard) regularisation charge.

The residents even believe, the charges fixed to provide development and basic facilities in the (PRN) scheme has become out of reach of people who have not taken lease deeds till date. Residents believe, initiative should have taken to reduce the development rates so that water, electricity, roads and sewerage can be provided to the residents on nominal rates.

Giriraj Singh Khangarot, president of Prithviraj Nagar Sanyukt Jan Sangharsh Samiti, said, “The plot owners who haven’t applied for lease deeds were actually poor. The development and regularisation rates of PRN were already high. The government should have provide relaxation to these owners rather than increasing rates,” he said.

Title: Illegal dairies flout rule, continue to thrive in Jaipur
Content:
Cows are being kept on a road in Walled City area

TimesView After decades, the quest for a ‘cattle-free’ Jaipur remains a distant dream. Illegal dairy farms continue to thrive in densely populated Walled City area, years after the high court ordered the municipal corporation to shift them outside the city. Apart from being illegal, these dairies are creating sanitation and health problems for both cattle and residents of the area. The Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) had taken action to shift these dairies after a foreign tourist was gored by a bull a year ago. However, the drive lost steam and dairies continue to flourish under the patronage of official and local politicians. If the situation is to change, authorities have to act against officials who are repeatedly failing the system.

JAIPUR: In a blatant violation of Rajasthan high court order, illegal dairies continue to thrive in the Walled City areas right under the nose of the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC). The JMC has stated in the high court in November 2019 that it will make the city free of illegal dairy within two months. However, nothing has changed.Illegal dairy business has been a problem for Jaipur for a long time and the JMC has been asked to shift them to the outskirts of the city. Many drives were started by the JMC officials to close down the dairy but one round in the Walled City area can show the reality.As per norms, an owner having more than four animals will be considered to be running a dairy. Following the order to shift the dairy owners, land was allotted to them three places in Jaipur.Around the Govind Dev ji temple cattle are tied on road without any fear of the authorities. The business is carrying on despite all the raids that have been conducted in the past. Deputy commissioner, animal husbandry at JMC, Ram Kishore Meena wasn’t available for any comment. In the past, there have been many attacks on the employees of JMC as well when they went to seize the cattle. Officials at JMC said that people in power have been backing these dairy owners due to which it gets difficult to move them.In 1999, the dairy owners were allotted land outside the city by Jaipur Development Authority (JDA). Dairy owners took the land went to live there for a while but after some time they sold them and shifted back to the city.Ganesh Gurjar, one of the dairy owners, said that it is their livelihood and they don’t have place to shift.

Title: Kavalekar backs devolution of powers to ZPs
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Margao: Deputy chief minister Chandrakant Kavalekar on Thursday expressed his support to the demand by zilla panchayat members for devolution of funds and powers to the local self government bodies as envisaged in the 73rd amendment to the constitution.

Speaking to reporters on the sidelines of an event, Kavalekar said that he has even raised the issue on several occasions in the House.

“It’s a misconception that the powers of the MLA will be curtailed if zilla panchayat members are given more powers. On the contrary, pressure of work on MLAs will be eased to a large extent if ZPs are also given more powers. After all, we are here to do the service of the public. Devolution of more powers and funds to the zilla panchayat members will lead to better service of the public,” Kavalekar said.

Replying to a query, Kavalekar said that all ZP members who supported him while in Congress, are now with him in BJP, even as he exuded confidence about the victory of his candidates in the ZP elections.

Title: Lt Gen CP Mohanty assumes command of Southern Army
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Lt Gen CP Mohanty

PUNE: Lt Gen CP Mohanty assumed command of the Southern Army on Thursday.

He laid a wreath at the National War Memorial to pay tribute to the fallen soldiers. Later, the 1st battalion of the Maratha Light Infantry (MLI) gave a guard of honour to the army commander at the Southern Command Headquarters.

The general officer is an alumnus of the Rashtriya Indian Military College (RIMC), Dehradun, and National Defence Academy (NDA). He is a June 1982 batch Infantry officer from the Rajput regiment. Currently, he is also the colonel of the regiment.

“He commanded his battalion in Jammu and Kashmir and the northeast, the mountain brigade along the Indo-China border and a mountain division in counter-insurgency operations. Later, he commanded a strategically important corps in the eastern theatre post Doklam and also in Uttar Bharat Area at Bareilly,” said a statement issued by the Southern Command.

“He has held important staff appointments in an armoured brigade and the military secretary branch, besides being director-general of operational logistics and strategic movement at Integrated Headquarters of the Ministry of Defence (army) in New Delhi,” the release added.

Title: Karnataka: Attacker claimed he was posted as DSP
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Police said Prasad attacked the woman with acid because she spurned his advances and refused to marry him

HAVERI: Haveri police have nabbed a 25-year-old man in connection with an acid attack on a woman here on Tuesday. The man, identified as Prasad Chikkali, hails from Chikkabasur village of Byadagi taluk.

Prasad, who completed postgraduation in journalism from Karnatak University in Dharwad, is unemployed. The victim, who works at the human resource department in a garment factory in Byadagi, had also studied at the same PG centre.

The initial probe has revealed that the 24-year-old victim and Prasad were previously in a relationship and he had duped the woman making multiple false claims. He reportedly told her that he had cleared Karnataka Administrative Service and was currently posted as deputy superintendent of police.

“Initially, the girl believed him and agreed to the relationship. However, as time passed, the victim figured out the truth and began to avoid him. Subsequently, he turned suspicious,” said K G Devaraj, SP, Haveri.

“He called her multiple times asking her to marry him, show eight-months old call records,” he added.

Prasad, as a revenge for the woman’s refusal to marry him, resorted to acid attack to disfigure her, the SP said. Police are trying to find out where he had sourced the acid from, he added.

Sources in the department said the acid may have been sourced from outside the district and effort is on to locate the supplier.

Plastic surgery only after

a week, say doctors

The victim, undergoing treatment at the Karnataka Institute of Medical Sciences , has suffered burn injuries on face and neck, said doctors. Although the parents have consented for a plastic surgery, doctors may wait for at least eight days to decide on the surgery.

Speaking to TOI, the sister of the victim said, “ He should feel the pain that my sister going through. He needs to be dealt with stringent punishment and justice must be served.”

Title: ‘Need to make journalism more people oriented’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: In his publication ‘Mooknayak’, Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar wanted to make ‘mute’ people the leaders, the heroes. Therefore, efforts should be done to make this kind of 100-year-old journalism more people-oriented was the view speakers at a seminar on ‘Purogami chalwali aani aajchi patrakarita’ said on Thursday.

The national seminar, divided into three sessions, was organized by the department of Marathi of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar College, Deekshabhoomi as part of Mooknayak Shatabdi Mahotsav.

In his address, senior scribe Shailesh Pande said journalism today has undergone a lot of changes with many social media portals indulging in spreading canards and sullying the image of mainstream reporting which is not a good sign as people easily fall prey to fake news.

Pande said, “Earlier the situation on the journalistic front was different from what it is today. There may have been different schools of thought that time too, but journalism was maintaining its dignity and giving a fair report of the changes taking place in various fields.”

“It is observed these days that revealing the truth may not go down well with some quarters and therefore a journalist has to think twice before cracking a story. In Dr Ambedkar’s times, journalists had the freedom to put forth their views without any fear,” he added.

Emergence of social media has completely changed the scenario with the vested interests taking undue advantage and branding fake news as the genuine which is nothing but playing mindgames with innocent citizens, he added.

It is also true that there are some issues in society which cannot be changed by journalists or the government. This can be achieved by bringing about a change in the mindset of the society, Pande said.

Those who spoke in various sessions included senior journalists Prakash Dubey, Shripad Aparajit and Sunil Khobragade; Satish Pawde, Balwant Bhoyar, Bhimrao Gote, Surendra Gondane, Mahendra Gaikwad, Ishwar Somnathe and Bhushan Ramteke.

The speakers were of the opinion that journalism in old times was fearless and contributed to the betterment of the society. These days, there are reports of paid media playing its part, they said.

The speakers said journalism was a mission in the past. But things have changed these days with most of the youngsters joining the profession for money and glamour it provides, they added.

Kalpana Shinde conducted the proceedings. Satish Kapre proposed a vote of thanks.

(Reporting by Rushabh Rathod)

Title: 5 temples get leaf composters
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Coimbatore: The city corporation in association with Bharathi Park Ladies’ Association (BPLA) on Thursday installed leaf composters at five temples in and around Saibaba Colony. The idea is to compost flower and leaf waste generated in the temples.

President of BPLA Menaka Vairavan said, “Until recently, the green waste, especially leaves and flowers, was getting mixed with other waste and ending up at the dump yard in Vellalore. The purpose of installing the composters at the temple is to prevent mixing of the waste and to ensure that flower and leaf waste is composted on the temple premises itself.”

For the waste generated in a temple, one composter is sufficient as flower and leaf waste shrink once dried up. The waste would get decomposed within 45 to 60 days naturally. On the floor of the composter, a banana leaf and soil should be placed before putting wastes into it. Once in three days, water should be sprinkled on the waste, said Menaka, who is also a Swachh Bharat Ambassador.

The compost could be used either to produce incense sticks or used as fertilizer for flowering plants, she said.

The corporation has also warned the public of slapping a penalty of up to Rs 5,000 if they were to mix other wastes in the composter. Upon mixing the other waste, including food, in the composter, chances for the formation of worms and emanating foul smell is extremely high, she said.

“The corporation has not imposed penalty for not segregating waste due to lack of awareness among the people. Now that the awareness level has increased, penalty should be imposed on the violators,”Menaka Vairavan said.

Title: Forest dept seizes mining co’s excavator
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Bicholim: The forest department on Tuesday raided a mining company’s area at Shirgao where trees were allegedly felled, and seized an excavator from the site.

The department also conducted a panchanama of 19 trees that were allegedly felled by the company.

A few days ago, a video was recorded by Shirgao residents showing the company undertaking some excavation work instead of ore transportation at its premises.

Bicholim mamlatdar Pravinjay Pandit inspected the site and said that no illegal excavation was being undertaken by the company. He also said that the mining company has been instructed to seek permission from the competent authority in case any tree-felling is to be undertaken.

However, late Monday evening, villagers found that many trees were felled and the entire area was deforested.

On Tuesday, forest officials, including range forest officer Vivek Gaonkar, round forestor Pradeep Sinari and forest guard Vishnu Amonkar attached to the Kerim range forest outpost inspected the site, seized an excavator and conducted the panchanama.

Title: Elderly woman murdered
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: Sindhu Gedam, 55, was found dead on the morning of January 27 at her native village of Niharvani in Mouda tehsil. She was missing since the late hours of January 25.

It’s learnt Sindhu had gone to see a dance programme organized at her village. Her son Rajesh and his wife too had gone to enjoy the programme. It’s learnt that Rajesh’s wife was the first to leave for their residence followed by her mother-in-law Sindhu after some time. Sindhu had been missing since then.

The family could not spot Sindhu despite daylong searches on January 26. They had also lodged a missing complaint the same day at Mouda police station. As the cops and others started making inquiries about the unexplained disappearance of the woman, her body was found along the roadside around 50 meters away from her house with a shawl covering it. There was a green cloth around the neck and no ornaments were found on her.

Mouda police and Local Crime Branch (LCB) of Nagpur Rural police have started a probe in the matter.

Title: Criminals gun down realtor in Muzaffarpur
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

MUZAFFARPUR: A 40-year-old property dealer was shot dead by unidentified criminals in Sahbazpur locality of the town under the Ahiapur police station area on Thursday.

The incident occurred around 9am when the victim, Krinchi Sahni, was returning home after meeting one of his friends at Zero Mile. Locals took Sahni to Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital here, where he succumbed to his bullet injuries.

Agitated over the incident, locals vandalised some shops and blocked interjections of National Highway-57 and 77. Vehicular movement remained paralysed on these NHs connecting Darbhanga and Sitamarhi, respectively, for more than six hours.

The situation was brought under control after City SP Niraj Kumar Singh and deputy SP (town) Ram Narain Paswan reached the spot with heavy reinforcement. The locals were demanding immediate arrest of the the killers, payment of compensation to the next of the kin of the deceased and government job to one of his family members.

The City SP said an FIR was registered at Ahiapur police station on the statement of the Sahni’s wife. “We are scanning the CCTV footage to identify the killers and arrest them. The motive behind the murder is yet to be ascertained,” the SP added.

Title: Major clean-up drive in Mangalbazaar area
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Large quantity of materials from street vendors was seized

Vadodara: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) conducted a major anti-encroachment-cum-removal drive in the congested Mangalbazaar area of the city on Thursday. A large quantity of materials used by street vendors was also seized during the drive.

According to officials, the drive was conducted as street vendors and squatters had occupied internal roads and streets in the market leading to huge traffic snarls in the area. Also, a few shops in the area too had made unauthorised extensions encroaching upon the lanes. Teams of VMC removed handcarts, counters and other materials from the market in the morning. The teams removed eight truckloads of materials from the area to clear the streets. Five structures that were unauthorised were also razed by the civic body’s teams.

The civic body has been conducting drives periodically to remove encroachments in the area. However, these keep returning and thereby leading to congestion.

Title: Experts urge APPSC to hold fresh Group I prelim exam
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Amaravati: The comments made by the Andhra Pradesh High Court , during the hearing of a PIL, has put a question mark on when the Group-I main examinations will be held.

The HC had suggested that the APPSC may consider a fresh preliminary examination given the fact that nearly 50 out of the 120 questions were not appropriate.

Although, the HC adjourned the court seeking affidavit from APPSC, experts have advised the government to annul the examination. They say even if the HC allows APPSC to go ahead, students would approach the Supreme Court which might delay the process.

“Instead of wasting students’ time, it is desirable for the PSC to conduct fresh examination,” said Dr Hanumantha Rao, a faculty at a training institute. He said there were instances where the SC had cancelled many state services exams on such grounds and it was better not to delay the process posing more trouble to the students.

Sources said many candidates had quit their jobs in private sector to prepare for the test. Government employees, including teachers and college lectures, had been preparing for the examination by applying for leave under loss of pay.

Many candidates were irked by the recent developments. “I have lost nearly 18 months since I started my prelims preparation,” said a woman candidate. She said she had turned downed several job offers since the completion of graduation with the sole aim of clinching the Group-I job.

Title: Rationalists decry Centre’s advisory on Coronavirus
Content:
As countries around the world struggle to contain the spread of the deadly Coronavirus, the advisory of the mi... Read More

MANGALURU: As countries around the world struggle to contain the spread of the deadly Coronavirus, the advisory of the ministry of AYUSH (ayurveda, yoga & naturopathy, unani, siddha, sowa rigpa and homoeopathy) has irked rationalists.Condemning the Union government’s attempt to promote quackery in the name of alternative medicine, Federation of Indian Rationalist Associations (FIRA) president Narendra Nayak said: “When all the authorities including World Health Organisation claim there is neither any vaccine nor any treatment for Coronavirus, the government is promoting unproven therapies to lull people into a false sense of security that they can be safe if they consume such concoctions.”FIRA members also questioned the silence of medical bodies on “this blatant falsehood”.AYUSH ministry, in a health advisory, had recommended that homeopathic and unani medicines could be effective in the prevention of Coronavirus infections.The advisory was issued following a meeting on Tuesday of the scientific advisory board of the Central Council for Research in Homoeopathy (CCRH) under the AYUSH ministry to discuss ways and means for prevention of the infection through homoeopathy, the ministry said in a statement.It had recommended that homoeopathic medicine Arsenicum album 30 could be taken empty stomach daily for three days as a prophylactic medicine against the infection besides hygiene measures.

Title: Woman aborts 7-month-old foetus, dumps it in toilet
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Coimbatore: The Kovilpalayam police on Wednesday registered a case against a 36-year-old woman for aborting her seven-month-old foetus and dumping it in a private hospital toilet.

Police said the woman, Amaravathi, of PN Palayam, works in the hospital as supervisor for the past one year. On Wednesday around 6am, Amaravathi came to the hospital with stomach ache and went to the restroom. Immediately, she left the hospital with her 19-year-old son. When a cleaning staff visited the restroom at 8.30am, the foetus was found dumped in a toilet. Hospital officials alerted the police.Amaravathi had conceived through an extramarital affair and had consumed pills to abort it. tnn

Title: Major Amrut scheme likely to miss deadline
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The capital has already started experiencing water shortage much ahead of the summer. The lone hope of city is in the proposed commissioning of the 75mld treatment plant at Aruvikkara under Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation ( AMRUT ) in March, which could boost the supply of drinking water to the city.

However, there is uncertainty on whether the project can meet the March deadline as there is delay in release of funds. Restriction imposed on release of funds from the treasury due to financial crisis is the reason for the delay.

Under AMRUT project, 50% fund is provided by the Centre, 30% by the state government and 20% by local bodies. For the past several months, around Rs 30 crore is pending for various projects under the sewerage wing and the Kerala water authority (KWA). Of these, the 75mld treatment plant alone has a pending dues worth Rs 17 crore.

Executive engineer of KWA has recently sent a letter to the corporation secretary demanding immediate steps to allot funds for pending bills worth Rs 30 crore for various works under AMRUT in the city. Some of the bills are pending since March, 2019.

Earlier, exemptions were given to release of funds for schemes sponsored by the Centre. However, later the government imposed restrictions on such schemes too.

Sources said the construction of the 75mld treatment plant was progressing as per schedule, but delay in payment would affect the work. “Now the work has entered a phase where the machinery will have to be purchased for the plant. Unless there is immediate release of funds, it will be difficult to meet the March deadline,” said sources. The 75mld treatment plant is being constructed by Chicago Constructions International Private Ltd.

Some other works which are affected by the delay in payment are renovation works of sewage treatment plant at Medical College and laying of pumping main line from Edathara pump house to sewage treatment plant at Muttathara.

Sources said that fund release under AMRUT went without hassles for the first two years and issues cropped up later. For projects with March deadline, the financial hurdles are set to be a major roadblock.

Title: Fight over feeding stray dogs reaches police station
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

cap

Vadodara: Feeding stray dogs resulted in a clash between two neighbours in Gorwa that eventually ended at the police station on Wednesday.

Tired of dog barks throughout the nights, two residents of Shantinagar Society in Gorwa – Dipen Patel and Aatish Patel – chased away the dogs with sticks from their society on January 28. But this action of the duo irked their neighbour Bina Joshi and her daughter Prerna. The mother-daughter duo confronted Dipen and Aatish regarding shoving sticks at stray dogs and allegedly started recording video in their mobile phone.

Beena alleged that it was Dipen and Aatish who started the arguments. The duo shouted at Beena saying who will be held responsible if the stray dogs bite someone and asked her to keep the stray dogs in her house. Both alleged each other of using foul language and lodged cross complaints at Gorwa police station.

Beena lodged a case of using obscene words in public and under Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act against Dipen and Aatish. On the other hand, Dipen’s wife lodged a case of using obscene words and criminal intimidation against Beena and Prerna.

“The stray dogs have bitten five to six people in the society and my husband and our neighbour were chasing the dogs away only because one of the canines attacked our three-year-old daughter last Sunday. Although the dogs have been barking all nights, we have never chased them away, it was only after the attack on our daughter that we felt that these animals cannot be tolerated any longer,” said Dipen’s wife Trupti. She added that Beena and her daughter have been feeding the dogs daily for past two years.

TOI tried to contact Beena, but the calls were not answered.

Title: Ranji trophy: U’khand-Haryana test match ends in a draw
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand’s test match against Haryana ended in a draw at city’s Rajiv Gandhi International Cricket Stadium on Thursday. Rain played spoilsport in this Ranji trophy match and the game wasn’t played at all on Day 2 and Day 3 of the match. The game could resume only after the lunch session of Day 4.

In first innings, Uttarakhand scored 109 runs and Haryana put up 142 runs. The last day of the match ended with Uttarakhand scoring 109 runs for the loss of 3 wickets in 32 overs. Haryana team was awarded three points and Uttarakhand was given one point after the game.

Title: Mangaluru hospitals receive directives
Content:
Representative image

MANGALURU: As the neighbouring Kerala grapples with suspected cases of coronavirus Dakshina Kannada district health department has issued directives to hospitals in the city and the airport to contain the spread of the virus.District health and family welfare officer Dr Ramakrishna Rao confirmed that no suspected cases of the infection have been recorded in the district.“We have already sent circulars to all hospitals in the district. Similarly, directives have been given to the authorities of Mangaluru International Airport. We have directed hospitals and the airport authorities to inform us if they come across any such suspected cases. We have also requested airport authorities to create awareness among passengers arriving at the international terminal. They will collect the passengers’ travel history and inform us in case of any suspicion,” Dr Rao said.“All the necessary arrangements have been made at the Wenlock District Hospital. An isolation ward has been set up with five beds,” he added.“We are well-equipped with a five-bed isolation ward. The ward will have sufficient number of staff including physicians, senior specialists and professors from KMC. All protective equipment required for the staff have also been arranged,” said Dr H R Rajeshwari Devi, medical superintendent, Wenlock Hospital.

Title: APSERMC to scrap exam centres in private schools
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vijayawada: AP School Education Regulatory and Monitoring Commission (APSERMC) has proposed to cancel examination centres in private and corporate schools.

Addressing a media conference here on Thursday, APSERMC chairman Justice Kantha Rao said that the commission has noticed several discrepancies in the conduct of practical examinations at these centres.

Rao said private schools and colleges were taking advantage of practical examinations. “College managements are at liberty to influence the authorities and get high marks for their students in practical examinations. We came to know that some colleges were giving marks without conducting the exams. This is a serious issue and we have decided to take stringent action,” he said.

The commission said inspecting authorities, including district, deputy and mandal education officers, were found wanting in their duties.

The commission has also proposed to establish a mechanism to conduct regular inspections in private and government schools in order to improve the quality of education in the state.

The commission said it would take serious action against teaching and and non-teaching staff who were found guilty of sexual harassment charges.

“Teachers who were suspended on charges of sexual harassment against students and co-faculty will not be posted in the same school. The commission has proposed to complete departmental inquiry within a month and initiate action against the guilty,” he said.

The commission said that it would suggest including lessons on gender equality in curriculum. “We should sensitize the students about gender equality and there would be punishment for misbehaving with women. This will help the next generation to respect women and treat them equally. We have started designing special lessons on gender equality and they will be included in the curriculum for high school classes,” said Kantha Rao.

Title: A great escape!
Content: Kottayam: It was a great escape for me from China which is gripped by the novel coronavirus infection, said a Kottayam native who returned home on Wednesday.Many are still struggling to return home due to the shortage of flights, he said. “There were long queues at the airport as people from other countries working and studying in China wanted to flee the country at the earliest,” said the 45-year-old, who has been working at a hotel, a few hundred kilometres from Wuhan, for more than a decade.He left the country after the hotel was shut following the outbreak of the disease. “On the day I left, nCoV infection was confirmed in around 20 people in my locality,” he said adding that the China government had put lots of restrictions in using the Internet and social media.He was subjected to a medical examination upon his arrival at the Nedumbassery airport. “My residential address was registered at a special counter,” he said adding that health workers and medical officials visited his house twice. He has also been directed to inform the health department if he has some health issues.

Title: Vacant plots in PN Pudur a den of anti-social elements, reptiles
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Coimbatore: Residents of PN Pudur on Thursday petitioned the city corporation to clean and fence the vacant plots, which were filled with thick vegetation , in their area as they have become home to reptiles and anti-social elements. They said their safety was at risk.

In PN Pudur, vacant plots are present at Radhika Avenue, Chinnasami Nagar, Veerasami Colony, Periyar Ramasamy Extension, Aiswarya Nagar and Vivekanandan Extension, among others. “There are more than 20 vacant plots and each of them on an average measure anywhere between two cents and five cents. Filled with shrubs, they are today breeding grounds of mosquitoes and home to snakes,” said N Chandran, a resident of the area.

He said around a year ago a wild boar had taken refuge in one of the plots, creating panic among the residents. “The animal entered the area early in the morning and it was captured only by night.”

Anti-social elements, meanwhile, use these plots to consume liquor. “After drinking, they simply dump the bottles there itself,” he said.

Pointing out that civic body officials were having the list of people who own the vacant plots, he urged them to direct the landowners to clean their plots and fence them.

A resident said, “While the vacant plots would be cleaned whenever we undertake some maintenance work in the area, we want them to be cleaned regularly.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Rejuvenated, jumbos to go back home today
Content:
On Friday, the elephants will be fed fruits in a ceremony and sent to their temples starting from 4.30pm

A total of 28 elephants from temples and mutts across the state and Puducherry have been participating in the camp since December 15, 2019

COIMBATORE: The 48-day rejuvenation camp for temple elephants at Thekkampatti in Mettupalayam is all set to conclude on Friday.A total of 28 elephants from temples and mutts across the state and Puducherry have been participating in the camp since December 15, 2019. All these days, they were fed nutritious food and taken on morning and evening walk to ensure their well-being. Their health was also taken care of by providing the needy with required medical aid.K Rajamanickam, joint commissioner, Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HR&CE) department, Coimbatore, said they would issue a special health report and health card for every elephant. “Doctors would assess each elephant completely and prepare the report, copies of which will be handed over to mahouts and HR&CE officials in temples.”The doctors would also frame a daily schedule for elephants to be followed in temples based on their age and weight. “The schedule will be handed over to mahouts, who have to ensure that the same is followed,” the officer said.This year, a team of experts from Kerala and Tamil Nadu had visited the camp and assessed the elephants. “They also held a meeting and came up with suggestions. Elephants that had wounds in the feet were treated for that,” he said.The team had found that several elephants were overweight and hence prescribed a high-fibre diet for them. They had also suggested pedicure for elephants as their nails were vulnerable to get cracked.According to the official, mahouts would be issued certificates for participating in the camp.On Friday, the elephants would be fed fruits in a ceremony and sent to their temples starting from 4.30pm after various rituals and procedures, the official said.This was the 12th rejuvenation camp for temple elephants. It was conducted using a budget of Rs 1.4 crore.

Title: Kapil Wadhawan formed 5 shell companies to divert over Rs 2,000 crore
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kapil Wadhawan (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Enforcement Directorate has found that the arrested promoter of Dewan Housing Finance Ltd (DHFL), Kapil Wadhawan, and others had formed five shell companies to divert over Rs 2,000 crore from his company. The money was allegedly siphoned in the form of loans to these paper companies.

While a company named Faith Realtors Private Limited was given Rs 685 crore, another shell firm named Marvel Township was given Rs 510 crore, the ED said. A firm by the name of Able Realty got Rs 215 crore while Rs 392 crore were given to Poseidon Realty and Rs 353 crore to Random Realtors Private Limited.

The loans to these five companies were sanctioned in 2010-11 by bypassing the loan policy of the firm and were shown as “unpaid” till July last year. The ED has found that that no collateral was taken against these loans. These five companies were later amalgamated with a firm named Sublink, controlled by Wadhawan brothers.

This money was part of the Rs 12,773 crore which have been siphoned out from the company by fraudulently claiming loans. The Wadhawan brothers allegedly got made one lakh fictitious individual customers, using over two dozen shell companies.

Title: High spirits: You may have to pay more for premium booze in Chandigarh
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The prices of premium brands of whisky and beer are likely to go up in the next financial year.

The Chandigarh administration is considering to increase prices by 10% to 15% in the next excise policy, which will come into force from April 1. Sources in the UT administration said the officials were contemplating hike in prices of whisky and beer and those of wine and beer at microbreweries were likely to go down. A senior UT officer said they were working on the proposal and final decision would soon be taken by the top officials of the UT administration.

In the current excise policy, the prices of premium brands of whisky had gone up by around 20%. However, the rates of beer and wine had remained unchanged and those of beer at microbrewery had gone down.

Recently, the UT administration had invited members of the Chandigarh Hospitality Association for suggestions and objections on the proposed excise policy.

According to the UT administration, the 2019-20 excise policy would help the administration earn a revenue Rs 600 crore as compared to Rs 510 crore in 2018-19.

Under the current policy, excise levies on country-made liquor was increased by approximately 17% and on India-made foreign liquor (IMFL) by approximately 20%. To promote low alcoholic contents beverages, like beer and wine, and boost Indian wine industry, the licence fee was not increased and kept at Rs 12,000 for the whole year. The label registration fee of wine was reduced from Rs 15,000 to Rs 10,000 per brand.

In the current excise policy, the excise duty of microbrewery was reduced from Rs 50 per bulk litre to Rs 30 to shift consumers from hard liquor to soft. The licence fees of microbrewery, restaurants/pubs and bar was also not increased.

‘Lower age limit’

Representatives of the Chandigarh Hospitality Association had urged the UT excise and taxation department to lower alcohol consumption age in Chandigarh from 25 to 21 years for the next financial year. The hoteliers had also demanded extension of bar timings from 1am to 2am. The department had sought suggestions from hoteliers and wine merchants’ body before finalising the excise policy.

Title: Almora girl Aditi Bhatt picked for India’s junior badminton team
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand shuttler Aditi Bhatt , has been selected in the junior Indian team to represent the country in the forthcoming junior Dutch and German Open tournaments. The 17-year-old from Almora is the only player from Uttarakhand to feature in this year’s 16-member team. Bhatt has been selected for both girls’ doubles and girls’ singles making her the only female player in the squad to have achieved this feat. “I am extremely excited to represent the junior Indian team in international tournaments. My aim is to win some medals in both the tournaments as it will help me in improving my world ranking further. The competition will be challenging as world’s best junior players are participating in the tournaments,” said Bhatt.

The team for both tournaments was selected on the basis of performances in the recently-concluded Chandigarh Open and Bengaluru Open. Bhatt had won a gold and a bronze medal in the Chandigarh Open. However, she couldn’t secure any medal in the Bengaluru Open. Aditi is among the world’s top-20 in both girls’ doubles and girls’ singles junior category.

Title: Students come up with innovative products
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Table-top coconut de-husker, electric cycle on which one can travel for 60km at a cost of just two rupees and eco-friendly sanitary napkins were a few items that grabbed the attention of the visitors at ‘ Enlight 2020 Entrepreneurship Development Conclave’, which concluded here on Thursday.

The event, organized by the state industries and commerce department, came to a conclusion with Amal Jyoti College of Engineering from Kanjirappally bagging the first prize for their ‘Keranaveena’ table-top coconut de-husker.

“We are really happy about this achievement. The cost of this product is just Rs 550. Unlike the previous versions of coconut de-huskers, this one is suitable for everyone. In the traditional models, one must go out of the kitchen or house to de-husk the coconut, but with this machine, one can do the job comfortably sitting in front of a table,” said Prithviraj Anand, member of the team from Amal Jyothi College.

Goutham Prenoj, Prithviraj Anand, Prathyush J Binu, Anoop Jayakumar, Alen Anil and Bergin S Russel developed this product under the guidance of their professors, Jippu Jacob and Abi Varghese.

The team from Thangal Kunju Musaliar (TKM) College of Engineering won the second prize for their UMO electric cycle. Once fully charged, the electric cycle can travel at a maximum speed of 45Km per hour by carrying an overall weight up to 150kg.

“The cost for charging this cycle is just two rupees and we can convert any cycle into an electric one. This system can be customised and we can modify the cycle based on the needs of the customer. This system can be fixed on any bicycle with ease,” said Nikhil MS, a third-year student from TKM College. The initial cost of the GPS-embedded system is Rs 30,000. Devendu M, Asif Mohammed, Arjun Vignesh and Akhil A are the other members behind the innovation.

The second runners up also grabbed attention with their eco-friendly sanitary napkins. The team consisting of students Nanda Gopan and K Pooja from Santhigiri Vidhya Bhavan Senior Secondary School, under the guidance of their faculty member Bindu Nandana, finished third with their napkins made from the pulp of pine trees, cotton and butter paper.

“Personal hygiene, environmental protection and awareness against the use of plastic, these are our objectives. We gave these napkins to the students and members of Santhigiri Asram and,” said Bindu Nandana.

FISAT’s mobile fab-lab, solar e-rickshaws, crop prediction device, elephant detector, etc., were some other key highlights.

Title: Form internal complaints committee, pvt firms told
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Coimbatore: Collector K Rajamani has asked all the private companies to form internal complaints committee to address sexual harassment complaints of women at workplace.

Rajamani has warned that private organisations that do not form the internal complaints committee (ICC) would face government action. So far, 37 private companies and educational institutions have formed ICC and quarterly reports are collected from them. This apart, all government departments in the district have also formed the committees.

In a statement, Rajamani said that the Centre enacted the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, which mandates all government offices, private companies, educational institutions with more than 10 women employees should have an ICC. A local complaints committee formed at the district level will monitor the ICC.

While the ICC with three members should have a woman as its head, the district level committee will have five members with the district collector as chairman, the district social welfare officer, two representatives from NGOs and an advocate as members.

Rajamani said nodal officers were appointed in 2017 to inquire complaints within city corporation, municipality, two panchayats, block and taluk level in government offices. Victims who suffer sexual harassment can approach the district level committee or the nodal officers. So far, three complaints were received, and inquiry conducted where the identity of the victims were kept discrete, he said.

This apart, women can also submit complaints in the central government’s portal www.shebox.nic.in, he said.

Title: Condemn firing at Jamia students: Parents of Kasganj victim Chandan Gupta
Content:
Students of AMU took out a candle-light march on the campus on Thursday to protest against attack on a protest... Read More

AGRA: Hours before brandishing a country-made pistol and opening fire at a Jamia student, the minor from Jewar, who identified himself as ‘Rambhakt’, had posted on his Facebook wall: “Chandan bhai, ye badla aap ke liye (Brother Chandan, this revenge is for you)”. Kasganj youth Chandan Gupta , 21, was shot dead during a Tiranga Yatra he was leading through a communally sensitive area in the western UP town on January 26, 2018.However, Chandan’s parents Sushil Gupta and Sangeeta Gupta told TOI that they strongly condemn this act of violence.“I condemn the act of opening fire at Jamia protesters in the strongest possible words. We are a non-violent society and protest should always be peaceful. I have lost my son to one such act of violence,” Gupta said.“I support the Citizenship Amendment Act, but violence is not the answer for those who are against the law. In fact, this violent act hampers the government efforts on CAA. His act is not justified on any parameter,” Chandan’s father said.According to police, Chandan was killed in violence that began after a group obstructed another group taking out ‘Tiranga Yatra’ on motorbikes to mark Republic Day, at Abdul Hameed Chowk in Kasganj city, in 2018. After Chandan’s death, dozens of people were injured and widespread vandalism and arson had occurred in the district. The VHP held various Tiranga Yatras in Uttar Pradesh after his death until Chandan's family pleaded with chief minister Yogi Adityanath to "stop these yatras that often led to violence".In Video: Chandan Gupta's mother condemns firing incident at Jamia

Title: Two waste projects to be ready in 3 months: Desai
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Aurangabad: District guardian minister Subhash Desai on Thursday said that the Kanchanwadi biogas plant will be ready in February and 150-tonne waste treatment plant at Padegaon within two months.

The minister was speaking following his visit to Chikalthana and Kanchanwadi waste treatment facilities.

The state government has approved Rs 148 crore for Aurangabad ’s solid waste management (SWM) project. The project includes three 150-tonnes per day (TPD) capacity plants, a 30 TPD biogas plant, a sanitary landfill at Padegaon and closure of legacy dump at Naregaon.

One of the 150 TPD waste treatment plant became operational at Chikalthana in June last year. Currently, it is the only waste treatment plant in the city.

Desai said that when the other plants become operational, the load on the Chikalthana plant will reduce.

Incidentally, the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has missed several deadlines given to the high court previously on completion of the SWM project despite timely provision of funds by the state government.

In the Aurangabad district planning committee meeting held on Thursday, several city-related issues were discussed. Desai said that it has been decided that the electricity poles and cables that were becoming a hurdle in road widening will be removed with the allocation of funds.

On the Balasaheb Thackeray memorial at Priyadarshini Garden, the guardian minister said that the chief minister has reiterated that 100% of the trees will be conserved.

“The previous proposal of transplanting some of the trees has been cancelled. I have personally attended two meetings on the design of the memorial. The AMC has been asked to prepare and submit the DPR to the state government, so that it can be given technical and administrative approval,” Desai said.

The AMC had earlier sought Rs 65 crore for the construction of the memorial but according to the approved design, the cost has been reduced to Rs 25 crore. The reduction in civil works has led to reduction of costs, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said.

Title: Coonoor to host dog show on Feb 2
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Udhagamandalam: A one-day dog show of all breeds , organized by the Nilgiris Kennel Association (NKA), will be held in Coonoor on February 2. Over 300 dogs of various types of breeds from across the country are expected to take part in the show.

Secretary of NKA Vivekanand Lajapathie said, “For the first time, NKA has the honour of conducting the dog show of all breeds in Coonoor. Only this year, the Kennel Club of India (KCI) has offered us this opportunity”.

To be held at St Antony’s School ground in Coonoor, the show will see indigenous breeds such as Chippiparai, Rajapalayam and Kombai, among other breeds.

“Till date, about 300 entries have been received from dog owners across the country,” Vivekanand said.

Title: Sonu Shah murder: Bishnoi gang member arrested in Thailand
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Haryana Special Task Force, in a joint operation with Thailand Police, arrested a wanted gangster — Raju Basaudia — from the southeast Asian country.

After completing the legal formalities, Raju would be brought to India in a day or two, said Haryana STF DIG Satheesh Balan on Thursday.

Haryana and Chandigarh Police had announced a reward of Rs 1 lakh and Rs 50,000, respectively, on the gangster.

Raju, a resident of Basaudia village in Panipat, is a member of Lawrence Bishnoi gang.

“About 26 cases of murder, robbery and extortion are registered against Raju in different states. He was on the wanted list of Chandigarh, Haryana, Rajasthan, Delhi and Punjab. UT police had booked him for his alleged involvement in the Sonu Shah murder in September last,” said a cop.

During investigation into the murder case, Lawrence had revealed that he had given the job to kill Sonu to Raju Basaudia and Kala Rana and that they had further assigned it to contract killers Rajan Jaat, Subham Prajapati and others.

Sonu, alias Rajveer Singh, a resident of Burail in Sector 45, was shot dead and his two associates injured at his office in Burail in broad daylight on September 28.

In December 2019, UT police had announced a reward of Rs 50,000 for those providing information leading to Raju and Rajan Jaat.

Title: DMK functionaries avoiding me, says M K Alagiri
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: Former Union minister M K Alagiri on Thursday said that people, who were once his supporters, were now avoiding him and that the DMK was now full of ungrateful people.

Alagiri, who celebrated his 69th birthday during a marriage function of one of his supporters here, said, “Even MLAs and MPs from the AIADMK wished me when I met them in public places, but those who were previously my supporters avoided me,” he said.

He went on to add that nothing could change the fact that he was the elder son of Karunanidhi and said things would soon change.

Alagiri’s birthday has been a low-key affair since the demise of his father M Karunanidhi. Last year, he asked his supporters not to have any celebrations. This year, he had told them not to come to his house to wish him. However, they had put up posters marking his birthday across Madurai.

On Thursday, he participated in the marriage function of one of his most loyal supporters Manoharan, the Madurai advocates association secretary.

Alagiri came with his wife Kanthi Alagiri and his supporters used the opportunity to bring a cake to the venue and make him cut it.

Title: Hotel staffer found murdered in Kharar
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

tnn

Mohali: A 30-year-old woman was found murdered at her house in Kharar on Thursday evening.

Sukhwinder Kaur, a native of Gharaun in Mohali who worked at a hotel in Kharar, was living with her live-in partner.

Police said Sukhwinder had tied the knot with Harjinder Singh, a labourer, in 2012. The couple had three kids.

Sources in police said, “Harjinder is a resident of Solkhian in Ropar. A month ago, Sukhwinder had eloped with a man, Deepinder. Since then, the two had been living at a rented accommodation in Kharar.”

City Kharar SHO inspector Bhagwant Singh said, “Sukhwinder was strangulated with a cellphone charger. We are waiting for her family. A case will be registered after recording their statement.”

Kharar DSP Pall Singh said, “Deepinder as well as Harjinder will be questioned. The body has been kept at Kharar civil hospital.”

On January 16, a 21-year-old man had strangulated his wife to death with a cellphone charger in Panchkula.

Title: Punjab plans inter-city transportsystem over 91km around UT
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Punjab has proposed that to bring the other stakeholders (UT and Haryana) on board, an inter-ministerial group... Read More

Title: Aurangabad’s water supply project will begin in February: Subhash Desai
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The much-delayed water supply project that will bring water to the city will begin in February, said guardian minister Subhash Desai .

The Rs 1,680 crore project has been waiting for a green signal and the date of issuing its tender has been forwarded several times in the last two months.

Speaking to press during his visit to the city on Thursday, Desai said the state government had approved the water supply project that has a capacity to supply 605 million litres to the city till 2052. The project was handed over to the Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran (MJP) for its implementation.

The scheme was in limelight in December 2019 after the BJP lodged a strong protest against the Uddhav Thackeray government for putting a stay on it. However, during CM Thackeray’s meeting in the city on January 9, he instructed the MJP and the urban development department to see to it that minor hurdles in the project are cleared and that the work order is released within eight days. Despite, CM’s directive the last date to receive tender was once again forwarded.

On Thursday, when Desai was asked about the delay in the project, he said poor response to the tender required retendering but added that the new tender process is in its final phase. “I have spoken with officials of the MJP and they have told me that it will be completed in the first week of February and in the following week, the work order will be issued. We will start the work before end of February,” he said.

Responding on why the date was forwarded earlier, the minister said the tender did not get response. “The date to open the new tender is February 4. Now, the tender has received bidders. MJP is able agency as far as technical aspects of the project are concerned and we know that this project is highly important for the city,” he said.

Title: Gujarat: SRP clerk uses forged certificate to get promotion; convicted
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A senior clerk of state reserve police force (SRPF) was sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for five years on Thursday for submitting a forged certificate of passing Course on Computer Concepts (CCC) exam to get promotion as head clerk.

The convict Vasantkumar Samajpati, who lives on Ajwa Road and worked at SRPF Group-I in Lalbaug, was also fined of Rs 11,000 by the court of additional chief judicial magistrate P N Navin.

As per the details of the case, Samajpati forged the certificate with seal and stamp of Government Polytechnic for Girls from Ahmedabad sometime between November 2013 and April 2015 and submitted to get promotion as the head clerk at SRPF Group-V in Godhra. Government rules mandate passing of CCC exam.

After the promotion was granted to Samajpati, his certificate was sent to the Ahmedabad-based institution for verification.

The institute replied to the SRPF that no examination of CCC was conducted by them on the date mentioned in the certificate and no person with the name in the certificate took the exam there.

Based on the response, a departmental inquiry was conducted and then a case of forgery, using forged document as genuine and possessing counterfeit seal was registered at Navapura police station against Samajpati and one Krutal Shah from he had allegedly taken the forged certificate.

During trial, charges against Shah were not proven but the evidence against Samajpati convicted him.

While sentencing the punishment, the court stated, “It is a serious matter that the accused working in a disciplined force has used a forged certificate to get promotion … by using a forged certificate as genuine one, he has taken away rights of an eligible candidate and taken illegal benefits so the accused should get strict punishment.”

Title: UP: Two brothers crushed to death, kin claim murder
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Two brothers riding on a motorcycle were run over by a SUV near Babina in Jhansi on Thursday. However, the fa... Read More

JHANSI: Two brothers riding on a motorcycle were run over by a SUV near Babina in Jhansi on Thursday. However, the family members of the deceased claimed it to be a murder accusing their neighbour Sukhdeo Sharma with whom they had a fight over a trivial issue in morning.

SO Babina, Eshwar Singh said that they have arrested the main accused Rohit Sharma alias Chhotu, who was driving the SUV and the search has been launched for others too.

“We are in processes of lodging an FIR against seven men and three women including Chotu and Sukhdeo under section 302 and other appropriate sections on the basis of the complaint given by the brother of the two deceased. We have also seized the vehicle used by the accused”.

According to the sources, Neeraj Bhargav (32) and Vivek Bhargav (25) used to run a flour mill in their home along with their brother in village Murari, under Babina block. A few days ago they had some problem with electricity connection following which they were asked to get it changed by the electricity department. On Thursday morning the duo had gone to get it altered at the junction box to which their neighbour Sukhdeo Sharma objected claiming it as illegal.

The argument soon turned into a clash following which they decided to lodge a police complaint. In the meantime Sukhdeo alleagedly called one of his relative Rohit Sharma alias Chotu to stop the deceased from going to police.

By the time the two brothers reached village Koti Chamraua, Rohit along with others intercepted them and hit their motorbike with his SUV killing them on the spot. He then fled the scene abandoning the vehicle.

Some passers-by informed the police who took both the brothers to the nearby CHC where they were declared brought dead. The bodies have been sent for postmortem.

Title: Uttarakhand govt signs MoU with London-based institute
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Dehradun: The state government has signed a memorandum of understanding ( MoU ) with the Otermans Institute of London to provide the latest soft skills and transferrable skills training to secondary school students of Uttarakhand.

The objective of the training, officials said, is to “upskill the students for the changing job market in India and to tackle growing unemployment.”

Under the MoU, students will be trained in critical interpersonal skills, which ultimately aim at significantly reducing unemployment.

“Under the MoU with Otermans Institute of London, we will be conducting various certificate courses for state school students which will prepare them to seek jobs. As of now, the courses will be run in five schools of the Haridwar district and five schools of Pauri district,” said Mukul Kumar Sati, additional state project director of Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Theni man held with 22kg ganja
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Personnel of the Narcotics Intelligence Bureau (NIB) on Thursday arrested a 55-year-old man, who had smuggled ganja from Andhra Pradesh, to the city.

The man was identified as S Ilayaraja of Uthamapalayam in Theni district.

A team led by DSP R Vincent monitoring areas near the Coimbatore Junction Railway Station had apprehended Ilayaraja. The officers learnt that he had bought 22 kilograms of ganja from Andhra Pradesh to the city. They seized the contraband and arrested him. He was remanded in judicial custody at lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Ward 35 residents facing water woes
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Coimbatore: Residents of certain parts of Peelamedu, especially ward 35, on Thursday said they haven’t received non-potable water for more than a week and urged the city corporation to supply the same daily without any fail. Ward 35 mainly comprises Ramasamy layout and Indira Gandhi Road.

R Chandrasekhar, a resident of Ramasamy layout, said, “This is the water we use for bathing, kitchen and toilet purposes, and cleaning. Most areas receive non-potable water every day. We, however, always used to receive it only once in four days that too after meeting city corporation officials.”

Pointing out that drinking water was supplied to them only once in 10 days, he said they often run out of water after the seventh day of supply. “We also don’t receive enough drinking water.”

Another resident from Indira Gandhi Road also said they had to be extremely careful with the usage of drinking water, which was supplied once in seven or 10 days.

Another resident, R Venugopal, said, “While we don’t mind being careful with the usage of drinking water, not supplying us non-potable water is a big concern. We can’t even bathe or use toilets.”

Title: Rallies conducted in city on Mahatma’s death anniv
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Dehradun: To mark Mahatma Gandhi ’s death anniversary, several rallies were taken out in the city on Thursday (January 30).

Congress party also conducted a rally to mark the day in the Gandhi Park. The Student Federation of India (SFI) and other left-wing parties also organised a rally which commenced from Gandhi Park and ended at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel statue near Clock Tower. During SFI’s rally, anti-CAA and anti-NRC slogans were also raised by participants.

The Preamble to the Constitution was read and the participants of the rally pledged to defend the Constitution from anti-social elements. “More than 100 people participated in the rally. It is important in today’s world to remember Mahatma Gandhi’s ideology. Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens are against Constitution and against the interest of the nation. Human dignity and freedom should be our priority today,” said Himanshu Chauhan, state secretary of SFI.

Title: Man held with pistol, 10 cartridges
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vadodara: The special operations group (SOG) arrested a resident of Dahod with a country-made pistol and 10 live cartridges on Thursday.

Twenty-seven-year-old Manoj Mandal was nabbed from Mujmahuda area after SOG sleuths received a tip-off about him.

“We nabbed him from Mujmahuda circle and frisked him. He was carrying a Mauser pistol and live cartridges amounting Rs 26,000,” the police said. Mandal is a resident of Garbada taluka and studied till 10th standard.

He got married in Madhya Pradesh and has four kids. SOG sleuths said that he was arrested under the Prohibition Act in the past.

The cops are now questioning him to find out the person from whom he bought the pistol.

“He had brought this pistol from a turban wearing man in Madhya Pradesh. He told us that he got the pistol to sell it off for a good price here,” the police added.

Title: Nithyananda’s disciple found murdered in Pondy
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Puducherry: Controversial godman Nithyananda ’s disciple Vajravelu was found murdered in his car on the outskirts of the town on Wednesday. Police said his naked body was found in the rear seat at Kuruvinatham. The killers escaped with Rs 2 lakh from his possession.

Police said Vajravelu, a staunch disciple of Nithyananda, runs two bakeries named after the controversial godman at Embalam and Villianur. He visited his mother-in-law’s house at Kuruvinatham on Tuesday night. He received Rs 2 lakh from her and left for his house.

When he did not return home, his wife lodged a missing complaint the next day with police. Police found his car abandoned at a secluded spot in Kuruvinatham and his body in the vehicle.

Police suspect that a gang might have kidnapped the man in his car and strangulated him to death before fleeing with the cash he was carrying. Vajravelu was also involved in real estate business besides the bakeries. Police did not rule out business rivalry or disputes related to cash transactions as the motives for the murder.

Title: Kattakkada murder: One more held
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Kattakkada police on Thursday arrested one more person in connection with the alleged murder of Sangeeth Balan (37) of Ambalathinkala. The police identified the accused as Sanalkumar (43) of Ottasekharamangalam.

Sanalkumar is the 10th person arrested in connection with the alleged murder that took place last Friday. Sanalkumar is the brother-in-law of Uthaman, the fourth accused in the case.

Kattakkada station house officer inspector D Bijukumar said that Sanalkumar’s role in the case was pertaining to hiding the evidence. He drove away the tipper truck owned by Uthaman from the crime scene and hid it in a village called Meppala in Kanyakumari, Tamil Nadu. The police had earlier recovered the truck.

The alleged murder took place on the courtyard of Sangeeth’s residence. The gang, which turned up with an earthmover and tipper truck, started digging up soil from Sangeeth’s property. When he objected, the gang attacked him by hitting him using the earthmover, that caused his death.

Title: Egg price to be fixed daily at 12.15pm again
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NAMAKKAL: Nearly a week after it started to fix egg prices thrice a week, the National Egg Coordination Committee (NECC) on Thursday reversed to its previous method of fixing prices daily, but with a change in timing.
