According to NECC chairman Dr P Selvaraj, the decision was taken as the retail egg traders were not following the price fixed by them.

The retailers had earlier cited practical difficulties in following the price fixed by NECC. One of the issues that they highlighted was fluctuation in rate which was affecting the sales badly.

“They have formed a syndicate and is working against us. They are fixing their own price. We had warned them to change the price fixing pattern if they did not follow our rate,” the NECC chairman said.

Now, the egg price would be fixed at 12.15pm every day, against 7pm earlier. Selvaraj said the price would be fixed based on demand and supply.

While NECC has called on poultry farmers to sell eggs at the price fixed by it, the latter have found themselves in a difficult situation.

“When the egg retailers have formed a syndicate, how can we stick to NECC rate?” asked P Senthil Nathan, a poultry farmer. He also urged NECC to solve the issue amicably and help poultry industry grow.

NECC is the authority to fix the price of egg that is produced in Namakkal district .

Title: YSRC to oppose NRC, NPR in all forms: Midhun Reddy
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Amaravati: Peddireddy Midhun Reddy, YSRC MP from Rajampet, on Thursday said the party has raised its objection to the proposed National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and National Population Register ( NPR ).

He said the party has made this point clear at the all-party meeting convened by minister for parliamentary affairs Prahlad Joshi which was attended by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

He said the party has told the Centre that it would stand in support of the minorities and sought a debate on the issue in Parliament. “We requested the Prime Minister and minister for parliamentary affairs to allow a discussion on NPR and NRC in the Budget session of Parliament as the information sought in NPR is different from what was asked earlier,” said Midhun Reddy.

Speaking to media in New Delhi after the all-party meeting on Thursday, Reddy said there was a sense of unease among the minorities in the country after the Citizens Amendment Act ( CAA ) was cleared by Parliament.

Although YSRC has supported CAA, the party would oppose NPR and NRC in all forms. He said CAA was different from NPR and NRC. He said CAA was as an issue related to the granting of citizenship for the persecuted minorities in neighouring countries.

“We will oppose NRC and NPR if the Centre wants to go ahead,” said Midhun Reddy. He said that a discussion in Parliament would help the government to understand public mood on the issue. He said chief minister and party president Y S Jaganmohan Reddy has directed them to oppose anything that is against the wishes of the minorities.

Title: Private bar asked to pay consumer Rs 15k for overpricing beer bottles
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Tirunelveli: The consumer grievances redressal forum in Tirunelveli has ordered a private bar and excise officials to pay Rs 15,241 to a consumer for overpricing and deficiency in service. The order was passed by president of the forum K Devadas and members S Sivamoorthi and M Muthulakshmi recently.

Counsel A Brahma who appeared for the consumer Venkatesh said the incident took place in a private bar in Tirunelveli on October 8, 2017 when he had gone there. The consumer bought two beer bottles, for which he was charged Rs 481, against the total maximum retail price of Rs 240 for the two bottles.

Venkatesh said the MRP per bottle was Rs 120, but the bar charged Rs 240 per bottle. They also refused to return the two empty bottles when he demanded the manager and owner of the bar. The matter was taken up before the consumer forum, which passed the order in the consumer’s favour. The award of Rs 15,241 includes Rs 10,000 for causing mental agony to the consumer, Rs 5,000 towards legal expenses incurred for the case and refund of Rs 241 that was charged extra from the consumer. They directed the assistant commission of excise, Tirunelveli, and the owner and manager to pay Rs 15,000.

Stating that it has to be paid within a period of one month from the date of pronouncing the order, the forum said that on failing to do so they have to repay it with a 6% interest beyond the deadline.

Title: UP: Man found dead, FIR lodged against wife and in-laws
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

JHANSI: A man who had gone to fetch his wife at his in-law’s house in Kachwan Kalan village under Jariya police station of Rath Tehsil in Hamirpur, was found dead under mysterious circumstances on Wednesday.

Different accounts of the incident have surfaced. As per police, the deceased, during a fight with his in-laws, slipped from the staircase and died. The relatives of the deceased, on the other hand, accused that he was brutally thrashed and thrown from the terrace by his in-laws.

As per the details, the deceased identified as Suresh (37), who hailed from Atgaon village under Majguan police station, was married to Rekha for twenty years. Accompanied by his cousin, Udaiveer, he came to his in-law’s place to fetch his wife on Wednesday. According to Udaiveer, as soon as they entered the house, they had an altercation with Suresh’s in-laws which aggravated into a fight. Rekha’s father and brother thrashed Suresh and later, threw him from the terrace. Udaiveer took Suresh to a nearby CHC from where he was referred to Jhansi Medical College . He died on the way to the hospital.

An FIR was lodged on Thursday against Rekha, her father Dalchand, mother Parwati and brother Chavilal under Sections 323, 504 and 304 of IPC.

Hamirpur SP Shlok Kumar siad, “Preliminary investigations revealed that Suresh tried to run towards the terrace of the house and slipped from the staircase, which led to his death.”

“We have lodged an FIR and are investigating the matter. The body has been sent for postmortem,” he added.

Title: K’taka pans AP’s 2-lang edu system
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Objecting to AP’s decision to follow a two-language formula in its education system, Karnataka minister Suresh Kumar has requested AP to take necessary action to protect the interest of Kannadigas by continuing the minority language schools.

In a letter to AP CM Y S Jaganmohan Reddy, he said the decision to convert all schools into English medium and ‘compel’ every student to learn Telugu or Urdu ‘defies the spirit of bonhomie’ that always existed between the two states. ‘The resultant impact on the morale of Kannadigas residing in border areas of AP who did their schooling in Kannada medium these years is more than what meets the eye.

A cultural conflict is more demoralising than any other social conflicts," Kumar, minister for primary and secondary education, wrote. PTI

Title: Padma award for effort to keep art form alive
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The relentless effort of a single man for more than six decades has kept Ghoda Nacha, a unique folk art tradition of Odisha alive. Seventy-five-year-old Utsav Charan Das from Chaudwar not only revived the art form but also improved it with continuous research and value addition making it a powerful medium to create awareness on various social and relevant issues. Das was selected for Padma Shri for 2020.

“From the day I performed Ghoda Nacha for the first time on stage with my father in 1960s, the dance form has always occupied my mind. In good times or bad times, during adversity or pleasure I worked for promotion and preservation of the art form and will do that till my last breath,” said Das.

Ghoda Nacha is a folk dance form of fishermen community and as the name suggests dancers perform wearing a replica of a horse and are accompanied by singers and instrumentalists. Each troupe comprises of at least 12 performers, who dance, sing and play during the performance that continues for 30 minutes to two hours and so.

Earlier, Ghoda Nacha was performed in Chaitra (April-May) once a year. “Men used to dress as women artists and perform mostly on mythological subjects. But later I tried to give social messages through the performances on various occasions throughout the year and also made it popular by performances in All India Radio and Doordarshan,” he said.

A matriculate, Das had got a job as a stenographer in the state government but decided to quit as he wanted to make Ghoda Nacha his full-time profession.

Das, a recipient of Odisha Sangeet Natak Akademi award, writes, composes, sings and dances for the performances and has written many songs on issues like health issues, AIDS, malaria, leprosy prevention, Swachh Bharat, Beti Bachao Beti Padhao and so on.

“I have to do a lot of reading to write the songs on relevant topics and also to compose music for them. Over the years, several youngsters got encouraged to learn the art from and take it up as a career. But today’s youth dont have patience and want overnight success, so they are not getting success,” Das pointed.

Seeking government’s support for setting up an institution of fork art in Odisha, Das said, “The only way of keeping alive these dying art forms is by creating next generation of performers and documenting them for future. Government must set up an institute for transferring our rich legacy of art and culture from one generation to the next,” he said, adding, “There should be gradation of artists by the government instead of putting everyone in same category of folk artists”.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Three advised home quarantine in Vadodara
Content:
The 3 persons turned up at the SSG hospital on Thursday morning

VADODARA: Three persons turned up at the SSG Hospital (SSG) on Thursday morning to get themselves tested as they had just returned from China. They did not show any symptoms hinting at a possible coronavirus infection and were advised home quarantine.The hospital authorities were in for a surprise as three persons came in quick succession to get themselves examined. The three had visited China for official work and had landed at the Vadodara airport. From there, they went directly to SSGH for examination.SSGH sources said that the three patients’ history was recorded in detail and they were examined. Since none of them had any symptoms like the coronavirus infection, they were allowed to go with instructions regarding the precautions they have to take. The instructions included staying in home quarantine.Two of the three persons who had approached the SSG had gone for an official assignment for the company they worked for. “Due to the viral outbreak, the company asked us to return safely. We did not have any symptoms,” said one of two persons who came to the city via Mumbai.

Title: Johal’s wife refused leave to stay in UK
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

London:The wife of Jagtar Johal alias Jaggi , who is in Tihar Jail for his alleged role in targeted killings in Punjab , has been denied leave to remain in the UK .

Gurpeet Kaur, who revealed her identity for the first time in the Indian media, has been living in Scotland since April 2019. Speaking to TOI from Dumbarton, where she lives with Johal’s two brothers, their families, her father-in-law and grandparents, Kaur said: “Where am I supposed to go? My husband is in jail and my in-laws are in the UK. I have nowhere to go in India. Every girl dreams of getting married and spending the rest of her life with her husband. I should be with my in-laws.”

On January 18, the UK’s home ministry, called Home Office, turned down her application for further leave to remain in Britain. The family’s Edinburgh-based lawyer Damir Duheric, who lodged an appeal on January 22, said, “We are raising Article 8 and potentially Article 3 of the European Court of Human Rights in our appeal.” “Many factors need to be taken into account when claiming asylum, so a human rights application seemed more appropriate,” he said, adding the appeal process would take a few months.

Kaur, 30, came to the UK in April 2019 on one-month ‘outside of immigration rules’ visa, which is given in exceptional circumstances. “In India, she had applied for a two-year multiple entry tourist visa,” said Johal’s brother Gurpreet Singh, a human rights and asylum lawyer, in Scotland. “But all they gave her was this.” Before the one month visa expired, he submitted an application on her behalf on human rights grounds for leave to remain for two-and-a-half years so she could stay in Dumbarton. “She would be of no support to Johal in India as it is an eight hour journey from Punjab to Delhi by bus. She also doesn’t have anywhere to go in Punjab,” he said. “It took from May 2019 until last Saturday to get the answer.”

The grounds for refusal, he said, were that her application did not meet immigration rules and there were no exceptional circumstances. “Though they accepted this was a unique situation, and Jaggi’s situation was unique, they said sine she spent 30 years living in India, she should go back there,” he said.

“The British government is putting a post-Brexit trade deal with India above human rights,” he alleged. “Foreign secretary Dominic Raab still has not met us. The UK government is failing Jagtar and now his wife.”

Kaur was out shopping with Jaggi, 32, in Rama Mandir on November 4, 2017, just weeks after they tied the knot, when he was arrested. He maintains his innocence and claims being targeted because he was running a website in Britain translating from Punjabi to English about the events of 1984.

The chargesheet filed by the National Investigation Agency (NIA) in Punjab alleges he paid Rs 2.7 lakh to late Khalistan Liberation Force (KLF) chief Harminder Singh Mintoo in France in 2013, to execute the killing of RSS leader Ravinder Gosain in October 2017. He has also been named by NIA in Brig Jagdish Kumar Gagneja (retd) murder case.

At that time of his arrest, the newlyweds were staying with Jagtar’s paternal grandmother in a village in Jalandhar. “However, the Indian authorities were after her and she had to be on the run and stay in different places,” Gurpreet alleged. “A spouse visa could not be applied for because Jagtar would have to sign it off,” he added.

Title: Civic body seeks security to repair water pipeline
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Cap

Vadodara: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) sought police security on Thursday to conduct repair work on the main pipeline supplying water to the city from the French wells in Mahi river. The deployment was sought as villagers had stopped work on the pipeline demanding supply of water from it.

The pipeline was damaged near Sankarda village. While the civic body had diverted water from a new pipeline laid parallel to the existing one, the old pipeline was being repaired to ensure that an alternative was available.

According to VMC officials, the leakage had come to light early on Monday morning. The diversion was provided on the same day and work to repair the existing pipeline began on Tuesday. Late on Wednesday afternoon, a group of persons staying in the nearby areas came at the site and demanded that they should be given a tapping in the pipeline for drawing water.

A VMC engineer said that the demand could not be met due to policy limitations. Also, the portion of the damaged pipeline was being replaced with a steel pipeline making it difficult to provide any outlet. Villagers, however, did not relent and were aggressive. Work on the pipeline had come to a stall on Wednesday. Tempers of most people cooled only after intervention of MLA Ketan Inamdar, but some were still persistent with the demand.

As a precautionary measure, VMC sought police security for the repair of the pipeline. On Thursday, work was resumed in the presence of policemen and is expected to get over by Friday. Water suppy, however, will stay unaffected.

Title: Odisha: OSPCB fines polluting industries Rs 1 crore each
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

KENDRAPADA: The Odisha State Pollution Control Board ( OSPCB ) has slapped a Rs 2 crore fine on two industries and a penalty of Rs 25 lakh each on five hotels in Paradip for polluting the environment.

“We have fined the two industries Rs 1 crore each and the five hotels Rs 25 lakh each,” said Ramesh Kumar Ekka, regional officer of OSPCB, Paradip. They have been asked to deposit the amount within 15 days. The OSPCB had earlier issued show cause notices to them on January 24.

As per the OSPCB, the comprehensive environmental pollution index (CEPI) in Paradip at present is 60.61, bringing the town under severe pollution zone. “In 2018, the National Green Tribunal directed OSPCB to take stern action against the polluting units. It is because of this that they were fined,” Ekka stated.

Two years back, the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) identified Paradip Port as one of the most polluted areas of the state. It had declared Angul, Talcher, Ib Valley and Jharsuguda as critically polluted industrial areas under CEPI parameters.

CPCB’s analysis reveals that 43 industrial areas or clusters out of 88 in the country are critically polluted with respect to one or more environmental components. In this, Paradip ranks 44th. Five years back, the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi, identified Paradip industrial hub as one of the country’s most polluted places.

Locals welcomed OSPCB decision to fine polluting units in Paradip. “The fate of people living near Paradip and adjoining villages is at stake because of the air and water pollution caused by 15 polluting industries , including the port,” said Sarat Rout of Paradip.

Dust from coal dumped near Paradip port for distribution purpose spreads due to the wind and often settles on the ground, damaging crops, Rout alleges. He also claimed that water and air pollution are causing many people to suffer from skin diseases, kidney ailments and cancer.

Title: Government school teachers put in extra effort to reap cent per cent pass in board exams
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

ERODE: Teachers at the government higher secondary school at Alampalayam near Andhiyur are well aware that there is no gain without pain as they put in extra hours to prepare students of Classes X, XI and XII for the upcoming board examinations. And their target is to achieve 100% pass.

S Jayakumar, school headmaster, said, they were conducting special classes for a total of 153 students after the school hours at 5pm. “The classes would go on until 8pm-8.30pm. The classes are being conducted with the consent of students and their parents, who welcomed the idea wholeheartedly,” he said.

The headmaster said 80 of the 153 students were from tribal villages. “They have to travel long distances and won’t often get enough time to study. So, special classes will come handy for them. We will allow them to go to their houses only if they are accompanied by parents. Otherwise, we will arrange them stay in the school hostel.”

The students are provided dinner at the school itself and the fund for the same is being raised through the parent-teacher association. The headmaster said there were instances of teachers spending from their pocket when they were short of fund to arrange food for the students. The teachers have, meanwhile, prepared the lessons in both ‘audio’ and ‘video’ formats, allowing the students to play them on their smart phones. The teachers are also offering computer classes to the interested students.

Jayakumar said they would also conduct special tests for the students. “We will ensure that each student faces the board exam without any fear. We will cover all the subjects.”

The students said the special classes were very useful for them. “We feel free to clarify our doubts with the teachers. They are also preparing us for the National Eligibility cum Entrance Test,” a student said.

Started in 1962, higher secondary course was introduced in the school in 2001. Today, it has a strength of 300 students. The school benefits tribal villages of Alampalayam, Manalkadu, Kundhamthottam, Viralikadu, Kongadai and Burgur.

Title: O Raja assumes charge as chairman of Theni Aavin
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: A week after the Madras high court bench set aside the appointment of O Raja, brother of deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam, as chairman of the state-run Theni District Milk Producers Co-operative, he assumed charge in the post on Thursday amid fanfare in the presence of minister for milk products and dairy development K T Rajendra Bhalaji. Raja and the minister later said the appointment was made through legal and proper means.

The court had set aside Raja’s appointment, after the division bench comprising Justice T Ravindran and Justice M Duraisamy observed that the board of Theni Aavin had been constituted and chairman appointed invoking the wrong section of the Tamil Nadu Co-operatives Act.

P Ammavasi, president of the Milk Co-operative Union of Palanichettipatti in Theni district, had gone to court against the appointment of Raja as Theni Aavin chairman, as he was already the chairman of the Madurai Aavin. Ammavasi alleged the appointment was done in secrecy and that the members were not elected.

The bench had directed that the Milk Production and Dairy Development Department pass necessary and appropriate orders for the formation of an interim board, or regular board, in accordance with the Tamil Nadu Co-operatives Societies Act, 1983.

It was using this clause that managing director of the Cooperative Milk Producers Federation Dr M Vallalar passed a GO No 1120/52/2020, dated 29.01.2020 appointing O Raja and 17 members as the interim board of the Theni Aavin TID 483.

Speaking to reporters after Raja assumed charge, Rajendra Bhalaji said they had consulted legal experts and the interim board had assumed charge through legal means. He said the board members would hold office for a period of three months, and if their performance was good they might continue.

O Raja told TOI that he and his board had assumed charge through legal and proper means, and that they would soon convene a board meeting and take further decisions.

Title: JEE Main Result: NVS students maintain impressive record
Content: PUDUCHERRY: Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya (JNV), Puducherry, an autonomous institution under the Union ministry of human resources development maintained its impressive track record in cracking one of the toughest entrance examinations JEE-IIT.This year, all 31 students from JNV cleared the JEE-IIT main examination and have qualified for the advanced examination.A jubilant JNV principal P Ramachandran said 25 of the 31 students scored above 90 percentile in the exam. Aprameya Girish Hebbar of Karnataka, who joined the JNV in Class XI stood first in the school in the examination securing 99.83 percentile.“I take this opportunity to congratulate and appreciate all the students and teaching and non-teaching faculty members on their achievement. The students must now take the JEE-IIT advanced exam in the same spirit and clear it and prove themselves as the best among the best,” said Ramachandran.Last year too all the students cleared the main exam. All 23 students in 2018, 20 out of 21 in 2017 and all 23 students in 2016 cleared the JEE-IIT main exam.Ramachandran, students and teaching and non-teaching staff members attributed the achievement to the training extended by Avanti Fellows, a non-government organisation established by former Indian Institute of Technology students Akshay Saxena and Krishna Ramkumar.Ramachandran said Avanti in collaboration with five or six JNVs, including Puducherry, has been offering two-year online coaching classes for the students. “Everyday, subject experts from Avanti will offer online training from 11.30am to 12.30pm to help them crack the exam. Apart from the online training, mentors from IIT, Madras, will visit the residential school during weekends and motivate the students,” he said.Each mentor will interact with a batch of four to six students on all Saturdays and Sundays and clarify their doubts besides giving them vital tips for faring well in the exam.

Title: Kids start studies on Saraswati puja
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

BERHAMPUR: Hundreds of kids from different parts of the city started learning alphabets on the occasion of Sri Panchami or Saraswati puja at various temples in Silk City on Thursday. Saraswati is known as goddess of learning.

Telugu Bramhan Seva Sangh in collaboration with some other organisations at Prem Nagar and Gayatri temple at Tulasi Nagar organised samuhika aksharabhyas (mass learning of alphabets) to initiate the kids into studies.

Parents believe their children will be brilliant with the blessings of Saraswati if they start learning alphabets on the occasion of Sri Panchami also known as Basant Panchami.

The organisations also distributed learning materials among the kids, who came to participate in the programme.

The materials included school bags, tiffin boxes, biscuit packets, notebooks, slates, chalks, pencils, pencil sharpeners and erasers.

With chanting of slokas by pundits in a traditional manner, the kids started writing alphabets on the slates.

The Vedic Sangh distributed 1,000 pens among students, wishing them success in upcoming annual examinations.

The pens were distributed among students from Class 1 to MTech. “Most of the Class X students, who will take HSC examination this time, got the pens,” said president of Sangh BH Narayan Murty.

“We distributed the learning materials among the kids to encourage them start studying,” said S Ram Kumar , president of Telugu Bramhan Seva Sangh. He said the organisation has been organising the programme for last some years to keep a tradition alive.

“We got an opportunity to induct our children into studies on the occasion of Sri Panchami. We hope our children will excel in studies as they started learning with the blessings of Maa Saraswati ,” said A Radhika, mother of one of the kids.

Title: Kotia now on speed dial as government sets up mobile tower
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The mobile tower at Kotia in Koraput's Pottangi block

KORAPUT: In an attempt to strengthen infrastructure at Kotia panchayat under Pottangi block — an area to which both Odisha and Andhra Pradesh claim credit — the state government on Thursday commissioned a BSNL mobile tower.

“Now the area is covered under mobile connectivity which will facilitate quicker flow of information and help in expediting development activities,” Koraput district collector Madhusudan Mishra said.

Kotia residents erupted in joy after getting mobile connectivity, which was a long-standing demand of people in the region. “We are happy to have got mobile connectivity. Now we can call the ambulance, police and district officials at the time of need. We can also talk to our friends and relatives,” said Arjun Gamel, a Kotia resident.

Officials said that special attention is being given towards strengthening infrastructure at Kotia and development projects worth over Rs 55 crore and involving roads, bridge, hospital, education complex are at various stages of completion in the panchayat.

“We have set March 31 as the deadline for the completion of the projects and once they are done, they will boost infrastructure facilities at Kotia,” the collector added.

Project director, district rural development agencies, Prabir Kumar Nayak said apart from the 10-bed hospital, which will cater to the healthcare needs of around 8,000 residents of the panchayat, the state government is constructing a 300-seater hostel for tribal boys and a 200-seater hostel for tribal girls, an education complex, cluster houses for residents under Biju Pucca Ghar Yojana, community centres in some villages and numerous roads in the interiors to resolve connectivity problems of residents to the panchayat headquarters and to the block and district headquarters.

“Furthermore, the state government has identified at least three acres of land for the construction of a police station at Kotia,” Nayak added.

Both the Odisha and Andhra Pradesh governments are engaged in a five-decade-long tug-of-war over the ownership of 21 of the 28 villages in Kotia panchayat. The case is sub-judice in Supreme Court since 1968.

It may be recalled that peeved with frequent intrusions from Andhra officials and various welfare programmes being offered by the neighbouring government to Kotia, the Odisha government had finalised a special package worth Rs 150 crore for the development of the place in April 2018.

Title: Three corporation-owned shops remain unoccupied for the past four years
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The shops were constructed at a cost of Rs 60 lakh

COIMBATORE: Three shops constructed by the city corporation four-and-a-half years ago at Peelamedu are yet to open shutters to the public.

The shops, constructed at a cost of Rs 60 lakh, at the point where VK Road and Pioneer Mill Road meet behind PSG College of Technology , have never been occupied or used even for a short period, say residents and local activists.

“It has been more than four years since the shops were constructed. Initially, corporation officials told us that they will set up an Amma Unavagam there,” said activist and MDMK member SP Velliangiri. “After some months, they said the complex will house a ration shop and a public library apart from the Amma canteen. A year later, they said they will rent it out to private parties. But none of that has happened.”

Patrons of the nearby Tasmac outlet have made the frontage of the shops their hub, said Velliangiri. “They find it a convenient place to have liquor. Political parties stick their posters on the walls of the shops.”

The corporation should rent out the shops to small businesses that will benefit the community, said R Prema Rani, a resident. “The place is ideal to set up a petty shop, grocery shop or a stationary shop. The corporation can also earn a revenue. The civic body spent Rs 60 lakh to construct the shops, only to leave them idle. But corporation officials say they lack funds for new roads and drainage pipelines,” she said.

Title: Cop caught red-handed while taking bribe
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: DVAC sleuths arrested the inspector of Parthibanur police station for accepting a bribe of Rs 5,000 from a man to discharge his grandson from a case.

Police said Bhoominathan of Idayayoor Melakudiyiruppu near Parthibanur in Ramanathapuram district was working abroad.

His wife Hemalatha had lodged a complaint against Bhoominathan, his mother and brother-in-law Balakrishnan alleging harassment. Parthibanur police inspector A Rajarajan registered a case against ten people including Balakrishnan in the case.

Later, inspector Rajarajan bargained with Balakrishnan’s grandfather Thangavelu and asked him to give him Rs 20,000 to discharge Balakrishnan from the case.

The first installment of Rs 15,000 was handed over to the inspector. But, as he continued to demand the remaining Rs 5,000, Thangavelu lodged a complaint with Ramanathapuram DVAC.

The DVAC officials, including DSP Unnikrishnan and inspector Peter, who kept a watch on Rajarajan, arrested him when he was receiving Rs 5,000 from Thangavelu at the police station.

Title: New night train starts service between Coimbatore and Mettupalayam stations
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The eight-coach train will leave Mettupalayam at 7pm and reach Coimbatore Junction at 7.50pm. It will again le... Read More

COIMBATORE: Evening college students and workers shuttling between Coimbatore and Mettupalayam have a reason to rejoice with the Southern Railway introducing a new night train between the towns.

The new eight-coach train will leave Mettupalayam at 7pm and reach Coimbatore Junction at 7.50pm. It will stop at Karamadai at 7.09pm, Periyanaickenpalayam at 7.17pm, Thudiyalur at 7.24pm and Coimbatore North Junction at 7.29pm. It will again leave Coimbatore Junction at 8.25pm and reach Mettupalayam at 9.15pm, with stops at Coimbatore North at 8.31pm, Thudiyalur at 8.36pm, Periyanaickenpalayam at 8.41pm and Karamadai at 8.52pm.

The new service is in addition to the four MEMU train services between Coimbatore and Mettupalayam — which leave at 9.30am, 11.50pm, 3.25pm and 5.55pm — and the Nilgiris Express.

Railway authorities said that the additional service will also help to handle the extra rush of tourists travelling to and from the NMR destinations.

The last train to Mettupalayam used to depart from Coimbatore at 5.55pm, to the chagrin of regular commuters, who finish work only around 5.30pm.

Haritha R, who works in a clothing store at Race Course, said her shift gets over only at 7.30pm, which makes it impossible for her to get a train to Mettupalayam. “So, I end up taking bus, which are crowded. Also, I have to take a town bus from Race Course to the Mettupalayam New Bus Stand,” she said. “Buses are also a lot more expensive with a ticket costing Rs 20.”

Title: Saamna backs Centre on JNU student Imam, says chop off his hands
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Mumbai: Saamna , the Shiv Sena mouthpiece, on Thursday tore into anti-citizenship law protester Sharjeel Imam ’s “inflammatory and anti-national” statement and supported the government’s crackdown on him, raising fears of discord in the government it runs along with NCP and Congress.

Saamna said Imam’s hands should be chopped off and hung up on the 22km highway — the ‘chicken’s neck’—that links the NE with the rest of India.

JNU student Imam was arrested on Tuesday for sedition and other charges.

Calling on the Centre to crush the “pest” of separatism, it wondered if there was a well-planned plot to “poison” the minds of students. “Imam is an IIT-Mumbai alumni ... This is a conspiracy to plant separatism (in the mind of the educated people) and take them on the path of extremism,” said the Saamna editorial. “The conspiracy is to perpetuate Hindu-Muslim disharmony and a prolonged civil war... Urban Naxalism is very much on. Add to this, the extremism of intellectuals which is being fanned by politicians,” it added.

This stand can bring Sena into direct conflict with Congress, which has been pro-active in the anti-CAA, -NRC protests, and NCP, which claims the Elgar Parishad case was foisted on intellectuals and activists and wants it quashed.

Urging the Centre not to indulge in a political game, Saamna endorsed Amit Shah’s statement that Imam’s ‘chicken neck’ remark was more dangerous than Kanhaiyya Kumar’s ‘freedom’ utterances and that Imam’s next seven generations will not succeed in cutting the Northeast from the country.

Sharpening the Sena versus BJP narrative, the Union home ministry had transferred the Elgar Parishad probe to the National Investigation Agency (NIA) right after Sharad Pawar’s letter to CM Uddhav Thackeray seeking an SIT on the case. Nine suspects, dubbed ‘urban Naxals’ were detained by Pune police for their alleged links with the banned CPI (Maoist).

“While NCP has thrown its weight behind the intellectuals, Saamna has stated the intellectual class, misled by politicians, is taking to anti-national activities. This could trigger tension in the MVA government,” said a former bureaucrat.

The editorial also reflects Sena’s anxiety over an MNS morcha planned on February 9 to demand immediate eviction of illegal Bangladeshis from Mumbai. There have been reports of MNS and BJP cosying up, and Sena strategists are worried that MNS backed by BJP may dent it with an aggressive anti-Bangladeshi stance. After recent talks between Raj Thackeray and former CM Devendra Fadnavis, BJP’s Ashish Shelar called on Raj on Wednesday.

Title: MBBS student studying in China suspected to be infected with coronavirus, admitted in AIIMS Rishikesh
Content: Dehradun: A girl from the city, pursuing MBBS in China’s Wuhan, has been admitted to AIIMS, Rishikesh, on suspicion of being infected with coronavirus . The girl, who returned from China on January 16, was taken to Doon Hospital on Wednesday night with symptoms of cough, cold and fever.On Thursday, parents of the woman brought her to AIIMS, Rishikesh. Her blood samples have been sent to Pune’s National Virology Institute for further diagnosis. AIIMS officials confirmed that the girl is showing symptoms which are similar to those of coronavirus patients.Sources told TOI that the girl was earlier taken to clinics in Dehradun and her parents brought her to AIIMS Rishikesh after her condition worsened. The girl has been complaining of severe cough, cold, sore throat and fever.While speaking to mediapersons, Dehradun’s chief medical officer Dr Meenakshi Joshi said, "It is not a confirmed case of coronavirus. We received information of her admission from AIIMS administration and a team was sent to collect samples of the patient."

Title: Steep rise in helmet, seatbelt violation cases in Madurai dist
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: Helmet and seatbelt violations witnessed a massive jump in 2019 with the Madurai district police registering about 2.33 lakh cases and a total Rs 2.33 crore collected as fine from the offenders. The violations is 153% higher when compared to 2018

Two-wheeler riders coughed up Rs 1.62 crore as fine for not wearing helmet, with the rural police registering 1,62,759 helmet rule violation cases, while Rs 71 lakh was collected as fine from nearly 71,000 people who were booked for not wearing seat belt in 2019. In 2018, only 92,267 cases were registered for not wearing helmet and seat belt. Officials said that the registration of more number of helmet rule violation cases played a vital role in bringing down the road fatalities considerably in 2019. While 330 road deaths were recorded in 2018, it came down to 282 in 2019, a decrease by 14.5%.

District superintendent of police N Manivannan said that most deaths in two-wheeler accidents are caused because of head injuries. Stringent enforcement of the helmet rule helped them bring the death rate last year. While police will continue to book helmet rule violators, he urged the commuters to wear helmets.

Usilampatti police range recorded the highest number of 39,000 helmet cases among six ranges in the district. It was followed by Samayanallur with around 34,000, Thirumangalam with 30,500, Peraiyur and Oomachikulam with around 21,000 each. Melur range recorded the least number with 16,600 cases.

A police officer from the district police unit said that regular checks are being carried out in all important roads, junctions and towns. “Bikers should wear helmet irrespective of distance, since no one can predict accidents. Accidents can also take place in village roads and one should be prepared,” he said. The district police are planning to bring down the road fatalities in 2020 further by conducting more sensitization programmes. In 2019, about 5,000 sensitization programmes were carried out and this year they are planning to to double it.

Title: Barodian’s ‘cancer care’ now in 6 cities
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The cancer support circle will be launched on February 4

VADODARA: He dresses up as a clown and visits patients and children at hospitals to amuse and encourage those suffering from cancer. Now, this Bengaluru-based Barodian has joined hands with an organization to start cancer support groups in six cities of the country.

The cancer support circles will be launched on February 4 that marks World Cancer Day . Harish Bhuvan, who had embarked on the journey of spreading smiles a couple of years back, has joined hands with Onco.com, country’s first internet aggregator for cancer care.

“We will be conducting cancer support groups throughout the week covering six different cities on six different dates,” said Bhuvan, who had earlier launched ‘Compassionate clowns’ that conducts clowning events at hospitals. The cancer support groups will be launched at Mumbai, Hyderabad, Kolkata, Delhi, Ahmedabad and Bengaluru between February 3 and 8.

This year, world cancer day is themed on ‘I Am and I Will’ campaign. “The campaign is aimed at promoting dialogues around cancer. What a better way to do that than starting cancer support groups, a concept popular in developed countries,” said 30-year-old Bhuvan, adding that the cancer support groups are named ‘Talk Your Heart Out’.

Bhuvan, who has completed his bachelor of arts degree in psychology from Christ University , has so far done 12 cancer support circles including 11 in Bengaluru and one in New Delhi touching around 100 individuals.

After graduating, Bhuvan had taken up a job as an educational researcher at Bengaluru but left it to continue clowning.

“Cancer patients receive support from their families and friends. But what about the caregivers, their mental health. With every circle, we realize that everybody has a story to share,” said Bhuvan, who has created a team of hundreds of volunteers who regularly visit hospitals, care centres and cancer treatment centres to spread happiness.

Title: Disqualify rebel MLA, says govt whip
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Puducherry: A day after rebel Congress MLA N Dhanavelu, who was suspended from the party, submitted a memorandum to lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi levelling corruption charges against chief minister V Narayanasamy and his cabinet colleagues, government whip R K R Anantharaman on Thursday urged V P Sivakolundhu, speaker of the legislative assembly, to disqualify Dhanavelu on charges of attempting to topple the Congress government in the Union territory.

Anantharaman, accompanied by Congress MLAs, called on the speaker at his chambers in the assembly and submitted a petition in this regard. Later speaking to the media, Anantharaman said as the government whip he urged the speaker to disqualify Dhanavelu under the provisions of the anti-defection act as the rebel MLA has been attempting to topple the Congress government with the help of opposition members.

“We have also furnished enough material evidence against the MLA on his efforts to topple the Congress government,” Anantharaman said.

He pointed out that the MLA led a procession against the Congress government and called on Bedi on Wednesday and submitted a memorandum levelling corruption charges against the Congress dispensation in Puducherry and urged her to ‘put an end to this rule’.

A Namassivayam, Puducherry Pradesh Congress Committee (PPCC) president, told reporters that Dhanavelu, despite being elected on a Congress ticket, continued to resort to anti-party activities. He said the PPCC suspended him after consulting the high command and issued him a show-cause notice.

“He (Dhanavelu) submitted his reply to the notice. But, he continued to target the party publicly. He joined hands with the opposition parties and called on the lieutenant governor and requested her to remove the government, which invites stern action under Anti-Defection Act,” Namassivayam said.

The PPCC president maintained that there is no threat to the government.

“There is no threat to the government. Congress-DMK alliance is very strong and the Congress government will complete its five-year term,” he said.

Brushing aside the corruption charges raised by the rebel MLA against the chief minister and his cabinet colleagues, Namassivayam said not only the CM but every elected member will resign if the charges are proved.

Dhanavelu, in a memorandum submitted to Bedi, requested her to constitute an inquiry commission to probe the corruption charges he levelled against the chief minister and other cabinet ministers. He also sought an inquiry in the registration department and Puducherry planning authority to probe specific real estate and land dealings.

Title: Minor rejig in cabinet portfolios
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Amaravati: To bring all agriculture related subjects under one-roof, chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy has brought marketing and food processing departments under the agriculture ministry.

As part of this, agriculture minister Kurasala Kannababu has been given additional charge of agriculture marketing and food processing department.

Earlier, Mopidevi Venkata Ramana was handling agriculture marketing and industries minister Mekapati Gautham Reddy was overseeing food processing.

While Mopidevi Venkata Ramana will continue to look after animal husbandry and fisheries departments, Gautham Reddy will be in-charge of industries, IT and skill development.

Title: ‘Govt using CAA to divide people on basis of religion’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Saligao: To mark Martyrs’ Day, the Goa Alliance Against CAA-NRC-NPR on Thursday recited the preamble of the Constitution in different languages at a gathering at Hutatma Chowk, Mapusa.

Former journalist Pradip Padgaonkar said, “Our government does not know what humanity is. They (BJP-led central government) are dividing us on basis of religion and caste. CAA is brought to create their vote bank..” Another member of the alliance, Savio Braganza asked why only three of India’s many neighbouring countries were mentioned in the act. TNN

Title: Nithyananda’s disciple found murdered in Puducherry
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: Controversial godman Nithyananda ’s disciple Vajravelu was found murdered in his car on the outskirts of the town on Wednesday. Police said his naked body was found in the rear seat at Kuruvinatham. The killers escaped with Rs 2 lakh from his possession.

Police said Vajravelu, a staunch disciple of Nithyananda, runs two bakeries named after the controversial godman at Embalam and Villianur. He visited his mother-in-law’s house at Kuruvinatham on Tuesday night. He received Rs 2 lakh from her and left for his house.

When he did not return home, his wife lodged a missing complaint the next day with police. Police found his car abandoned at a secluded spot in Kuruvinatham and his body in the vehicle.

Police suspect that a gang might have kidnapped the man in his car and strangulated him to death before fleeing with the cash he was carrying. Vajravelu was also involved in real estate business besides the bakeries. Police did not rule out business rivalry or disputes related to cash transactions as the motives for the murder.

Title: Energy Conclave 2020 from Feb 15
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The Chamber of Marathwada Industries and Agriculture (CMIA)’s energy cell has organised Energy Conclave 2020 on ‘energy storage devices’ on February 15.

Eminent speakers and experts from the field will make presentations and interact with participants from industries and academia at the session.

During this conclave, educational institutions will get an opportunity to make paper presentations on energy storage technology, fuel cells, applications of energy storage devices in grid, electric vehicles, electronics, robotics, medical, gravity storage, ultra capacitors & their application.

Bengalis perform Saraswati Puja

The Bengali community of Aurangabad performed Saraswati Puja with religious fervour on Wednesday. The programme began at 8.30 am with puja followed by mahaprasad in the afternoon and evening.

In the evening, a cultural programme themed on the poetic works of Rabindranath Tagore, Kazi Nazrul Islam and Sukanta Bhattacharya was organised. Children performed traditional dance on the occasion. About 300 people from Bengali and other communities participated in the programme.

Title: CAA will affect overseas Goans, says Churchill
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Margao: Voicing his opposition to CAA, Benaulim MLA Churchill Alemao Thursday said that the “unconstitutional” Act was a prelude to NRC which he claimed would spell trouble to 70 percent of overseas Goans.

Stating that his support to the BJP government was only because of chief minister Pramod Sawant as he hails from the “weaker section of society”, Alemao said it has always been issue-based.

Explaining the rationale behind his anti-CAA stance, Alemao said, “As they say, give them an inch and they will take a mile. If CAA is allowed to happen, NRC will definitely follow.”

Elaborating on his concerns, Alemao, while speaking to reporters on the sidelines of an event at Ravindra Bhavan here, said, “Today there's Brexit happening. Goans there don't know what to do. If they go to Portugal, they will have no jobs. So then they will come to Goa. With no (citizenship) registration, they will lose everything. Do we want this to happen?” TNN

Title: Russian investment in Auric to generate 2,000 jobs
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Aurangabad: State industry minister Subhash Desai on Thursday informed that the investment of Rs 5,000 crore to be made by Russian firm Novolipstek Steel (NLMK) in Aurangabad Industrial City ( Auric ) — a greenfield industrial smart city in Shendra — will generate around 2,000 jobs.

Desai was in the city on Thursday to attend a district planning committee meeting. While talking to reporters about investments in Auric, Desai said he had a meeting with NLMK officials on Wednesday.

“They (NLMK) manufacture special steel for electrical transformers. Currently, there are transformer-making factories in various states but import the steel required for it. NLMK will create good quality steel and produce transformers from it,” he said.

The industry minister added that when NLMK starts its operations in Auric, 20 transformer manufacturing factories will start functioning around it creating a transformer manufacturing cluster. “The NLMK has been allotted a plot in Auric for setting up the plant,” he said.

Shinde along with deputy chief minister and minister of finance and planning Ajit Pawar and public health minister Rajesh Tope visited the Auric hall in Shendra on Thursday morning.

During his visit, Pawar said that stress should be made on producing skilled workforce for the upcoming companies so that Auric can see employment generation at a large scale.

Aurangabad Industrial City (AURIC) — a Smart and Integrated Industrial City (SIIC) that is first of its kind and the most advanced township in the country — has been built as part of Delhi Mumbai Industrial Corridor (DMIC).

Its development and implementation is being undertaken by Aurangabad Industrial Township Ltd (AITL), a special purpose vehicle between Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation and DMIC.

Title: Driver arrested for smuggling IMFL from Puducherry
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Villupuram: In a huge haul, the Prohibition Enforcement Wing (PEW) of Kotakkupam seized about 2 ,000 bottles of Puducherry-manufactured Indian Made Foreign Liquor ( IMFL ) that was to be smuggled to Kancheepuram in a van at the Kotakuppam check post in Villupuram district on Thursday morning.

A police officer said based on a tip-off received by Villupuram SP S Jayakumar that a consignment of Puducherry liquor was being smuggled through East Coast Road, police personnel led by Kotakuppam PEW inspector Vishnu Priya, while conducting a surprise vehicular check around 6am, stopped a Tempo Traveller heading towards Chennai.

Preliminary investigation by police revealed that the driver of the vehicle was V Mohan, 29, of Orikai in Kancheepuram district. During further investigation it was found that the accused was smuggling about 2,000 (180 ml) bottles concealed in 40 cartons to Kancheepuram district.

Speaking to TOI, Vishnu Priya said, “Following our preliminary investigation, the accused has been booked under Section 4(1-aaa) and 4(1-A) of the Tamil Nadu Prohibition Act. We are conducting investigation to identify the kingpin of the racket.”

Title: WII starts course prepare youths for jobs in environment sector
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

WII

Dehradun: With an aim to impart skills for job in environment conservation, the Wildlife Institute of India ( WII ) announced initiation of a special training for people interested in receiving education related to wildlife.

A meeting was held at WII on Thursday wherein people from all walks of life from across the country participated to learn the skills required for bird identification, especially migratory birds of India. The programme is being conducted under the aegis of the Union environment ministry.

Over 500 people showed keen interest to participate in the “Green Skill Development Programme” (GSDP) course which started on Thursday and will continue for a fortnight at WII.

The programme witnessed participation from Ladakh, Assam, West Bengal, Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, Mizoram, and Maharashtra. These participants will be taught “Bird Identification” and “Basic Ornithology”, so that they can become self-dependent and create employment opportunities.

"In our eco-system, everything is inter-dependent and wildlife is directly linked to nature. Hence, we are trying to look at each possible segment through which we can provide knowledge and increase opportunities of jobs for the country’s youth," said Dhananjai Mohan, WII director.

The institute has commenced the project especially for the people residing in and around protected areas so they can contribute to forest and wildlife conservation.

“The Environment Information System (ENVIS) Centre at Wildlife Institute of India has taken the initiative to start an academic course in nature interpretation for rural youth in protected areas to enable them to become nature guides. These people are emotionally connected to their areas and hence, we prefer to educate them and impart skills among them to create a win-win situation,” said K Sivakumar, senior scientist and ENVIS Coordinator at WII. Prior to this programme, three more courses have been held in different places of India under ENVIS.

The first such course was started in Manas Tiger Reserve, Assam, followed by a course on “Nature Conservation and Livelihood: River Based Ganga Prahari” in Sarnath, Uttar Pradesh and a Certificate Course in “Nature Interpretation for Large Zoos and Safari Parks: Zoo Guide Training Programme” in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

“India is the second most populated country in the world and there exists a demand-supply gap of skill sets (both cognitive and practical) at various levels in environment/forest sector in India.

“Green skills are crucial for cleaner and greener production and service patterns. It prepares people for green jobs that contribute to preserving and restoring environment while simultaneously improving social equity and enhancing quality of life,” added Sivakumar.

Title: ED raids top Mumbai builder in DHFL case
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The Enforcement Directorate (ED) on Thursday raided the residences and offices of builder Sudhakar Shetty in connection with a money laundering case involving the late drug smuggler Iqbal Memon, alias Mirchi, and the promoters of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation Ltd ( DHFL ).

The raid continued till late in the night.

Shetty, who once owned the infamous Deepa dance bar at Vile Parle (West), entered the construction business over a decade ago under the name Sahana Group and is presently developing several big-ticket projects in the city in partnership with prominent builders. He owns a helicopter, runs a TV news channel and is close to several senior politicians.

Despite several attempts by TOI, Shetty remained unavailable for comment.

The Enforcement Directorate suspects that Shetty was a conduit for DHFL’s money.

Sources said that during the money laundering investigation, the ED learnt that DHFL promoters Kapil Wadhawan and his brother Dheeraj, aka Baba Diwan, had bought three buildings from Mirchi in 2010 through their front company Sunblink for Rs 111 crore. Baba paid Rs 154 crore more to Mirchi, abroad, through his company in Dubai. The ED suspects that the Wadhawans, along with others, siphoned off Rs 12,773 crore from DHFL with the help of 79 shadowy entities and 1 lakh fictitious accounts through dubious transactions and used a part of the sum to clear the payment due to Mirchi.

The ED claimed to have found a financial link between the companies they are probing in the Mirchi-DHFL case and Shetty. During the raid on Shetty’s premises, the ED collected several documents and digital records of his companies and their financial transactions.

On Monday, the ED arrested Kapil Wadhawan, who told officials he was unaware about the questionable transactions. One of his company’s officials, during questioning, had told the ED that all dubious transactions happened at Wadhawan’s instance. The ED had called a former director of DHFL to confront Wadhawan on Thursday, but this couldn’t materialize as Wadhawan complained that he was unwell. He was taken to JJ Hospital and admitted there after he was examined by his personal physician (H1N1 is suspected).

Title: Teri seeks to team up with state govt
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vijayawada: Energy institute TERI , in association with Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES) and Japan government , has offered to provide energy-efficient technology to AP under Japan-India technology matchmaking platform (JITMAP).

TERI director general Ajay Mathur said on Wednesday that developing states like AP would immensely benefit through energy efficiency technologies in the long run. “We would be happy to provide clean, energy-efficient solutions to AP and would like to partner with the state government,” he said.

Mathur observed that adoption of Japanese technology would help reduce intensity of greenhouse gas emissions in the industrial sector, help the energy intensive small and medium enterprises (SME) sector, besides bridging the gap between power supply and demand. Adoption of energy efficient technology can reduce greenhouse gas emission in the industrial sector by up to 33-35% by 2030, he added. “We will request IGES to select a cluster in AP for a deep-dive intervention. We would be happy if the APSECM (AP State Energy Conservation Mission) and energy department agree to partner us in the initiative and provide logistical support to the project,” Mathur said.

Title: Goa: Anti-CAA protesters vow to march to Assembly on February 3
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The speakers urged MLAs Churchill Alemao and Vijai Sardesai to raise the issue in the assembly.

MARGAO: Noted environmental activists Claude Alvares and Ramesh Gawas on Thursday lent their voices to castigate the central government at an anti-CAA protest meeting held at Margao, even as the large number of people gathered were called on to join a protest march to the state legislative assembly on February 3 , the first day of the Assembly session.

“...And if needed we won’t allow the assembly sesison to be held,” said activist Rama Kankonkar . He urged the two MLAs present at the meeting – Churchill Alemao and Vijai Sardesai – not to attend the Assembly and to join the protesters instead. Another speaker, Iftikar Shaikh urged the MLAs to raise the issue in the Assembly. Chairperson of Margao Municipal Council Pooja Naik was also present at the meeting.

While Gawas said that the CAA/NRC/NPR was part of the larger goal of “Hindu Rashtra” as propounded by RSS second sarsanghchalak M S Golwalkar, Alvares warned that deportation of Muslims on grounds of failure to produce citizenship documents would happen “only over our dead bodies.”

“The concept of making Bharat a Hindu Rashtra has been an integral part of RSS ideology since 1925. As regards Muslims, Golwalkar wrote in his book ‘Vichar Dhan’ that if Muslims wished to stay in India, they should do so as secondary citizens. The government’s moves are in furtherance of the same ideology,” Gawas said.

Alvares accused prime minister Narendra Modi of “assaulting” the Constitution of India by bringing in the CAA. “An amendment to the Citizenship Act has for the first time excluded Muslims from the Constitution. And therefore more than 150 writ petitions have been filed in the court on the grounds that it is violating the Constitution of India,” Alvares said, adding that the CAA was also against the secular credentials of the nation.

Fr Savio Fernandes of the Council for Social Justice and Peace, the co-organiser of the meeting, accused the government of trying to drive a wedge into society by launching an attack on the Constitution.

Title: Industries in Maharashtra told to use 40% recycled sewage water
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Subhash Desai visit waste processing unit in Aurangabad on Thursday

AURANGABAD: During his visit to Kanchanwadi sewage treatment plant, district guardian minister Subhash Desai on Thursday said that it is mandatory for industries to use 40% recycled sewage water of their total usage.

Desai, who is also the industries minister, reviewed the operations of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s Sewage Treatment Plant (STP) at Kanchanwadi.

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey, who was also present at the site, explained the features of the plant to the minister. Pandey said that with the capacity to treat 161 million litres of sewage per day, the sewage treatment plant at Kanchanwadi is the largest facility in the state barring the one coming up at Navi Mumbai.

The plant was built at Aurangabad under Urban Infrastructure Development Scheme for Small and Medium Towns (UIDSSMT) of the Government of India.

Currently, the plant is treating 60 million litres of sewage generated by the city on a daily basis. The sewage is brought to the plant via the underground drainage system, Pandey told Desai. He said that post treatment, the water is released into the Kham river.

An official of Khillari Infrastructure, the agency operating the plant, showed a sample of the treated sewage to Desai. The water collected in a transparent beaker visibly appeared clean.

Desai asked the official if the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) made use of the treated water. Responding to Desai, Pandey said that he has instructed all the major construction projects in the city to strictly use recycled water and has included it as a criterion to secure a completion certificate.

Desai announced that the industries around the state will be provided 40% less water from the dams and instead they will have to suffice the said amount of their water needs with the water treated at STPs. “This measure will help to address the water crisis in the state,” Desai said.

Title: Key dates for AMC election announced
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Aurangabad: The state election commission on Thursday announced the dates to organise a draw for selecting wards based on different criteria and publish the final draft of ward formation. The dates are significant to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) elections due to be held in the coming months.

In a circular issued by the state election commission secretary Kiran Kurundkar on Thursday, it has been stated that the draw for selecting wards for backward classes and women wards will be held on February 3. A public notice announcing the venue of the draw will be published on January 31.

The draw will decide the candidates and the wards from which they will contest. Notably, all existing ward categories will be changed. Following the draw and fixing of category of wards, the draft ward formation plan will be published as a gazette on February 4.

The objections or suggestions on the ward formation can be lodged with the election department of the municipal corporation till February 11. The AMC election department will submit the filed objections to the three-member committee comprising divisional commissioner, district collector and the municipal commissioner. After the committee’s approval, the plan will be sent to the state election commission by February 12.

Overruling its previous decision, the state election commission had decided to hold the civic body election as per the single-ward pattern earlier this month. Subsequently, a new ward formation plan was prepared by the election department of the AMC. Following the approval of the plan by the three-member committee, it was sent to the state election commission.

On January 22, a TOI report stated that the process of finalising the draft ward formation plan is in its final stage. A team of AMC officials led by deputy municipal commissioner Kamlakar Phad had camped in Mumbai for the process.

Meanwhile, all eyes of candidates and parties are on the draw as the category of the ward will play a decisive role in the election strategy.

Title: Two teens among three arrested for snatching cellphone
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vellore: Two teenagers were among three people arrested on Thursday for snatching a mobile phone from a bank employee at Green Circle in Vellore on Tuesday.

After two days of investigation, police arrested all the three accused tracing their two-wheeler registration number.

A senior police officer identified the accused as M Udhaya, 19, and S Gopi, 19, of Konavattam, and L John Kennedy, 24, of Mullipalayam in Vellore.

The incident took place around 9.30pm on Tuesday when D Udhaya Sarathi, 38, of Vasanthapuram, a deputy manager in HDFC Bank Vaniyambadi branch, was proceeding to catch a share auto while speaking on his cellphone. The three accused, who were following Udhaya Sarathi on their two-wheeler, snatched his cellphone and fled.

Based on a complaint by Udhaya Sarathi at the Vellore North police station, police officers who were searching for the accused, traced the vehicle registration number and arrested them on Thursday.

Speaking to TOI, K Narayanan, sub-inspector of the North police station and investigation officer of the case, said that during investigation it was found that the three were involved in a series of robbery and mobile snatching incidents and several cases were pending against them at the Thurinjapuram and Vellore North police stations.”

The arrested accused were been booked under Section 379 (Punishment for theft) and remanded in the Vellore central prison,” Narayanan said.

Title: Divisional-level commissioner fined for plastic use
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Aurangabad: Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey on Thursday slapped a fine of Rs 5,000 on deputy commissioner of planning Ravindra Jagtap for using plastic gift wrapper for presenting a book to deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar.

Pawar, who is also the minister of planning in the state government, was in the city to chair the divisional-level meetings of the district planning committees. This was Pawar’s first visit to the city after the government formation. Subsequently, a large number of well wishers, including officials and political personalities, felicitated him with bouquets and gifts.

Divisional commissioner Sunil Kendrekar had asked that a book be presented to Pawar. Jagtap, who is the deputy commissioner (planning) at the divisional commissionerate, wrapped the book in a plastic wrapper. Pandey, who was present there, noticed the cover and asked his officials to fine Jagtap for using a plastic wrapper, which is a banned material as per the state government’s plastic ban notification. Jagtap had to pay a fine of Rs 5,000.

Pandey had previously fined his own subordinate at Aurangabad Municipal Corporation, a corporator and a person who came to greet the chief minister for plastic use.

Title: Kids at protest: FIR against Church body
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Panaji: Goa police has filed a first information report (FIR) against a Church body—Council for Social Justice and Peace (CSJP) and others under the Goa Children’s Act and Juvenile Justice Act, for participation of children at the anti-CAA/NRC/NPR meeting held at Lohia Maidan, Margao, last week

“The above noted organisation misused children for holding the meeting in protest against the CAA, NRC/NPR and exposed the children to political ideology and aggressive language, thereby subjecting them to psychological abuse and not providing a safe environment,” women’s police station PI Sudiksha Naik said in the FIR.

Stop Child Abuse Now (SCAN) coordinator Emidio Pinho had written to the women’s police station, Panaji, with photographs of children at the meeting, asking that action be taken against CSJP and National Confederation of Human Right Organisation, Goa unit, for including children in the anti-CAA meeting. Pinho in his complaint had said that having impressionable children at such events places them in vulnerable situations.

Title: Gandhi remembered on ‘Martyrs’ Day’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: Hundreds gathered to pay tribute to Mahatma Gandhi’s statue at the Gandhi museum on his 72nd death anniversary on Thursday.

Gandhi Museum secretary KM Natarajan and director Nanda Rao paid floral tributes to Gandhi’s statue in the presence of other officials after hoisting of the national flag. Various leaders, activists, professors of Gandhian studies, students, freedom fighters and public paid tribute to Gandhi’s statue and memorial throughout the day. Floral tributes were paid to Mahatma Gandhi statues located at various spots throughout the city by leaders and public.

The department of physical education of MKU meanwhile conducted the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial cycling and trekking program. The MKU vice chancellor Dr M Krishnan flagged off the event, which began at the Kamaraj statue in the university and ended at Samanarmalai in Keelakuyilkudi.

During the program, the participating students recalled Mahatma Gandhi’s education ideals and were also explained the importance of trekking. The head of the department, Dr K Chandrasekaran, professors V Jeyaveerapandian and C Ramesh, as well as Keelakuyilkudi panchayat president Sundaravalli also took part in the event.

Title: Madurai: Man, 30, arrested for raping minor
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

Title: ACB to register cheating, forgery cases for submitting false documents
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The state anti-corruption bureau ( ACB ) — getting strict with public servants and people representatives being probed for disproportionate assets (DPA) —has decided to register cheating and forgery cases if the suspects are found submitting forged records for their assets.

A decision in this regard was taken during the crime review meeting of the state ACB headed by directorate general of police (DGP) Param Bir Singh in Mumbai earlier this week.

During the meeting it was found that on several occasions the suspect government servants are found submitting forged records to show that their wives took tuition classes or owned beauty parlour or claim to have earned several lakhs from farming.

An officer, who attended the meeting, said these are the most common sources of income shown by spouses of the suspect public servants. In DPA cases, probe is carried out in two stages — discreet and open.

Discreet inquiry is carried out to find if there is any substance in the allegations against the said public servant amassing wealth more than his known sources of income.

After finding substantial records, an offence is registered and an open inquiry is initiated, during which the suspect is asked to submit all documentary records to prove that his assets are the result of legitimate income.

While doing so, the suspect submits records, which if found to be irrelevant or fake, were rejected by the ACB. Henceforth, it has been decided that additional sections would be slapped if fake records are submitted.

When contacted, superintendent of police (ACB) Arvind Chawria said, “It has been decided that additional sections of cheating, forgery would be added to the existing case if any government servant is found submitting fake or forged records to justify his claims about making assets from known sources of income.”

Not only the credentials of all submitted records would be cross-checked, but also the department concerned, issuing receipts to such suspects, will have to officially certify the documents. These departments will also be held accountable if any forged receipt is issued.

The officer, citing the standard operating procedure followed during DPA inquiries, said cost of things as petty as footwears to tables, furniture, mobile phones, and so on in the suspect’s house in taken into account.

Everything, including cost of children’s education, jewellery, cross-verification of the returns filed with income tax, all declared and undeclared assets are taken on record with the help of multiple government agencies, before auditing his salary from day he joined the service.

Title: Several people from U’khand working, studying in China, kin worried
Content: Haridwar: Family members of Uttarakhand natives working or studying in China are gripped by anxiety in the backdrop of the deadly coronavirus outbreak which has affected thousands of people in the neighbouring country. Concerned about the safety of their loved ones, kin of around 200 yoga teachers from Rishikesh who are working in China have asked for central government’s urgent intervention.“My daughter works in China and although we speak to her on phone regularly, I am concerned about her safety. China’s Wuhan city is in a curfew-like state and every resident has been asked to stay inside home and all workplaces have been closed,” said Ramji Shukla, whose daughter Anamika is a yoga teacher in Wuhan.He added, “My daughter’s company has shut operations for now and has asked all employees to stay indoors. Anamika has food supplies for almost two weeks but we have no idea as to how she will manage things after that. Our government should approach Indians in China and provide them all possible help.”According to local yoga trainers, around 200 yoga trainers from Rishikesh are currently working in different cities of China. Akhilesh Bhatt, a yoga teacher who returned from China last year, said, “I worked for seven years as a yoga trainer in China. The number of yoga teachers from India is quite sizeable there since there is demand for those who are qualified to teach yoga and meditation.”

Title: Educators’ conference in Vellore tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Vellore: A Bengaluru-based education technology company (Learning Matters Pvt. Ltd) will organise a free educators’ conference at hotel Darling Residency in Vellore on Saturday.

The conference aims to discuss and share strategies to improve teaching-learning environment in schools.

Members of the school managements, principals, founders and educational activists can participate in the conference and share their ideas.

The key topics that the conference will address include enhancing productivity of teachers, using artificial intelligence in classrooms and transforming schools with tech and non-tech tools.

Regardless of the medium of education the school follows (Tamil or English) and the kind of syllabus they are invited to participate in the free conference.

According to K Anand, vice president of the firm, “Attendees will have the opportunity to discuss with eminent speakers and to network,” he said.

Title: Guv blocking ‘most unfortunate’: Speaker
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Speaker P Sreeramakrishnan has said the incident that took place in the assembly on Wednesday when governor Arif Mohammed Khan had come to address the House was “most unfortunate”.

On Wednesday, the governor, accompanied by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan , the speaker and parliamentary minister A K Balan, had to wait for a few minutes inside the well of the House as the Congress-led opposition members blocked their passage. The opposition members were then forcibly removed by the watch and ward staff of the assembly.

The speaker, however, ruled out any action against the opposition members who had blocked the governor.

Sreeramakrishnan made it clear that only the prepared text of the governor’s address will feature in the assembly documents. “Whatever the governor has said outside the prepared text will not be there in the documents. What the cabinet approved is the prepared text of the speech made by the governor in the House. Hence, only that will go into the assembly records,” the speaker said. The governor had said on Wednesday that he was reading out the paragraph as requested by the chief minister, though he had his own reservations. “I have been corresponding with the chief minister on the matter for the last few days. I disagree with the government view, but I will read to honour his request,” Khan had said.

The speaker said that the opposition had lodged a complaint against the watch and ward staff entering the House. “A decision on this will be taken soon,” he said.

On the notice moved by opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala to pass a resolution urging President Ram Nath Kovind to recall the governor, the speaker said: “The business advisory committee meeting of the assembly will take a decision on this notice.”

“As per the rules, the notice given by the opposition leader is valid. But, whether it has to be admitted in the House for discussion or not has to be decided during the meeting of the business advisory committee,” Sreeramakrishnan added.

Title: Plastic covers stay in Hatibagan, Gariahat even after mayor diktat
Content:
Plastic sheets strung over stalls in Hatibagan

TimesView It is important to set a policy and then stick to it; and this policy should be uniform for all areas. Too many frequent changes and climbdowns can encourage violations of law.

KOLKATA: Some have fallen in line. But many others continue to play truant. A section of hawkers in Esplanade-New Market belt has removed the plastic sheets they had strung up over their stalls as shade after mayor Firhad Hakim issued a warning a fortnight ago. But a majority of them in Gariahat and Hatibagan continue to defy him and use plastic that are both an eyesore and a fire hazard.It was hawkers in Esplanade who took off the plastic sheets after Hakim issued a stern warning. KMC had made several pleas before. But they had been of no avail till Hakim issued a stern warning 15 days ago, calling for the removal of all plastic sheets from hawking zones. Pointing out that the monsoon had long passed, the mayor had said the sheets not only posed fire threat, they also allowed dust to settle on them, thereby causing pollution.While hawkers in Esplanade area were the first to oblige and took off plastic sheets last week, those doing business on the pavements in New Market-Lindsay Street stretch followed suit. Hawkers in Bertram Street, Humayun Place and Lindsay Street also removed the plastic cover after cops from local New Market police station conducted a couple of raids.According to Mohammed Irfan, a hawker who sells ready-made garment at Grand Arcade, they were compelled to take off the plastic sheets following a warning from the civic bosses. “A team of officials from the KMC headquarters asked us to remove plastics or face the consequences. Cops from New Market also reminded us about the civic action.
