Thinking of a punitive action we decided to remove plastic materials from around our space,” he said.Though a section of New Market traders welcomed the move, they pointed out that hawkers continue to pile the plastic sheets at the main entry points to the heritage market at night and posed a threat to the entire market. “If there is a fire at night, the entire market will get burnt down. We have brought it to the notice of authorities time and again but to no avail,” said Uday Sahoo, a shop-owner and functionary of the SS Hogg Market Traders’ Association.At Gariahat, the scene remains unchanged with grimy plastic sheets covering the stalls that occupy half the pavement width. A section of businessman said though plastic sheets had been taken off in the run-up to Durga Puja, they returned shortly after.“Though hawkers were asked to remove plastics after KMC began distributing stalls, most hawkers have not moved into them and continue to do business the old way,” said traders who owns a garment shop. Ratan Dhar, one of the few hawkers who had removed the plastic sheet over his stall, said he put them back again when he saw that no one had complied.At Hatibagan, too, compliance is poor with over 80% hawkers still using plastics sheets. “KMC market department has asked us to remove plastic materials. But, we need some more time,” said Swapan Mondal, a hawker who sells cosmetic items.A senior official in the KMC market department said after mayor Firhad Hakim ordered removal of plastics from hawkers’ markets, the civic body was in touch with local police stations to assist the civic official implement the plastic ban.

Title: Deputy chief minister raises question over feasibility of water grid project
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Ajit Pawar

AURANGABAD: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar on Wednesday expressed doubts about the financial feasibility of the ambitious water grid project . Citing expert opinion, he said that even if the project is executed, thousands of crores will have to be paid as electricity bills for the same.

Pawar said though this government does not have the mindset to scrap the projects, there are contradictory views amongst the experts. He pointed out that during the previous government’s tenure too, some experts, and even government officials, had tried to explain the same — but their views were ignored. “How can a project be executed, when it is not feasible?” Pawar asked.

His statement is being looked upon as the first step towards the scrapping of the water grid project.

Pawar went on to state that even the Mumbai-based Hyperloop project is like the water grid project. He said as per the expert opinion, both the projects are not feasible. Speaking about the Hyperloop project, he said: “It is a project that no one has experimented with before. There is a serious question about should public money be spent on such projects.”

He said the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation had an outstanding power bill of Rs 100 crore for the water supply project. He, however, clarified that his words should not be taken as if the incumbent government was scrapping all the projects initiated by the previous government.

Pawar skipped answering questions on if the water grid project would be allocated funds in the upcoming state budget. He said even if a project does is not mentioned in the budget, it can be added as a supplementary demand during monsoon or winter sessions.

When asked about the allocation of funds for Jalyukt Shivar, Pawar said that there are questions about the success of this project.

The deputy CM was in the city for a review meeting of the planning committees in the region.

Title: HC imposes cost for misusing PIL remedy
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay High Court has imposed a cost of Rs 5,000 on a petitioner for misusing the remedy of public interest litigation ( PIL ) in settling a matter that is already being heard by a civil court.

The petitioner, Rameshwar Baburao Suryawanshi, claiming to be president of RTI Karyakarta Manch, Latur, had filed a PIL in the HC seeking directives to the government authorities for cancellation of two sale deeds on land carried out in the year 2016.

The petitioner stated that based on the application of one Baburao Mallappa Takale, the then tehsildar of Nilangan in January 1994 allotted him a portion of government land. “In violation of the terms laid down by the revenue authorities, the man allegedly indulged in illegal transfer of land.”

Assistant government pleader SP Sonpawle represented the state and pointed out that the matter was already pending before appropriate civil court.

The division bench of the HC comprising Justices Prasanna Varale and Anil Kilor observed: “The petitioner is seeking direction in respect of certain land property which is already a subject matter before the competent civil court and as such, it is our clear opinion that this petition is nothing but a misuse of the remedy of public interest litigation.”

Though the petitioner has claimed to be an RTI activist, the HC observed: “Nowhere it is stated in the petition that this document is obtained by taking recourse to Right to Information Act. There is not a single word in the petition to show the source of this document.”

The HC further said that on the one hand, the petitioner has submitted the record showing that the matter is pending before the civil court while on the other, he has stated on oath that there is no civil or criminal proceedings filed or going on which could have legal nexus with the issue involved in the public interest litigation.

The HC cited a series of flaws in the PIL and concluded that the “PIL is thoroughly meritless and deserves to be dismissed at the threshold with imposition of costs on the petitioner for misusing the remedy.”

The petitioner failed to mention his source of livelihood in the petition, following which the HC specifically inquired about. On learning that farming is his source of livelihood, the court ruled: “Considering the source of livelihood of the petitioner, we deem it appropriate to impose costs of Rs 5,000 upon the petitioner.”

Title: VOC Port tightens measures to prevent coronavirus outbreak
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Tuticorin: V O Chidambaranar (VOC) Port in Tuticorin has tightened safety measures to prevent coronavirus outbreak in China from spreading to India through sea.

Chairman of the port T K Ramachandran has said that the port has been put on high alert to address the coronavirus issue that has raised safety concerns globally.

In a statement, he said that this is in line with the measures taken by the ministry of shipping that has directed all the ports to undertake screening and isolation activities while disembarking seafarers and cruise passengers, to prevent the outbreak of the deadly virus through the ships that are calling the seaports of India.

Ramachandran said that VOC Port is closely coordinating with the ministry of shipping and the ministry of health and family welfare in monitoring crew and passengers.

The port health officer (PHO) has made arrangements for obtaining self-declaration from arriving crew and passengers.

An isolation ward has been arranged at the government medical college and hospital at Tuticorin with necessary facilities and infrastructure.

VOC Port has issued the standard operating procedure (SoP) for surveillance of vessel, crew and passenger management. The SoP has been forwarded to all the stakeholders for compliance.

The SoP has also been circulated to the port users through social media.

In order to sensitize port users and stakeholders operating in the port regarding precautionary measures to reduce the risk of exposure to coronavirus, the port has placed signages at the administrative offices, green gate, yellow gate, red gate, Zone-B, port hospital and at the entrance of the navigation channel.

Stating that periodical review meetings with PHO, stakeholders of the port and port users are also being conducted by the management to assess the situation, port officials said that these measures will continue till further instructions from the ministry of shipping and ministry of health and family welfare.

Title: Forest dept to rehabilitate Van Gujjars
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Huts Of Van Gujjars encroached in Pathari- jwalapur Forest area

Dehradun: The state forest department has decided to rehabilitate the Van Gujjars in Chillawali range of Rajaji Tiger Reserve (RTR) and nearby areas. In the first phase, around 28 families (out of 104 identified families) will be rehabilitated in the Pathri and Gaindi Khata area where some forest dwellers already live. The department has plans to give out existing forest plots to these dwellers. These would be the plots which were either abandoned or sold by forest dwellers despite not having the right to sell forest land.

Another site at Shahmansur in Khanpur range has also been identified for relocating the remaining Van Gujjar families. It is being planned that forest dwellers will be given 1 acre land and Rs 5 lakh per family. A proposal for the same will be prepared by RTR director to send to state government. “Van Gujjars are integral part of our forests and we cannot throw them out to suffer. We have directed RTR officials to form their society so that they have registered GST number and related documents. This will help us provide them with maximum possible forest department jobs,” said Jairaj, head of forest force, Uttarakhand.

Uttarakhand has around 5,000 Van Gujjar families, as per forest department data. Most of these families claim to be inhabitants of RTR and Corbett reserve. The forest department is planning to conduct an in-depth survey to get adequate details and rehabilitate these Van Gujjars.

Title: Rs 171 crore sanctioned for new Nashik district court building
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The high-powered committee (HPC) of the state government , led by state chief secretary, has sanctioned Rs 171 crore for the construction of a 7-storey building for the Nashik district court.

According to district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal , the HPC has sanctioned the new building and provision for the same would be made in the upcoming state budget.

The issue of construction of new court building has been pending for a long time. Bhujbal, who is also the civil supply and consumer protection minister, stressed on the same as a result of which the HPC headed by state chief secretary Ajoy Mehta sanctioned the project.

Additional chief secretary Manoj Saunik, chief secretary of public works department Ajit Sagne, Nashik superintending engineer Ranjeet Hande, executive engineer Siddharth Tambe, assistant engineer Abhijeet Shelar, among others were present for the meeting.

The building construction plan was given to the chief secretary, following which there was discussion about importance of the district court and how the new building will would resolve the issues faced by the court.

“The HPC immediately sanctioned the construction of the building at a cost of Rs 171-crore and announced that the provision for the construction would be done in the budget,” read a statement issued by Bhujbal.

At present, there are 34 courts functioning inside the existing court building. At this point in time the court is short of at least 44 more establishments – courts and other offices – to ensure that work goes on smoothly in the building.

The law and judiciary department has got a 2.5 acre land which was with the commissionerate of police falling under the home department. Accordingly, a building design was proposed by the architects and the same was sanctioned by the HPC.

Title: Tension during indirect polls
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Cuddalore: Tension prevailed at Kumalangunam in Cuddalore district after a section of people registered their objection for holding the indirect polls for the post of panchayat vice-president. The protesters argued that indirect polls should not he held until the panchayat president assumes charge.

The district poll officials had erroneously declared the losing candidate as the winner in the panchayat president polls earlier following a confusion over their names. Vijayalakhmi (1,478) was erroneaously declared the winner instead of Jayalakshmi who polled 2,512 votes. The swearing-in ceremony of the president was cancelled citing law and order situation.

Against this backdrop, the indirect polls to elect the vice-president on Thursday witnessed a few tense moments.

Police acted swiftly and removed the protesting people enabling the conduct of the polls in which seven elected members unanimously elected Ananthi Sekar as vice president.

Title: SC stays HC proceedings on petition challenging Kanimozhi’s election in LS polls
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

New Delhi: The Supreme Court on Thursday stayed the Madras high court proceedings on a petition challenging the election of DMK leader Kanimozhi Karunanidhi from Tuticorin constituency.

A bench headed by Chief Justice S A Bobde took note of the submissions of the DMK leader’s lawyer and stayed the high court proceedings.

“Having heard counsel appearing for the parties, we direct that until further orders, the operation of impugned judgment and order dated November 19, 2019 passed by the high court of judicature at Madras in original application nos...in election petition no.3 of 2019 and the further proceedings in election petition shall remain stayed,” said the bench which comprised justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant.

The bench has now posted the plea filed by the DMK leader against the high court order for further hearing after four weeks.

Kanimozhi contested from the Tuticorin constituency in 2019 and her election was challenged by a voter, A Sanathana Kumar, on the grounds that she failed to mention her husband’s permanent account number (PAN) in her election affidavit disclosing family assets.

The Madras high court had earlier rejected the plea of Kanimozhi seeking dismissal of two election petitions filed by the voter and a BJP leader separately challenging her election to the Lok Sabha.

The election petition should necessarily be taken to its logical end, it had said.

While dismissing Kanimozhi's plea, the high court had said that the election petitioner must be given a chance to marshal evidence to prove his claim of improper acceptance of nomination.

The DMK leader had said her husband was an NRI living in Singapore and he neither possessed a PAN card nor does he pay any income tax in India.

Kanimozhi had defeated her nearest rival Tamilisai Soundararajan (now governor of Telangana) of BJP. Another plea challenging the election of Kanimozhi was filed by Soundararajan, who withdrew the plea after becoming governor of Telangana.

A Muthuramalingam, a local BJP leader, has substituted Soundararajan as a party in the high court. PTI

Title: ‘File counter on plea seeking stay on Classes V, VIII public exam’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has directed the state government to file a counter on a plea seeking an interim stay on the amendment to Section 16 of the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2019 which made it compulsory for children of Classes V and VIII to undergo state-level public examinations.

The petition came up for hearing before a division bench comprising justice M Duraisamy and justice T Ravindran. In his petition, S Louis, said that public examinations for the classes V and VIII is wholly unwarranted and not conducted in any other state this academic year.

He said the impugned amendment Section 16 of the Act and consequential impugned government order (GO) dated September 13, 2019 is highly arbitrary and violative of Article 21 A of the Indian Constitution.

The state level public examinations for classes V and VIII at the end of every academic year and conducting re-examination after a period of two months for those who failed is nothing but a harassment to the children at their tender age which would result in giving up further learning.

Collection of examination free of Rs 100 for Class V and Rs 200 for the Class VIII is against the fundamental right of free and compulsory education provided under Article 21A of the Constitution.

The bench directed the state government to file a counter and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Gold chain worth Rs 2.29 lakh snatched from woman
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

VELLORE: A bike-borne man snatched a seven-sovereign gold chain, worth about Rs 2.29 lakh, from a Karnataka-based woman who had come to attend a relative’s marriage at Jolarpet in Tirupattur district on Thursday. Police said Padma, 60, wife of Seenivasalu, from Kolar district in Karnataka, had come to Jolarpet for the marriage. Around 6am when she was outside the marriage hall, a man who came on a two-wheeler snatched her gold chain. The woman, who sustained bruises on her neck, was administered first aid at a nearby hospital. The Jolarpet police registered a case.

Title: Sudhir Mungantiwar day dreaming to form govt, says Ashok Chavan
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Ashok Chavan

AURANGABAD: Public works department (PWD) minister and Congress functionary Ashok Chavan on Thursday came down heavily on former minister Sudhir Mungantiwar for stating that Shiv Sena is their natural partner and the option for forming government with the BJP is still open.

Chavan on Thursday took a review meeting of the works being carried out by the PWD in the region. After conclusion of the marathon meeting, the former chief minister attended a couple of events organized by the local unit of the Congress.

During an interaction with the journalists, Chavan said he (Mungantiwar) thinks he is still in government. “His statement that BJP and Shiv Sena are trying to form a government again is a distant dream. Mungantiwar has a habit of dreaming, but our government is working smoothly,” he added.

Being asked about controversial statements of Maha Vikas Aghadi , Chavan said, “Those who are part of the alliance should avoid giving statements that may lead to controversy. It is a good thing that Jitendra Awhad has taken back his statement over Indira Gandhi.”

Awhad, an NCP functionary, on Wednesday had said that Indira Gandhi implemented emergency and tried to suppress democracy. This led to sharp criticism from state Congress and soon Awhad withdrew his comments.

Title: Senior PI loses increment for foreign visit without permission
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

AURANGABAD: A senior inspector serving with Nanded police will be denied a year’s increment as punishment for visiting Vietnam to study guerilla warfare without obtaining permission from higher-ups.

Nanded superintendent of police Vijaykumar Magar on Wednesday issued the order against the senior PI, Pandit Kachve , on cancellation of annual increment.

“There are standing orders from the state police headquarters that any police personnel going on a foreign tour should obtain prior permission and clearance from the appropriate authorities. The officer violated the norms and accordingly he has been punished,” Magar told TOI.

When contacted, Kachve, who is currently heading the Nanded rural police station, said it was his personal trip and he paid for it. “Being a history student, I am keen on doing PhD on the subject. I went to Vietnam for three days for studying guerilla warfare. Going on a foreign tour without prior permission was my mistake and I have confessed to it before our unit commander,” he said.

In May-June 2019, Kachve availed of leave for seven days and went on a personal tour to Vietnam. It was after he returned to Nanded and resumed duty, his photos of the foreign visit went viral on social media and also published by some vernacular newspapers.

Activists working under the banner of ‘public welfare anti-corruption committee’ took note of the visit and lodged a written complaint with the superintendent of police, who initiated a probe against the senior PI.

Taking cognizance of the newspaper reports, A memo was issued to the officer and simultaneously a show-cause asking why action should not be initiated against him.

Police sources informed that during the internal probe, the seniors inspector admitted to have gone on a foreign tour without prior clearance from higher-ups, following which the punishment was awarded to him.

Title: Dadi slams Naidu for comments on Visakhapatnam
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: YSRC state general secretary, Dadi Veerabhadra Rao on Thursday slammed TDP chief Chandrababu Naidu for calling Visakhapatnam cyclone-prone and unsuitable for capital.

Addressing the media, here, Rao accused the former chief minister of misguiding the public. “What about cities like Chennai and Mumbai, are they not prone to cyclones? Visakhapatnam is the largest city in AP and the economic hub of the state. It has two ports and major industries. In what way have the cyclones affected its growth?” Rao asked.

Veerabhadra Rao accused Naidu of venting his anger against YS Jaganmohan Reddy by trampling the aspirations of Rayalaseema and north-coastal districts. tnn

Title: Improvment in condition of sanitation workers a key focus
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: Many startups who presented their innovations at the Ink@Wash event not only devised solutions for water, sanitation and solid waste issues but also focused on improving the work conditions for sanitation workers, who they claim are the largest informal force that India has.

On the first day of Ink@Wash, a platform that promoting innovations in WASH (water, sanitation and hygiene) areas, as many as 11 startups presented their innovations. While many startups devised solutions for recycling waste, water conservation and cleanliness, several also showed their worked on employment models which can empower the sanitation sector.

A city-based start-up, Banyan Nation, had mapped the kabbadiwalas (rag-pickers) in Hyderabad in order to streamline waste management mechanism in the city. “In Hyderabad, we found that there were four recyclers for every kilometre. For every 250 households, there is one dedicated recycler. We have mapped the kabbadiwalas and integrated the supply chain,” said Banyan Nation direstior, Rashi Agarwal. She added that India has one of the largest networks of waste-pickers which can be streamlined and monetised using innovative technologies.

Similarly, Hasiru Dala Innovations claimed that it had fostered entrepreneurship among waste-pickers by providing them waste management services. “While there is a lot of discussion over devising solutions in WASH areas, governments rarely talk about those collecting and/or segregating waste. We offer fixed salaries, incentives and a network to the waste-pickers for collecting, segregating and recycling of waste,” said co-founder of Hasiru Dala Innovations, Shekhar Prabhakar.

Title: Only 14 Karnataka agencies have MEA nod to get jobs abroad
Content:
Newly opened protector of emigrants office in Bengaluru

BENGALURU: The newly established protector of emigrants office in Karnataka is planning to crack down on hundreds of illegal agencies recruiting people for jobs abroad as there are only 14 registered in the state with the ministry of external affairs .The office of POEs started operating in Karnataka from December after a long-standing demand from the government. It is responsible for protecting interests of Indians migrating abroad for jobs.According to sources, foreign job frauds are seeing a rise in the state, especially in coastal areas where aspirants are being duped by some agencies. Most of the gullible are being cheated with UAE job offers and the agencies are collecting thousands of rupees. The agencies are supposed to offer technical support, healthcare and other jobs in Gulf countries but some of them have cheated people.Shubham Singh, protector of emigrants, Bengaluru said Indians cheated with job offers abroad can approach the POEs office to get their issues resolved. “If we get complaints, we will investigate and bring the culprits to book,” he said.The officer said it is mandatory for a recruiting agency to register with MEA. “Our objective is to solve the problems of emigrants and aspirants who get cheated and are denied the benefits promised,” Singh added.

Title: Pune: Accident fatalities on rural highway stretches a worry
Content:
Highest fatalities on the highways

PUNE: Fatalities because of accidents on highways passing through the rural parts of the district showed a marginal dip in 2019, but the number was high enough despite police stepping up measures to arrest the nearly four-year trend.After registering the highest fatalities on the highways across the state in 2016, 2017 and 2018 (see graphic), the Pune rural police recorded 855 such deaths last year — the second highest in Maharashtra.The police said a large number of state and national highways, along an expressway, passed through their jurisdiction and most of the accidents on these roads occurred during early morning hours.Superintendent of police (Pune rural) Sandip Patil said “The district has a vast network of national and state highways and it is not possible to monitor all. We have, however, prepared some focused plans to reduce accidents and fatalities on the highways.”He told TOI, “We started a traffic branch at each police station last year. Each branch has a staff of 15 personnel and an officer. They have a patrolling vehicle to man the highways passing through their respective jurisdictions.”At the same time, the Pune rural police claimed to have taken action against motorists violating the road rules. “The main focus was on motorists taking the wrong side of the roads. We also repaired several punctures illegally created along various highways,” Patil said.The officer added that the Pune rural police were working in coordination with Highway Safety Patrol (HSP) officers to ensure safety on the state and national highways.An HSP officer said with the introduction of the interceptor vehicles, the police have managed to keep a check on speeding and rash driving. “We have taken action against over 1200 people for speeding and rash driving in two months. There are a few infrastructure issues related to the highways and the police have discussed the issues with the authorities concerned,” he said.“The Pune rural police and HSP authorities have in the past one year stepped up the heat on people resorting driving in a drunken condition,” he added.City-based traffic activist Ranjit Gadgil said the police must focus on ways to stop speeding on the highways. “The intensity of the accidents on the highways is high and speed is the major reason. The accident casualties have come down by 17%. It can be further reduced if there’s a check on speeding,” he said.Frequent accidents on the Pune-Mumbai expressway had prompted the state traffic police last year to reduce the maximum speed limit of vehicles from 120 kmph to 100 kmph. The Centre had through a notification in April 2018 enhanced the speed limit from 80 kmph to 120 kmph. The enhanced speed limit was implemented in the middle of 2019.The notification had stated that a review of road accidents in Maharashtra revealed that 30% of the fatal accidents occurred because of “over speeding”. It added that no cognisance of the violation of the speed limits should be taken under Section 183 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 , if the speed detected was within 5% of the maximum notified speed.Gadgil said the government agencies must fix the black spots on the highways, where accidents are a routine. “I think the enforcement of the traffic rules in the rural parts of the district was better in 2019 than the previous years and such an initiative should continue,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: Suspected coronavirus cases to be treated at four private hospitals too
Content:
Representative image

4 people found negative

BENGALURU: People with travel history to China can henceforth seek treatment and get tested for coronavirus infection at select private hospitals in Bengaluru. Hitherto, Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases (RGICD) was the only hospital in the city authorised to treat suspected cases.The decision was taken at a meeting held by chief secretary Vijay Bhaskar on Thursday morning with officials of health and family welfare department and RGICD.On Thursday, TOI had published about self-reported patients complaining of lack of facilities in the isolation ward of RGICD. The patients demanded they be shifted to private hospitals, raising concerns over cross infection within the ward.At the meeting, it was decided that four more hospitals in Bengaluru be allowed to admit patients with travel history to China. Manipal Hospitals, Apollo, Narayana Health and Fortis were asked to set up isolation wards for keeping suspected cases under observation. Patients at the RGICD isolation ward were told they could shift to any of these four private hospitals if they wanted. One person is likely to shift to Manipal Hospitals. Isolation wards will be set up at every district-level government hospital for suspected coronavirus patients.Besides, two labs in Bengaluru will be upgraded to test for coronavirus. The branch of National Institute of Virology located in RGICD and another lab at Bangalore Medical College and Research Institute will conduct coronavirus tests. Karnataka was sending sputum and blood samples of suspected patients to NIV, Pune.Of the 13 self-reported suspected coronavirus cases at RGICD, four patients have tested negative. Tests reports of nine others, including a Chinese woman, are awaited. “On Thursday night, one more patient came to the hospital with travel history to China and his sputum and blood samples are yet to be sent for testing,” said authorities.Family returned from Wuhan, neighbours worriedResidents of an apartment complex on Bannerghatta Road were a worried lot on Thursday when they found a family of four members in their midst had recently visited Wuhan in China, epicentre of the infection.“While the family has been saying they are fine, the apartment RWA has been asking them to get tested. Calls made to the RGICD landline number seeking help went unanswered,” said sources.

Title: Being threatened with acid attack: Leonia witnesses
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Two weeks after the Enforcement Directorate (ED) arrested Leonia Resorts MD GS Chakravarthy Raju for fraud , key witnesses have claimed that they are being threatened with ‘acid attack’ by a group of miscreants.

Cyberabad police booked two separate FIRs under criminal intimidation and trespass sections of IPC against three persons, who allegedly threatened the witnesses.

On January 15, ED officials arrested Raju for diverting public money obtained through bank loans.

Also, the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) has booked three FIRs against Raju and others. Raju is in judicial remand now.

In the FIRs, complainant D Chandrashekar Reddy and D Chitta Reddy residents of Shamirpet explained how on January 10 the ED conducted search operations and obtained their signature as ‘panch’ (material) witnesses and seized documents. ED officials gathered information about the diversion of funds and benami transactions on whom the properties were purchased with the diverted funds.

Complainant D Chandrasekhar Reddy identified CH Krishna Reddy, D Krishna Reddy, D Sudhakar Reddy and S Srinivas Reddy as close associates in connection with the benami transactions. Now, Chandrasekhar Reddy says unidentified people are frequenting his house in the village, and also put some anti-social elements on his trail.

“They are threatening to eliminate me for giving information and standing as a panch witness. D Sudhakar Reddy and CH Krishna scolded me in unparliamentary language and threatening that they will throw acid on my family and eliminate us,” Reddy said. The complainant said that he and his family are in danger.

“Anything happens to me… GS Chakravarthy Raju and his associates are responsible,” he said.

So far, the ED investigation has revealed that Raju and other accused of Leonia Resorts floated 33 shell companies in the name of employees and diverted the funds. ED said that the total outstanding loan amount defaulted by the accused and his company stood at Rs 1,768 crore.

ED said that money from Leo Meridian Infrastructure Projects & Hotels Limited is diverted to the shell companies based in Kolkata.

The Enforcement Directorate in December 2019 had attached assets worth Rs 250 crore of the accused.

Cyberabad police booked two separate FIRs under criminal intimidation and trespass sections of IPC against three persons, who allegedly threatened the witnesses. The complainant said he was being threatened as he became a material witness during an ED raid on January 10

Title: IOB’s Q3 loss up at Rs 6,076cr due to higher provisioning
Content: Chennai: State-owned Indian Overseas Bank (IOB) plunged deeper into red during October-December 2019 with net loss widening to Rs 6,076 crore, as against a loss of 346 crore in the previous year, due to higher provisioning.However, its bad loans or net non-performing assets (NPAs) dropped below 6% of advances to 5.81%. The bank is under RBI’s prompt corrective action (PCA) framework, which imposes certain restrictions on its functioning. “We have successfully reduced our net NPA to 5.81%. After reporting loss for over five years now, we are positive to achieve profit in the March quarter of 2020,” IOB MD & CEO Karnam Sekar said.The lender reported fresh slippages at Rs 5,875 crore for nine months ended December, 2019, “It also includes a one big account — DHFL. We are now focusing on 100% provided accounts for a better recovery rate.”The debt-ridden PSU bank has tripled its provisioning at Rs 6,664 crore on yearly basis. The lender had received capital infusion (equity) of Rs 8,217 crore few months ago. On reporting bad loans, IOB’s gross NPA has come down to 17.12% in December, 2019, from 23.76% in December, 2018, and 20% sequentially. “We formed a centralised set up to transfer NPAs from all branches, and increased the man power from 2-3 membered teams to 10-15 members, to exclusively work for recovery,” Sekar said. Under the bank’s one-time settlement (OTS) scheme about Rs 5,000 crore was recovered from 500 accounts.“Slippages of retail, agri and MSME accounts’ (RAM) has come down due to efficient recovery mechanism including third-party agencies,” he said.Provision coverage ratio has improved to 86.2% in the December quarter, as against 75.85% on quarterly basis. Net interest margin (NIM) stands at 1.94% in this quarter, compared to 1.86% in the last quarter.Total capital adequacy ratio as per Basel III guideline stood at 5.53% on December 31, 2019, as against regulatory requirement of 10.9%.Shares of IOB closed at 9.92 apiece, up 1.95% on BSE.

Title: Hyderabad: Water board will use GIS to track illegal connection and track consumer dues
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: In its efforts to track illegal water connections, Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) has proposed the mapping of every asset (property) using geographical information system (GIS). Currently, the water board physically visits the properties of the consumers concerned which has become a difficult task owing to the lack of man power.

“The water board records show that there over 9.8 lakh registered consumers but there is no data on the number of illegal water connections and no separate mechanism to track them either,” a senior water board official told TOI. The water board plans to use GIS technology to map each and every asset in under GHMC limits and its peripheral areas.

The information to be collected for this initiative will include a photograph of the property along with details such as the consumer’s name, their consumer account number (CAN), size of water connection and even the consumer’s dues. “Following the completion of asset mapping, there will be no need for physical visits as the information till even the consumer’s door number will be available (to us) with a single click,” explained the water board official.

The water board sees two benefits in this approach. They believe it will help curb illegal water connections which can end up saving around 50 million gallons of water per day that goes unaccounted for and that its new approach will help boost their revenue. “The water aims to complete this initiative in another six months,” the official said.

Title: Kol students unite against Jamia hate crime, vow not to give in
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kolkata: The firing at Jamia Millia students on Thursday, which coincided with the date of Mahatma Gandhi’s assassination by Nathuram Godse, left a scar on the students in Bengal. They have now vowed to raise the protest pitch against the amended citizenship act as well as those who have become “intolerant towards an alternative narrative”.

“It seems Gandhiji’s killers are still roaming freely. Today’s incident has completed the circle that started in 1948. Nathuram Godse brandished a gun and fired at Mahatma Gandhi and 72 years later, the same scene played out on the Delhi road when a person aimed a gun at students and fired at them. Intolerance towards any alternative narrative has blinded people who now seek an eye for an eye,” said Abhinandan Sinha, a research scholar at the Indian Statistical Institute.

“There is a concerted effort to brand the agitators as anti-nationals and hatred is being spewed against them on social media. The protest at Jamia Millia Islamia was against the way CAA was bulldozed through Parliament. The Supreme Court has started hearing the petition and it shows that the apex court finds merit in the argument of a number of organizations and individuals who have challenged the government’s move,” said Sneha Brishti Nandi, a Bengali literature student at Jadavpur University.

Manjima Dasgupta, a post-graduate student of Bengali literature at Presidency University, felt the person who wielded the gun is a victim of the hate propaganda. “He has anger inside and that is against the unjust system. Unfortunately, he has been brain-washed into finding a common enemy for all his woes. This hate politics in the country has to stop now,” Dasgupta said.

Arkaprabha Mukhopadhyay, a research scholar at the Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, felt such intolerance is palpable even in Bengal where anti-CAA students are being tagged as ‘azadi gang’ by a section of saffron outfits. “We faced similar hatred when we organized meetings at Kharagpur. Local BJP leaders branded us as azadi gang just because we raised questions,” Sinha said.

Arka Dev Sinha, a first-year student of international relations at Jadavpur University, claimed they were often being targeted as ‘gaddars’. “You will often find them (saffron brigade) saying ‘Desh ki gaddaron ko, goli maro saalon ko (shoot the anti-nationals)’ without even thinking why they are branding someone as anti-national. Just because someone has raised a question against the government cannot turn him into an anti-national. Today, he is just one person and tomorrow there will be five,” he said.

Title: Fire at Paikpara building sparks panic
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kolkata: A fire broke out at a four-storey building on Birpara Lane near Paikpara on Thursday afternoon following a blast in the garage , which had been converted into a fireworks warehouse . About 20 fire tenders took nearly two and a half hours to douse the flames. No casualty was reported.

Panic gripped around 24 people living in the building.

While the blast occurred at 1.40pm, all of them vacated their flats and came down to the street in 20 minutes. Swarup Karmakar, one of the residents, found it an uphill task to help his 72-year-old ailing mother-in-law Chandana Barua climb down the stairs. Chinmoy Ghosh, a businessman, who owns a second-floor flat, vacated the flat with his wife and pregnant daughter.

However, neither the fire officials nor the residents had an inkling about the source of the fire. They were all surprised when some fire fighters cut the shutter of the garage and found the fireworks warehouse. After the fire was extinguished, locals gathered at the spot and demanded a strong action against the promoter who had constructed the building and allowed the garage to be turned into a fireworks warehouse.

Bappa Sil, another resident of the building, said, “It is a matter of relief that the explosives have been deactivated.”

Anupam Biswas a marketing manager and a resident demanded a probe into the conversion of a garage space into a fireworks warehouse in a residential area.

An officer of Chitpore PS said they have started a probe and would book the culprit in consultation with the officials of KMC and fire services department.

Title: Two killed, three hurt in bike accident
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: Two persons lost their lives in a road accident while three others were injured in a bike accident on Thursday.

The incident took place in Rangareddy district’s Jangareddypally village. The two persons died on the spot.

Thalakondapally police said that a mason, 36-year-old Gummadaiah was travelling on his bike along with Mallaiah from Jangareddipalli to Amangal. At the same time, another person, Mahesh, along with two others — Shiva and Naresh — were travelling on a bike and coming in opposite direction as they were heading towards Rampur.

Both bikes collided and Gummadaiah and Mahesh died on the spot as a result of the crash while the other three were critically injured. They were shifted to a nearby hospital where they are currently undergoing treatment.

Local police have registered a case and are currently investigating it.

Title: Eflu students continue stir against admin rules on JRF
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: Several students from the English and Foreign Languages University ( Eflu ) continued their sitting protest against the administration on Thursday. The students demanded a complete rollback of the recently introduced policies by the executive council.

The Standing Committee of Academic Council (SCAC) had earlier recommended that PhD candidates who clear for the University Grants Commission Junior Research Fellowship (JRF) will be exempted from appearing in the entrance test and directly appear for an interview.

“Marks obtained out of 30 shall be calculated to arrive at the score out of 100, however, no explanation has been given as to how this score out of 30 will be converted into a score out of 100. This will put the non-NET aspirations in a precarious position as they will be expected to score unreasonably high scores in entrance exam. This move will put non-NET PhD candidates at a disadvantage,” said students’union vice-president, Harshal.

As per the new guidelines, only 30 students can enrol for a course and the registration will be on a first-come-first-served basis.

“This means the university will have to employ more faculty in each department as currently, most departments are understaffed,” said another student.

A protest rally was held on Thursday at the NCC Gate of Osmania University (OU) too by the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) student union demanding “an end urban Naxalism”. The ABVP protesters called for the removal of anti-CAA protesters from universities and said there was a need to take stringent measures and organise awareness camps for students in government universities.

Title: Vehicles set afire after truck runs over man in Patna
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Mob anger after the accident on New Bypass Road on Thursday

PATNA: Two vehicles, including a Bihar State Road Transport Corporation (BSRTC) bus, were torched and more than 24 other vehicles damaged by an irate mob after a man was crushed to death by a speeding truck while trying to cross NH-30 near Ramlakhan Path under the Kankarbagh police station area in the city on Thursday.

Traffic movement on the highway remained disrupted for at least three hours due to the protests.

The deceased was identified as Deepak Kumar (22), a daily wager and resident of Sheikhpura village under the Ramkrishna Nagar police station area in the city. The incident occurred when Deepak was on way to a hospital where his mother-in-law was undergoing treatment.

Locals alleged that though the truck involved in the accident was intercepted by them near Mithapur bus stand and handed over to traffic police, the latter set the vehicle free.

Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma, however, said the truck was not set free by traffic police. “The truck fled after the accident. Locals had gone on rampage after accidents on this stretch of national highway earlier as well,” the SSP added. He denied reports that police fired four to five rounds in air to disperse the mob.

Sharma, who reached the spot along with City SP (east) Jitendra Kumar, managed to pacify the mob. “Police are trying to identify the people involved in damaging property. An FIR will be registered at Kankarbagh police station in connection with the incident,” the SSP said.

He said the body of the deceased was sent for autopsy. “The district administration has started the process of providing ex gratia to the victim’s kin,” he added.

Title: Protest at University of Hyderabad over admin ‘apathy’ on medical insurance
Content:
UoH students’ union protest at the varsity’s admin block on Thursday.

HYDERABAD: Members of several student unions gathered at the University of Hyderabad (UoH) administrative block to protest a multitude of issues faced by students. The protesters raised slogans against the recent directive to ban public talks and gatherings with loudspeakers on campus.“Earlier, we had conducted several gatherings and public talks without loudspeakers. For the past four months we have been getting e-mails, circulars and notices from the registrar prohibiting all gatherings...This is an attack on campus democracy and constitutional democratic rights,” said UoH student union president Abhishek Nandan.The students also said that almost 45% students in the varsity are from poor backgrounds and face issues with medical insurance whenever they fall sick as they have to shell out money from their own pockets despite university providing insurance. However, they claim that they are getting little or no help from university in resolving the issues.“The university provided medical insurance but every time a student falls sick they are shifted to corporate hospitals, where the bill comes minimum Rs 30,000. Students have been facing problems claiming their insurance and are shelling out money from their own pockets. The university is now asking us to deal with the insurance company directly. Most students are from economically weak backgrounds, how will they manage that kind of fund?,” Nandan said.The students also raised slogans against the bifurcation of the students’ union fund and demanded the rollback of restrictive clauses of integrated studies which bars students from moving to post-graduation from graduation in case of backlogs.Speaking against the protest UoH Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) president Abhishek Malhotra said the stir was “bogus” and an attempt to create drama.“We all believe in voicing out state and national issues as active students but not at the cost of peace and harmony in the university.“Public talks should be a right for all but who defines the limit because we have seen these organisations forgetting all bounds,” Malhotra said.Nearly 20 policemen were deployed on campus after the students called for the protest.

Title: PIL quizzes 5-acre largess to director, HC seeks T reply
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana high court has issued notices to the state government, revenue secretary, HMDA commissioner, Rangareddy district collector and others asking them to explain the rationale behind allotting five acres of land in Mokilla village in Rangareddy district to film director N Shankar at a nominal cost of Rs 5 lakh per acre when the prevailing price in the area is far higher .

A bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy, while hearing a PIL which challenged this allotment, gave four weeks to the authorities to respond to the contentions in the plea.

Petitioner J Shanker filed the plea contending that the prevailing price in the area was Rs 5 crore per acre and giving it at Rs 5 lakh was irrational. The registration department’s official value in the area itself was Rs 20 lakh per acre and the market value was Rs 5 crore, he said. The state made the allotment by issuing GO Ms No 75 through its municipal administration department on June 21, 2019.

“The state should keep in mind that it is not the owner of the land,” the petitioner said, adding “it is a trustee, a custodian of the public assets. The land belongs to the people of the state and the government of the day must protect the land for the benefit of its people.”

Film director Shankar made a representation to the state seeking allotment of land for setting up a film and TV studio and, based on his plea, the state issued the GO allotting five acres land to him, the petitioner said.

Title: Startups to establish sanitation hub in T
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: With numerous startups working in the water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) focused areas, the Telangana government is now planning to establish a sanitation hub that will promote and support innovation that will devise solutions on issues related to WASH.

Speaking at the Ink@Wash event, organised by the Administrative Staff College of India, TK Sridevi, commissioner and director of municipal administration, Telangana government said: “We are working on a sanitation fund with urban poverty groups. This fund will attract investments under corporate social responsibilities.”

The managing director of Hyderabad Metro Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) M Dana Kishore admitted that while there are numerous innovations and solutions available to tackle WASH-related issues, there are not enough citizen engagement programmes that are conducted to spread awareness.

“Urban behaviour has not changed as people do not know how to treat waste, recycle it. In Hyderabad alone, almost 38% of water is wasted every day which amounts to 20 million gallons. The reason being a lack of awareness among people on water conservation,” Kishore said while explaining the water board’s new initiative under the water leadership and conservation programme wherein people are being educated about water conservation.

On Friday, municipal administration minister KT Rama Raowill speak on Telangana’s vision for achieveing sustainability development goals.

Title: Mobile app to make customs check faster
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: To facilitate arriving international passengers with e-filling of baggage and currency declarations, Visakhapatnam customs has launched an app called ATITHI.

Passengers travelling to Visakhapatnam airport from an international destination can download the app and declare the currency and belongings they are carrying with approximate value. As soon as they submit their declarations on the app, it would automatically reach the customs officials at the Visakhapatnam airport.

Once passengers reach the Visakhapatnam airport they need not undergo any checking procedures. Customs officials will match the contents of the baggage in the x-ray conveyor with the declaration filed by the passengers. If they are convinced that declaration matches the contents, concerned passengers will be allowed to leave.

“It has been observed that on long haul flights, passengers become extremely tired once they the destination. The customs check is the last check at the destination. So the app will give them some respite,” DK Srinivas, principal customs commissioner, Visakhapatnam, told TOI.

At present, there are three international flights from the city – an Air Asia flight to Malaysia, a Scoot Air flight to Singapore, and an Air India flight to Dubai via Hyderabad.

Title: 2 auto drivers held for fake number plates
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: Two auto drivers were arrested on Thursday for using fake vehicle registration number plates.

Balanagar police said that the arrested auto drivers — Mohammed Jahangir and A Ashok— had been plying their auto-rickshaws using the registration number from another three-wheeler belonging to one Rambabu.

During a vehicle check at Narsapur Crossroads on Thursday, Jahangir and Ashok were arrested by police.

The accused, during investigation, allegedly claimed that they had replaced their auto rickshaw’s registration number with Rambabu’s vehicle number to avoid paying their equated monthly installments ( EMI ) and escape from receiving e-challans.

There had been eight traffic challans for various violations recorded against the vehicles. belonging to Jahangir and Ashok

Title: PACS poll on February 15
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Hyderabad: Elections to primary agriculture cooperative societies (PACS) will be held on February 15 and results will be declared the same day. The schedule for the PACS election was issued by the department of cooperation on Thursday. CM K Chandrasekhar Rao on Thursday directed the agriculture and cooperation department to hold elections to PACS immediately. Nominations would be accepted for the elections between February 6 and 8 and withdrawal of nomination would be allowed on February 10. TNN

Title: Karnataka: Pay Rs 2 more for Nandini milk, curd from Saturday
Content:
The price of Nandini toned milk (blue sachet) sold by Karnataka Milk Federation will increase from Rs 36 to Rs... Read More

BENGALURU: From February 1, Nandini milk price will go up by Rs 2 per litre across the state. Curd will also cost Rs 2 more.The price of Nandini toned milk (blue sachet) sold by Karnataka Milk Federation will increase from Rs 36 to Rs 38. A litre of curd will now cost Rs 43.“KMF had proposed an increase of Rs 3/litre across the board, but chief minister BS Yediyurappa approved a hike of Rs 2, keeping in mind the interest of both consumers and milk farmers,’’ said KMF chairman Balachandra Jarkiholi.It is said that 14 district milk unions had stepped up pressure on KMF to increase prices — last done three years ago. Milk unions had also urged the federation to transfer 75% of the hiked amount to farmers.Following this, the KMF board convened a meeting on January 17 and requested the government to hike the rate by Rs 3/litre.Jarkiholi said the hike was imminent as farmer families dependent on dairying for a living need more income to meet losses caused by floods and drought over the last two years.The KMF had also requested the chief minister to increase subsidy to farmers, but no decision was taken on that.

Title: Karnataka: 3,400 schools severely damaged by floods yet to see redevelopment
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The roof of a school in Togarsi, Shivamogga, had collapsed during last year’s rain

BENGALURU: Nearly 3,400 schools that sustained severe damage during heavy rain and subsequent floods in 15 educational districts and needed to be rebuilt are yet to witness any kind of renovation six months later. Of the 6,000 schools which required partial repair, only around 1,000 are ready, while work is under way in over 4,500.

The flood-affected schools were divided into two categories — those which had to be demolished and built from scratch and others which needed repair. The government released Rs 199 crore for repair through the districts’ deputy commissioners, but no allocation was made for institutions where where classrooms were completely damaged and had to be rebuilt.

According to the January 28 data available with the planning section of department of public instruction (DPI), repair work in 1,034 schools has been completed and has been initiated in another 4,513. It is yet to begin in 525 schools, of which the highest number is in Shivamogga district.

The government has approached National Bank for Agricultural and Rural Development Fund (NABARD) for funds to rebuild classrooms. “We’ve been informed that Rs 600 crore will be granted from rural development funds for school reconstruction. However, we are yet to get written approval,” said KG Jagadeesha, commissioner for public instruction.

The cost of reconstruction ranges from Rs 11.5 lakh to Rs 17.2 lakh per school. Around 6,500 classrooms in 3,227 primary schools and 159 high schools have to be rebuilt.

No damaged school is completely ready in Gadag, Uttara Kannada, Chikkamagaluru and Dakshina Kannada districts. In Udupi, where 135 schools were affected, work has been completed in only five. Belagavi has the highest number of schools which have been renovated (232), followed by Shivamogga (149), Hassan (135) and Dharwad (133).

Title: Asaduddin Owaisi: Give prize for being helpless to Delhi cops
Content:
Asaduddin Owaisi

. @DelhiPolice What happened to the bravado that you showed in #Jamia last month? If there’s a prize for being ‘he… https://t.co/Ym3aQNAhK5 — Asaduddin Owaisi (@asadowaisi) 1580377351000

HYDERABAD: All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Thursday questioned the role of Delhi police and said that they should get a prize for being ‘helpless bystanders’ after a gunman managed to climb over a barricade and shoot at anti CAA-protesters. Hours after a man identified as Gopal was caught for injuring one person, the Hyderabad MP tweeted: “@DelhiPolice What happened to the bravado that you showed in #Jamia last month? If there’s a prize for being ‘helpless’ bystanders, you’d win it every time.”“Can you explain why a gunshot victim had to CLIMB over a barricade? Do your service rules stop you from being HUMANE?” added Owaisi. He also took potshots at PM Narendra Modi on Twitter, asking if he could identify the accused by his clothes. “Thanks to @ianuragthakur & all the 9 pm nationalists who have created so much hatred in this country that a terrorist shoots a student while cops watch Hi @PMOIndia identify him by his clothes,” the MP tweeted.

Title: Nashik is coldest at 7.9°C as northerly winds chill Maharashtra, warmer days ahead
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Night and day temperatures have dipped significantly in the state as forecast by India Meteorological Department (IMD) earlier this week.On Thursday, the minimum temperature in Shivajinagar fell to 11°C while Lohegaon recorded a minimum temperature of 12°C on Thursday.The temperatures in the two locations were among the lowest for Pune this winter. The season this year has been recording high night temperatures which have mostly been around 15°C or more.Day temperatures have also plunged 1 to 2 degrees below the normal in the state, and lower than 30°C in many parts.The lowest minimum temperature on Thursday in Maharashtra was recorded in Nashik at 7.9°C, followed by Jalgaon and Ahmednagar at 8.5°C and 9.7°C, respectively.The spell may be short-lived. Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune told TOI that on Friday morning, there might be a slight rise in minimum temperatures but some stations could still record temperatures below 10 degrees celsius. The minimum temperature in Pune is unlikely to go below 10°C on Friday.“Cold northerly winds began to penetrate partially uninterrupted in the state on Thursday, especially over north Maharashtra, which is why Jalgaon and Nashik recorded single digit night temperatures. But from Friday afternoon, the wind regime may start changing to the easterly flow, causing a gradual rise in the minimum temperatures till February 3,” Kashyapi added.From February 1 to 3, a cyclonic circulation in the lower atmospheric level is likely to form over Madhya Maharashtra and Konkan, which will block the northerly wind flow till February 4.“This system will also result in a slight moisture incursion mainly from the Bay of Bengal and also Arabian Sea, causing partly clouding during the night time and early morning. Night clouding is usually associated with higher than normal night or minimum temperatures,” Kashyapi added.

Title: No entry to Goans on casinos for gambling from Saturday
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The state has a dozen onshore and six offshore casinos

PANAJI: From February 1, 2020, Goans will be completely banned from gambling in casinos, except those working on them. Currently, a dozen onshore and six offshore casinos are operating in the state.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Thursday that a gaming commissioner will be appointed soon, and he will be vested with powers to check the identity of the visitors to casinos. A notification will be issued in this regard on Friday.

“We are appointing the commissioner of commercial tax department as the gaming commissioner. From February 1, he will stop entry of Goans into casinos. However, those working on casinos will be out of its purview,” he said.

The chief minister said the government will also come up with rules and regulations under the Goa Public Gambling Act 1976. “Gaming commission will draft the rules and regulations,” he said.

It was a long-pending demand of the people, with the legislators echoing their concerns in the House, as many families had turned bankrupt.

In June 2015, the home department had first drafted the rules in which there was a provision to arrest any person under 21 years of age and any Goan, irrespective of age, found gambling in a casino in the state. But the file could not cross the bureaucratic hurdles.

Under the draft rules, the home department had given powers to the state government to appoint a gaming commissioner, who could be a private person or a government officer.

The department said that if a private person is appointed then s/he should be provided logistic support including staff. The draft rules also said that the collector, excise commissioner or commercial tax commissioner could be appointed as the gaming commissioner.

It was in June 2012 that the state government passed the amendment to the Goa Public Gaming Act, 1976 by introducing the Goa Public Gaming (Amendment) Bill, 2012.

Title: 40-year-old man found dead in Almora, officials cite cold weather
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: A 40-year-old man died allegedly due to cold weather conditions in Molekhal block of Almora district. If it is confirmed then it would make the second cold weather-related death in Kumaon region of Uttarakhand.

The deceased has been identified as Puran Chandra Singh, a resident of Almora.

According to police, Singh was found unconscious on Wednesday morning after which he was taken to the hospital. “However, the doctors declared him dead on arrival," said a police official.

Though the official said the post-mortem report of the deceased is awaited, “but prima facie, it looks like he died of cold”.

“The man was drunk and was found lying in the open. We could not find anything suspicious about the death and therefore, it looks like he died of cold,” the official said, adding that Chdra was and his family was also informed of his death.

Earlier this month, another man was found dead in Nainital with police suspecting that he too died of freezing temperature in Lake Town.

Title: AIADMK wins Kovilpatti union chairman post amid DMK protest
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Tuticorin: Drama and tense moments prevailed at the Kovilpatti panchayat union on Thursday after the additional director (panchayat) and returning officer, Umashankar declared AIADMK’s ward 3 member S Kasthuri as the winner of the indirect election for the post of chairperson amidst protest from the DMK led by Tuticorin MP Kanimozhi.

However, the indirect election for other posts had to be called off as the mandatory minimum requirement of 50% of the directly elected ward members (10 out of 19) did not take part and boycotted to show their protest to the election officials, accusing them of misusing power and colluding with the ruling party to declare Kasthuri as chairperson.

Of the 19 wards in Kovilpatti union where direct election was held on December 30, 2019, DMK won eight seats, followed by AIADMK (5), independents (4) and the CPI and DMDK one each. Indirect election for the post of chairman and vice-chairman could not be conducted on January 11 as returning officer S Jayaseelan was hospitalised due to cardiac arrest.

On Thursday, DMK’s member from ward 9 M Poomari and AIADMK’s Kasthuri were in the fray. The poll began around 10.30am and by 11.15am Umashankar declared Kasthuri as winner 10 votes against the nine got by DMK.

Agitated by this, the DMK ward members staged a protest there and were forcibly removed from the meeting hall by the police. Led by MP Kanimozhi, the 10 DMK supporting ward members staged a blockade on the Pasuvanthanai Road. They refused to take part in the indirect poll for the vice-chairperson’s post in the afternoon.

Around 4pm Kasthuri assumed office as union chairman in the presence of information and publicity minister Kadambur C Raju. Heavy police deployment was made to avert law and order issues. Riot control vehicle was also brought to the spot and barricades were put up to keep the situation under check.

DMK cadre Saravanan and his mother Lakshmi doused themselves with fuel to attempt self-immolation over the turn of events and were stopped by the police.

Title: Pune: Engineer loses Rs 1.18 lakh in bid to buy 2-wheeler on e-com site
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Warje police have booked three men on the charges of cheating a 21-year-old engineer from Karvenagar to the tune of Rs 1.18 lakh by promising him to sell a second-hand motorcycle in May 2019.

The engineer, who works with a private company in Kothrud , lodged a complaint with the Warje police on Wednesday.

Police said the victim ran a search on an e-commerce website for a second-hand motorcycle and came across an advertisement which said that a man from Gujarat wanted to sell his motorcycle.

The victim called up the phone number mentioned in the advertisement.

According to the first information report, a man who answered the phone informed him that he was in the Army and posted in Gujarat. He said he wanted to sell his motorcycle as he had been transferred to a far-off location.

The suspect then shared the photographs of the motorcycle with the engineer.

The police said the victim liked the motorcycle and decided to go ahead with the deal. The suspect asked him to transfer Rs 10,000 on his Unified Payment Interface (UPI) as an initial payment. The victim immediately transferred the money from his UPI app.

In the next two days, the suspect kept on demanding money from him under various pretexts such as insurance, courier insurance, courier and other fees. In just two days, the victim transferred a collective sum of Rs 1.18 lakh.

The suspects promised to send the motorcycle to him and then stopped answering his call altogether. After waiting for a couple of months, the victim realised that he had been duped. He approached the Warje police and lodged a complaint.

In December last year, a Nashik resident was arrested by the city police for duping several people on the pretext of selling his scooter and then stealing the vehicle from buyers using a duplicate key after receiving money from them.

The man would post advertisements on an e-commerce website to sell his scooter.

Title: Delhi shooting sparks safety concern at city sit-in spots
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

KOLKATA: Protesters at various sit-ins have expressed their concern over the firing at Jamia Millia students by a gunman on Thursday and expressed anxiety on the safety of the demonstrators in Kolkata. Many of them went into a hurdle soon after the news to review security at the sit-in spots.

There are at least five sit-in spots in Kolkata and Howrah — including the ones at Park Circus, Ekbalpore, Zakaria Street, Hogg Street and Pilkhana — where thousands have been sitting on round-the-clock vigil, demanding a complete repeal of the amended citizenship law.

“We condemn the cowardly act of firing on the students of Jamia Milia. Several attempts are being made to derail the entire movement that has so far been peaceful,” said a core member of the organizing team at Park Circus Maidan. “The incident has also forced us to rethink the security at Park Circus. Anybody who identifies with the cause is welcome, so it is difficult to scan every entrant,” he added.

Currently, there are 200 volunteers who taking care of different aspects, including security, cleaning, distributing food and chalking out the schedule. Several cops are posted inside and outside the park through the day. “We will be more vigilant and increase the number of volunteers,” an organizer said.

The attack in Delhi was the talking point among the participants at almost all the sit-ins across the city. “It is an attempt to instigate the students at Jamia Milia and JNU and those protesting peacefully at Shaheen Bagh. In the last few days, a section of politicians have made several unpleasant remarks and even issued threats,” said Ijaz Wadud, a businessman in central Kolkata.

At Nawab Ali Park in Ekbalpore, too, the organizers have decided to review the security at the sit-in spot. They have also cautioned the protesters not to get provoked by anybody. “Hundreds of women and children come here everyday. We cannot compromise with their safety,” said Arshad Parvez Khan , one of the organizers.

At Hogg Street, the sit-in spot is cordoned off with guard rails and several cops have been deployed since it is in the midst of a very busy pocket. In Zakaria Street, too, cops are posted round the clock.

Title: Update voters’ lists: Botcha to officials
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: State minister for municipal administration and urban planning, Botcha Satyanarayana , announced on Thursday that the preparations for municipal elections in the state were underway. During a video-conference session with municipal officials here, the minister said that the elections were proposed to be held in February.

During the video conference the minister for municipal administration and urban planning instructed officials to implement all government programmes thoroughly and ensure that the incomplete housing projects are taken up under TIDCO and completed on war-footing.

Urging officials to work hard and make sure the government’s programmes reach the people, the minister instructed officials to fill up ward volunteer and secretary vacancies immediately. Botcha added that from next month the volunteers would go from door to door to provide pensions to beneficiaries.

The minister also instructed the officials to update the voters’ list and publicly announce the updated list in every ward. He added that any objections raised would be addressed by the electoral registration officers (EROs).

Title: Man strangled to death by brother, mother
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: A 26-year-old man along with help from his mother strangled his younger brother over a monetary dispute in Vandiyur in Madurai in the early hours of Thursday. The Anna Nagar police have registered a case under IPC Section 302- punishment for murder and arrested Yasser Arafat, and his mother Kabiba Begam. The deceased has been identified as Azaruddin, 22. According to police, Arafat and Azaruddin, on Wednesday night had a quarrel over a money transaction. The quarrel turned murkier. Neighbours intervened and stopped the fight. Police said the two went to sleep late in the night. Arafat and Begam woke up at around 2am and strangled him using a towel. Neighbours came to know about it and alerted the local police. tnn

Title: Nashik is coldest at 7.9°C as northerly winds chill Maharashtra, warmer days ahead
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Night and day temperatures have dipped significantly in the state as forecast by India Meteorological Department (IMD) earlier this week.On Thursday, the minimum temperature in Shivajinagar fell to 11°C while Lohegaon recorded a minimum temperature of 12°C on Thursday.The temperatures in the two locations were among the lowest for Pune this winter. The season this year has been recording high night temperatures which have mostly been around 15°C or more.Day temperatures have also plunged 1 to 2 degrees below the normal in the state, and lower than 30°C in many parts.The lowest minimum temperature on Thursday in Maharashtra was recorded in Nashik at 7.9°C, followed by Jalgaon and Ahmednagar at 8.5°C and 9.7°C, respectively.The spell may be short-lived. Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune told TOI that on Friday morning, there might be a slight rise in minimum temperatures but some stations could still record temperatures below 10 degrees celsius. The minimum temperature in Pune is unlikely to go below 10°C on Friday.“Cold northerly winds began to penetrate partially uninterrupted in the state on Thursday, especially over north Maharashtra, which is why Jalgaon and Nashik recorded single digit night temperatures. But from Friday afternoon, the wind regime may start changing to the easterly flow, causing a gradual rise in the minimum temperatures till February 3,” Kashyapi added.From February 1 to 3, a cyclonic circulation in the lower atmospheric level is likely to form over Madhya Maharashtra and Konkan, which will block the northerly wind flow till February 4.“This system will also result in a slight moisture incursion mainly from the Bay of Bengal and also Arabian Sea, causing partly clouding during the night time and early morning. Night clouding is usually associated with higher than normal night or minimum temperatures,” Kashyapi added.

Title: Beware of being duped by Nigerian fraudsters: Visakhapatnam cops
Content:
Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Be careful of the friends you make on social networking sites and believing the promises they make, for on the other side might be a Nigerian fraudster looking to dupe you of your hard-earned savings. Following the arrest of four Nigerians from New Delhi by the cybercrime department of Visakhapatnam city police, the police is looking to spread this message to port city residents.“Opening fake accounts on social networking sites, befriending someone, gaining their trust over the years and then duping the person is nothing new for these Nigerians fraudsters. They follow a typical modus operandi,” a police official said.The modus operandi of these fraudsters is simple. The fraudsters become friends with a person and stay in touch with them online for a few months. Once they earn the person’s confidence and trust, the fraudsters make the victims a lucrative offer and once the latter is is ready to accept the offer, the fraudsters ask the victims for money to ‘convince’ them that the victim is serious. Once the fraudsters get the money, they just disappear.“The offer varies from person to person, depending on what can actually convince the victim. The fraudster sometimes tells the victim they will transfer money as gift. Or, they might tell the victim that they want to strike a lucrative business deal,” the police official added.Once the victim is convinced, the fraudsters ask them for money on a different pretext. “They might call pretending to be a customs or RBI official and ask for money as ‘tax’ to clear their gifts. The victim falls for it as they have decided to transfer the money as an investment before receiving as huge sum of money as promised by the fraudsters,” the official added.Police said that such crimes can only be stopped if there is awareness among users of social networking sites, because once the crime is committed it becomes difficult to zero in on the culprits. This is because the fraudsters normally don’t target people from the city they are operating from.Even if the police makes an arrest, it becomes difficult to recover the stolen amount. By the time the arrests are made, the fraudsters send the money to their relatives in Nigeria through a hawala racket.A senior official explained that there are a few wholesalers in south India who export commodities to Nigeria, which the fraudsters use to transport the money. When importers in Nigeria needs to pay money to wholesalers in India, they pay the money to the fraudsters’ relatives in Nigeria. The fraudsters in India then pay the duped amount to the Indian wholesaler.“Earlier investigations revealed that a lot such transactions take place through accounts opened in nationalised banks branches in Kerala. But it is really impossible to recover those amounts,” an official said.

Title: EC asks Arvind Kejriwal to explain mohalla pitch
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: The Election Commission of India (ECI) has issued a notice to chief minister Arvind Kejriwal for making a promise at the Tis Hazari court complex on January 13 to open a mohalla clinic there if land is provided. The remarks, made after the model code of conduct came into force on January 6, have been verified by the chief electoral officer (CEO) of Delhi.The Election Commission has found Kejriwal in violation of a provision that prohibits ministers and other authorities from making any promise of construction of roads, provision of drinking water facilities etc. Part VII of the code says the party in power, whether at the Centre or the state concerned, should ensure that no cause is given for any complaint that it has used its official position for the election campaign.In a complaint to the commission, BJP member Neeraj alleged that Kejriwal, as the chief minister, had announced at a gathering of advocates organised by Delhi Bar Association for Makar Sankranti and Lohri celebrations. “If land could be provided on the premises (of the complex), a mohalla clinic will be set up,” Neeraj quoted the chief minister as saying.Kejriwal has been asked to explain his position before 5pm on Friday. If no explanation is submitted by then, the poll panel will take a decision without any further information to the AAP convener. An AAP functionary said the party had received the notice and would send a reply within the deadline.The chief minister had reportedly said the AAP government was ready to set up mohalla clinics in all courts if space was available and also promised gyms. “I hope that this time I will get the positive support from you,” he had been quoted as saying in the Delhi CEO’s report submitted to ECI.On January 6, the dates for the Delhi assembly elections were announced, immediately bringing into effect the model code of conduct across the city.

Title: Jamia News: Shooter was livestreaming just before attack at Jamia
Content:
The person who opened fire at Jamia students (PTI)
