NEW DELHI: On the morning of January 30, the youth who opened fire around 1.30 pm at students gathered for a march in Jamia Millia Islamia wrote on Facebook : “I’m about to bring them azaadi”. And “You may have heard of tandav, now you will see…”.Not just that, he livestreamed a video of himself walking around the Jamia neighbourhood before he took aim. The video had 16,000 views. A Facebook friend posted: “You are on the news and I recognised you. Serve them azaadi in a fitting manner.” Comments included several congratulatory messages.The display photo on one of his Facebook profiles, in which the joining date is July 2018, shows him kissing a sword, the hilt wrapped in a red cloth with gold trims, with a saffron cloth around his neck. His posts are interspersed liberally with emojis of triangular red flags and flexed biceps.The youth’s posts read as if he was on a suicide mission: “On my last journey (antim yatra), wrap me in saffron and let there be calls of Jai Shri Ram.” Another post at the same time read “Game over, Shaheen Bagh”. Another says, “Chandan bhai, this revenge is for you.” The reference seems to be to Chandan Gupta, a 22-year-old killed in a Tiranga Yatra in Kasganj, UP, in 2018.His posts of the day earlier also reflect his thinking. “Some people say preaching Hindutva Hindutva will not feed, so listen you xxxx, if you are alive to earn bread alone there is no difference between you and a dog,” wrote the shooter, who TOI is not naming since he is a minor going by his Class X marksheet.On January 28, when a gunman was overpowered at Shaheen Bagh, this young man posted at 3.20pm: “Dhandabagh, tera baap aaya.” Earlier that day, at 1.36pm, he had reacted to a post by an Updesh Rana, who runs a private Facebook page called Youth Brigade, which has over 1.25 lakh followers. The rules for members state they should only talk about “Hindu Samaj and nationalism.” The January 27, 10.50pm, post by Rana was: “In a week, Shaheen Bagh should fold up, or else one lakh people will squat on dharna at the very place to evict you. What we say, we have done so far (sic).”The gunman disagreed: “By then administration itself would have evicted them, EC will evict them, what’s the point of going there later? Why no action so far????? If I had half your followers I would have made Shaheen Bagh Jallianwalah Bagh by now (sic).”He seems to have made up his mind by the evening. On January 28 at 9pm, he announced: “Attention! Till the 31st, do not ignore my posts.”After the lone-wolf attack on January 30, his Facebook profile became off-limits for public viewing, but not before screenshots had been captured on various media and online platforms.He also has an earlier Facebook profile, by the same name but with a younger photo, where he associates himself with Bajrang Dal. He posted pictures of him in Dal meetings with friends, as a teenager with a rifle and on March 30, 2018, of a Bajrang Dal rally in Jewar, his hometown, in which he participated. His profile said, “I am member of (BJP, Bajrang Dal or RSS)” and that he lived in Noida.

Title: Pune: Cops trace ex-serviceman to Delhi wedding venue
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 54-year-old retired Army subedar, who was on the run after being booked nine months ago in a Rs19 lakh cheating case , was arrested by a city police team from a wedding ceremony venue in New Delhi on Wednesday.

Police said Shailendra Mahirprasad Gupta, a resident of NIBM Road in Kondhwa , was facing charges of duping a wholesale pharmacy shopowner in Sadsahiv Peth by representing himself as an Army officer and offering help to the latter for securing a medicine supply order from the Delhi Cantonment and the Directorate General of Army Course.

The Vishrambaug police were searching for Gupta after the shopowner, Mahendra Pannalal Pitaliya (50) of Bibvewadi-Kondhwa road, lodged an FIR against him in March last year. Acting on a tip-off, senior inspector Dadasaheb Chudappa, sub-inspector A I Pathan and other team members flew to Delhi and arrested Gupta from the wedding venue. He was brought to Pune on Thursday and produced before a court that ordered his remand in police custody till February 3.

Pathan told TOI, “We had visited Gupta’s house many times in the past. But he was not in the city. We received a tip-off four days ago that he was supposed to attend a ‘Haldi’ ceremony in Faridabad. But he did not attend this ceremony. We came to know later that he was to attend the wedding ceremony of a close relative in Delhi.”

The policemen went to Delhi and prepared themselves to attend the wedding ceremony. “We wanted to show that we were not policemen. If we would have gone there in uniform, Gupta might have been alerted. The policemen dressed up nattily for the wedding function and reached the venue. We found Gupta there and nabbed him,” Pathan said.

According to the FIR filed in March last year, Gupta told Pitaliya that he had “good contacts” in the Delhi Cantonment and the Directorate General Army Course, New Delhi. He told the shopowner that the two establishments needed 30 bottles of a costly medicine. Gupta told Pitaliya that he could help him with the registration formalities.

Title: Squatters removed, Sealdah gets swanky food court
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

KOLKATA: Passengers passing through Sealdah station can now enjoy affordable meals at a swanky 1,911 square feet two-storey joint run by a major food chain of the city under the aegis of Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC). The unique food court was inaugurated on Thursday in the presence of senior IRCTC and Eastern Railway (ER) officials.

“It was a challenge for us. The space in the south section of the station was encroached by some illegal occupants. We had never expected that it would turn out so good in the end. Pre-fabricated structures were used to construct the two-storey building. The company that finally agreed to build this food court also took up the challenge and decided to create something unique. Passengers can enjoy all kinds of vegetarian meals and snacks there,” said Debasish Chandra, group general manager (east), IRCTC. The food court came up after the railway authorities realised the demands of nearly two million passengers using Sealdah station daily. Most of them are suburban passengers who may stop for a quick bite while long-distance passengers can stay longer for a meal before starting their journey. Passengers of the trains like the Darjeeling Mail and Padatik Express , which don’t have on-board catering facilities, also needed a proper place to pick up dinner. A major concern was pricing and the vendor was convinced to keep rates down.

“As this is a unique venture, the company doesn’t want to look only at profits. They have offered food at ‘factory prices’. There are also some interesting offers for packaged items sold on the ground floor. We have ensured safety and hygiene. The first floor is for diners. The food is not cooked at the station to prevent fires, rather it’s brought there by the vendor from its kitchens elsewhere. Only heating is allowed. Quality of food will also be checked routinely,” said another IRCTC official.

Title: Ragging rears its ugly head in Srikakulam med college
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A case of ragging came to light on Thursday at Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS), Srikakulam , where two senior medical students allegedly harassed and beat up two juniors with cricket stumps.

Although the incident took place on January 24 and 25, it came to light on Thursday after the two students who had been allegedly ragged, accompanied by their parents, lodged a complaint against the seniors at Two-Town police station in Srikakulam.

The complainants have alleged that two students—Rahul Roy (final year MBBS student) and Nagesh Kumar (house surgeon) assaulted them—Nitesh Kumar and Akshay Kumar (both second-year MBBS students) with cricket stumps.

Nitesh and Akshay said that they had a minor dispute with some senior students during a party in the first week of January. Following the altercation, senior students Rahul and Nagesh began harassing them, alleged the complainants.

Complainants said that they informed the RIMS authorities about the incident seeking action against the two seniors, but the authorities allegedly did not take action and only tried to pacify them. Upset, the complainants— one of whom belong to the SC community while another to the ST community lodged a complaint with the police.

Speaking to TOI, PV Ramana, inspector of Two-Town police station said that the police have registered cases against the accused—Rahul and Nagesh—under the SC/ST Prevention of Atrocities Act, AP Prohibition of Ragging Act and Sections 322, 324, 342 R/W 34 of the IPC.

“Our preliminary investigation has revealed that a small dispute led to the seniors assaulting the juniors,” said Ramana.

The juniors have further complained that the seniors have been harassing them in various ways, including asking them to get alcohol and cigarettes, according to the police.

Inspector Ramana further said, “We have sent the complainants to the government hospital for medical examination as injury marks were found on their backs. We are investigating the case from various angles and have also visited the RIMS campus to ascertain the facts.” He added: “Once our investigation is complete, we will take action against the two seniors (accused).”

According to the police, the punishment under the Anti-Ragging Act includes suspension from college, while the jail term depends on the severity of the ragging. The police also plan to appeal to principals and managements of colleges to improve the functioning of anti-ragging committees.

Title: Drunk CAA supporter beaten up by angry anti-CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: During an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protest held at Bypass Road in the city, a man shouting slogans supporting CAA while in an inebriated state was beaten up by protesters.

The drunk man identified to be an executive member of the trade union wing of AIADMK, Anna Tholirsanga Peravai, reportedly barged into the anti-CAA rally on his bike, shouting ‘Bharath Mata ki Jai’ and several slogans in favour of CAA. Angry protesters beat him up after which he was removed by the police.

A massive anti-CAA rally with the formation of a 3-km long human chain at Bypass Road in Madurai was organized on Thursday. Various Muslim organizations took part in the rally which saw participation of around 1,000 people seeking removal of the CAA. The protesters held various creative placards and shouted slogans against the CAA.

Tamil film director Ameer Sultan also took part in the protest. The director observed that if the government continues to be stubborn in implementation of CAA, the protests won’t stop and will only intensify.

Title: Protesters take to poetry to link the country by one common thread
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

When power leads man toward arrogance, poetry reminds him of his limitations. When power narrows the area of man’s concern, poetry reminds him of the richness and diversity of existence.

— John F Kennedy

People protesting against the amended citizenship law in the city are using poetry to show their resilience and express their resistance and defiance. People carrying posters having couplets written on them in Bengali, English, Hindis and Urdu has become a common sight at the numerous protest sites in the city and beyond. Even social media is flushed with small yet catchy poems and couplets.

Students reciting poetry and others joining in can be heard at any of the several processions that have been organised to protest against the CAA and the NRC. While many recite iconic lines like ‘Lazim hai hum bhi dekhenge’, others have coined their own couplets, poems or shayaris to express the situation and show their defiance. Many are also using poetry to inspire others to join the movement.

“Such oppression has a strong cultural reaction. At times of such unrest and unease in the country, poetry does make us calm and make people realise the injustice being meted out to them. This is a phenomenon that has been around for several centuries. Several slogans or political poetry strive to rhyme and are used as metaphors to be used as a medium for voicing protests,” said Barnali Mukherjee, who teaches English literature in a city college.

Businessman Asif Iqbal has written a Bengali song titled ‘Amar Bangla’ that talks about the diversity and inclusiveness that exists in Bengal — ‘Sara prithvi ghure dekhlam amar bangla kothao pai ni, Oei mishit kothao paini, oei hanshi kothao payi nei’ (I travelled the entire world but did not find any other place like Bengal, Neither did I find the sweetness nor that smile). “The prevailing political situation inspired me to write the song. People of Bengal have decide to resist fascism,” said Iqbal.

Soon after protests against CAA broke out in December last year, comedian Varun Grover had released a poem ‘Kaagaz Nahi Dikhayenge’ (we won’t show the papers). The Bengali version of the poem was recited by several Bengali actors and other artistes, which vent viral on social media.

Many students have been spending couplets to portray the situation in the country. They either write them on colourful posters or use them to raise slogans. Inspiration is also being drawn from the popular culture so that it resonates with the youth. “We are using the power of social media to reach out to more and more people with our message. When the message is articulated through poetry, it has good traction,” said Ujjal Ghosh, a student of Jadavpur University.

Title: Maharashtra: Roses may turn out to be the most extravagant gift this Valentine’s Day
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Rose prices are likely to soar before February 14

PUNE: The extended rainy season last year, coupled with high humidity and fungal diseases, has resulted in 30%-40% drop in cut roses production this year. The drop may also be witnessed during the Valentine’s Day period and thereafter, rose growers stressed.

Vinay Shinde, who owns a floriculture farm in Talegaon, said that the dip in production of cut roses has been to the tune of 30%-40% from June last year up till now due to severe rains in 2019. “There may also be some shortage of roses in the domestic market around February 10-12 not only due to a fall in production, but also early harvests due to a warm winter. This may cause an increase in rose prices around V-Day,” he said.

Further, first advance estimates of 2019-20 from the state horticulture department have revealed that cut rose production is likely to fall to 12,000 metric tonne in this crop year from 37,000 metric tonne in 2018-19. However, officials also said that the latest estimates are yet to include production data from some districts in the state.

Praveen Sharma, president of the Indian Society of Floriculture Professionals, Talegaon Dabhade, told TOI that in 2019, Maharashtra farmers experienced excessive rainy days as compared to 2018, with approximately 15% fall in sunny days. “The sunshine and temperature play a crucial role in flower production. There is an overall drop in cut roses production this year by 10%-15%. Also, due to a warmer January, some farmers have received early flush by a week. Usually, V-Day production begins from January 25 till February 12. Due to warmer days, the production has arrived from January 20 in some cases,” said Sharma.

Avinash Jadhav, a rose exporter based in Pune, said that in general, there has been a 30%-40% drop in qualitative production of cut roses despite being grown in greenhouses. This may affect supplies during V-Day. “The rough winds and heavy rains affected qualitative production of roses even in greenhouses,” he said.

Jaysingh Hulawale, a rose grower in Maval region said there has been a 25% drop in production as compared to last year. “In some cases, harvests have also happened early due to warmer temperatures this winter,” he said.

Title: Indirect polls postponed again in a few local bodies
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Indirect elections to some of the rural local bodies in the southern districts were once again postponed on Thursday citing lack of quorum, while in other places the AIADMK bagged some of the coveted posts.

The state election commission had announced that the indirect elections to 335 posts, which were pending, would be conducted on January 30. Sivaganga district panchayat chairman election was once again postponed. After the direct elections to various rural local bodies, indirect elections to the posts of chairman and vice-chairman of panchayat unions and district panchayats were held on January 11. But, the indirect elections to the district panchayat chairman and vice-chairman of Sivaganga and 26 panchayat union chairmen and vice-chairmen were not held. There is a contest between the DMK and the AIADMK for the Sivaganga district panchayat. It is a 16-member district panchayat council in which the DMK and the AIADMK has eight seats each. On Thursday only the DMK members turned up for elections leading to the postponement of the election.

Similarly, indirect elections to the posts of chairman and vice-chairman of the Thirupuvanam panchayat union was postponed by Sivaganga district collector J Jayakanthan citing law and order issues, as some of the elected councillors had sought police protection fearing threats to their lives. In the Narikudi panchayat union, clashes erupted between the parties where Panchavarnam contested on behalf of the AIADMK and Kaleeswari the DMK.

Title: Man gets 20 years of jail for raping daughter
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

Title: Vidya Bal, strong voice for women’s rights, dies at 84
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The activist with her Nari Samata Manch team (above) and with friends Sadhana Dadhich and Suniti SR, two years... Read More

PUNE: Vidya Bal ’s crusade for women's rights and against oppressive practices began when she was around 40 years old. It continued for four decades, and almost till her last breath.

The veteran social activist and feminist writer, who turned 84 on January 12, passed away at a private nursing home in Pune on Thursday. Faced with several health issues, she took comfort in palliative care. She is survived by a daughter and two sons.

Scores of activists were at Vaikunth crematorium for the last rites. Deputy chairperson of the legislative council Neelam Gorhe was present. Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar sent condolence messages.

This year, Vidyatai had pledged to fight for euthanasia, the practice of intentionally ending life to relieve the pain and suffering, her close friends and associates said.

As the writer of several books and the editor of a well-read magazine, Bal raised many issues concerning women. Through PILs that ranged from the demand for good toilets for women in every ward or a law that allowed entry to all in all religious places, her positive spirit guided her, her close friends said.

Forty years ago, Bal came across the deaths of two women due to domestic violence. She formed Nari Samata Manch to address the problems of middle-class housewives whose issues never came out in the open.

“Vidyatai’s courage and hope to bring about a change prompted us to start the endeavour in unchartered waters,’’ her friend Sadhana Dadhich, who now heads the forum, said. “Tai (as she was fondly called) worked right through, till she was well. She never believed in hierarchy,” she added.

Preeti Karmarkar, who has worked with the manch for 20 years, said she was a stalwart and unique in addressing several women’s issues. Her editorial pieces in her magazine, Miloon Saryajani, which she founded in 1989, reflected social milieu. Her writings in Stree, another magazine, in 1964 and her short stint at the Pune division of Akashwani in the late 1950s led her to take up several issues, Karmarkar said.

She added to her work with each passing year, social activist Asim Sarode who has been associated with her for over three decades, said.

“She was not afraid to face challenges. Her discussions on euthanasia made death less intimidating,’’ Sarode said.

Her journalistic pieces on the problems and issues women faced, especially in the rural areas, were powerful, yet sensitive, another friend Suniti SR said. “Along with Medha Patkar , Tai addressed various issues as part of Narmada Bachao Andolan,” she added.

In her work for gender equality, Bal set up a centre for men’s issues called Speak Out and a marriage bureau Saath Saath where men and women could have open discussions to find out their compatibility.

Activist Kiran Moghe said Vidyatai’s passing away was a personal loss. “All women activists sought her guidance and her campaign for equal rights for both men and women will never be forgotten,”she added.

Maharashtra Andhashraddha Nirmulan Samiti president Avinash Patil said she has left behind a void. “She was a feminist with a practical approach and united all of us to work with her for women’s empowerment,” he added.

Title: Pune: 3 travellers test negative for novel coronavirus infection
Content:
Representative image

Three from Kasturba hospital discharged

PUNE: Throat swab samples of three travellers isolated at Naidu hospital tested negative for novel coronavirus infection on Thursday, allaying fears of the contagion reaching the city.“These travellers had recently returned from China and were isolated on Tuesday and Wednesday after they developed minor illness. Their throat swab samples tested negative for the novel coronavirus on Thursday. Earlier, two travellers had tested negative for the disease,” Ramchandra Hankare, chief of the health department at Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) said.He said the throat swab samples of the five isolated travellers would be retested at the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in the next three days days. “They will be discharged if they test negative again,” Hankare said.A total of 4,846 passengers returning from China and other affected countries have been screened at the Mumbai’s Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport since January 18. Of them, 28 travellers, who are residents of Pune, Mumbai, Pimpri Chinchwad, Kalyan, Vasai, Virar and Nanded, are under the surveillance for the next 28 days.Three travellers quarantined for suspected coronavirus last week at Kasturba hospital at Chinchpokli in Mumbai were discharged on Thursday after they tested negative for the infection twice.Besides, two more individuals with travel history from China were admitted to the hospital on Thursday, taking the count of isolated patients in Mumbai to five. Overall, 11 patients are quarantined across the state, including five from Pune and one from Nanded.The discharged patients included a 31-year-old woman from Nalasopara, a 36-year-old man from Kalyan and a 65-year-old British national.

Title: Mining companies can start work in 8 days, says CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
CM Pramod Sawant (ANI Photo)

PANAJI: Following the Supreme Court order on Thursday allowing mining companies in the state to export the iron ore extracted before March 15, 2018, chief minister Pramod Sawant said that mining activities can start within eight days.Stating that this is the first time a judgment has come in favour of mining in Goa, Sawant said, “I welcome the Supreme Court order on behalf of Goa.”The chief minister said that now mining companies should re-employ retrenched workers and pay full wages to those whose salaries were slashed due to mining closure.Mining activities can start within eight days as the companies already have buyers for the ore, the chief minister told reporters.He said that this order allows the mining companies to export iron ore stocked at plots and mining jetties till June 1, 2020. “As per state government records, over nine million tonnes of iron ore is lying at jetties and plots,” Sawant said.Sources said that iron ore of grade 48 to 54 is lying inside mining leases. Most of the ore would be exported to China. Since there is no extraction of ore, only truck, barge and machinery owners would benefit, they said.He said that the government will not get any direct revenue as the mining companies have already paid royalty, but it is important for the state to start mining activities. “Small amount of revenue would be generated in the form of transport permits and others,” the CM said.“After mining companies complete all formalities they will be allowed to handle the ore. In the interest of the people, the state government will cooperate with the mining companies,” Sawant said. He also said that the mining companies will get the entire mining season to export the ore.Chief minister said that there is a good international market for iron ore and there is a scope for export of iron ore. “Most of the mining companies will export the ore and it will help accelerate the economy,” he said.Sawant said that they were hoping for positive judgments in other mining-related cases too.Mining in Goa came to a halt in March 2018 after the Supreme Court quashed the second renewal of 88 mining leases.

Title: Maharashtra: Dog breeders steal Lhasa Apso, booked
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A case of theft was registered against two dog breeders for allegedly stealing a Lhasa Apso from a farmhouse at Nimbalkarwadi in Katraj. The offence was registered at the Bharati Vidyapeeth police station on Wednesday.

The Lhasa Apso breed of dogs is considered to be among the most expensive. The stolen dog was said to be worth Rs2.80 lakh.

The trainer of the dog, Sachin Maduraj Anthony (36), has lodged an FIR with the Bharati Vidyapeeth police. According to the complaint, the theft happened on Tuesday between 4.30pm and 7.30pm.

Anthony told TOI that he had kept the Lhasa Apso along with 15 other dogs of different breeds at the farmhouse at Nimbalkarwadi in Katraj. “I also have a kennel there,” he stated.

The complainant said that on Tuesday a lady living near the farmhouse told him that two men sneaked into the farmhouse and fled with the Lhasa Apso. “The lady knew their names. She was also aware that the duo were dog breeders since they had come to Nimbalkarwadi with a dog cage a few months ago,” Anthony said.

The dog trainer searched for the Lhasa Apso at different spots on Wednesday and later in the night lodged an FIR with the Bharati Vidyapeeth police station. “The dog was 2.4 years old and was of golden colour,” Anthony said.

About a fortnight ago, the Lhasa Apso had won a prize in the dog show organized in the city. “I am worried about the health of the dog,” Anthony said.

Sub-inspector Mahendra Patil said that the police are yet to make any arrests in the case. “We are investigating the case from all angles,” he said.

Title: Fire breaks out at mattress factory in Roorkee village, no casualty reported
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Roorkee: A small-scale factory of quilt and mattress manufacturing in a village near Roorkee was gutted after a massive fire broke out on Thursday evening. According to the police, the fire was caused due to electric short-circuit.

The incident took place in Padli Gujjar village. Two fire tenders were deployed to the spot and it took them more than two hours to douse the flames.

At the time of the incident, five workers were asleep inside the factory, but there were no reports of human loss or injuries. The exact loss incurred is yet to be calculated, but it is being assumed that the goods destroyed were worth Rs 15 lakh.

“Since huge combustible materials like cloths, cotton, etc., were in the factory, the fire rapidly caught spread inside the building,” said Rajesh Sah, in-charge of Gangnahar police station.

Meanwhile, a dejected owner, Abid Ali, said, “I don’t know the exact loss I incurred in this fire, but my factory has now been reduced to ashes.”

Title: Dissertations on housing designs to be awarded
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The housing commissioner under the state housing department has announced cash awards for dissertations/project reports on weather-resilient house construction techniques by civil engineering and architecture students.

An amount of Rs 50,000 each will be given to selected dissertations on the topic ‘weather-resilient housing designs for Kerala’ to be submitted by final year students of MTech/M Arch/PhD courses in engineering colleges in the state, said an official release issued here on Tuesday.

The completed dissertations or project reports (two copies), along with a letter of attestation from respective principal/department head, will be accepted for consideration till 5pm on February 10.

An expert committee will assess the proposals thus received for the awards.

The proposals should be sent to the housing commissioner, KSHB Building , Santhi Nagar, Thiruvananthapuram – 695001, phone: 0471-2330720, e-mail: housingcommissioner@gmail.com.

Title: Rathod pitches for Tipeshwar tiger reserve; proposal ready
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: With notifying Tipeshwar wildlife sanctuary as a tiger reserve being one of the priorities of forest minister Sanjay Rathod, a proposal has been readied by extending adjoining forest area of the sanctuary.

Tipeshwar, 180km from Nagpur in Pandharkawda tehsil of Yavatmal district, is currently 149sqkm. Sources said an additional 40sqkm adjoining reserve forest area with no villages will be added, making it 189sqkm. There is already existing tiger population in the forest area proposed to be extended. There are 10-12 tigers in the sanctuary.

The proposal has been forwarded to APCCF (wildlife) HS Hooda’s office at Nagpur. Hooda did not respond to TOI’s calls.

NTCA guidelines say that to maintain viable populations of tigers and life support ecological systems in natural wilderness areas, a minimum inviolate space of 800-1,000 sqkm should be maintained as inviolate area to support a viable population in tiger landscapes, based on tiger life history parameters, territory sizes and population viability analysis.

Citing this norm, state’s wildlife wing is reluctant to declare Tipeshwar a tiger reserve, despite a demand for the last five years from wildlife buffs, conservationists, and, more importantly, politicians.

The first proposal was pushed in 2014-15 by notifying same area as reserve. In 2016, to make the tiger reserve viable, then field director of Pench MS Reddy mooted a proposal by combining Painganga sanctuary (425sqkm) and Tipeshwar (149sqkm), making it 574sqkm. This is the third proposal, which has added adjoining forests.

“Tiger reserve issue had come up in review meeting with forest minister after he assumed charge. Though officials explained Tipeshwar was too small to be declared a reserve, the minister asked to extend the sanctuary and wanted it done to benefit locals through Dr Shyamaprasasd Mukherjee Jan Van scheme, and boost tourism,” said sources close to the minister.

Earlier, ex-minister Sudhir Mungantiwar and local MLAs too favoured notifying Tipeshwar as a reserve. “While declaring any area a reserve, political will is necessary. When there is so much political support, why not declare it a tiger reserve? It will help enrich corridors to Kawal tiger reserve in Telangana and Painganga,” said Ramzan Virani, honorary wildlife warden.

“Tomorrow, it is possible the same forest area, which is to be added to the sanctuary, may get encroached upon or is diverted for some other purposes. Hence, we need to act positively,” Virani added.

Virani said the dispersal of male cub T1-C1 in June 2019 also underlines the importance of the sanctuary, and need for protecting its corridors and strengthening areas between Tipeshwar and Painganga. Earlier too, at least 3-4 tigers from the sanctuary dispersed to Telangana and Painganga.

A section of wildlife officials fear that the restrictions will be resented by people if the sanctuary is notified as a reserve. “Once declared a reserve, we will also have to create buffer zones as per NTCA guidelines,” they said.

They added the area is already being protected due to which tiger numbers have gone up. Declaring all tiger bearing areas as reserves doesn’t augur well, they said.

IMP BOX

1) Sanctuary Vs Tiger Reserve

* All rights of people in a national park/reserve must be settled, while in a sanctuary certain rights can be allowed

* Livestock grazing is prohibited in reserve but it can be allowed in a regulated manner in sanctuaries

* A sanctuary can up be upgraded to a reserve but a national park cannot be downgraded to a sanctuary

2) Present position: There are 6 tiger reserves in state — Tadoba-Andhari, Melghat, Bor, Pench, Sahyadri and Navegaon-Nagzira

3) Why Tiger Reserve?

Tiger is a top predator which is at the apex of the food chain and keeps the population of wild ungulates in check, thereby maintaining the balance between prey herbivores and the vegetation upon which they feed

4) Tipeshwar: It was declared a sanctuary in 1997. Spread in Kelapur and Ghatanji tehsils, it has support of forest minister Sanjay Rathod, BJP leaders Sudhir Mungantiwar, ex-MLA Raju Todsam, ex-MP Hansraj Ahir & Cong’s Vijay Darda

Title: CEO: Didn’t ask schools to hold special classes for Class VIII
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Madurai: Amid reports that the school education department has directed government and aided schools to hold special classes for class VIII students, in view of the upcoming board exams, Madurai district chief educational officer(CEO), R Swaminathan, cleared the air and said that that no such directions were given to schools.

Speaking to TOI, Swaminathan said that though the students need to be adequately prepared to face the exams, such classes would only result in increasing mental stress for students. “We have not asked for any special classes to be conducted nor has any circular been issued to us directing the same. Already normal classes are held for 7-8 hours in schools and an extra hour will lead to unnecessary pressure for students,” he said. Government school teachers welcomed the announcement saying that special classes would be a burden for the students. “Mandatory special class beyond school hours would be tough on the Class VIII students because of their young age. It won’t add to their productivity,” said the principal of a government middle school.

Many teachers said that they face many challenges while training Class VIII students for the board exams. The most prominent among their concerns is that students, who are used to writing exams term-wise as per the Continuous and Comprehensive Evaluation, now have to study the whole year’s portions. “Students will find it difficult. To be honest, some of the students had even thrown away their first term books after their first term exams as the announcement about the board exams only came later,” said a teacher.

Title: Human Chain in Delhi: Delhi Police stop 300 from forming human chain
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

CPM leaders and others, who were spared detention, managed to reach Rajghat and formed a human chain

NEW DELHI: A call to form human chains across the city to protest against Citizenship Amendment Act , National Register for Citizens and National Population Register on Thursday was disrupted as police detained most people in the gathering. Barring 15 people, the others were taken away by police. According to police , 300 people were detained.

Members of Left parties were spared detention and CPM leaders Prakash Karat, Brinda Karat and Sitaram Yechury, women’s rights activist Kavita Krishnan and others managed to reach Rajghat and form a human chain. They sang the national anthem at 5.17pm, the time when Mahatma Gandhi was shot dead in 1948.

Seema, a resident of Turkman Gate, said, “Jab jab sarkar darti hai, police ko aage karti hai (Whenever the government is scared, it puts police in front). We know we are not supposed to raise slogans, that is why we are standing here peacefully. In a democracy, it is our right to protest.”

Karat said, “We are here to remember Mahatma Gandhi, who was the symbol of Hindu-Muslim unity. This is the double standard of Amit Shah’s home ministry. On one hand, you are not filing an FIR against politicians indulging in hate speeches, while on the other you are not letting us even form a human chain.”

Around 2.8km from Rajghat, former JNU professor Kamal Mitra Chenoy and Delhi University teachers were detained at Delhi Gate. “They are taking us away without giving us a reason,” Chenoy told TOI, while being taken to a nearby police station.

About half an hour later, political activist Yogendra Yadav and senior lawyer Prashant Bhushan came with others holding the national flag. Sporting badges with “Hey Ram” written on them and holding the Constitution, they marched to Delhi Gate metro station, from where they were detained. However, at 5.17pm, despite being detained, they sang the national anthem. They were subsequently taken to a stadium in Hari Nagar.

“People with pistols are walking around freely, but those who hold the Constitution are being detained. This is the governance of the country. Ultimately, Godse will lose and Gandhi will win,” Yadav said.

However, people managed to form a small human chain at Jama Masjid and near Lal Qila.

Delhi Police said no permission was granted for forming a human chain. DCP (Central) MS Randhawa tweeted, “Some organisations applied for permission to form human chain in and around Rajghat. Their permissions have been denied as it is not a traditional route and the organisers have been informed. Organisers have been requested to apply for designated places like Jantar Mantar, Ramlila Maidan, etc.”

Title: Rival factions of Cong knock doors of national leadership
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Dehradun: A major discontent is brewing in the state Congress as seven out of its 11 MLAs plan to meet Congress chief Sonia Gandhi in the first week of February. The MLAs have blown the bugle against Indira Hridayesh and sought her removal from the post of leader of Opposition in the state assembly. On the other side, Congress state chief Pritam Singh, too, has sought time from Gandhi.

Though the senior members are reluctant to comment on the issue, insiders termed the ongoing tussle within the party as the outcome of the differences between former CM Harish Rawat and leader of Opposition Indira Hridayesh. In the last assembly session in December 2019, Congress MLAs Harish Dhami and Karan Mahra had accused the state leadership of ignoring Rawat in party events. However, the Rawat camp blew the bugle against Hridayesh, when Dhami’s name featured on the last slot in the 98-member list of state secretaries, which was announced recently. While other MLAs were included in the special invitee list of Congress committee, only Dhami featured in the list of secretaries.

“We are seven of us and are going to meet the party’s national leadership so that the facts and developments, which are going around in Uttarakhand come to their knowledge,” Dhami said, adding that the MLAs intend to meet the party chief in the first week of February. He claimed that a section of the party was being ignored for a long period, “but knows we will not tolerate it any longer”.

Ranikhet MLA Karan Mahra too has been vocal in extending solidarity with Rawat. “He is a former MP, ex-CM and presently AICC general secretary and party in-charge of Assam. Rawat is the most senior Congress member in the state and we need to respect him rather than ignoring and targeting him. Barring few party members, others are with Rawat on the issue.”

Meanwhile, Congress state chief Pritam Singh has sought time from party chief in the first week of February. “We have sent the list of state committee, but some changes were there at the last minute. I will definitely discuss the issue with our national leadership and inform about the present situation in the state.”

On the other side, Hridayesh maintained that the list was made public after the consultancy of all senior leaders. “Our state chief is going to meet party chief and the issue will be discussed,” she said.

Title: Snowfall, rain triggers landslide at China Peak, just few metres from HC
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nainital: Heavy snowfall coupled with rain in the past two days triggered a landslide at China Peak, also known as Naina Peak, in Mallital area of Nainital. Incidentally, the landslide happened just a few meters from the Uttarakhand high court building.

According to eye-witnesses, the incident happened on Wednesday evening when, in two separate instances, some parts of the peak fell in the area, causing a scare among people.

“I heard some noise near the mountain. When I turned towards it, I saw a part of the mountain falling. Within minutes another noise came from the direction and I saw some trees and sand falling near the high court," said Rajeev Dubey, a local.

The incident reminded several locals of a similar incident in the 1990s when a landslide had damaged both the high court building and the houses in which several judges now live.

Speaking to TOI, Nainital district magistrate (DM) Savin Bansal said he has constituted a team under the SDM. “We understand the security concerns of the people living in the area and therefore, a team has been constituted to inspect the causes for the landslide and security threats posed by the landslide. The team will present its report to us and necessary action will be taken after that,” he said.

Title: China-returned bizman 1st patient in GMCH special isolation ward
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: A 31-year-old city businessman, who had returned from China on January 6 and developed flu-like symptoms, was moved into a 7-bed quarantine ward at the Government Medical College and Hospital on Thursday.

The hospital swung into action with the special ward for suspected patients of novel Coronavirus (nCOv) after the man came there with the complaint. The patient is into car accessory business.

The hospital has also kept a section in Ward 25 ready for patients requiring treatment with serious viral infection.

“This patient was in Shanghai on business tour between December 26 and January 5. He was duly screened at the airports and was not found infected. As he developed flu-like symptoms now, he reported to us today,” said Dr Avinash Gawande, medical superintendent of GMCH.

The man, whose identity is being withheld, is showing the symptoms since last five days. This illness is generally due to viral infection. His samples have been sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune.

While doctors believe it is a “local infection”, the patient will remain in hospital till his reports arrive. Family-members of the patient stated he voluntarily decided to report to GMCH to keep the infection under control.

“The high dependency unit is ready at GMCH for such patients. There is no need to panic. People who have returned from China after January 1 and developed flu like symptoms should report to us as a precautionary measure,” Dr Gawande added.

The Indira Gandhi Government Medical College (IGGMC) too has kept two rooms in Ward no 6 reserved in case patients suspected nCoV patients land up at the hospital.

“IGGMC is yet to establish isolation ward for such patients. We have kept two rooms ready. Patients may report to any of the two GMCs,” said Dr Ajay Keoliya, dean of IGGMC.

Doctors said that there was a sudden increase in the number of patients with viral infections due to weather change in Nagpur. Such patients are infected with local influenza-A virus and need not panic or report to GMCs.

Title: Dengue cases have dropped markedly, say health officials
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Except for sporadic cases, the number of dengue cases in Madurai has come down drastically in January compared to December, health officials have said.

“The number of dengue cases has come down to half. There is no particular dengue-affected area. Sporadic cases were however reported,” said a senior health official, adding that measures are in place to prevent dengue and its spread. Fogging, spraying abate solution and distributing nilavembu concoction in areas where dengue cases have been reported is done throughout the year by health officials. Officials told TOI that the cases are expected to come down further in February. “October to early January usually witnesses the highest number of dengue cases. This year, because of intermittent rains, the number of dengue cases was at its peak in November. Now, with no rains and drier climate, breeding of mosquitoes is less. However, work is still being done to eliminate any source of mosquito breeding that remain. There is no cause for concern,” said a source from the health department.

The source also added that the number of fever cases in the district had also declined in January. “The number of fever cases have also come down. Further hospitalisation has also decreased. January is seeing only 1/4th of fever admissions that was recorded in December. So, proportionately dengue cases have also reduced,” said the source. In 2019, only 18 dengue cases were reported between January and August.

Title: Citizenship in sight, Sindhi family cries for daughter kidnapped in Pak
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: Shrichand Chandwani, who is getting his documents together to get Indian citizenship under CAA, also keeps two more papers handy — a birth certificate of his daughter Pooja, who is now 24 years old, and a police complaint filed back in Derki town of Sindh province in Pakistan after her abduction.

While he is keen to get an Indian passport, Shrichand also longs to be reunited with his daughter, who he claims was abducted by locals from a neighbouring village in Pakistan, and has now been converted to Islam. The birth certificate is to prove that Pooja was a minor of 16 years when she was taken away in March 2011, as mentioned in the police complaint. According to Pakistani law a minor cannot be married off even with her wishes. Shrichand hopes that Indian authorities take note and intervene in the matter to get her back.

Pooja’s abduction took place a year before that of Rinkle Kumari, which drew international limelight, but Pooja remain a forgotten footnote. The family alleges the involvement of a politician — Miya Abdul Haq aka Miya Mithu — in Pooja’s kidnapping. The politician is linked with many other cases too, they said.

“Around 8 to 10 armed persons, including a woman, barged into my house and dragged my daughter Pooja Kumari to a car,” says the report written in Sindhi language. “The complainant has alleged that his daughter has been abducted,” says a note below by the police with a seal on it.

“The real culprit was Kamran Khan, who is now her husband, living in the neighbouring village Lagar,” says Shrichand, who says that he knocked every door, from the local panchayat to the court, but in vain. “Finally, my daughter herself deposed against me saying that she went away willingly and we lost the case,” he says.

“They also kidnapped and confined me for three days. I was stripped off and beaten, leaving my private parts injured, and had to undergo a surgery. They brought my daughter to the hideout where I was kept. They threatened to wipe out our entire family if she did not cooperate,” he alleges.

Shrichand says they soon fled to India as he feared his other daughter would also meet the same fate. Initially, only he got the visa for India. Once here, he met the then home minister P Chidambaram with the help of Kailash Joshi, a BJP member of Parliament, he says, showing a letter. “Chidambaram promptly got the visas cleared, and my family shifted to India, finally reaching Nagpur,” he says. Now, the family is on a long term visa.

“We are ruined now. I had a mansion in Pakistan, here it is a dingy rented apartment. A cloth trader there, now I sell vegetables on a handcart,” he says.

“One needs money to travel back to Pakistan and plead the case for my daughter’s release. You have to spend at least Rs50,000 on a single trip and we are hand to mouth these days,” says his wife Shradha.

The last they could establish any contact with her was two-and-a-half years go on phone, says the family. “We left Pakistan soon after but could manage to establish contact with Kamran’s family through our relative there. It ended with a brief conversation with her. We have heard that she is a mother of three children now,” says the mother.

“In the court, she acted as if she does not recognize us at all,” she said. “It was because she was under threat,” adds Shrichand as he shoes a passport sized photo of Pooja, which is among the few memories of her left.

Title: Man with reattached hands returns home, looks forward to life after rehab
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kolkata: Forty-year-old Sankar Saha, who had almost lost his hands , returned home on Thursday with his limbs intact. Doctors at state-run SSKM Hospital had conducted the crucial replantation surgery .

The Belgharia resident’s both wrists got severed on January 7 as his hands accidentally went under the record cutting machine on which he was working at a printing press. His colleagues rushed him to hospital immediately. Two plastic surgery teams worked simultaneously on the two hands to conduct a successful bilateral replantation surgery the same day. On Thursday, Saha was discharged after doctors said they were confident that the patient would not develop any post-surgical infection .

“After this replantation surgery, the patient will need to undergo two or three minor surgeries to repair a few tendons. We plan to conduct the surgeries in about three months,” said plastic surgeon Souvik Adhikary, under whom the patient was admitted. He said they could not repair all the tendons during the replantation as the patient’s condition had become unstable after the 10-hour marathon surgery.

While Adhikary and his team worked on Saha’s right wrist, another team led by plastic surgeon Kalyan Das replanted the left wrist.

“The patient’s hands have been saved. Now, in addition to a few other minor surgeries, he will also need a series of rehabilitation, including physiotherapy so that he can start moving his hands again,” said Das.

“I have come this far after the accident because of the doctors at SSKM Hospital. They have not only saved my life but also my hands. I am confident that my hands will start functioning fully again,” Saha said. He, however, will not be able to start working immediately.

“It’s nothing short of a miracle. So far, the person under whom my husband works at the printing press has ensured all support including financial help. Otherwise it would have been very difficult for us as my husband is the only earning member in the family,” said wife Papiya.

Title: NU Senate members foil bid to suppress data loss
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: On the day TOI exposed the big data loss of exam forms at Nagpur University (NU), several Senate members representing the students and teachers said they too were aware of the bungle which was cleverly kept under wraps by exam section under its director Prafulla Sabale.

Graduates constituency Senate member Manmohan Bajpai said several colleges had informed him about the data loss in mid-January which led him to seeking details of the incident from the varsity.

“I have placed questions regarding the data of 2019-20 summer exam forms during the upcoming Senate meeting in February. I came to know from colleges that they were asked to upload the details again as all data has been deleted by the private company Promarc,” Bajpai said.

Bajpai said while students and colleges are burdened with filling the forms again, possibilities of corruption and errors in hall tickets cannot be ruled out.

Bajpai, a lawyer by profession, also questioned the move to spend big amounts of university money on online system while Promarc’s poor performance continues.

“It is the duty of Promarc to have backup and safely save the students’ data. After switching to online system, students just had to opt the subjects and pay fee online. Now, fresh entries would have to be made,” he said.

Explaining the corruption angle, he said now colleges can claim all fee was paid in cases where transfer was pending or partially money was paid.

Another member Sarita Nimbarte said Promarc must be blacklisted now. “We have been highlighting poor performance of Promarc, but university was not ready to act. Our questions, critical of the company, are deliberately dropped during Senate meeting. Assurance to penalize the company have never been fulfilled though we have placed on record all bunglings by Promarc,” said Nimbarte, who comes from Gondia-Bhandara.

Senate member Keshav Mendhe held the exam section director responsible for the lapse. “We have never heard such issue cropping up before. The director doesn’t have proper knowledge about the online system and officials seem to be out of his control. Forms are missing, data is missing, college clerks are complaining the link is not working. This has become routine affair. This is biggest blunder in NU history,” he said.

Representing university teachers, member Omprakash Chimmankar said the company must be held responsible for the data loss. “It is expected of the company to have backup,” he said.

Vice-chancellor SP Kane didn’t answer to TOI’s calls.

In the last two Senate meetings, the members were assured that university would start fixing responsibility on Promarc for hall ticket, mark sheets and other online glitches. Yet, the NU has not taken any action against it till date.

Title: Denied 2 ZP posts, NCP tie up with Cong on edge
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: The alliance between Congress and NCP in Nagpur Zilla Parishad is virtually over. The development has also potential to cause ripples at the state level also.

NCP had demanded two committees in the ZP, but Congress was ready to offer only one. Irked over the rejection, NCP headed by home minister Anil Deshmukh decided to not accept even this post. However, NCP member Ujjwala Bodare contested the election for the post of woman and child welfare committee chairperson and was elected. While NCP members along with Congress voted for Bodare, NCP leaders termed her as a rebel.

After results of Nagpur ZP election were out on January 7, Deshmukh had demanded the post of vice-president and one committee from Congress. Congress has 31 members in the House of 58 and does not need help of any other party to rule the ZP. NCP has only 10. The two parties had contested the ZP elections jointly.

Deshmukh wanted to make his son Salil the deputy chief and thus launch him in politics. However, dairy development minister Sunil Kedar refused to accede and the posts of president and vice-president went to the Congress. Deshmukh then demanded chairmanship of two committees from Kedar.

Talks were held between the two leaders several times including a prolonged meeting on Thursday morning, but the impasse remained. Both leaders stuck to their guns. Deshmukh finally decided to not be a part of the government by not taking even one post. He, however, formally did not end the alliance.

Even as talks were going on, NCP members filed nominations for two committees while Congress members filed for all four. After Deshmukh’s final decision, he asked NCP members to withdraw their nominations. While one of them complied with his diktat, Bodare refused. Sometime later, she was elected by Congress and NCP members.

NCP members told the media that Bodare had reached some understanding with Kedar. Shivraj Gujar, district NCP president, described Bodare as a rebel. “We had decided not to be the part of government and asked all our candidates to withdraw their nominations. I can’t say whether she has some understanding with Kedar. As for future of the alliance in Nagpur ZP, the decision will be taken by top party leaders,” he told TOI.

After NCP was denied the vice-president’s post, Deshmukh had accused Congress of not following the coalition dharma by not offering two committees to the alliance partner and warned of statewide repercussions.

Title: Metro for one-way roads in Sitabuldi, shuttle at airport
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: After launching services on Reach 1 and 3, MahaMetro is now making efforts to push ridership by taking help of other agencies. It has made two proposals in this regard.

First is to make two roads in Sitabuldi one way that will enable city buses to stop under Sitabuldi Interchange. Second is to start shuttle services between city airport and Airport Metro station.

A MahaMetro officer said proposal had been submitted to Chinmay Pandit, deputy commissioner of police (traffic), to make roads from Variety Square to Munje Square and from Munje Square to Rani Jhansi Square one-way. Pandit told TOI he would approve the proposal soon.

As per proposal, traffic will only flow from Variety Square to Munje Square and from Munje Square to Rani Jhansi Square. “At present, about 5,700 vehicles move on these two roads every day. This makes them very crowded and there is no space for city buses to stop near Sitabuldi Interchange. We also want people to walk from Mor Bhavan bus terminus to Sitabuldi station. For this, there should be less traffic on these roads. If the roads are made one-way, the traffic would reduce to 2,700 vehicles per day. Thirty-nine city buses will stop below the station after that,” said the officer.

This proposal had been submitted to the then municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar who cleared it in November 2019. Now, it is with DCP (traffic).

Metro also wants Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) to provide shuttle service from airport’s departure and arrival area to Airport Metro station. It has also spoken to two private agencies — Bengaluru-based Tvarit and Pune-based Kinetic — for providing this service.

The Metro officer said NMC has been asked to start mini-buses from airport to the Metro station and elsewhere. “The fare will be Rs10, which is minimal,” he added.

“Tvarit had submitted a proposal for providing e-vehicles at airport. They want to charge Rs25 per passenger and Rs50 per group. They are conducting a study there and elsewhere in the city too. Kinetic wants to charge Rs10 per passenger. They are also conducting a survey all over the city. However, for these plans to be successful, Maharashtra Airport Development Company (MADC) has to provide free parking to these vehicles. We have already submitted a proposal to MADC and a reminder too,” he said.

TRAFFIC FLOW

* Traffic will be allowed from Variety Square to Munje Square

* Traffic allowed from Munje Square to Rani Jhansi Square

* No traffic in reverse direction on both roads

* Will decongest the roads allowing city buses to halt under Sitabuldi Metro station

* Will also enable large number of people to walk from Mor Bhavan bus terminus to Sitabuldi Metro Station

Title: Mumbai: ‘My stated religion is compassion’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Dr Anand Gokani, Gandhi’s great-grandson, at SIES College on Wednesday. He visited a pictorial exhibition and ... Read More

For the past 20 years, silver-haired diabetologist Dr Anand Gokani has been stating “compassion” as his religion in every official document. The habit has served him better than his friend in Delhi who wrote “Insaniyat” in the religion column of a form not too long ago. “He was arrested because the authorities had misread the Hindi word as ‘insanity’,” Gokani told a roomful of philosophy students on Tuesday before asking them if they too had the “courage” to write “compassion” as their official religion. Several hands went up in affirmation for the doctor who is the great-grandson of Mahatma Gandhi .

Ahead of his 72nd death anniversary, Gandhi seemed to leave an impression on at least 50 minds at Sion when Gokani—the grandson of his fourth son Ramdas—addressed students as part of a three-day event marking the 150th birth anniversary of the Mahatma, his great-granmother Kasturba Gandhi and 100 years of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.

At the start of the session organised by Sion’s SIES College of Arts, Science & Commerce along with the college’s Past Students’ Association and Matunga’s Guru Nanak Khalsa College , a philosophy student dressed like Kasturba found herself explaining what philosophy meant on Gokani’s behest.

Then, after dissecting the difference between “reputation” and “character” and invoking an Akbar-Birbal story, Gokani made students realise the nation continues to revere his patience-and-self-sufficiency-peddling great-grandfather because “the man stood for qualities that were as old as the hills”.

Prerana Desai, a petite Gandhian economist with a booming voice, described the leader in Hindi as someone who not only practised a non-violent revolution by inducing guilt among the colonisers and pride among the colonised but also challenged the economic status quo by boycotting mass-produced goods in favour of “goods produced by the masses”.

“Many critics now find it important to malign Gandhi as his principles question today’s staus quo and capitalism,” said Desai, whose speech even borrowed a take from the movie ‘Munnabhai’ about what to do when you get a slap on turning the other cheek.

Later, an unexpected Munnabhai-style spiel arrived when activist Ganesh Nochur described Gandhi’s spartan ways in casual Bambaiya Hindi that won him a handshake from a student.

“He never minced words or put on other people’s shoes and would stand his ground firmly, without chappal,” said Nochur about Gandhi’s clear stance against the Western idea of consumption.

“There is no other path left but his. He was a lighthouse on how to live,” said a middle-aged Nochur who invoked dying bees and polluted rivers to demonstrate how his generation had ruined the planet for the young.

“Sorry, you can’t even escape to Mars,” said Nochur, adding that he believes that luxury is reserved only for the likes of Sundar Pichai and Elon Musk.

Another unscripted moment was supplied by philosophy professor C D Sebastian who calls himself a “lover of Gandhi”.

In the middle of his impassioned take on Gandhi as someone who examined the consequences of things, when a few students stood up from their seats and moved to the other row, Sesbastian deadpanned: “You’re going to boycott me?”

Gokani's wife has already started boycotting him at events, saying she had seen him reduced to a showpiece by virtue of his lineage. Despite feeling like he was born with a “crown of thorns” and a bloodline he “must live up to”, Gokani continues to accept invitations to preach compassion out of some innate hope for change.

“Even if I can change five people in a room, it will have a ripple effect,” said Gokani. His great-grandfather would agree.

Title: Appalled by auto menace, Mundhe orders crackdown
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Autorickshaw drivers have created traffic nuisance at Variety Square

Nagpur: After getting first-hand experience of unruly autorickshaw drivers blocking traffic at busy Variety Square , municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe summoned deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Chinmay Pandit and directed him to check the menace.

On Thursday, Mundhe visited Variety Square to pay tributes to Mahatma Gandhi on his death anniversary when he witnessed how autorickshaws were blocking the flow of traffic.

One of the autorickshaw drivers even offered Mundhe to drop at his desired destination, eyewitnesses told TOI.

Angry over this, the new civic chief expressed anguish as to how the autorickshaw drivers were creating nuisance at one of the city’s most busiest intersections. “The municipal commissioner soon asked his officials to inform the matter to Nagpur city traffic police and also summoned DCP (traffic) to his office,” the eyewitnesses said.

TOI has been regularly highlighting how autorickshaw drivers create chaos at Variety Square and Rani Jhansi Square . They not only drive wrong side without fear of traffic police, but also create obstruction for other motorists while soliciting passengers.

At both these squares, the auto drivers blatantly jump the red signal, block free left turns and even a major portion of the road forcing motorists to criss-cross their way through the busy junctions, complained several harried citizens. The traffic police never paid any heed to the menace, they alleged.

Later in the afternoon, DCP traffic a and official from regional transport office visited the NMC headquarters and attended the meeting convened by the civic chief. Mundhe expressed anguish over the unruly autorickshaw drivers at such a busiest intersection in the city and stressed the need to streamline them.

Representatives from traffic police and RTO, Nagpur city, acknowledged the nuisance created by autorickshaw drivers. However, they were quick to put the blame on weak public transport system and lack of auto stands.

At present, the city has over 14,000 autorickshaws and only 317 stands for them. Some stands are encroached by roadside vendors, it was informed in the meeting. After a lengthy discussion, it was decided that the traffic police and RTO will soon conduct a joint survey to find out the status of existing autorickshaw stands.

64 delegations at Mundhe’s Janata Darbar

On Thursday, as many as 64 delegations met Mundhe over various issues during his Janata Darbar from 4pm to 5pm. Meanwhile, the civic administration succeeded in streamlining the otherwise haphazard parking of vehicles at its Civil Lines headquarters.

Title: Only 48 per cent engineering students in Tamil Nadu clear Python in first semester
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: More than 50% of first year students in engineering colleges were not able to clear Python programming language in the first semester exams for which results were declared on Tuesday. Of the 64,810 who appeared for the exam, only 31,044 cleared it (pass percentage 48%), according to Anna University.Python is a programming language, widely used in all emerging areas including artificial intelligence, machine learning and internet of things (IoT). To cater to industry demands, the university introduced it for first year students from 2017. But, this year, many colleges have recorded poor results in the subject. Private college principals said only a few colleges recorded more than 75% pass percentage in it, saying the question paper standard was very high. However, professors said the faculty members from these colleges lacked knowledge to teach the language.K Maran, director of Sairam Group of Institutions, said the question paper was tough. “First year students may not have exposure to programming. Faculty in many colleges lack training in Python,” he said, urging the university to standardise question papers.“Introducing Python for engineering students is a good move. Though Python is very easy, the question paper was tough and many colleges recorded poor results. The paper should have concentrated more on basics. For second and third year, they might have increased the difficulty level,” said professor K Manivannan, CEO of Mohamed Sathak Group of Institutions.Maluk Mohamad, chairman of MAM College of Engineering and Technology in Trichy, said only one third of students had computer science background. “The question paper is a standard one. But the quality of students joining engineering courses has come down and the university should keep this in mind while setting question papers.”Anna University vice-chancellor M K Surappa said coding experts from software firms had to brought to train faculty in Python and coding skills. Teachers also should be enrolled in programmes like NPTEL to enhance knowledge. “Students must realise the curriculum is changing and they face high competition to get jobs,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: Three isolated at Ram Manohar Lohia test negative for coronavirus
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: All three patients quarantined at Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) hospital have tested negative for novel coronavirus (nCoV) and were discharged on Thursday.

“Their samples were sent for testing to NIV Pune and have tested negative,” said an Union health ministry official. The three men had self-reported at the Centre-run hospital designated to deal with such cases on Monday with complaints of respiratory trouble and fever.

Priya Abraham, director, National Institute of Virology, Pune, said, “Till now, 49 samples have been tested of which one has tested positive.” She added that the positive sample belonged to a student from Kerala who was studying in Wuhan.

With China struggling to contain the fast-spreading novel coronavirus, the Union health ministry had on Wednesday urged Indians to refrain from travelling to China. The advisory further urged all those travelling to China to monitor their health closely. A 24x7 helpline number (011-23978046) to redress any queries related to the respiratory infection has been set up. The ministry has also made four more laboratories functional, other than the NIV-Pune, for testing samples.

Several states, including Delhi, Haryana, Punjab and Rajasthan have kept some people with travel history to China under observation after they showed novel coronavirus-like symptoms. Meanwhile, scientists said they have been able to map the symptoms among 99 patients diagnosed with the infection in China.

According to a new analysis published in The Lancet, most patients were treated with anti-virals (75 ), antibiotics (70), and oxygen therapy (75), and had a good prognosis. However, 17 patients developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), 11 of whom died of multiple organ failure.

Title: Smart City promises to save at least 35% trees
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: It took a commonsensical approach by authorities and environmentalists to make certain that not all 139 trees would be on the chopping block. A joint inspection held on Thursday resulted in saving at least 30-35% of trees facing axe for making five road stretches in East Nagpur.

TOI was the first to report that authorities sought permission to cut 139 fully grown trees in different areas for Smart City Project roads. Opposing the move, green activists filed objection letters with the garden department of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC).

Following the opposition, a team of officials including Mahesh Moroney, deputy CEO of Smart City Project special purpose vehicle Nagpur Smart and Sustainable City Development Corporation Limited (NSSCDCL), general manager (environment) Devendra Mahajan and others conducted a joint survey of the road stretches along with members of environment NGO Green Vigil Foundation.

The survey started at the approach road of Navkanya Nagar where three fully grown trees were proposed to be chopped off. After the site inspection, it was unanimously concluded that the trees need to be felled as they fall right in the middle of the proposed road.

Next in line was the stretch between Saduru factory to Bhavani Hospital in Pardi, where 68 trees were to be cut. However in a heartening news, officials decided to reduce the original road width of 18 metres to 15. “With this, we should be able to save around 40% of the trees on this route. These will include the ones situated on the edges,” said Moroney.

Officials took a similar decision for the road stretch from Bhandara National Highway to Punapur Road where 29 trees were to be cut. Again reducing the width to 15 metres, officials committed to save all the trees which are not coming in the middle of carriageway. “Trees which will not create any hindrance to vehicular movement will not be felled,” they said.

In addition to this, founder of Green Vigil Kaustav Chatterjee suggested not to cut trees coming on proposed pavement area. Agreeing to this, Mahajan said, “At some pavements where utility work needs to be carried out, it will become imperative to cut trees. However, we commit not to fell trees at rest of the footpaths.”

Against the felled trees, officials plan to carry out compensatory plantations in 1:5 ratio. They further expressed willingness to transplant ficus tree species in nearby open areas but members of Green Vigil dissented the idea, citing recent transplantation failures in the city.

At the end of survey, officials assured to bring down the number of felled trees to below 100. “We are working towards building a smart city in which sustainable development will play a crucial role,” said Moroney.

Welcoming the pro-environment move of officials, green activists stated that upcoming developmental projects should also incorporate such joint surveys. “During urban planning, focus should on protecting the existing green cover, especially the ecologically important tree species. All stakeholders should be involved in the decision-making process,” said Surbhi Jaiswal, team lead at Green Vigil.

Road stretch------------------------------------- Length----------Width------------- Trees to be cut

Saduru Factory to Bhavani Hospital (Pardi)---1.5 km---------15 m -----------------68

Entrance of Bhavani Mata temple to Bharatwada--1.5 km--12m----------------33

Bhandara National Highway to Punapur Road------600m------15m----------------29

Bharwatwada Road to Navkanya Nagar----------------1.4km------12 m--------------6

Approach road of Navkanya Nagar--------------------------1 km------12 m-------------3

Title: After weeks of protests, VB ‘gag order’ for employees
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The notification by the university sparked a row on the campus

SANTINIKETAN: The Visva-Bharati authorities on Thursday issued a notification , asking all teaching and non-teaching employees of the university not to make any statement on “matters pertaining to the university” to the media without permission from the university’s competent authority.

The notification, perceived to be a virtual “gag order” has sparked a row on the campus.

For the past few weeks, several employees of the university have been speaking in favour of the Left-leaning students protesting against CAA and other issues, including fee hike . A student was evicted for recording a speech by the vice-chancellor on CAA, alleged a section of students. On January 5, the agitators had gheraoed BJP MP Swapan Dasgupta when he was in the campus to speak on CAA.

In the wake of continuing unrest, VBU authorities had issued a notice on January 27 declaring the university’s Central Administrative Building including the area of Central Library as well as the academic and research section on campus as a no disturbance zone.

The notification directs all teaching and non-teaching staff of the university to air any public statement (on the institution) to the media through assistant registrar Anirban Sircar.

The notification states that it is unworthy of any staff member or employee of VB to seek the limelight through media. Declaring that VBU itself seeks no publicity, the notification makes it clear that genuine grievances of university staff will be sympathetically attended to by the authorities.

“This notification is against the Visva-Bharati statute. Such an order cannot be issued for university employees as the institution they serve is autonomous,” said Sudipta Bhattacharya, a professor of economics and president of the Visva-Bharati University Faculty Association ( VBUFA ). SFI ’s Somnath Sau said: “Vice-chancellor Bidyut Chakraborty is trying to clamp down on rights as basic as freedom of speech and expression.”

VBUFA has been speaking out in favour of the agitators and condemning the recent eviction of a student from the hostel.

Title: Shops sealed for non-payment of rent
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Trichy: With the financial year coming to a close and only 40-50% of the non-tax revenue, earned by renting the civic body’s properties, having been collected, the Trichy Corporation has intensified collection of pending rent from the tenants.

So far, the corporation has sealed three shops in Ponmalai zone for non-payment of rent for the past 15-20 years now.

The corporation’s revenue sources include state grants, property tax, central finance commission and non-tax revenue. With around 2,500 buildings in four zones, it was earning around Rs 55 crore every year through the shops and buildings rented out to private as well as government offices. However, a section of the tenants has been defaulting from paying the pending monthly rent for several years.

“We are in the process of identifying major defaulters. Sine the defaulters are approaching courts, the recovery process is taking time,” an official source said.

On Wednesday, the Ponmalai zone of the civic body sealed a transport office functioning in the Central bus stand for non-payment of monthly rent amounting to Rs 15 lakh since 2004. Similarly, on Thursday a couple of shops operating in the same building were sealed.

The corporation rented out a 2,700-square-foot building on the Bharathiyar Road to a man in 2000 on monthly rental for Rs 18,000. The man was running two shops in the space. Since then, the tenant was periodically defaulting on the rent which accumulated to Rs 3 crore as on January 2020.

“Fresh notice is served to repay the pending rent. If not, we will auction the tenant’s belongings inside the building to recover the pending sum,” the official added.

Similar lock and seal method is planned in Srirangam and Ariyamangalam zones, sources said.

Title: Panchayat school starts storytelling programme
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Trichy: The Panchayat Union Primary School at K Paramathi in Karur district has launched a unique storytelling programme for its students - an innovative practice for kids to nurture creativity and imagination skills through stories.

Vanithamani Arulvel, from Erode, in the inaugural storytelling session, shared among 189 children from classes I to V moral stories underlying the importance of eating vegetables and applying the presence of mind in critical situations.

“Creativity and vocabulary skills of the children will enhance on listening to stories as they tend to absorb words and imagine. They will also develop the patience to listen, a leadership quality,” Vanithamani Arulvel told TOI. Since the session was conducted completely in Tamil, the school management said the students were fully engrossed owing to the mother tongue connect.

School teachers said the children were enthusiastic throughout the session as the learning environment was different. “Stories often come with multiple moral values. In the absence of grandfathers and grandmothers, the storytelling practice is gradually declining, thus distracting students to other activities,” headmaster R Selvakannan said.
