The school is building a story corner on their campus to conduct storytelling sessions periodically to engage students regularly to develop good virtues through moral stories. A couple of teachers from the school are being trained on storytelling to sustain the programme every week.

Title: CAA illogical, immoral, ill-timed: Ramchandra Guha
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Ahmedabad: Historian Ramchandra Guha called the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), that was passed in the winter session of Parliament, “illogical, immoral and ill-timed”. Guha, also a biographer of Gandhi, delivered a public lecture on ‘What would Gandhi make of India today?’ in Ahmedabad on Saturday.

Speaking on Hindu-Muslim harmony as one of the four pillars of Gandhi’s idea of Swaraj, Guha said, “Even if Gandhi had never existed, any morally upright consciences, democratic citizens who believe in the Constitution, would non-violently oppose CAA. The act is illogical, immoral and ill-timed.”

“It is illogical because it completely excludes the largest group of refugees in India who have travelled from Sri Lanka, many of whom are actually Hindus. It is immoral because its entire phrasing discriminates against one community, Muslims. In conjunction with the National Register of Citizens (NRC), it makes any Indian Muslim fearful and insecure,” Guha added.

“Look at the phrasing. It is as if we have many neighbours but only those that are Muslim majority are discriminating and every refugee except someone who is a Muslim is welcome here. It is absolutely immoral. I am no constitutional expert, but even if the Supreme Court upholds it, it should be resisted because it is utterly immoral,” Guha said.

Guha also termed the Act be ill-timed, saying, “It is ill-timed because of the perennial state of the country now, unemployment levels at a 45-year high, agrarian distress, all kinds of other issues to be solved…Of course, Gandhi would have opposed it.”

About the CAA in the context of the northeast India, Guha said, “The Northeast is a part of India which always had difficulties because of geographic isolation.”

Title: Civic body to solve property tax queries in 35 days
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Ahmedabad: Citizens who do not agree with the civic body’s assessment of their property tax can now appeal for a reassessment. A web page will be launched by the civic body to accept requests from citizens for a reassessment of the carpet area of their respective properties. The launch of the facility will be soon announced claim Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) officials.

When asked how much time it will take AMC to solve such queries, AMC standing committee chairman, Amul Bhatt, replied , “It will take 30 to 35 days for a zonal officer to visit a premise, prepare a report to verify claims and then proceed with making changes in the tax bills.” He added, “A number of disputes over reassessment has reached civil courts. The whole idea of bringing in the carpet area based tax formula was minimising such litigations. But here too we find there is a conflict between our property tax office and individual property owners.”

It was in May 2014 that the then municipal commissioner Guruprasad Mohapatra had announced introducing a system of e-assessment for filing property tax. The scheme failed to take off after Mohapatra was transferred out of the civic body. The e-assessment system is followed in Bengaluru civic body.

Title: 24 take diksha on Sabarmati riverfront
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

A total of 24 men and women, youth and children took diksha (renunciation orders) from Acharya Vijaymuktiprab... Read More

AHMEDABAD: They used luxury cars and lived in posh localities, topped exams or raised two generations of children, but on Thursday morning, they all stood together in white clothes with heads shaven. A total of 24 men and women, youth and children took diksha (renunciation orders) from Acharya Vijaymuktiprabhsuri at a major ceremony held at the Sabarmati riverfront .

The ‘mumukshu’ (ascetics to be) included 10 from Mumbai, six from Ahmedabad and one each from Anand, Pune, Ladol, Karad, Ujjain, Bengaluru, Vapi and Surat. The event, held at ‘Vairagya Rangotsav Mandap’ on the Riverfront, saw 10,000 guests from across India and 300-odd Jain sadhus and sadhvis.

The acharya, in his speech, said self-control comes from observing one’s thoughts, acts and speech. “One who leaves home becomes a sadhu but the one who leaves old thoughts become a shishya (disciple),” he said.

On Wednesday, those taking diksha were taken out in a procession in the Paldi area in great regalia, but at 5pm on Thursday, the rites began for them to shave their heads and don the white clothes of renunciants. They were given new identities by the acharya.

“Those who took diksha included six members of a single family from Mumbai including Sandeep Jain, his wife Sejal, daughter Labdhi and son Vajra. Jain’s mother and brother had taken diksha earlier,” said an organizer, adding that those renouncing social life range from a 14-year-old boy to an 88-year-old woman.

Several of the senior citizens who took diksha said that it was their long-cherished dream to spend the twilight of their lives studying religious scriptures and understanding dharma. Sushila Shah, who was given the new name Sadhvi Paramgunashree, was inspired by her daughter, who had become a sadhvi a few years ago.

Title: Five arrested for murder of BJP functionary in Trichy
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Trichy: Police have arrested five people including the key accused in connection with the murder of BJP functionary F Vijaya Raghu, 38, of Trichy. Confirming the arrest, city police commissioner V Varadharaju on Thursday said the murder was a fallout of previous enmity.

A special team of police from Trichy city with the help of Chennai metropolitan police arrested M Babu alias Mittai Babu, 25, of pensioner street in Varaganeri in Trichy, and his accomplice M Hari Prasad, 20, from Tharanallur in Trichy, in Chennai on Wednesday evening. They were brought to Trichy the same night.

Another team arrested A Sudarvendhan, 18, from EB road, S Sanjay alias Sachin, 18, from EB road, and M Yasser alias Mohammed Yasser, from Ariyamangalam, at Sanjeevi Nagar in Trichy on Thursday.

“The murder was a fallout of previous enmity over personal issues between Babu and Raghu. There was no other motive into the murder as per our investigation. The accused belong to different communities. Still, we are investigating,” commissioner Varadharaju told reporters.

Raghu, who was the BJP mandal secretary in Palakkarai, was hacked to death near Gandhi market in the early hours on January 27 while at work, issuing tokens at parking lot.

The commissioner said that Babu and Hari Prasad murdered Raghu with two machetes. The others hatched a conspiracy with the two near banana auction centre to finish off Raghu adding that Babu and Hari Prasad went Chennai via Thanjavur and Nagappattinam, while the three others went into hiding.

Among the five, Babu is a history-sheeter and has already been arrested for disputes with Raghu and his relative Krishnakumar in 2019. He was detained under the Goondas Act and had come out on bail recently. Yasser was also a previous offender while the three others had no previous criminal antecedents.

The five special teams also a seized a bike and machetes from the accused. The arrested were remanded in judicial custody. Police have altered the case by including IPC sections under SC/ST Prevention of Atrocities Act and criminal conspiracy. The commissioner did not comment on theories by BJP leaders Pon Radhakrishnan and H Raja linking the murder to CAA and ‘love jihad’.

Title: Will review major projects & take up only feasible ones: Thackeray
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nashik: Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray on Thursday said the state government will review all major projects, including the water-grid proposed by the earlier government, to ensure that only the feasible projects were taken up in the interest of people.

Thackeray was addressing the media after the review meetings of five districts — Nashik, Ahmednagar, Dhule, Jalgaon and Nandurbar — of the division.

“If the projects require to be reviewed, we will do that. Only feasible projects will be taken up,” he said.

During the review meetings, Thackeray said the government was keen on completing the pending works of the Nilwande dam in Ahmednagar, setting up trauma centres, establishing a 100-bed hospital in Dhule, and ensuring availability of power to farmers.

The delegations of MLAs, led by the guardian ministers of the respective districts, met the CM and apprised him on the demands of their regions.

The CM assured the Nashik delegation that all efforts will be made to develop Nashik on par with Mumbai and Pune. “Mumbai-Pune-Nashik is a golden triangle, but it is incomplete. Therefore, the government will take up developmental works,” Thackeray said.

“Farmers need better power for drawing water for irrigation. The government will ensure better availability of power for them,” he said and added that the Jalyukta shivar works would be completed within the stipulated period.

The CM said the government would also provide Rs 1,100 crore for the completion of Nilwande dam works in the next two years. “The work on canals and distributories will bring relief to 189 villages and 25,000 hectare of land under cultivation in Ahmednagar,” he said. He also pointed out that the state government would play a role in ensuring the night landing facilities at the Shirdi airport. For Nandurbar, the CM said the government would take measures to lift the 5 TMC feet water from the Ukai dam.

Title: 5 held for stealing valuables worth Rs 51 lakh from businessman
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Police have arrested five burglars involved in stealing cash and valuables worth Rs 51.15 lakh from the house of a city-based businessman in Sarkarwada on Tuesday.

Commissioner of police Vishwas Nangare-Patil said, “The suspects had stolen cash, jewellery and branded watches from the house of one Ramesh Luthra in just one hour on Monday. All suspects involved in the case have been arrested.”

The crime branch unit 1 was actively involved in detecting the case. The team got a breakthrough when they detained Radhabai Gaikwad who worked as domestic help in Luthra’s house.

“During interrogation the woman broke down and informed that she was not alone and four other men were also involved in committing the crime. Also, this was their second attempt in which they were successful,” a police officer said.

According to police, Gaikwad is a resident of Motiwala College area and has been working with the complainant for long time. She along with her accomplices Balaji Ghagarmale and Datta Bhadarge had planned to the steal the goods.

As part of the plan, Gaikwad had already stolen the keys of the safe and lockers, cloned them and kept them back in their original place. Three months ago they had tried stealing the goods, but the plan was shattered due to untimely return of the family members.

“However, this time they got things in place as Gaikwad was aware when the members were going out of the house and for how long. Citing opportunity, the woman picked up the goods and gave it to her accomplices who fled the scene,” the police said.

Later, Ghagarmale and Bhadarge with the help of Yogesh Paikrao and Abhishek Nikam melted the golden ornaments and sold it to a jeweller in the city. Police have recovered Rs 25.75 lakh cash that the suspects had received from the jeweller.

“The suspects have been remanded in three-day police custody. We are now tracking down the jeweller who bought the gold,” the officer said.

Title: Six women get bail in Shah-e-Alam case
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Six women who were arrested after the protests against the new citizenship law turned violent in Shah-e-Alam, got bail from the Gujarat high court nearly 40 days after they were arrested on charges of attempted murder and rioting.

Justice V M Pancholi granted conditional bail to all six women accused on each of them furnishing a bail bond of Rs 10,000. They will have to mark their presence once a month at the concerned police station for six months.

Nineteen cops were injured on December 19, 2019, when a protesting mob turned violent to keep police from detaining protesters at Shah-e-Alam. Police arrested more than 80 persons after the incident.

The court also granted bail to another accused, Umar Khan, who was arrested for allegedly circulating a video clip of a protest in north India and passing it off as footage of the Shah-e-Alam protest. He was booked under Section 153A of the IPC, for causing a rift between communities. He was also behind bars for the last 40 days.

All these accused persons had been refused bail by a city sessions court in December,

Title: NLEP to bring down leprosy deformity rate
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Trichy: The office of the deputy director of health services (DDHS), leprosy in Trichy has pledged to reduce to the deformity rate to below one per 10 lakh population in the district on account of World Leprosy Day which was observed on Thursday.

Deputy director of health services (leprosy) Dr A Shanthi said the present deformity rate in Trichy was at 1.64. “We are striving hard to bring down the deformity rate under one,” she said.

Under the national leprosy eradication program (NELP), the health department officials carried out programmes to identify leprosy patients who were mostly unaware of the symptoms. “Leprosy is completely curable if detected at an early stage and treated. The chances of deformity can also be reduced,” Dr Shanthi told TOI.

Trichy district has 105 leprosy patients under treatment. Dr Shanthi said that annually, 3.98 new cases per one lakh population are detected in the district. The officials conducted two leprosy case detection campaigns in two phases in the district last year and identified 31 new leprosy patients in each phase.

Dr Shanthi also said that the leprosy prevalence rate that stood at 118 per 10,000 population in 1983 when the national leprosy eradication programme commenced and has come down to 0.34 in December 2019.

From January 30, Sparsh Leprosy awareness campaign will be conducted in the form of camps and door-to-door campaigns across the district till February 13.

The awareness programmes includes skin camps, prevention of disability campaign, awareness rallies, quiz programmes, enumeration in slum areas and few other programmes.

Title: IIFPT-FSSAI to ensure safe prasadam in temples
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thanjavur: Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) has initiated a project to encourage all places of worship to adopt and maintain food safety and hygiene in the preparation and distribution of ‘prasadam’, FSSAI chairperson Rita Teaotia said.

After inaugurating a modern food testing laboratory-cum training centre on the Indian Institute of Food Processing Technology (IIFPT) campus in Thanjavur on Thursday, Rita said that global food safety has to be ensured in the country by promoting modern food safety practices. It has been a big challenge to cover the population of 1.35 billion people with minimum facility and resources in the country.

While speaking about BHOG (Blissful Hygienic Offering to God) project, she said that the places of worship are a very important part of Indian society and food served at these places is regarded as pure and sacred. Food safety measures also need to be implemented at such places. “FSSAI has initiated a project to encourage all places of worship to adopt and maintain food safety and hygiene in the preparation of prasadam. All the places of worship that distribute prasadam, including vendors are required to obtain FSSAI licence or registration and they also need to follow the sanitary and hygiene practices as per the food safety standards regulations. In this context, IIFPT has signed an MoU with the managements of Brihadeeswarar Temple, Punnainallur Mariamman Temple and Shirdi Saibaba Temple in Thanjavur for ensuring safe distribution of prasadam,” she said.

Earlier, IIFPT officials signed an MoU with temple managements for safe distribution of prasadam in the presence of FSSAI chairperson Rita Teaotia. Over 700 people participated in an awareness campaign organized during the event on ‘Eat Right India’. tnn

Title: 3 apply for citizenship with amended form
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kannur: Amid uncertainty over the implementation of Citizenship (Amendment) Act, which is yet to come into effect, the amended application form for applying for citizenship has appeared online , and new applicants have started use it.

Though the Union government has said the amended act has not come into force, the application form downloaded from the website of the Ministry of Home Affairs has asked a specific question as part of a sub section (7A). The question — Do you belong to one of the minority communities from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan, namely Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis and Christian religion? Yes/No If Yes, Please specify... — was not there in the earlier application form, according to legal experts.

Kannur collectorate has got three such applications. All are from Panoor area and they have applied for citizenship as one of their parents earlier had Pakistani citizenship, but now holds Indian citizenship.

One resident of the district has submitted the citizenship request in the amended form as he is a Pakistan citizen by birth but living here since 2008.

The youth filed the application on January 14, after he turned 18 on January 11. His father, an Indian citizen, had migrated to Pakistan for business and married a Pakistani woman there. In 2002, the applicant was born in Pakistan. In 2008, they came back and his mother got Indian citizenship. So naturally the youth can get citizenship, but he was worried since he was born in Karachi, and has a Pakistan passport, said P R Vinod, his lawyer. When he applied online for Indian citizenship, the amendment was noticed, and after filling it, he submitted three sets of the application as per the norms, at the collectorate and got the acknowledgement as well, the lawyer said.

The reports that registration as per CAA has begun in Kannur is baseless, said district collector TV Subhash. He said the mailing section of the collectorate got three applications on January 23, but no action has been taken.

The applicant’s lawyer also said the same, and added the application was submitted as per procedure. But this has brought to the fore the fact that the state government cannot do anything with regards to such issues, he added.

Title: Man from held in Karur for sharing child porn on Facebook
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Karur: The Karur police on Thursday arrested a 23-year-old man from Uttar Pradesh for sharing child pornographic content on Facebook. The arrested, identified as Niyaz Ali of Bilaspur in UP, has been working at a beauty parlour here for the past six months.

Acting on an input from a state agency, a police team visited the parlour and checked his cellphone on Wednesday evening. They confirmed he had shared child pornographic content among his Facebook contacts. Police sources said Niyaz Ali had been continuing the practice since May last year. The state police have been cracking down on child pornography and law enforcement agencies have been screening social media accounts of individuals to check their activities.

Police picked up Niyaz Ali and questioned him before booking him under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act and Information Technology Act. Police said he will be produced before a court.

It’s the third arrest in the state for sharing child pornography since December 2019. On December 12, 2019, the all women police station (AWPS), Cantonment, Trichy, arrested Christopher Alphonse, 42, of Kajapettai near Palakkarai for creating Facebook accounts and sharing child porn to his FB contacts. The AWPS in Jeeyapuram arrested Saravanan, 31, of Vasan Valley near Somarasampettai on January 26 on charges of sharing child porn pictures on social media.

Title: 36 arrested in connection with violence in Dhule
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK/DHULE: The Dhule police have arrested more than 36 people so far in connection with the riots and arson on Wednesday. They had earlier booked more than 5,000 people for violence during protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).

“The police first acted swiftly to bring the city to normalcy. Now it has started the operation to look for the individuals engaged in arson and stone-pelting. We have arrested 36 people and the search for their accomplices is on,” said sub-divisional police officer Sachin Hiray.

On Wednesday, the protesters — supporting the bandh called by various organisations against the CAA, NRC and NPR — had turned violent and had started pelting stones on houses and public property at the 100-feet road in the city.

“Inspector-General, Nashik Range, Chhering Dorje visited Dhule against the backdrop of the riots and instructed the police to take severe action against the individuals who took the law in their hands. Hence, the action,” said police sources.

Lending support to CAA, NRC and NPR protests, the demonstrators had first struck the National Highway 3 at Chalisgaon phata and had attempted to stop the traffic. The police foiled the attempt for two hours as people kept turning up at intervals of 10-15 minutes at various places. Thereafter, the protesters gathered at the 100-feet road at 12.30 pm and started pelting stones on the houses, vehicles and public properties. They torched a couple of two-wheelers and tyres. The police tried to intervene, but the stones were pelted at them as well. The police finally had to open fire to disperse the crowd. Two rounds were fired in the air and six rounds of tear gas shells were burst followed by light use of charge, after which the crowd dispersed.

The situation in most parts of the Dhule city was normal except for a section where window panes of three buses were targeted. The police claimed that none of the citizens, except the policemen, were injured during the violence. Cases have been registered against the office-bearers of the Bhim Army , Samvidhan Bachav Samiti and their accomplices at the Chalisgaon, Dhule City and Shirpur police stations. The police are going through video recordings and photographs.

Title: Gujarat: ‘Paying guest facilities need permission from society’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

AHMEDABAD: If a cooperative society or other members of the society object, it will means shutters down for paying guest facilities . The Gujarat State Cooperative Board of Nominees, in an interim order passed on Tuesday, has stated that in a residential society, no member can indulge in commercial activity, including the setting up of a paying guest facility, if other members of the society object to such activity.

The board, in a case involving of Hilldarshan Co-operative Society Limited Part-II (Chinar Bungalows), Bodakdev, has in its interim order banned commercial activity and even barred the member concerned from selling his house.

A petition was filed by the society against its member Asit Bhatt. The society claimed that as it was a residential society no member could indulge in commercial activity including providing lodging and boarding facilities. The society claimed that Bhatt was flouting the bylaws of the society by running the PG facility.

The society had issued a notice telling Bhatt to immediately shut down the the PG facility, terming it illegal. When Bhatt continued running the facility, the society imposed an additional Rs 1,000 fee on him. Bhatt then even stopped paying the administrative charges to the society.

Through his advocate, Bhatt contended that the society does not have the power to file such a case witht the board of nominees. And Bhatt had also filed a complaint at Vastrapur police station against the society, and the case in the board of nominees was aimed at harassing him.

The board, in its order, noted that the society bylaws clearly state that if a member is giving his bungalow on rent, he would have to give the society details of the family the house was rented and even seek its permission . The bylaws are clear that hostels, offices or commercial activity are not permitted.

The board’s interim order noted that the respondent was a wilful defaulter and it was established that the respondent was operating a PG facility in contravention of the bylaws of the society. The society had also passed resolutions against such PG facilities, which was also ignored by the member.

Title: ‘Want NIA probe into funding of protests’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kochi: The Ernakulam unit of Janajagarana Samithi has alleged that the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protests in the state received foreign funding and the central government should initiate an NIA investigation into it. The samithi recently landed in a controversy after a viral video showing a mob pushing a woman out of a hall and being verbally abused during a pro-CAA meet at Pavakulam temple on January 21.

During a press meet held by the samithi’s district convener C G Kamalanandan and C V Sajini, secretary of the industrial cell of the Bharatiya Janata Party, here alleged that the recent CAA protests reminded of those youths in Kashmir who pelted stones at the central forces for money.

“Anti-national elements like SDPI and Popular Front of India (PFI) are unnecessarily creating ruckus during the peaceful pro-CAA rallies, held by Sangh Parivar constituents in Eloor and Pathalam, by using provocative and violence-inciting statements. The same has happened during our rally held in Aluva on January 27. Jihadi’s are also calling for boycotting shops and institutions run by Hindus. All these incidents show that people with vested interests are trying to create riots and communal divisions,” said Kamalanandan.

Referring to the incident at Pavakkulam temple, Sajini alleged that the police officers investigating the case are facing political pressure.

“All these are fake news. The woman who trespassed into the hall and interrupted our meeting received help from others who have vested agenda. The person who took the video of the scuffle was her accomplice and the entire scene was preplanned. We have submitted all the evidence including videos of the event and CCTV footages in the premises to the police, but we assume they have pressure from outside,” she said.

Sajini and Kamalanandan, during the press meet, denied that police have registered cases and made arrests, and called it “fake news”.

Meanwhile, Ernakulam North police have arrested and released on bail five activists of Sangh Parivar in connection with the incident. The charges against them include unlawful assembly, rioting, voluntarily causing hurt, criminal intimidation, use of obscene words, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman. Earlier, cases were registered against 29 persons.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Businessman held for raping son’s girlfriend in Vedaranyam
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representtaive image

Title: LDF retains prez post in Thodupuzha
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kottayam: LDF has retained its hold over Thodupuzha block panchayat. Following the elections held on Thursday which resulted in a tie, CPM-backed independent candidate Sinoj Jose Erichirikkatt became president again by draw of lots. His opponent Sathish Kesaven, who was elected as an LDF independent, had withdrawn support to LDF and had switched over to UDF , which lead to a no-confidence motion against LDF.

There were a total of 13 members in the panchayat. One member belonging to UDF was not present during voting. This resulted in the tie (6-6). Since there was a tie, the returning officer decided to draw lots to elect the president. tnn

Title: Gujarat: ‘43 China arrivals screened, coronavirus not detected’
Content: Officials at the Ahmedabad Civil Hospital said the hospital is the nodal centre and will serve as a base ho... Read More GANDHINAGAR/ AHMEDABAD: After the first confirmed coronavirus case in India was reported from Kerala on Thursday, the state health department said that its screening of arrivals from China had been strengthened. Jai Prakash Shivahare, state health commissioner, said that 43 such recent arrivals had all have been screened.“They are all healthy. They are under medical observation at their homes as a precaution,” said Shivahare. “Citizens need not panic as the coronavirus has been reported in 17 countries but so far there has been no case in Gujarat. The state administration is fully prepared for any scenario.”He said arrivals from China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, Japan and South Korea are being screened according to government of India guidelines. Of the 43 screened, 16 were from Mehsana, six from Panchmahal, three from Anand, five from Surat, four from Ahmedabad, two each from Junagadh and Vadodara, and one each from Ahmedabad district , Mahisagar, Patan, Jamnagar and Rajkot.Shivahare added that at the Ahmedabad international airport Terminal II, round-the-clock screening has been initiated and there are doctors and paramedical staff stationed at the spot. “The medical team has thermal scanners, PPE kit, N-95 masks, three-layer masks, oxygen, emergency medicine and self-declaration forms,” he said.Health department officials said all those returning from China are requested to approach the screening desk not only for their own well-being but also for the health of their families. Apart from the Ahmedabad airport, airports at Vadodara, Surat and Rajkot have health alerts displaying coronavirus symptoms and requesting passengers to get screened if they experience any of the symptoms and have visited China recently.Officials at the Ahmedabad Civil Hospital said the hospital is the nodal centre and will serve as a base hospital. “Staffers from more than 100 government hospitals and medical colleges in the state have been trained on coronavirus and more will be trained this week. Isolation wards have been readied at major hospitals,” said a senior hospital official.

Title: NEET-PG Toppers 2020: Four from Ahmedabad in top 25 list
Content: AHMEDABAD: The results of the National Eligibility-cum-Entrance Test for postgraduate medical courses (NEET-PG) was declared on Thursday night.A total of 4,324 students from Gujarat cleared the exam. Some 7,097 students had taken the exam from Gujarat, of which 61% passed. Gujarat has 2,100-odd PG medical seats. Experts said the exam was conducted across the country on January 5 and the result was declared in a matter of 25 days.For the last two years, NEET-PG has been mandatory for PG medical courses. Experts added that the current figures don’t reflect the economically weaker section (EWS) seats and thus students will have more seats from the next academic year. However, compared to last year, it’s likely that the cut-off mark will go up.While Parth Durgia, a medical student from Rajkot, got the all-India rank (AIR) of 6, Harshil Shah from BJ Medical College stood tenth.“The paper was different from earlier years with more emphasis on practical aspects of the problem compared to theoretical knowledge. I believe it’s a step towards NEXT which will replace NEET-PG soon,” said Shah. ]“I intend to take up a PG course in medicine at either BJ Medical College or Maulana Azad Medical College in New Delhi.”In the current results, the cut-off percentile for various categories is 50th percentile for open, 40th percentile for reserved categories and 45th percentile for persons with disabilities (PwD).

Title: YCMOU forms its alumni association
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

NASHIK: The Yashwantrao Chavan Maharashtra Open University (YCMOU) has formed its own alumni association, after completing 30 years.

The varsity has asked its students to register as an alumnus on their website to join the association and provide the data regarding their year of passing out and current work details.

Santosh Sable, co-ordinator of the alumni association, said, “We have uploaded the data of over 2.5 lakh students who have passed out from our varsity. We are sending messages, emails and contacting the students through social media. We urge our students to upload their details so that we can get in touch with them.” The varsity is planning to conduct a grand alumni festival. According to Sable, about 35 lakh YMCOU alumni are spread across the globe, contributing to the society.

All the students who have done their diploma or degree courses from the varsity can join the alumni association via the web link ycmoualumni.org.

Title: Renovated kalasam reinstated atop Big Temple tower
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thanjavur: The Hindu religious and charitable endowment (HR&CE) department on Thursday reinstated the renovated and gold-coated ‘kalasam’ atop the main ‘gopuram’ in Brihadeeswarar Temple (Big Temple) ahead of the consecration ceremony, to be held on February 5.

As part of the consecration ceremony, authorities of the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) along with HR&CE started cleaning the temple, including the main gopuram a few months ago.

Scaffolding has been erected above the main sanctum sanctorum covering the tower to facilitate the workers to perform chemical cleaning. The HR&CE officials started cleaning the giant ‘kalasam’ fixed atop the 216ft tower (main gopuram) on January 5.

The kalasam, which is 3.81m (12.5ft) tall, is being erected above the centre of the ‘vimanam’ (granite block). Nearly 25 tonne of copper is used to cover it.

A group of artisans cleaned it and did the gold-coating. It was brought to the temple and a special puja was performed before fixing it atop the gopuram.

Earlier, a team of experts including M Amirthalingam, faculty of Metallurgical and Materials department of IIT Madras, inspected the condition of the kalasam on January 5. The inner portion of the kalasam was filled with ‘varagu’ millet. Scientists from Indira Gandhi Centre for Atomic Research also examined the kalasam after it was brought down.

The last consecration of the temple, which is a World Heritage Monument, was held in 1997.

Title: Shirgao locals threaten stir if bills not paid
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Bicholim: At a recent meeting at the office of Bicholim deputy collector Sachin Desai, Shirgao residents gave a mining company two days to make a decision regarding the payment of their pending water bills. Last week, locals blocked transportation of the e-auctioned ore twice, protesting the company’s failure to pay bills pending for the last two years. tnn

Title: Ex-minister, Cong leader Kamalam passes away at 94
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kozhikode: Former minister and Congress leader M Kamalam passed away on Thursday morning. She was 94.

Kamalam, who entered active politics at the age of 19, started her political career as the councillor in the then Kozhikode municipality.

She was the minister for cooperation in the K Karunakaran ministry from 1982 to 1987 and the chairperson of the Kerala state women’s commission.

She was the convener of the women’s wing of the Congress and state general secretary of the party. She also served as the state vice-president of the party.

She resigned from Congress in protest against the declaration of Emergency in 1975 and was imprisoned. She joined the Janata Party and contested Lok Sabha elections in 1977 unsuccessfully.

Later, she returned to Congress and was active till she developed age-related problems. Late Mambatta Samikutty was her husband.

Kerala governor Arif Mohammed Khan, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala and KPCC president Mullappaly Ramachandran have condoled the death of Kamalam.

In his message, the governor said that Kamalam had earned people’s respect through her leadership and administrative capabilities during her seven-decade long political life.

The chief minister said that Kamalam was an active presence in the fight against Emergency. She was active in politics for over seven decades, he said.

The last rites were held at the Mavoor Road crematorium with full state honours in the evening.

Title: Ahmedabad: Rs 50/hour for parking at Law Garden ‘Happy Street’!
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The newly developed street next to Law Garden

AHMEDABAD: Now you will have to add parking charges to your food bills at the Law Garden khau gully aka ‘ Happy Street ’. Incremental parking charges for Ahmedabad’s gastronomy street were announced by the AMC standing committee on Thursday.

The charges will be on an hourly basis. One hour of day time parking, between 8:30am and 4pm, will cost Rs 10 for two-wheelers and Rs 20 for cars. There will then be a premium between 4pm to 5am, when one hour will cost Rs 30 for two-wheelers and Rs 50 for cars. Construction work on the khau gully is over and it will be soon inaugurated. The street between NCC and Law Garden circle has been brightly lit and has special street markings and furtniture.

“Every hour at Happy Street will cost you,” said AMC standing committee chairman Amul Bhatt. The newly renovated Law Garden food street has been designed to accommodate 446 two-wheelers and 35 cars on both sides of the road in the day. In the evening hours, as food handcarts take their spots, the parking slots will halved to 221 two-wheelers and 21 cars. “As there will be limited space in the evenings, parking rates will more than double,” said Bhatt.

When the number of visitors increase at the ‘Happy Street’, new localized parking plans will be put in place. In all there is space for 42 food vans, from evening to dawn, spread over a 300 metre stretch. According to AMC. There will be 31 big stalls which have been let at a price of Rs 1.67 lakh per month. A senior AMC official told TOI that the 11 small stalls were let for a price of Rs 90,000 per month. For the remaining two small stalls, the highest bids were Rs 73,000 per month.

Title: ‘MK Stalin is opposition leader today, will be the CM tomorrow’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

MK Stalin

THANJAVUR: V K Dhivaharan , brother of V K Sasikala, a close aide of former chief minister J Jayalalithaa and now undergoing imprisonment in Parappana Agrahara jail in Bengaluru, surprised everyone on Thursday by describing DMK president MK Stalin as the future leader of Tamil Nadu and the next chief minister of the state. His speech set off speculation about his possible switching over to the DMK camp.

“Stalin is the opposition leader today. He will be the chief minister tomorrow,” Dhivaharan said, while adding that only Stalin can uphold the Dravidian principles. He shared the stage with Stalin at a wedding in the family of Thanjavur DMK MP SS Palanimanickam .

The situation in Tamil Nadu has worsened and Tamils are being treated as second rate citizens. It has even emboldened a man from Karnataka (referring to actor Rajinikanth ) to speak against Periyar. “Such a situation has risen because Dravidian stalwarts have passed away, one after another. Tamil and Tamil Nadu are important for us and Stalin is the only leader who can safeguard them and we all should back him,” Dhivaharan said.

Touching upon the results of the recent rural local body polls, he said, had DMK leaders been more vigilant they could have secured almost 85% of the seats. But, AIADMK had snatched them away in several places," he said. As if queering the pitch further, Stalin while addressing the gathering, cited a recent speech at a marriage function, by BJP leader PT Arasakumar, who after praising him, had since joined the DMK. “I do not know, where Dhivaharan will be headed to next,” Stalin said.

"Only because of our vigilance, we were able to secure this success. Had the polls been conducted in a free and fair manner, we could have achieved 90% success", Stalin said, countering Dhivaharan’s observation about laxity on the part of DMK leaders.

While the developments set off speculations about Dhivaharan, who is the general secretary of Anna Dravidar Kazhagam (ADK), switching camps, his son and party youth wing leader Jeyanandh Dhivakaran denied any such move. “It was a wedding in the family of a DMK leader and it will be inappropriate to talk about the three-decade old political feud between the two camps. Honouring the host is in our culture,” Jeyanandh said in a post on social media.

“If AIADMK ‘split’ is not sorted out, it will happen eventually is the message to AIADMK cadre. Just a wake up call to them about the reality,” Jeyanandh told TOI, when asked about Dhivaharan naming Stalin as the next chief minister.

Title: 5 maps drafted for greenfield township, feedback sought
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The smart city company has proposed a greenfield township project over 753 acres in the Makhmalabad area

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation (NMSCDCL) has prepared five different maps for the township project under the town planning scheme. The smart city company has put these maps on display and sought feedback from the farmers .

The maps are to be sent to the director of the town planning department of the state government for its technical approval. NMSCDCL will invite suggestion and objection by the farmers after technical approval by the state’s town planning department.

NMSCDCL chairman and senior IAS officer, Sitaram Kunte, said efforts are being made to complete the project within the deadline. “The suggestions and objections are to be sought after the final approval to the draft and maps of the township project by the office of the director of the state town planning department. The project will be cancelled if more than 50% farmers or land owners oppose the project,” added Kunte.

The smart city company has proposed greenfield township project over 753 acres in Makhmalabad area of the city. The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) is a planning authority of the project. The land is to be acquired under the town planning (TP) scheme project, similar to the model implemented in Gujarat.

Some farmers recently met municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game, opposing the project. “These 400 farmers, who are opposing the project, have around 50 hectares. The remaining farmers owning 700 hectares have given their consent to give their land,” he said.

Game reiterated that he himself will cancel the township project if more than 50% of total farmers or land owners oppose the project.

Title: No artists & activists, only ‘artivists’: CM
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said here on Thursday that artists can no longer remain in an ivory tower but must get involved in the struggle for safeguarding freedom and other democratic values. Pointing out that freedom was facing serious threats in the country, he said, “Creative people can longer confine themselves to their creative work only. They can no longer be dismissive about activism. The dividing line between artists and activists is fast getting blurred. In this age of oppression, there can be no artists and activists in its puritan sense. There are only ‘artivists’,” while inaugurating the third edition of Mathrubhumi International Festival of Letters.

He also said that literature festivals in Kerala were a pride of India in general and Kerala in particular. Some Malayalam books published in recent times have crossed 110 editions in no time, he said. “Malayalam is a language to which the weighty works of leading writers in English, Spanish or any other major language get translated without delay. Jean-Paul Sartre, who propounded the theory of existentialism, probably had more fans in Kerala than in France itself,” he said.

The CM also took a dig at foreign journalists who berated Indian reading habits. “An international weekly has said that Indians as a society is yet to evolve a culture of serious book reading. The editor of the weekly, I am sure, wouldn’t have come to such a conclusion had he been to Kerala and exposed his good self to a string of annual book festivals various publishers host here. I am only happy to have him in Kerala,” the CM said, referring to a report in Guardian Weekly on the recently-concluded Jaipur lit fest.

Well-known Hindi poet and novelist Vinod Kumar Shukla won the inaugural MBFIL book of the year award for his ‘Blue is like Blue’. The award, which carrying a cash prize of Rs 500,000, a memento sculpted by Riyas Komu and a citation, was decided by a three-member jury comprising Dr Shashi Tharoor, Chandrasekhara Kambar and Dr Sumana Roy.

Title: Home after 7-day isolation for novel coronavirus, Kalyan man relieved
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Away from family, friends and besieged by information about a raging new virus, this Kalyan man (36) spent this past week in isolation at Kasturba Hospital, Chinchpokli, for suspected novel coronavirus (nCoV).Speaking to TOI following his discharge on Thursday, the father of two said he was relieved to have not carried the infection home.The sales executive and his 31-year-old female colleague from Nalasopara, who had both travelled to China for work, were the first from the city to be isolated at Kasturba on January 23. He had volunteered to meet local doctors after his cold and cough persisted for 24 hours on his return from China’s Guangzhou where he spent six days.“There were moments of euphoria, panic and frustration in the last seven days (of quarantine). The fact that little is known about the virus and how to treat it scared us. We were constantly reading about cases and deaths in China on our phones. When the first report came negative, I was filled with relief and excitement,” he said, adding that staying in touch with loved ones helped him cope with the isolation. The authorities then decided to carry out the second round of tests. “However, they refused to discharge us even after the second test reports arrived on January 28... We got frustrated and anxious.”The Kalyan man recalled that everything was normal when they landed in China on January 16. “By the time we returned, though, things had changed. The Wuhan outbreak had become big. The airport was teeming with people in masks,” he said. “The temperature there was 10 degrees and I had a cold”He said nurses checked on them at least three times a day donning protective gear. “Quality of food was alright but there is room for improvement in cleaning of dishes. The rooms were cleaned multiple times in a day,” he said. “I would urge all with symptoms to seek medical advice.”

Title: US business panel with global brands to visit Defence Expo
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

LUCKNOW: A high profile US delegation comprising top defence manufacturers supplying their products worldover will be visting Lucknow during the Defence Expo next month.

The US companies will visit Lucknow under the banner of US-India Business Council (USIBC), which has been a bridge between India and the US to strengthen economic and security relations and production. The USIBC delegation also comprises top executives of General Atomics, Northdrop Grumman, Harris Corporation , Telephonics, Raythen, Textron, BAE Systems besides Boeing and Lockheed Martin.

Many of these global brands are likely to invest in the upcoming defence corridor in UP. Already, top French defence manufacturer Thales, which supplies strategic parts to Rafale, accepted the state government’s invite to visit the Defence Expo.

In a communication, USIBC president Nisha Biswal has apprised the state government of its plans and the name of the comapanies participating in the Defence Expo in Lucknow.

State MSME minister Siddharth Nath Singh, who is interacting with global companies on behalf of the government, confirmed to TOI that US giants in the field of defence manufacturing committing their participation and evincing interest in investing in the defence corridor. Singh said he has spoken to USIBC members individually and found that that the companies were interested in not only in participating in the exhibition, but committed to invest in the defence corridor in Bundelkhand.

“They have also praised the government’s defence production promotion policy. Various companies inquired about the defence corridor and its progress and the offers under the defence policy,” said Singh.

Title: Traffic cops play Hamlet over helmet rule
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Even though the state government stated before the Gujarat high court that the rule of wearing helmet compulsorily was always there, the cops are still in a dilemma as to whether implement it or not as they haven’t received any instructions from the government.

Sources in the city traffic police said that the government had not sent any circular for helmet rule implementation, but they kept getting conflicting instructions.

“Whenever the government made any announcement for implementation of the rule or to give relaxation, we were given instructions. So, we fined two-wheeler riders for not wearing helmets as and when the government wanted,” said a traffic police cop deployed in the Navrangpura area.

The cop said that when they implemented the helmet rule strictly, people began wearing it to avoid hefty fines. But when the government later relaxed the implementation, people again stopped wearing helmets.

Another traffic policeman said that they have to implement the rule and invite conflict with people who were unaware of the changing stance of the government.

“We are all likely to impose fines on two-wheeler riders found without helmets from February 1,” said the cop.

Joint commissioner of police, J R Mothalia said that he did not know about the high court proceedings, and will take decision on implementation of the helmet rule only after detailed study of the court order.

On asked about the government’s affidavit which states that the rule to wear helmets was always there, Mothalia said that he was not aware of that affidavit and will prefer to go through the court order before speaking on the issue.

Deputy commissioner of police, traffic (West), Ajit Rajian said that he will seek clarification on the court’s order before implementing the helmet rule.

Title: Game pulls up civic officials over pendency of grievances
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

The new application lets citizens choose from a list of the top 10 grievances or type a different complaint

NASHIK: Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game has pulled up civic officials over pending grievances of the citizens.

Grievances related to various departments like water supply, sanitation, electric, health and garden are being filed by citizens through the NMC e-connect mobile application. And over 500 grievances related to various departments are still pending.

During a recent meeting with the head of departments, Game took the officials to task. “Many online grievances are pending. I have directed all the officials to speed up the disposal of pending cases,” Game said.

In 2014, the municipal corporation had launched Smart Nashik App to help citizens in filing complaints. Later, the then municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe had directed the officials to make the app more citizen-friendly. Accordingly, the Smart Nashik App was restructured and was newly launched on March 1, 2019, with a new name: NMC e-connects.

This new application lets citizens choose from a list of the top 10 grievances or type a different complaint. Earlier, junior-level officials were involved in the grievance redressal process. But in the new app, the officials in-charge of addressing the grievances are divisional officers, heads of the departments, additional municipal commissioner and municipal commissioner.

Game has instructed all the HODs to ensure that all online grievances are cleared on the same or next day. They should also ensure that no cases remain pending.

“Maintenance of the garden near Guru Gobind Singh College is not being carried out by the NMC. I filed an online complaint in this regard 15 days ago, but the civic administration has not done anything,” social activist Jalbir Singh said.

Game also reviewed the biometric attendance system of the civic employees. Currently, 58 devices have been provided to the civic administration for bio-metric attendance. Still most of the employees are still not using this new system.

The Municipal commissioner directed the civic administration to withhold the salaries of the employees who are not using the bio-metric attendance.

Title: It’s final! Helmets are compulsory in Gujarat
Content:
Wearing a helmet is compulsory for two-wheeler riders in Gujarat

AHMEDABAD: Wearing a helmet is compulsory for two-wheeler riders in urban areas and there has been no change in the law in Gujarat in this regard. The state government finally put these words on to paper before the Gujarat high court on Thursday, in response to a PIL that exposed the government’s doublespeak on the subject, one thing on paper and the other in practice.The high court disposed of the PIL but not without quashing a circular issued by the commissioner of transport on December 5, 2019, in which all RTOs and ARTOs were told that the use of helmets by two-wheeler riders was optional in municipal limits. This circular was apparently issued after the government issued a press note announcing a temporary relaxation in the rules pertaining to helmets.The petitioner, Sanjeev Ezhava, pointed out in his PIL that the Gujarat government had relaxed the mandatory helmet rule in urban areas, contrary to provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act , which was amended and made more stringent by the Centre in September 2019.The principal secretary of the ports and transport department, Kamal Dayani, filed an affidavit informing the HC that the PIL was “mis-founded and filed without verifying correct records”. The affidavit asserted, “The state government has not issued any order or notification making wearing of protective headgear optional for every driver and pillion rider.” It was also submitted that the state government had in July 2016 done away with the exemption granted to women and children riding pillion from the compulsory helmets rule.The government also cited its communication with the Supreme Court’s committee on Road Safety and submitted that it was informed on January 7 that the Gujarat government had not set any new standard for helmets. The government, in fact, said that the newspaper reports carried reports about a public demand for relaxing the mandatory helmets rule, but no official decision was taken by the government.

Title: Smuggled firearms embolden trigger-happy, gun-toting criminals
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Bhopal: In a disturbing trend in the state capital, several firing incidents have been reported in the last few days. In the first 20 days 0f 2020, half a dozen firing incidents have been reported in the city. Sources claim that due to the easy availability of firearms in the city, not only the hardcore gangsters, the small-time miscreants too possess pistols and openly use them in petty disputes. Along with single shot 'kattas', sophisticated country-made pistols, which can fire multiple shots, are also being smuggled in Bhopal in large numbers and supplied to college students and miscreants at cheap rates.

The craze for guns has been on the rise among youngsters; recently police registered a case against three youth for posting their selfies with illegal guns on social media. And gun runners are out to exploit this fetish for quick money. If a novice contacts them, they charge anything between Rs 15000 to Rs 25000 for the illegal firearms, although these illegal pistols are usually sold for Rs 3000 to Rs 12000 in the city through discreet contacts.

Police sources, requesting anonymity, maintained that situation has become worse because there have been no major seizures of firearms in the city recently. Sources also claimed that some of the senior officers and special city police units formed to investigate such cases have not tracked the real source of seized firearms, which could have led to busting of the gang of firearm suppliers. In 2019, police had registered 1510 cases under Arms Act and seized 28 ‘kattas’, 27 pistols, six revolvers and 80 cartridges.

Retired CSP Salim Khan, who conducted major drives and seized a large number of firearms during his tenure, told TOI that police must launch a major drive against suppliers of illegal guns. Cops will have to find the source of firearms coming in the city and track the supply chain and stop it. He also said that this process must be repeated at regular intervals.

Khan said illegal firearms are supplied in the city mostly from Khargone and Dhar by the notorious ‘Sikligars’. Another route of firearms supply is from Uttar Pradesh via Morena and Bhind. There are a number of suppliers in the bordering districts who smuggle firearms in the city. A senior cop, wishing anonymity, said unemployment and urge to become powerful draws youngsters to guns. Posing with pistols has become a craze on social media and many city youths can be seen holding guns in their profile pictures. He added that everyday young professionals and businessmen approach police in large numbers to get a gun licence. He also emphasised that planned drive against illegal firearms has to be conducted to control this problem.

Ex-DGP Dinesh Chandra Jugran said a lot of youngsters, influenced by movies and social media, are lured to carry pistols with them to create an impression on their peers. He said that psyche of the youth is changing because of many factors in the present scenario, which have a cumulative effect on people. Jugran also said that cops have to play a vital role in controlling the menace and ensure that it doesn't spread. There has to be a minute checking of vehicles on the city borders and inside the city. Police needs to step up new strategies to control this free use of illegal weapons.

ASP (crime branch) Nishchal Jharia admitted that number of people possessing firearms just for craze has gone up, ‘although they don’t use them’. DIG Irshad Ali, however, said that average number of firing incidents had decreased gradually last year, compared to the previous two years. He denied that firearms are being smuggled in the city and added, “Illegal firearms used by the accused in recent firing incidents were with them for years and even decades.”

Title: City shivers at 7.9°C, coldest in Maharashtra on Thursday
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nashik: With mercury dipping to 7.9 degrees celsius on Thursday, the city is once again reeling under cold wave-like conditions.

The recorded minimum temperature was 6 degrees below normal and was lowest in the state on Thursday. Earlier, the city had recorded season’s minimum temperature at 6 degrees celsius on January 17, but the minimum temperature again went up to 15 degrees celsius in the following days.

According to India Meteorological Department (IMD), the northerly winds have penetrated North Maharashtra and that has led to drop in the minimum temperature. “The minimum temperature of Nashik city will be below 10 degrees celsius for a day or two and will increase gradually thereafter,” an IMD official said.

“We were feeling warm for the past few days, but suddenly felt the cold on Thursday morning. I was out for jogging and this is a really good time to exercise,” Pratik Salunke, who works in a private firm, said.

The Malegaon tehsil town recorded a minimum temperature of 10 degrees celsius while the maximum was recorded at 26.2 degrees celsius.

North Maharashtra’s Jalgaon city recorded a minimum temperature of 8.5 degrees celsius on Thursday — 3 degrees below normal. However, the maximum temperature of the city was recorded at 28.4 degrees celsius.

The minimum and maximum temperatures for Ahmednagar city on Thursday were recorded at 9.7 degrees and 27.8 degrees, respectively.

According to Mahatma Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth in Rahuri, Niphad taluka — the grape-growing belt — recorded a minimum temperature of 6 degrees celsius on Thursday. The taluka has recorded season’s lowest temperature at 2.4 degrees celsius on January 17.

Title: Irrigation department repairs eight critical spots in Mutha canal
Content:
File photo of Mutha canal

PUNE: The state irrigation department has undertaken the repair and strengthening works at eight critical spots on Mutha right bank canal to prevent seepage and weakening of its wall.The repairs were carried out near Janata Vasahat , where the canal wall had breached in September 2018, Swargate, Vadgaon, Dhayari and Pulgate, among others, after water discharge into the canal was stopped.In addition to the strengthening work, the irrigation department also removed silt and huge piles of garbage from the canal’s channel to ensure uninterrupted water flow.The Mutha canal , which carries water to the rural areas starts from Khadakwasla dam, covers about 24km distance up to Phursungi. It flows via Sinhagad Road, Dhayari, Janata Vasahat, Parvati, Swargate, Sopanbaug and Hadapsar .Officials in the irrigation department said the canal’s wall was damaged at various spots because of encroachments over the years and construction of ramps. During inspections, it was seen that most spots located within the city limits required repairs and srengthening works, which were undertaken in last one month, the officials said.About 11,345 cubic metres of banking work was carried out at these eight spots, of which most work was done at Vadgaon followed by Dhayari and Swargate stretches. All the possible spots in Janata Vasahat area were also plugged.“Banking work is vital as it includes maintaining adequate width of the canal wall. Till now, the department was not able to carry out repairs on such a large scale because the canal had continuous flow of water. Once the water was stopped, the mechanical department team was able to reach to the bottom of the canal. Though the seepage has not stopped completely as it requires more minute work, it has reduced considerably after the repairs,” an irrigation department official said.He said about 4,996 cubic metres of silt was removed from various spots of the canal to ensure better flow of water. “Similar works have now been extended beyond the city limit ahead of Phursungi,” the official added.

Title: Time-bound entry of all vehicles in BRTS lane on police, PMPML radar
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Local transport authorities and the traffic police have finally come on the same page on opening the Sangamwadi-Vishrantwadi BRTS corridor to all vehicles and decided to brainstorm about time-bound entry into it, after being at loggerheads close to four months.The traffic police unilaterally opened the corridor for all vehicles in October last year. Ajay Charthankar , the joint managing director of the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML), told TOI, “With the corridor being open to all vehicles, a number of accidents have occurred in the recent past. Last week, officials from the PMPML and the police inspected different corridors in a bid to take stock of the safety. We are thinking of setting up a system to facilitate time-bound entry of vehicles into the BRTS corridor. Proper planning will precede execution.”another PMPML official said, “The idea is to ensure that the sanctity of the corridor, which is meant only for buses, is maintained.”PMPML has not formally allowed the traffic police to open the BRTS corridor for all vehicles till now, a source said.Charthankar said, “The police had sent us a letter last year demanding that the corridor be opened. We didn’t grant them the permission and the status is still the same. We have not said anything to them formally. We never wanted to open the corridor to all vehicles but the police did it anyway.”

Title: UP: Teachers to double up as Ganga Yatra hosts
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Ganga Yatra takes precedence over teaching in schools

LUCKNOW: Government teachers posted in 10 primary schools in UP’s Hardoi district have been directed to provide hospitality to the delegation participating in ongoing Ganga Yatra .

An order (a copy is with TOI) was issued by block education officer (BEO) of Bilagram in Hardoi asking teachers and cooks working in 10 primary schools to ensure accommodation and food to Ganga Yatris.

The four-day Ganga Yatra, which took off from Bijnor and Ballia on January 27, reached Hardoi on Thursday. The yatra will culminate in Kanpur on Friday.

The yatra aims at increasing awareness on Ganga cleanliness and rejuvenation. “According to the letter of the district basic education officer dated 28/01/2020, participants of the Ganga Yatra will have a night stay (on January 30) in gram panchayats near the banks of Ganga. Teachers and cooks of schools mentioned below should provide lodging and food to the delegation,” the order said.

Four primary schools of Bilagram and six of Sandi block of Hardoi were mentioned in the order.

The order, however, did not go down well with teachers. “For anything happening in the state, be it bridal makeover for mass marriage, pulse polio campaign, updating of voter list, they (government) assign responsibility to us. And now we have to take care of Ganga Yatris. How do they expect us to impart quality education,” asked a teacher.

Repeated attempts to contact basic shiksha adhikari (BSA), Hardoi, Hemant Rao failed. He also did not reply to messages sent by TOI.

The order came days after government teachers in Siddharthnagar district were assigned duties to do bridal makeover for brides getting married under the government’s mass marriage programme.

However, after the order went viral on social media, basic education officer of Siddharthnagar Surya Kant Tripathi cancelled the order issued by block officer and proposed an inquiry against him.

Title: Sriram’s suspension extended
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Turning down the recommendations by chief secretary to reinstate IAS officer Sriram Venkitaraman back to service, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan ordered that his suspension period be extended by another three months.

The order comes in the wake of his suspension period completing six months this week. As per the rules, the period of suspension of a member of the All India Service on charges other than corruption can go up to a maximum of one year, during which the inquiry against him should be completed and appropriate order should be issued failing which the suspension order will automatically stand revoked.

Despite holding four sittings and recording the statements of all those who have been mentioned in the police report, the departmental inquiry that was initiated against Venkitaraman could not prove that he was drunk while driving the car that rammed the motorcycle of journalist Muhammed Basheer, resulting in his death. The departmental inquiry commission headed by principal secretary (industries) Sanjay Garg which gave a report to the government citing that the charges against Venkitaraman could not be proved, had to reach the conclusion because of the grave error on the part of the police of delaying the medical test on the officer to check presence of alcohol in the blood.

The extension of his suspension comes as a prelude to police chargesheet, which is likely to be filed in a day or two.

Title: TMA-Adani to honour startup companies
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Trivandrum Management Association ( TMA ) has invited nominations for TMA-Adani startup award 2020 from startup companies in the state.

This award is intended to recognize a business owner or the founder of an organization who has developed a unique business model and has made remarkable progress in the initial phase of starting the business. The award comes with a citation and a trophy and will be presented at the inaugural session of TRIMA 2020 — the annual management convention of TMA scheduled for February 27.

A nominal processing fee of Rs 1,000 is applicable for submitting nominations for the award. The nomination with details of the project, current status of the project, amount spent, latest audited annual accounts, etc, should be forwarded to the secretary, Trivandrum Management Association, TMA House, Lions Centre Building, Jawahar Nagar, Kowdiar P.O., Thiruvananthapuram - 695 003 or mail to trima_85@yahoo.co.in. There is no standard format, and applicants are advised to provide maximum details, presentation materials, etc. The last date for submission of nominations is February 15. For details visit: tmakerala.com, Phone: 0471-2714786. tnn

Title: NIA plea: Shift Elgar Parishad case proceedings to Mumbai court
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The National Investigation Agency (NIA) moved an application on Wednesday before the special UAPA court here seeking transfer of all the records and proceedings related to the Elgar Parishad case to the special NIA court in Mumbai.

Special UAPA judge S R Navander is expected to hear the NIA plea on February 3 and has called for written submissions from the state and the nine activists arrested so far in the case.

Special public prosecutor Ujjwala Pawar told TOI, “The NIA had approached the court with their lawyer to file the application. As of now, we have no instructions from the investigating officer or any other state authority. Unless I get instructions, I won’t appear in the matter.”

On the written submission sought from the state, Pawar said, “The investigating officer will file the say. We will wait for instructions.”

The lawyers appearing for the arrested activists said notices for written submissions had been served on them directly at the Yerawada central jail, where they are currently lodged under judicial custody.

One of the defence lawyers told TOI, “While we are yet to receive a copy of the NIA application, we have gone through its contents. Among other things, the letter mentions re-registration of an FIR by the NIA in Mumbai on January 27.”

He said, “The UAPA charges have been invoked in the matter, nine activists have been arrested and two chargesheets have been filed so far.”

It is the Pune police’s case that the Elgar Parishad held on December 31, 2017, at Shaniwarwada was funded and supported by the banned CPI (Maoist) organisation as part of a conspiracy to create unrest and overthrow the government. Alleged inflammatory speeches at the conclave contributed to the January 1, 2018, caste riots at Koregaon Bhima .

Since June 6, 2018, nine activists — Sudhir Dhawale , Rona Wilson, Surendra Gadling, Shoma Sen, Mahesh Raut, P Varavara Rao, Sudha Bharadwaj, Arun Ferreira and Vernon Gonsalves — have been arrested for their alleged links with the CPI (Maoist).

On January 24, the Union home ministry had passed an order transferring further investigation into the case from the Pune police to the NIA after the newly formed Maha Vikas Aghadi government in the state initiated a review of the investigation done so far by the police. The review was started after NCP chief Sharad Pawar had demanded setting up of an SIT to inquire into the police action in the case.

Title: Smart Corp to identify space for citizens’ centre
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) has decided to identify a new space for its proposed citizens’ experience centre.

Earlier, it had identified space at the Mahatma Phule Art Gallery in the city.

However, NMSCDCL chairman and senior IAS officer Sitaram Kunte said that the space identified at the gallery is inadequate.

“We have identified few other sites, near Golf Club ground, the planetarium of the civic body and Bhalekar High School building of the Nashik Municipal Corporation. The new site will be finalised soon. The work for the project will begin thereafter,” said Kunte.

The information about the city and various projects under the smart city and by NMC are to be showcased at the experience centre.

This is part of NMSCDCL Project Nashik Safe and Smart City, which is implemented by MahaIT and to be executed by M/s UST Technology International Pvt Ltd.

The objective of the centre is to bring awareness of smart city initiative, to promote Nashik as historical, religious and cultural destination, form futuristic digital showcase and unique virtual experience centre.

This experience centre will help bridge the gap between perception, expectation and reality.

NMSCDCL officials said they will finalise the place for the proposed citizens experience centre within a fortnight.

Title: Anganwadi stir: Protesters gherao child welfare dept office
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Anganwadi

Dehradun: Days after holding captive a team of medical personnel who had come to check on them, protesting anganwadi workers laid siege to the office of the women and child welfare department (WCD) on Thursday.

Irked over the director’s move to send notice to the protesting anganwadi personnel to resume work or else face suspension, the protesting workers locked the main gate and met the director of WCD, Jharna Kamthan.

Speaking to TOI on the issue, Kamthan said, “The notice was issued by the respective districts and not from the directorate. Also, we are ready to listen to their demands provided they resume work first. In some places like Chamoli and Pithoragarh, the anganwadi workers have resumed work. The rest should also do it.”

The protesters, however, expressed scepticism over the official’s assurances and asserted that they will continue with the protest until the officials heed to their demands.

“Why should we bow down to their demands when our basic rights are being trampled upon? The director told us that they are following the orders from political leaders, which means we are being fooled by the politicians. Year-on-year, each government keeps on giving us assurances, but no one fulfills them,” said Rekha Negi, president, Anganwari Karmachari Union of Uttarakhand.

Meanwhile, two of the protesters were lifted from Parade Ground in the evening on Thursday and forcibly taken to a hospital by the police. At the same time, two other anganwadi workers from Kalsi area of Chakrata sat on an indefinite hunger strike. Till date, 14 anganwadi workers have been lifted from the protest site.

The anganwadi works are on a strike from the past one-and-a-half month which has impeded several programmes run by health, education and statistics department.

The agitators have been fighting for Rs 600 daily wage and regular employee status.

Title: IIT-Hyderabad to appoint 1 more counsellor in bid to reduce student stress
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

HYDERABAD: Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Hyderabad has decided to appoint an additional psychological counsellor and coordinators in hostels for students going through a stressful time and for those seeking help from fellow students or management in the campus.

The decision to prioritize mental health comes after the institute witnessed three suicides by students in the last year.

Unveiling the ‘IIT Hyderabad’s Vision for 2024’, Prof BS Murthy, the new Director of IIT Hyderabad said, “Major emphasis is being placed in reducing stress levels of students. We are going to add an additional psychological counsellor on the campus and appoint a pod coordinator for each floor of the hostel where one student will be made in charge and provided financial support to organize regular meetings to just gather students of their hostel floor and have a small get together and open up by just talking to each other.”

Murthy informed that IIT Hyderabad is also taking measures to have faculty and alumni mentor students, conduct ‘stress relieving’ sessions by psychologists and motivational speakers and introduce shared accommodation for first year UG students.

Dr C Krishna Mohan, professor of computer science and engineering and dean of public and corporate relations said, “We are appointing one male psychological counsellor on the campus apart from the two female counsellors that we already have. We also have class advisors and one teacher for every three students to discuss their concerns. We are taking all possible measures to reduce suicides.” The institute has set a target of generating Rs 200 crore per year for funding research by 2024. The current level of research funding stands at Rs 50 crore a year.

Title: Yale prof warns over handling of coronavirus cases
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Bhopal: Yale professor Joseph Vinetz, ly an expert on how infectious disease spread, has raised an alarm about the way suspected Coronavirus patients are being handled in India.

A visiting faculty at PGI Chandigarh, Prof Vinetz said: “WHO, CDC scientists are extremely concerned about suspected Coronavirus patients being discharged without molecular tests in densely populated countries like India. Neither molecular tests nor the complete WHO and CDS protocols of testing are being followed. The patients could be a great danger to the community at large.”

The internationally renowned expert explained: “The new Coronavirus seems to have become stable in humans and the spread of cases reflects this new adaptation to humans.”

At this point, it’s fair to say that this (mutation) probably happened at the time that this virus jumped from whichever animal sources to humans.

“The best strategy is to wash hands well and to stay away from crowded places for a few weeks,” said Prof Vinetz.

Experts indicate at the possibility of mutation of coronavirus in a student at Ujjain, where the suspected patient’s mother was also treated for viral influenza. The MP health department is also directed for surveillance of suspected Coronavirus family members for any mutation. Novel coronavirus (nCoV) is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans. “We usually do not diagnose most of the viruses. India needs easily available diagnostics facilities,” said Prof Vinetz.

The only way to diagnose Coronavirus is extensive molecular-based testing. Blood test will not be helpful. Molecular test on serum sample or swab from back of the nose is tested in reference laboratory, he said. Molecular tests are generally are not available (in India), except in highly specialized reference laboratories, he added.

Title: Govt clears spl pay for SPU as other units still wait
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: The state home department on Thursday issued a government resolution (GR) sanctioning risk allowance to Special Protection Unit (SPU), which functions under the State Intelligence Department (SID), following the revised pay scheme under the seventh pay commission.
