If any person suspected then his or her blood samples will be sent for further tests,” said director, public health, Ajit Kumar Mohanty.

The central team will monitor the measures being taken to tackle bird flu in the state for next 10 days. “It is good that the virus was detected before it was too late. All measures have been taken according to the guidelines and situation is well under control and there is nothing to panic. Sanitisation and surveillance works in the area will continue,” said Alok Vajpai, a member of the three-member team from Union ministry of health.

Though the bird flu scare has little impact on midday meal, the chicken price has dropped from Rs 180 per kg to Rs 160 in the city. “Except for one locality in Bhubaneswar, bird flu has not been detected anywhere in the state. So there is no point in not serving eggs in midday meal. District administrations will decide whether egg will be served in midday meal or not after discussing the situation with chief district veterinary officer,” said state nodal officer for midday meal Gangadhar Sahoo.

In wedding receptions, mutton, prawn and fish are preferred than chicken items. But, consumption of chicken has not stopped completely. “We included mutton in the main course instead of chicken after bird flu was detected in the city and served chicken in starter during the wedding reception of my sister and people ate without hesitation,” said Durga Prasad Nayak, a resident of Satya Nagar.

(EOM)

(EOM)

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Congress holds Hanuman jaap, BJP hurls a barb
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

CM Kamal Nath greeted by Pt Vijay Shankar Mehta at a ‘Hanuman Chalisa’ path held at the Minto Hall in Bhopal o... Read More

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath organised a Hanuman Jaap on the martyrdom anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi on Thursday, but it led to political controversy when BJP criticised it.

The saffron party took a dig at Congress, claiming its ‘soft Hindutva’ will not work. CM Nath shot back, “We are all religious. I don’t know why BJP gets stomach ache when we visit temples and talk about religion. Is BJP the sole guardian of Hindutva? It only misuses religion for political gains. Congress does not mix religion with politics.”

Nath is a devotee of Lord Hanuman and has installed a mega idol at Chhindwara. Banners put up at Minto Hall, the venue of the Hanuman Jaap on Thursday, described Nath as ‘Hanuman Bhakt’.

The BJP, however, criticized Congress, with party state president Rakesh Singh saying, “If Congress thinks it can confuse the majority population by chanting Hanuman Chalisa, they are mistaken. They are free to perform any religious ritual, but people of the country cannot be misled by any such acts.”

Nath hit back with a stinging retort: “I do not want to talk about Rakesh Singh as he is prone to making statements without applying his brain. The Hanuman Jaap is being organised for the welfare, progress and development of people of Madhya Pradesh . I urge BJP leaders to join this religious event in the interest of public welfare,” Nath said.

Ever since it came to power in Madhya Pradesh, the Congress government has undertaken a series of steps to show its Hindutva side. It has announced Ram Van Gaman Path, promised to build 1,000 cow sheds and provide funds for construction of permanent Ramlila platforms in urban local bodies. Recently, the government decided to contribute to the development of Sita Mata temple in Sri Lanka.

Title: Jamia firing: Students protest outside police HQ
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Police immediately detained the students and took them to IP Estate and Rajendra Nagar police stations. They w... Read More

NEW DELHI: Demanding strict action against the person who opened fire in the Jamia area and injured a student on Thursday, dozens of people, including students from different universities, gathered outside the Delhi police headquarters at ITO around 7 pm on Thursday. They also sought action against the police personnel deployed at the incident site who allegedly did not do anything to stop the gunman from firing at the protesters.

Police, however, immediately detained the gathered students and took them to IP Estate and Rajendra Nagar police stations. They were released after an hour.

“We want strict action against the person who went around brandishing guns and even injured a student. What is most worrisome is the way the police stood there doing nothing. We cannot let them go scot free,” said a DU student. He was earlier detained while participating in a human chain in protest against CAA and NRC.

Many others demanded action against BJP leaders Anurag Thakur, Kapil Mishra and Parvesh Verma. “Today’s incident is the result of hate speeches by these leaders. When Delhi Police can file sedition charges against students, why are they being spared? It is unfortunate that BJP is using hate speeches to polarise voters,” said Kawalpreet Kaur, a DU student and an AISA activist.

“Somebody could have died in the firing today. However, police and BJP seem to be least bothered,” said Sanya, a first-year student.

Around midnight, over 200 students again gathered near the police headquarters to protest and the carriageway in front of it had to be blocked.

Title: Ganjam gears up to check accidents on fatal stretch
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Berhampur: The Taptapani ghat road under the Mohana-Digaphandi stretch on National Highway-326 (Vijayawada to Ranchi) has turned into a death trap. Since May 21 last year, at least 20 people have died on this stretch, including the eight who were killed when a passenger bus fell off a bridge early on Wednesday morning.

The latest incident has raised question mark on the district administration’s efforts to check accidents. Ganjam district collector Vijay Amruta Kulange has asked engineers of the National Highway to conduct an inquiry to ascertain if there’s any defect in road construction or whether there is lack of road safety measures for which accidents have been occurring.

“We have already submitted a report on road safety measures to the superintendent engineer, National Highway, Berhampur, after conducting an inquiry following Wednesday’s accident,” said Ashok Das, executive engineer, National Highway’s Paralakhemundi division.

“As part of road safety measures, signages have been put up on the spot along with tree-guard and cross barriers,” Das said. “The width of the road is 7 metres. We think there was no fault on our part as far as road safety measures on the stretch are concerned,” he added.

Eight persons, including six women, died and more than 30 were injured when a Berhampur-bound passenger bus fell 20 feet below from a bridge near Taptapani ghat, about 60 km from here. The condition of most of the injured persons are said to be stable.

On Thursday, BJP’s Ganjam district unit president Bibhuti Jena said a traffic post should have been set up in the area and traffic police deployed to check the speed of vehicles at the black spots. “Speed-breakers must be set up on the stretch to control the speed limit of vehicles,” Jena said.

Aska sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) Suryamani Pradhan said patrolling was frequently conducted in the area. Checking of vehicles was also done frequently in the area and drivers were advised to control their speed.

“Lack of experienced drivers and violation of road safety rules led to most of the accidents on this stretch of the highway,” Pradhan said. “The drivers should ensure that the vehicles are in proper condition and that they don’t fall sick and neither drink and drive. Continuous driving is also dangerous,” he added.

Title: Mumbai: Rajmohan Gandhi visits CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Rajmohan Gandhi (PTI file photo)

MUMBAI: Showing solidarity with hundreds of women staging a sit-in against the Citizenship Amendment Act, National Population Register and National Register of Citizens at Mumbai Bagh or Mumbai’s Shaheen Bagh at Nagpada, historian and Mahatma Gandhi’s grandson Rajmohan Gandhi said on Thursday his grandfather would have stood with the protesters.

“I am Gandhi’s grandson, but you are real Gandhians because you are protesting something which you think is wrong,” he said. “Gandhi would have sided with you because he believed in ahimsa (non-violence) and your protests are peaceful,” he told the women who have been staging a sit-in on Morland Road at Nagpada from the intervening night of January 26 and 27.

He said, “People will try to provoke you, insult you with statements. Don’t get provoked. Keep protests peaceful,” he said. He, along with many activists and protesters, observed a two-minute silence of 2 minutes in memory of the Mahatma who was martyred on January 30, 1948. Activists Firoz Mithiborewala, Fareed Khan and filmmaker Anand Patwardhan had accompanied Gandhi. “Rajmohanji’s visit gave women protesters new courage,” said Khan.

Title: Guilty won’t be spared, told top cop to act: Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Amit Shah

NEW DELHI: Home minister Amit Shah on Thursday said incidents such as the random firing by a youth on anti-CAA protesters in Jamia area would not be tolerated and directed the city police commissioner to take strictest possible action in the case.

“There was a firing incident in Delhi today... I have spoken to Delhi Police commissioner about it and directed him to take strictest action. The Centre will not put up with such incidents, there will be serious consequences and guilty will not be spared,” Shah said in a tweet on Thursday afternoon.

In another tweet a couple of hours later, Shah announced that Delhi Police special commissioner Pravir Ranjan had been tasked to hold a comprehensive probe into the firing incident.

Shah’s statement came in the backdrop of the opposition’s attacks on the home ministry and Delhi Police for failing to prevent the attack. However, special commissioner Ranjan rebutted the charge that police personnel deployed near Jamia were lax. He said the incident could not be prevented as it happened in a “split second”.

Title: Cabinet to bring ordinance to authorise govt to shut slaughterhouses in state
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Urban development minister Madan Kaushik said that the Cabinet hasdecided to amend the minor mineral policy

Dehradun: The Uttarakhand cabinet on Thursday gave a nod to a slew of proposals, including giving authorisation to the state government to close slaughterhouses, allocating 200 acres of land for AIIMS Rishikesh and amending the Uttarakhand Minor Mineral Policy, 2001 among other decisions.

Among the major decisions, the cabinet, chaired by chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat, approved a proposal to promulgate an ordinance which gives power to the state government to shut down slaughterhouses. Till now, the municipal corporation concerned used to take a call on this matter.

The decision comes in the wake of the slaughterhouse at Manglaur in Haridwar district being a major issue of contention with many especially those from the saffron party being against having a slaughterhouse near the holy city. CM Rawat had also categorically said that slaughterhouses would not be allowed in Haridwar.

In another major decision, the cabinet also decided to amend the Uttarakhand Minor Mineral Policy, 2001, thereby permitting mining on the banks of rivers up to 3-metre-depth. Earlier, mining was permitted upto a depth of 1.5 metre.

Providing the rationale for the decision, government spokesperson and urban development minister Madan Kaushik said, “We have decided to amend the Uttarakhand Minor Mineral Policy, 2001, to boost revenue in the mining sector.”

Among other decisions, the Uttarakhand government decided to take back the 830 acres of land in Rishikesh which was leased out to drug manufacturing company, Indian Drugs and Pharmaceuticals Limited (IDPL). The lease is ending in March.

Out of the total land, 200 acres would be given to AIIMS Rishikesh and the remaining would be transferred to the tourism department.

Apart from that, the cabinet decided to increase the upper age limit for recruitment to technical posts in the state roadways department from 35 to 42 and the time for hearing VAT-related cases from January 2020 to March 2020.

It was also decided to set up a residential college at Jaiharikhal in Pauri district. The college would be operated through a trust, which would have the chief minister as its chairperson and education minister as its vice-chairperson. An NGO would provide 60 % fund for the project.

In decisions related to Kumbh 2021, the cabinet approved the creation of 31 posts for the mega festival to be held in Haridwar next year. The posts include those of deputy mela adhikari, information officer, assistant accountant, senior assistant, junior assistants, data entry operators etc.

Title: 4 years on, state zoo authority is a nonentity lacking powers
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: Four years after Maharashtra Zoo Authority (MZA) was set up with an aim to streamline functioning of zoos in the state, the authority itself has become a nonentity.

In 2014, then forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar had made announcement in his budget speech to set up MZA. Accordingly, it came into existence on December 30, 2015.

The main aim of setting up the MZA was to monitor and improve zoos, rescue centres and transit treatment centres in the state. Maharashtra has nine zoos, four rescue centres and four transit treatment centres. Set up with much fanfare, there is no regular head to lead the authority for the last 16 months. It also doesn’t have a full-time wildlife veterinarian and an engineer.

The last chief conservator of forests (CCF) and member-secretary of MZA, SS Dole, retired on August 31, 2018. Since then, additional charge was handed over to CCF and Pench field director RS Govekar .

Govekar planned to improve things in the MZA, but he is already in-charge of two tiger reserves (Pench and Bor) and two sanctuaries (Tipeshwar and Umred-Karhandla) along with buffer area of Pench, besides several other responsibilities.

Govekar told TOI, “Last year, we had discussions with top officials in the ministry of environment, forest and climate change (MoEFCC) on autonomy for MZA, but were told that there is no such provision in the Wildlife Protection Act.”

Under the Wildlife (Protection) Act (WPA), 1972, the controlling body of all zoos is Central Zoo Authority (CZA), Delhi, which executes its decision through state chief wildlife warden (CWLW) in whom statutory powers are vested. To decentralize work of zoos from CWLW and better functioning, MZA came into existence, but the authority has been reduced to an insignificant body.

Former MZA chief Dole says, “When CZA has all statutory powers to monitor zoos, the MZA becomes redundant. We had proposed autonomy to MZA by seeking powers to release grants to zoos in the state, but the proposal was rejected. Every aspect right from master plans to any preparatory works need CZA approval.”

Dole added, “MZA’s role is minimized as all the zoos, barring Gorewada and a zoo in Mumbai, are managed by either separate institutions or municipal corporations. These bodies are also opposed to interference in their affairs. Moreover, with CZA having inherent powers under the WPA, the state zoo authority has been marginalized.”

In the last four years, the MZA has organized a few training workshops and has nothing much to its credit. Its governing council and executive committee also doesn’t meet regularly. The MZA was entrusted with a major task to appoint consultants for the ex-minister’s dream projects to start leopard and tiger safaris in Chandrapur, Pune and Amravati, but these safaris have derailed.

The last time MZA was in news was for ugly fight between an accountant and divisional forest officer (DFO) Kamlakar Dhamge in which the latter was injured.

“We expect MZA to liaison with CZA to streamline working of state zoos and address their problems. The Maharajbagh zoo plan is pending with the CZA for long. The high court has already asked to grant recognition to the zoo,” said Dr SS Bawaskar, zoo officer in-charge.

Title: 123rd batch of recruits attested as soldiers
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: The recruits of the 123rd course at the Guards Regimental Centre (GRC), Kamptee, were attested as soldiers of the Indian Army.

The occasion was marked by an impressive Passing Out Parade at the centre.

In the parade, they took the solemn oath to protect the nation even at the peril of life.

The event was witnessed by their near and dear ones who came from various parts of the country.

The parade was reviewed by Maj Gen Raju Chauhan, General Officer Commanding of a Sub Area.

The reviewing officer impressed upon the recruits that becoming a soldier is a matter of pride and also an onerous responsibility. He exhorted the recruits to commit themselves to the service of the nation — physically, mentally and in all dimensions.

He gave away medals to the outstanding performers of the course.

Recruit Mannu Vishwakarma was adjudged the Best Recruit. He hails from District Gorakhpur (Uttar Pradesh).

Title: Speeding truck kills elephant, injures another
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Dhenkanal: An elephant died and another was injured after being hit by a truck near Jibankhol in Dhenkanal district on NH-55 early on Thursday. The elephant died on the spot, said a forest official.

Another elephant, which was injured in the mishap, reportedly ran away into the forest while its broken tusk lay near the spot, said the official.

An official source said a herd of 24 elephants were crossing the NH-55 at Jibankhol when a truck hit them around 4.30am. Police said the truck driver failed to see the animals either due to darkness or dense fog.

The spot has been marked ‘elephant corridor’ by the forest department. Owing to the mishap, road traffic was disrupted for long hours. Hundreds of trucks, buses and other heavy vehicles were stranded for hours on Dhenkanal-Angul highway stretch.

Locals alleged that due to lackadaisical attitude of the forest department, the mishap occurred.

Santosh Kumar Behera, sarpanch, Odapada, alleged, “Though the herd has been crossing the National Highway everyday, the forest department has not taken any measures for the jumbos’ safe passage.”

Arabinda Kumar Majhi, a wildlife expert from Dhenkanal, said, “For past 10 years, elephants have been crossing the NH-55 and a railway line to reach the Brahmani river for water. Though the forest department is aware of this, it has not taken any measures for jumbos’ safety.”

Dhenkanal DFO B P Acharaya said, “We have put signboards on both side of the road, marking them as elephant corridor. Besides, our staff in morning and evening alert motorists to be careful while crossing the road.”

The DFO said, “We have seized the truck. As both the truck driver and helper are on the run we couldn’t ascertain what exactly caused the mishap.”

“We will register a case and investigate into the incident. We buried the elephant after conducting postmortem. Besides, we would track the injured elephant to treat it,” the DFO said.

The DFO maintained that they will adopt all safety measures to protect the elephants. “We will adopt methods that are being followed in other states to protect the elephants, particularly when they cross the National Higways,” the officer said.

Title: Ahead of budget, industry wants roadmap and simplification of GST
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Bhopal: Amidst reports of growth rate shrinking from 8 per cent to 5 per cent and recommendation of International Monetary Fund (IMF) to take steps to reverse the economic slowdown, the business fraternity in MP expects NDA-II to prepare a long-term roadmap for the industry in its forthcoming budget.

On Feb 1, Narendra Modi led NDA government will table its first budget after coming to power for the second time. Though there have more than 300 amendments in the GST regime, industrial fraternity wants further ‘simplification’ and lowering of GST on some items.

Voicing his concern, chairman of Confederation of Indian Industry (CII), Bhopal zonal council, Animesh Jain said, “Government has taken several steps to improve the industrial scenario and the economy, but a comprehensive road map also needs to be made for the next two-three years. It would help industrialists to invest.” Jain went on to add, “Whenever some investment is done with an eye to generate employment, by the time production starts, some new policy comes into play. Therefore, a holistic plan, at least for the next two-three years, is required. It would give clarity on how to move ahead.”

Though a lot of changes have been done on the GST front, Jain said, there is scope for doing a lot more on this front. The CII chairman said that automobile sector also needs government’s attention. “This sector contributes almost 18 % to the economy ; it needs greater attention. GST should be lowered for the vehicles in Rs 15 lakh to 16 lakh bracket,” he added.

City -based industrialist and founder member Confederation of MP industry service and trade (COMPIST), Akash Jain said, “There have been so many amendments that it has become difficult for the industrialists and chartered accountants to keep pace with these changes. Government should also take initiatives to increase the consumption and think of providing income tax relief to individuals.” Chairman of Bhopal chambers of commerce, Lalit Jain, said, “Drugs for cancer should be made tax -ree.”

Title: Woman consumes poison in police station
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Chandrapur: A woman consumed poison in Jiwti police station on Thursday, after cops arrested her allegedly innocent husband for illegal possession and sale of liquor . While the woman has been admitted to Gadchandur rural hospital and is battling for life, Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) has demanded strong action against PSO of Jiwti police station.

Sources informed that Jiwti police had got a tip-off that the mother of one Pooja Kalpe is involved in illegal liquor sale, and raided her house on Wednesday night. They seized a few bottles of liquor, however, instead of registering an offence against the woman, the cops decided to book Aakash Kalpe, son-in-law of the woman for possession of liquor. The woman, whose name could not be ascertained, claimed that she had begged the cops not to do so, since her daughter Pooja Kalpe and son-in-law live separately at Shengaon. However, they did not agree, and called them to the police station the next morning.

On Thursday morning, the woman and her daughter Pooja went to the police station. However, cops said the offence was registered against her son-in-law Aakash Kalpe, and asked them to bring him to the police station. Shocked and baffled by the police action to register offence against her husband, Pooja consumed poison in the police station in an attempt to commit suicide.

Her mother claimed the cops did not even bother to take her daughter to hospital for treatment, and the family had to arrange to take the woman to Gadchandur rural hospital more than 25km away.

MNS Rajura wing has taken up the issue and demanded inquiry into the matter, and action against the PSO Jiwti for his alleged insensitive behaviour.

Title: I’m going to school, Jamia shooter said at home
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

JEWAR: A little before Thursday noon, he picked up his bag and told his grandfather he was going to school. A bit late for school, but then his family was away for a wedding in Jhajjar and no one really was asking questions. He said he would head to the wedding after classes.

The wedding, in reality, was far from his mind: the boy, a Class XII commerce student at a private school, had packed a gun in his bag and headed straight for Delhi ( Shaheen Bagh was the subject of all the recent hatred he had been spewing on Facebook). A couple of hours later, his relatives and friends saw him on national TV — some on the Facebook Live he webcast before that — wildly brandishing a gun at Citizenship Amendment Act protesters near Jamia Millia Islamia and shooting at a student who tried to stop him.

His 80-year-old grandfather, the only one home when the news broke, was in a state of disbelief. “I have no idea how he got a gun or who asked him to do this,” he said. The shooter’s mother teaches at a primary school. His father runs a store that is at the front of the house in a narrow Jewar village road that threads through a warren of single and double-storey homes stacked against each other. The boy’s brother is 13 years old. His family shares the two-storey ancestral home with the family of his deceased uncle — an aunt and a cousin who is about as old as he is.

Within minutes of the news of his arrest, the lane was bustling with people, curious and confused in equal measure. Relatives and friends who had gathered said they had never seen a violent streak in him and insisted he was a well-behaved boy, drawing a personality sharply divergent from the one his Facebook friends saw: of undisguised hatred towards one community and his own violent intentions.

“He’d stay home and not get too involved in things,” said Yogesh, a neighbour. But over the past few days, there had been a change in his behaviour when he was sullen and irritable. “He seemed unwell and disturbed about something. But we hadn’t expected things to take this turn,” he added.

A friend who went to school with the shooter said he was shocked. “He was always quiet. We drifted apart a little after we chose different streams after Class X — I picked science and he studied commerce,” said the friend. “We would meet during recess and sometimes at the end of the school day. I don’t know how he got involved in all this. I am shocked.”

What, then, was the trigger? Some speculated about community groups “brainwashing” him. Who he was at home and how he projected himself online were often at odds. “He held strongly nationalistic views. He would move around with certain groups, he would single out a community to abuse in his Facebook posts and would pick fights on social media,” said a neighbour.

His posts were widely commented on and many of the reactions were congratulatory. But the consistent rants of hatred and threats of violence from a place barely 90km from the national capital did not, surprisingly, come to the notice of Noida Police, which has a digital volunteer force of citizens and former cops specifically for this purpose. Noida police have in the last three months registered eight FIRs against people for writing ‘objectionable’ social media posts and made six arrests. Additional CP Sriparna Ganguly, who is also the spokesperson for Noida police, admitted they were unaware about the boy. “Our digital volunteers didn’t share any information about the suspect in question but we’re surely going to take cognisance of it and rectify things in future,” she said.

Title: Maharashtra: Man gets 10-year jail for raping 7-year-old
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

Title: Officials behaving like social activists, says Uma Bharati
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Bhopal: Former Union minister Uma Bharati said on Thursday that Madhya Pradesh chief secretary should ask government officials to not speak on controversial issues like CAA. She said that officials who want to work as social activists should resign and protest in Shaheen Bagh.

She said, "The officials are behaving like activists in Madhya Pradesh. They should be controlled. I request the chief secretary to instruct government officials that they are not supposed to speak on certain issues in violation of service rules. If they want to work as social activists, they should resign and stage a protest in Shaheen Bagh."

The BJP leader also hit out at the state government for misguiding the public with regard to CAA. "Congress is trying to create a situation that prevailed in 1947, when India was partitioned. Those protesting against the Citizen Amendment Act don't know about the new law. People are being misled, but we will not allow that to happen," she said.

The BJP leader also disapproved of ex-minister Badrilal Yadav's objectionable remark against Rajgarh collector Nidhi Nivedita during a public meeting. She said that she does not support Yadav’s comment, but you cannot slap a person who is holding the Tricolour in his hands. “When chief minister Kamal Nath led an anti-CAA rally it was not stopped by authorities, how can they stop a demonstration in support of the new law and slap the leaders of opposition party?” said Bharati.

On BJP's inaction over Maihar MLA Narayan Tripathi's anti-CAA remarks, Bharti said, "Tripathi is a rolling stone. He bites like lice. I will talk to BJP chief Rakesh Singh about this matter," said Bharati.

Title: When a ‘voice of calm’ came in the line of fire
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

A student was hit by bullet during a protest march at Jamia on Thursday

NEW DELHI: Artist, curious reader, amateur photographer and theatre enthusiast — Shadab Farooq dons many hats. But his most important role, his friends claim, is that of a “hyperlocal pacifist.”

Farooq, the 23-year-old student, who was shot at by a gunman during an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protest near Jamia Millia Islamia on Thursday, is originally from Jammu ’s Doda district. A second semester student at Anwar Jamal Kidwai Mass Communication Research Centre, Farooq had completed his graduation from the English department at Jamia before joining MCRC.

The mass communication student had been the voice of calm, especially after the new citizenship law came into effect, said Simran, a close friend. “He believes in non-violence, in the power of dialogue and in standing up for justice. When protests started at Jamia and police stormed into the campus, Shadab helped ferry people into ambulances and was there when the injured were admitted into hospitals,” she added.

On Thursday, Farooq and his friends reached Jamia Millia Islamia early to mobilise people to join the march to Rajghat in north Delhi. “We were ahead of the march just to scan the area and generally observe the conditions. There was a lot of police presence and they had barricaded the road leading to Sukhdev Vihar,” said Aamna, an eyewitness of the shooting.

Aamna said a man brandishing a gun suddenly appeared out of nowhere and began to shout. “He was facing us and we could very clearly see that he was waving a gun. He looked disturbed and it seemed like he would shoot. He kept on shouting yeh lo azaadi. Since the police was just a few metres away, we called out to them for help, but nobody did anything. They just stood there and watched,” she added.

She claimed that police apathy was apparent in the way they dealt with Farooq after he had been shot. “We repeatedly pleaded with the policemen to remove the barricade so we could take him to Holy Family Hospital. But the policemen did not listen to us. Farooq finally had to scale the barricade, with blood dripping from his left hand, to reach the hospital,” she added. After being administered first aid, the 23-year-old was referred to All India Institute Of Medical Sciences trauma centre.

“Ironically, Farooq’s birthday falls on Independence Day. And he was shot at on the same day that Nathuram Godse gunned down Gandhiji. The man who shot him seems to follow Godse’s ideology,” said Shafaq , a college senior.

There were seniors, classmates, members of Jamia’s theatre group and friends from different regions and religions waiting outside the trauma centre, reflecting the idea of India that students have been fighting to preserve. According to close friends who visited Farooq at the trauma centre, the shards from the bullet remained lodged in his left hand, but there was no nerve damage.

“If I had to use one word to describe Farooq, it would be brave. He knew he could get shot, but he did not want others to get injured. But we will never forget what happened today. In the end, we need to remember that he is a student who was shot because mainstream politicians are constantly calling for violence,” Simran added.

In an official statement given in the evening, Jamia authorities said that Farooq successfully underwent surgery and is recovering well. Farooq’s father, who is a teacher in Jammu, and his elder brother are expected to reach the capital on Thursday night.

We pleaded with the cops to remove the barricade, but they didn’t. Farooq finally had to scale the barricade with blood dripping from his hand, a friend says.

Title: Official remains in Budget lock-in despite dad’s death
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

NEW DELHI: Kuldeep Kumar Sharma , deputy manager manning the press in the finance ministry where the budget documents are being printed, chose the call of duty over his personal loss — the death of his father.

The finance ministry on Thursday said Sharma lost his father on January 26 and being on budget duty, he was in the lock-in.

“Sharma is the key hand in completing budget document printing within a very tight schedule, owing to his 31 years of experience in the budget process. Displaying exemplary commitment, Sharma symbolised extraordinary sincerity towards his call of duty, ignoring personal loss, (sic)” the finance ministry said on Twitter .

Several finance ministry staffers are locked in for the printing of budget documents in the basement of North Block which houses the ministry. They do not have access to any phones to maintain highest level of secrecy. These staffers surface only after the finance minister ends the budget speech.

Title: BS-VI costs: Oil companies to raise rates by rupee 1 at one go in April
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: State-run fuel retailers will raise fuel prices by 50 paise to Re 1 per litre in one go from April to recover investments made for producing Bharat Stage-VI (BS-VI, akin to Euro-VI standard) petrol and diesel.

“I don't think premium (for BS-VI fuels ) will be large enough for it to be staggered,” Sanjiv Singh, chairman of the country’s largest oil refiner and fuel retailer Indian Oil , said on Thursday after announcing trebling of the company’s net profit in the December quarter to Rs 2,339 crore.

Pump prices are linked to petrol and diesel rates in regional trading hubs — Singapore and Dubai — as well as the rupee-dollar exchange rate. Since international benchmark prices for BS-VI equivalent fuels are higher, domestic rates will also have to rise. “We are in the process of working out the implications of supplying BS-VI fuel from April,” Singh said.

State-run companies appear to have received a nod from the parent oil ministry for a one-time increase, using the window provided by benign benchmark prices and no state elections in sight. Crude prices are in the comfort zone and product prices are expected to face deflationary pressure as coronavirus casts a shadow over trade, air traffic and global economic growth revival in general.

India is set to leapfrog from BS-IV to BS-VI standard, which has nearly the same — or better in some regards — emission level as a CNG ( compressed natural gas ) vehicle, from April 1. Delhi had switched to BS-VI two years before the deadline, while the entire NCR (national capital region) covering neighbouring cities in UP and Haryana had been getting cleaner fuels since October 2019.

Singh said IOC refineries have started producing BS-VI grade fuel and the same will reach depots across the country by next month. “We are very much sticking to the April 1 deadline,” he said. The company has invested Rs 17,000 crore to upgrade its refineries, while the total investment made by all state-run refiners is pegged at Rs 30,000 crore.

“Switchover to BS-VI fuel supplies by IOC's marketing and retail network is also in full swing across the country. As per current progress, about 80% of IOC's 121 bulk storage terminals/depots will achieve the conversion from BS-IV to BS-VI fuels by January 31. In the markets catered to by them, 100% dispensing of BS-VI fuels at petrol/diesel stations is likely to be achieved by the end of February,” Singh said. “IOC is confident of supplying BS-VI fuels across India well ahead of the deadline,” he added.

Title: RTC plans to rope in school buses for public transport
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In light of the state government’s proposal to make Visakhapatnam the executive capital of the state, the Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation ( APSRTC ) has come up with a fresh proposal to hire school buses for passenger transport in the near future.

This proposal was mooted as part of RTC’s necessary arrangements to meet the projected rush of passengers if the city were to become the executive capital. The purpose of this proposal is to improve the public transport system of the city.

Currently, APSRTC runs 600 buses in the city that carry nearly 7 lakh passengers along 45 different routes every day. Sources project that the city might need at least 1,000 buses to meet the expected rush.

Sources informed that Madireddy Pratap, managing director of APSRTC held an in-camera meeting with Visakhapatnam staff to discuss the future of organisation and infrastructure facilities after the city becomes the executive capital.

The managing director is also believed to have met managements of private bus operators and operators that run school buses to get their opinion on the proposal of hiring these buses when they are not in service, like on Sundays, Pongal holidays, Dasara and summer vacation.

“It is difficult to procure new buses. The new proposal came up for discussion at the in-camera meeting,” an APSRTC official told TOI on condition of anonymity.

However, a senior official of road transport authority (RTA) does not think that the RTC’s proposal is viable.

“We were not invited to the meeting. But the proposal to hire buses is not practical. Every school bus runs without a gap. In summer vacations, these buses go for fitness maintenance,” the official said.

Title: Mumbai: Tribunal awards Rs 1 crore payout to kin of mishap victim
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A Motor Accident Claims Tribunal recently ordered an insurance company and the owner of a dumper truck to pay a total compensation of around Rs 1.02 crore to the wife, minor daughter and parents of a 39-year-old man who died after the heavy vehicle rammed into his bike on the Western Express Highway in 2013.

The victim, Darryl Dsouza, a Mira Road resident was working at a private firm and earning a monthly salary of Rs 42,000 at the time of the incident. The tribunal found the impact of the hit had caused his helmet to fall off, and the victim had suffered severe head injuries.

The victim's wife, Bernadette Dsouza, was riding pillion when the accident occurred. Seeking a compensation of Rs 1 crore, the family told the tribunal at 6.45 am on May 21, 2013, the dumper belonging to Thane-based Reliable Enterprises was being driven at high speed when it rammed into the bike. Darryl died before being admitted to hospital.

ICICI Lombard General Insurance Co Ltd tried to pin the blame on the victim. It submitted he was not wearing a helmet at the time of the accident.

The tribunal said this did not mean the offending driver had the licence to hit a driver who was without a helmet. Referring to the FIR, the tribunal held Darryl was wearing a helmet and, after being hit by the dumper, the helmet fell off and he came under the dumper's wheel.

While calculating the compensation amount, the tribunal considered the victim's age, salary, future earning capacity, the nature of loss suffered by his family members and funeral expenses. While the wife and child will get 40% of the compensation each, Darryl's parents will get 10% each.

Title: Dreaded dons caged, Mumbai cops to relax celebs’ security
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

With gangster Ravi Pujari (in pic) arrested in Senegal, and Bunty Pandey and Chhota Rajan lodged in Tihar jail... Read More

MUMBAI: The Mumbai Police recently withdrew protection extended to nine builders who allegedly faced threats from the underworld, including a Bandra-based builder and member of Waqf board, saying most of the dreaded gangsters were lodged in jails. Police said security cover of celebrities, including film stars and VIPs, too would be reviewed as part of their annual assessment and security provided to them would be downgraded.

Joint commissioner of police (crime) Santosh Rastogi said, “The crime branch has made an assessment and removed security given to nine people.” He said dreaded gangsters were in jail and it was not possible for them to issue threats over cellphone. Police said with CCTV cameras and high-density jammers now inside jails, it was almost impossible for an undertrial to use cellphones from inside the jail.

With gangster Ravi Pujari arrested in Senegal, and Bunty Pandey and Chhota Rajan arrested and lodged in Tihar jail, police officials said there were hardly any threats from the underworld in the city.

A fortnight after Mumbai Police arrested gangster Ejaz Lakdawala (50) from Bihar, they withdrew security cover given to Khalid Babu Qureshi, a Bandra-based developer and BJP functionary and member of the Maharashtra waqf board. Crime branch officials said Khalid was not alone, they had withdrawn security of others too who were apparently on Lakdawala’s hit-list.

It was Khalid’s complaint in November last year against Lakdawala that led the police to locate the gangster in Bihar. Lakdawala was picked up after his daughter Shifa alias Sonia Shaikh was arrested while trying to leave the country on a fake passport. Lakdawala, a gangster earlier close to Dawood as well as Chhota Rajan, had ben shuttling between Nepal and India via Bihar.

“Initially, when I lodged the complaint in November, I had mentioned that Lakdawala had threatened me and demanded Rs 50 lakh. Later in December, police requested me to include Shifa’s (Lakdawala’s daughter’s) name in my statement and I did. I was scared, but police assured me they were with me. Now I am a little uncomfortable as gangsters in the past have been active from jails,” Khalid told TOI. A crime branch official said during assessment, they found the Lakdawala gang was defunct and if there is any threat, they would provide security cover accordingly.

Title: SIT probing Vizag land scam submits interim report to CM
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The special investigation team (SIT) appointed by the state government to enquire into tampering of government land records and encroachments into government lands submitted an interim report on Wednesday. The SIT , whose term was supposed to end on January 31, has got its term extended for a few more months.

The three-member SIT comprising retired IAS officers Dr Vijaya Kumar, YV Anuradha and retired sessions judge Bhaskara Rao was appointed by the state government in the month of October. The SIT began its investigation in November. It accepted proposals from 13 mandals surrounding the Greater Visakhapatnam area.

The investigation team received 2,434 petitions of which 1,563 came under the SIT’s purview.

As per the schedule, the SIT was supposed to submit its interim report in the second week of January before the Sankranti festival. At the time, the date of submission was postponed for a week.

Following the postponement, the government got busy with the three capital proposal and the SIT members could only meet the chief minister on Wednesday.

The 170 pages long interim report was submitted by the three members during the meeting. Speaking to TOI, Vijay Kumar, who is heading the team said, “We have submitted the report to the government and have elaborated (upon) issues to the chief minister. The government will extend the term of the SIT as we have in go further in depth and will submit a comprehensive report.”

According to sources, the SIT has told the chief minister that violations in terms of land allotments and issuance of no objection certificates had taken place and that officials from tehsildars to IAS officers are believed to be involved.

The SIT told the chief minister that it could recommend criminal action against a few officers if it is found that procedure was not followed. The SIT reportedly even told the chief minister that it has identified the officers involved in irregularities.

Title: Woman, who was set ablaze, dies
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: 35-year-old woman D Ramalakshmi, who had suffered over 80 per cent burn injuries after she was set ablaze allegedly by her sister-in-law D Pavani at Kothapalem under Gopalapatnam police station limit breathed her last at King George Hospital in Visakhapatnam on Wednesday night.

The accused, Pavani, is also reported to have received 30 per cent burn injuries. She too is undergoing treatment at the King George Hospital. Her condition is reportedly stable.

According to police, Pavani poured kerosene on Ramalakshmi and set her ablaze over some family disputes. Police sources say that Pavani suspected that Ramalakshmi was having an extra-marital affair with her husband. The families live in a two-story building at Kothapalem.

G Swaroopa Rani, ACP (west division) said that Ramalakshmi suffered 80 per cent burn injuries in the incident and succumbed.

“We have registered a case against Pavani under Section 302 of the IPC and will arrest her once she is discharged from the hospital,” added the ACP.

Title: SFI holds protests over student’s death
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Students’ Federation of India ( SFI ) Andhra University committee on Thursday held a protest at the campus over the death of student, who allegedly died of dengue.

SFI leaders Gowtham, Chinnari and a few others said that a second-year PG student from the public administration department, Blessi died of dengue in a hospital. They alleged that poor sanitation at the university hostels has led to death of Blessi.

They demanded that the AU authorities take immediate steps to improve the sanitation in AU campus and quality of food. The agitators also alleged that the varsity has been neglecting student facilities in spite of collecting substantial fee. tnn

Title: 34 years on, NDFB factions give up arms, 1,600 cadres surrender
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Assam CM Sarbananda Sonowal (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The National Democratic Front of Bodoland (NDFB) gave up arms on Thursday, marking an end to a 34-year armed struggle for a separate Bodoland state. Three days after signing of the Bodo accord, 1,615 cad- res from all four factions of NDFB laid down arms in front of Assam CM Sarbananda Sonowal at a ceremony in Guwahati.

Over 4,800 weapons, including AK rifles, light-machine guns and stenguns were laid down by the cadres, PTI reported. Assam minister Himanta Biswa Sarma said a special rehabilitation policy would be prepared after talks with chiefs of the four factions to ensure cadres remain in the mainstream.

Title: ‘Fernandes’s dream of reforms in defence sector now a reality’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Nagpur: The menace of middlemen in defence procurements, who used to get commission for the deals, has been eliminated following the strict policies the Union government has put in place, said former group captain Dinkar Deshpande on Wednesday.

He was delivering a lecture on ‘Defence policy and former defence minister George Fernandes ’ at a programme titled Samvad, organized by Lohiya Adhyayan Kendra at Madhu Limaye Smruti Sabhagruh, Subhash Marg. Senior journalist Prakash Dubey and Suresh Agrawal were present.

“It was former defence minister George Fernandes who sought to end the reported practice of paying kickbacks in such deals, and usher in reforms in defence sector as he was forthright in his views to not compromise on national security. His dream was given shape by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah,” he said.

Deshpande said, “When the Kargil war broke out, Fernandes was the defence minister. Though a simple man, Fernandes handled the situation with an iron hand. He wanted to give Pakistan a befitting reply for its misadventure, and got success.”

Commenting on Kargil conflict, Deshpande said, “There were over 15,000 Indian soldiers fighting the war in an inclement weather, having to carry a hundred bullets and mounting the inhospitable terrain to scale 15,000 to 16,000 feet. The then air chief marshal and Fernandes meticulously planned and executed the strategy to teach Pakistan a lesson. Behind Fernandes’s simplicity lay a strong man who would take the enemy head-on.”

On economy, Deshpande said, “People are constantly complaining of a slowdown. But the economy will definitely take off by year 2022.”

Dubey spoke about Fernandes’s tryst with Pokhran nuclear tests in 1998. He said Fernandes had criticized China for providing war paraphernalia to Pakistan as he was an upright man.

Title: 103 years later, Chilaka ship’s wreckage discovered
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Two scuba divers with the shipwreck (right) along the Baruva coast.

VISAKHAPATNAM: A team of scuba divers have discovered a shipwreck along the Baruva coast in Srikakulam district. This is the third such shipwreck to be discovered along northern Andhra Pradesh .

The ship whose wreckage has been found— Chilaka, sank in the Bay of Bengal in July, 1917. Around 80 people had lost their lives.

After gathering information from locals, the team of scuba divers from an adventure sports firm Livein Adventures dived into the Baruva coast. Baruva was used as a port till 1948. Half a kilometre from the shore, the divers noticed a small broken part of the mast of a cargo ship.

Upon diving six meters deeper, the divers discovered the scattered top deck of the ship.

The approximate length of the ship is 120-150 meters and its breadth is 25-30 meters. On touching the bow point of the ship, the draught of the ship was measured at six meters.

The team discovered deck plates, iron parts of the cargo ship, diversified aquatic life including hard corals and shells.

The three-member team from Livein Adventures comprising Balaram Naidu, Rahul and Lakshman dived in at 9:30am.

Speaking to TOI, Balaram Naidu said that he was curious about the shipwreck at Baruva after reading about shipwreck locations online.

Title: 4-day AIIEA conference concludes
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The four-day general conference of All India Insurance Employees’ Association (AIIEA), attended by around 2,000 employees, concluded on Thursday in the city. The main demands put forward during the conference by the members included demand for reversal of neo-liberal policies and opposition to disinvestment of PSUs.

President of AIIEA, Amanulla Khan said, “India is going through a tough economic phase and unemployment is growing. AIIEA strongly opposes CAA and NRC. We are requesting the government to withdraw 18 % GST on insurance premiums, which is illogical. We will also go on a strike if LIC share is listed on the stock market. ” tnn

Title: FCRA relaxation for all bodies set up by governments
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Centre has exempted all organisations set up by or under a central or state Act or by an administrative or executive order of the central or state government and wholly owned by the respective government and required to have its accounts mandatorily audited by the Comptroller and Auditor General of India from the provisions of the Foreign Contribution (Regulation) Act, 2010. The exemption will, however, not apply to political parties.

The order, notified by the home ministry on Thursday, will benefit central and state universities. In the notification, the MHA said, “The central government is of the opinion that it is necessary in the interest of general public to exempt organisations (not being a political party), constituted or established by or under a central Act or a state Act or by any administrative or executive order of the central government or any state government and wholly owned by the respective government and required to have their accounts compulsorily audited by CAG or any of the agencies of CAG, from operation of the Foreign Contribution (Regulation) Act, 2010.”

Title: Kalakshetra ‘no’ to TM Krishna’s book launch
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

T M Krishna, renowned Carnatic vocalist (File photo)

CHENNAI: Three days before launch, Carnatic vocalist T M Krishna was informed by the Kalakshetra Foundation that he won’t be allowed to release his book on the history of mridangam makers in its auditorium “on account of the subject matter of the book touching upon controversial issues” which it was earlier “unaware of”.

A letter to the publisher by Kalakshetra director Revathi Ramachandran says the foundation, an autonomous body under the Union culture ministry, “cannot allow any program that may instigate political, cultural and social disharmony”. “I find it astounding that it is okay for the mridangam to be played on that very stage of Kalakshetra, but one is uncomfortable with people saying cow is slaughtered to make it,” said Krishna, adding the book will be released on February 2.

Title: 24x7 customer care centre for water supply planned in Mangaluru
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Photo used for represenattional purpose only

MANGALURU: Suez India Private Limited , which has been given the contract to implement the 24x7 drinking water project in the city, has plans to open a 24x7 customer care centre.

Suez India officials said the customer care centre of the company will address grievances related to water supply in the city, round-the-clock, and solve their problems instantly. The company has already commenced a survey to implement the project in the city.

Valsan Moolakkat, executive engineer, Karnataka Urban Infrastructure Development and Finance Corporation (KIUDFC), said ‘Jalasiri’, the 24x7 drinking water project, will be implemented by Suez Projects Private Limited (lead partner), Suez India and DRS Infratech at an estimated cost of Rs 792.4 crore.

In addition to the existing water storage facilities, 20 more tanks of different capacities will be built in the city as part of the Jalasiri project. To connect these new water storage facilities, 40km of new pipelines will be laid in the city. Pipes of various measurements from 200mm to 450mm will be used to pump water from storage areas to different parts of the city. Meanwhile, 25.1km of existing pipelines will be replaced with new ones. Additional underground sumps, eight boosting pump houses and a new water purification plant of 80MLD capacity will also be constructed. In addition, 1,388km of distribution lines will also be laid, and roads damaged during the work will be restored either by being concreted or asphalted, he said.

Supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) system of software and hardware will be used to monitor, gather, and process real-time data of water supply from the vented dam at Thumbe to all storage areas. A customer care number will address all types of grievances of people with regard to the water supply in the city. There will be no illegal connections once the Jalasiri project is completed, he said.

Title: Sharana reformers strived for gender parity, says academic
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Former pro VC of EFLU, Hyderabad Prof Maya Pandit-Narkar delivered the first of the Sarojini Shintri Endowment... Read More

DHARWAD: Tracing the thread of women English writers in India to the Bengali Renaissance in the 19th century, former pro vice-chancellor of the English and Foreign Languages University (EFLU), Hyderabad Prof Maya Pandit-Narkar on Thursday said, “The history of women writers who took to English in our country is an inspiring one. These authors gave wind to a radical feminist movement after Independence, although one must note that the Sharana poets had already made headway in this direction as early as the 12th century.”

Prof Maya, delivering the first of the Sarojini Shintri Endowment Lecture Series organised by the department of studies in English of Karnatak University, highlighted the role that Constitutional reforms had essayed in improving the condition of women in the country. Pointing out that women who had seen through the stratagems of men’s ‘whiskey and cigar’ politics had taken the lead in emancipating themselves, Prof Maya added, “Women novelists such as Kamala Das and Arundhati Roy questioned man-made barriers such as caste and gender. Constitutional reforms helped women gain an education, employment and social participation.”

The other pioneering women, the contributions of whom she highlighted, were Cornelia Sorabji, Attia Husain and Venu Chitale, who were at the vanguard of movements against social evils such as Suttee, child marriage and dowry. “On the other hand, writers such as Kripabai Sathianadan and Manju Kapur, in their works, upheld the dignity of women, while Shobha De went a step further, discussing marriage and gender issues with candour,” Prof Maya added.

She sought to highlight the efforts made by global bodies such as the United Nations Organisation, several human rights’ bodies and governments to bring about a level-playing field. “Women writers also spoke of the New Woman. In both public and private sectors, several reforms have been drafted to further the cause of women. Modernisation, globalisation and privatisation have all helped women find their voice. The ‘long silence’ has finally shattered and the dignity of woman restored,” Prof Maya said.

In-charge vice-chancellor of Karnatak University Ashok Shiralashetti, varsity registrar Honnu Siddartha and head of the department of English Shamala Ratnakar were among those who shared their thoughts on the subject.

Title: Outfit appeals to Venkaiah Naidu against dedicated BRTS corridor
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

HUBBALLI: Stating that the Hubballi-Dharwad Bus Rapid Transit Systsm (HDBRTS) corridor was far from complete, and highlighting the unscientific execution of the high-profile infrastructure project, members of the Sama Sena on Thursday appealed to Vice-President Venkaiah Naidu not to officially inaugurate the dedicated bus lane.

Sena member Gurunath Ullikashi said that they would submit a memorandum to the Vice-President by fax, urging him against coming to the city to dedicate the corridor. “The Vice-President’s post is sanctioned by the Constitution, and the position he holds cannot be insulted. That is the reason we want to pre-empt his arrival here so that he does not officially inaugurate the incomplete corridor,” said Ullikashi.

He said that the quality of the flyover built on the corridor left a lot to be desired, besides pointing to the lack of lavatories at many stops along the dedicated lane. “Nearly Rs 1 crore has been spent on the construction of each bus stop but the lack of facilities at these terminals leaves commuters upset nevertheless,” Ullikashi added.

Ullikashi said that the many problems had been brought to the notice of Dharwad deputy commissioner Deepa Cholan, who served as the managing director of HDBRTS earlier. “We also mentioned the many persistent problems with the dedicated lane to former MD MG Hiremath and the incumbent director Rajendra Cholan. Although all of them gave us assurances of looking into these problems, nothing has been done on the ground. The formal inauguration is being arranged owing to pressure being exerted by Union minister Pralhad Joshi, Dharwad district in-charge minister Jagadish Shettar and MLA Arvind Bellad,” he added.

Ullikashi said that their outfit would launch a massive stir if the agencies concerned failed to fix the many problems marring commuter experience on HDBRTS within 100 days of its inauguration by Naidu.

Premanath Chikkatumbal, Yamanur Gudihal and others were present in the press conference.

Title: Suryanamaskar ensemble of 12 sculptures opens in Hubballi gallery today
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

HUBBALLI: To encourage people to learn Suryanamaskar and provide the younger generation a ready reckoner of sorts, a group of artists has sculpted 12 postures of the routine in iron. The set of life-size sculptures will be open for public viewing on Friday.

Sculptors of Artwaley, an art gallery, said they wanted to experiment with iron to create an easily relatable experience for all. While more people are turning to yoga, especially to tackle stress, blood pressure and even diabetes, not many are aware of the exact postures that make up the set of exercises that constitute Suryanamaskar, one of the artists said.

“While interacting with those who practise yoga, we came to know that many were not aware of the different types of asanas in the Suryanamaskar. This inspired us to explore how people could be better informed and instructed on how to strike the right postures for maximum benefit,” said Sudhanva Deshpande, art manager of Artwaley. “We decided to make 12 different Suryanamaskar sculptures in iron. A team of 12 artists worked for more than three months to craft the pieces.”

The sculptures depict Hastauttanasana, Padahastasana, Ashwa Sanchalanasana, Parvatasana, Pranamasana, Bhujangasana and Ashtanga Namaskara.

“Most sculptures these days are made from fibre but iron is a huge challenge,” said artist Manjunath Annigeri. “We used 40kg of iron to make each sculpture, and cut the iron into 1,000 -1,500 pieces for each sculpture. It required a lot of patience because any mistake in cutting the iron could upset the balance of the entire sculpture.”

Added artist Basavaraj Ganiger, “we worked 8 to 12 hours a day to give the final touches. We are happy that the sculptures are in keeping with anatomical specifications.”

Title: Mangaluru porn shoot case: Victim seeks court’s permission to give evidence through video conferencing
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

MANGALURU: The cross-examination of one of the victim’s into the Mangaluru porn shoot case was held on Thursday. The in-camera proceedings into the case commenced at the sixth additional district and sessions court on January 17, when one of the victims was examined as the first prosecution witness in the case, said public prosecutor Jayarama Shetty .

The case was reported on December 19, 2013, and the trial began after six years. Meanwhile, the victim, through an advocate, asked for the court’s permission to give her evidence through video conferencing, said Shetty.

In an attempt to blackmail, a gang of eight men targeted medical students by taking them to an isolated house and forcing them to have sex, and they filmed the act on their mobile phones. Once the act was complete, they began blackmailing them for ransom. While the male victim was held hostage, the woman was sent to get cash. She managed to get to the police. The accused were chased, and they even managed to give the police the slip once, but soon all of them were arrested.

Title: SC OKs rape-accused MP’s parole for oath
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Supreme Court of India

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Thursday refused to stop BSP MP from Ghosi Atul Rai , who is accused of rape and is in custody, from taking oath as member of Parliament eight months after he got elected as a candidate of the SP-BSP Mahagathbandhan last year.

An SC bench refused to stay an Allahabad HC decision granting him parole for the purpose of attending Parliament to take oath on January 31. An FIR was lodged against him by a student last year accusing him of sexually assaulting her. Allahabad HC and the SC had refused to grant him protection from arrest. He was elected from Ghosi constituency but was absconding till his arrest from Varanasi on June 22.

Title: 6-year-old testifies, driver gets 10 years for sex abuse in Mumbai
Content:
Representative image

‘Girl had no reason to lie about sex assault’

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

MUMBAI: A special Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act court has sentenced a van driver to 10 years’ imprisonment for sexually assaulting a six-year-old girl twice near her Andheri school in 2016. The court observed that the testimony of the victim (now 10) was fluent and without embellishments. The convict, Abdul Rehman, was also fined Rs 15,000. Of this, Rs 10,000 will be given to the girl.On February 11, 2016, the girl was in the school playground when a man dragged her away and sexually assaulted her. On her return home, she looked upset and her mother found stains on her innerwear. On repeated prodding, the girl revealed that an uncle had touched her inappropriately. The man sexually assaulted the girl again the next day. This time, he even threatened to kill her parents. The child went to a teacher and they tried to find the man, in vain.On returning home, the girl confided in her mother, who, along with a neighbour, went to the school. Rehman was standing at the school gate, and the girl identified him. On spotting the girl’s mother making note of his van’s registration number, the driver fled. The girl’s parents then approached the school management and lodged a police complaint a few days later.The convict claimed before the court that he was not present when the alleged incident occurred, but the court observed that he couldn’t produce witnesses to substantiate his claim. The court also observed though there were cameras in the school, the principal said they were of poor quality, and more cameras had been installed only after the incident.A medical officer told the court that no injury was found on the victim’s private parts. At this, judge H C Shende said, “The reason for me to believe the victim’s testimony is the medical officer’s explanation that due to her tender age and the time gap, healing process could be rapid.”“The court took into account there was no reason for a child to falsely accuse a man of sexual assault. Her family wasn’t acquainted with him and she did not commute by his van,” said prosecutor G Malankar. “The victim and her family had to move out of Mumbai because of the trauma.”Rehman’s counsel sought leniency as he had three dependents. “The victim was only six years old. What was her fault?” judge Shende said.

Title: SC lets mined Goa iron ore to be transported
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Thursday allowed mining lease holders in Goa to transport mined iron ore extracted between February 7 and March 15, 2018, and lying at the pithead, stockyard or any other storage place. Mine lease holders had challenged an order of Goa bench of Bombay HC , which had stopped transportation of mined iron ore after March 15, 2018, by interpreting the SC ’s February 7, 2018, order allowing lease holders to manage their affairs and continue mining till March 15, 2018 as the period within which the minerals should have been transported out.

An SC bench of Chief Justice S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant said there was no rationale behind stopping transportation of iron ore if the mineral was mined before March 15, 2018, and royalty had been paid to the Goa government.

Title: Mumbai: Saamna backs Centre on JNU student Sharjeel Imam, says chop off his hands
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

JNU student Sharjeel Imam

Title: Karnataka: Warning of suspension for House ruckus angers opposition MLAs
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Governor Vajubhai Vala will address a joint session on February 19. Officials want to ensure order during his ... Read More

BENGALURU: A communiqué has warned Karnataka MLAs that they could be suspended if they tried to disrupt the governor’s address to the joint session of the legislature next month.

The message, issued by the secretaries of Karnataka legislative assembly and council in the form of a bulletin, comes in the wake of the ruckus created by the opposition in the Kerala and West Bengal assemblies. Though it’s a routine exercise, it has angered Congress and JD(S) legislators, who allege the BS Yediyurappa government is trying to curtail their freedom of speech and right to protest.

The two parties have been itching to confront the six-month-old BJP government over various issues, and they see the upcoming session in the legislature as a great opportunity to ratchet up pressure.

Governor Vajubhai Vala will give a speech to the joint session on February 19. The secretaries of the assembly and council have cited Rule 26 of the House to issue the suspension warning for any disruption. “This is against the freedom of expression of MLAs. We will not allow our rights to be curbed. If I am speaking in the assembly, it is the voice of the people, and not mine. The speaker should act as per the Constitution,” Congress’s Siddaramaiah , who is the opposition leader in the assembly, said.

This week, Congress-led opposition MLAs blocked Kerala governor Arif Mohammed Khan’s path as he arrived in the assembly. They held placards with the messages “Call back governor” and “We resist CAA”. Karnataka council secretary K R Mahalakshmi said the latest directive to maintain order was a routine exercise. “The rule is regularly quoted by the secretariat when putting out the bulletin on the governor’s address. There is absolutely nothing new in this; it’s a routine affair,” Mahalakshmi said.

Assembly secretary MK Vishalakshi said: “The assembly only asks MLAs to maintain decorum and urges them to not disturb the governor while he is addressing the joint session.”

Instances of a serious disruption during the joint session in Karnataka have been rare.

Meanwhile, a committee of presiding officers has been formed to look into Schedule 10 (anti-defection law) and the speaker’s powers. It is headed by Rajasthan speaker CP Joshi; Karnataka speaker Vishveswar Hegde Kageri and Odisha speaker SN Patro are the other members.

Title: Coronavirus: Hospital turns away suspect, now hunt is on
Content: GWALIOR: A 30-year-old patient, who returned from China a week ago and turned up at Gwalior district hospital on Thursday with coronavirus-like symptoms , was told to go back home.This, only a day after health minister Tulsiram Silawat ordered a statewide alert on the virus that has killed 170 people in China. The administration is frantically looking for the patient. Chief medical and health officer Dr Mridul Saxena has sought explanations from the civil surgeon B K Gupta and the doctor who treated him.

Title: Hope ‘sabka...’ motto guides CAA: UK
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Outgoing British high commissioner Dominic Asquith (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Outgoing British high commissioner Dominic Asquith Thursday expressed hope the Indian government will continue to address the CAA-related issues in the spirit of its manifesto commitment of “with all, development for all and trust of all”. He also said that even after Brexit, UK will remain India’s most important European partner and that the two sides will see expansion of trade diplomatic and security activities.

“There is protest in every single democracy. I refer back to the ‘with all, development for all, and trust of all (sabka saath, sabka vikas , sabka vishwas)’ as the objective set by this government and I am sure that in that ‘trust of all’ (is) the trust that it will be addressing the concerns that have been expressed about the CAA. But that is for the Indian government to deal with,” he said.

He also said the British side had not received any proposal from India to visit J&K following the repeal of Article 370 and that UK diplomats remained willing to visit J&K. Briefing the media, he also expressed regret over threats that, he said, Indian high commission may have felt because of violent protests on its premises. “I am glad to note that the last two protests have passed off without serious concern. That balance between the right to protest and ensuring that they don’t cross the line to illegality is a balance that is always difficult to maintain,” he said, adding that Metropolitan Police has the responsibility to do so.

On the anti-CAA resolutions in the European parliament, he said that parliaments as key democratic institutions have the habit to debate a variety of subjects.

Title: Central Railway’s first AC local flagged off amid Shiv Sena MP’s criticism
Content:
CR’s first AC train flagged off on Thursday

MUMBAI: The launch of Central Railway ’s first AC train on Thursday started with a political spat as Shiv Sena MP Arvind Sawant criticised the Union railway ministry for not mentioning the name of Mumbai mayor Kishori Pednekar and a few guardian ministers and MPs like him in event ads and also on the stage banner.Sawant, invited to speak first after the flagging off of the Panvel-Thane AC local, said, “Do not take us (Sena) for granted. If somebody does good work, we appreciate, but this is uncalled for.” Sawant said this was not the first time the mayor or MP were not being respected. “In the past, during inauguration of Elphinstone Road FOB, I was invited. But I did not see my name though I was a local MP who had fought for interests of commuters.” He said “Yeh jo tareeka hai, yeh sirf Mumbai mein hain… Bahar karne ki himmat bhi nahi hogi... UP mein karenge kya? Saansad jeene nahi dega (This kind of thing is done only in Mumbai, will they dare do this elsewhere, like in UP… local MP won’t spare them).”Chief guest for the launch was junior minister for railways, BJP’s Suresh Angadi, who quietly heard Sawant’s comments. BJP MP (Mumbai North-East) Manoj Kotak, who was present on stage, later told mediapersons it was a “credit war” launched by the Sena MP. Sawant however clarified, “We are not the sort of people who will only criticise --one who is good will be appreciated. I also want to mention here that the minister is a gentleman and he should ensure such things dont recur.” City guardian minister Aslam Shaikh (Congress) and Raigad guardian minister Aditi Tatkare (NCP) were present. Shaikh said there should be no fare hike with AC trains coming in.Sawant criticised railways for having “multiple inaugurations” of 12 FOBs, wifi, toilets, etc at a single event at CSMT (with a video launch). “Why can’t you ask MPs or MLAs to launch these in their areas?” he said. In his reply, Angadi apologised and directed railway officials to ensure protocol next time. “Be it MP, minister or mayor, everybody is people’s representative and should be respected and mentioned at such events,” he said. Angadi said railways will invest Rs 50 lakh crore in ten years and added the bullet train was the PM’s dream and will come true. “We expect the Maharashtra government to cooperate in this,” he said.
