Title: Thane: Section 420 added in Dongri building crash case
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Thirteen people died in the Kesarbai building collapse in Dongri on July 16, 2019

MUMBAI: Dongri police, probing the July 16 Kesarbai building collapse that killed 13 persons, recently added section 420 (cheating) under Indian Penal Code against five trustees of the building for collecting rent from tenants and allowing illegal work, which allegedly caused the crash.

Police had on July 23, 2019, registered an FIR against the trustees, civic officials and contractors under sections of IPC for causing death by negligence and causing grievous hurt by an act endangering the life or personal safety of others. While police have recorded statements of most victims and witnesses, they have not made any arrest.

"We invoked the section of cheating against five trustees of the building. They collected rent from tenants since 1996," said a police officer. At the time of registering the FIR, police did not mention the names of any accused. "We are investigating the case and will file a charge-sheet soon," said the officer.

Prima facie, police found that illegal construction work had been carried out. The owner/trustees permitted or turned a blind eye to illegal extension or illegal construction, which led to the crash, police said.

Huma Zariwala, who lost her brother Arshan and niece Kashaf Aamir Azad, and whose mother Sajida was grievously injured, said police had not arrested any accused and she had approached the court for justice.

Title: Sharjeel Imam case: SIT quizzes 3 students
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Sharjeel Imam in New Delhi on Wednesday. (Photo: ANI)

NEW DELHI: The Special Investigation Team (SIT) questioning JNU scholar Sharjeel Imam has found that he was not alone when he addressed the crowd at Jamia Millia Islamia and Aligarh Muslim University . The people who accompanied him are under the scanner too.

On Thursday, for the first time the SIT questioned three Jamia students in connection with the violence that broke out on December 15. Sharjeel had given his speech in the campus two days before.

Police sources said the three students — Abdul Bari, Junaid Ashraf and Rahim Yusuf — are pursuing their bachelors’ degrees from Jamia. They were spotted during the riots and at the protest attended by Sharjeel. They were also reportedly found instigating the crowd during the riots. Their role during the protest on December 13 is being probed.

Police were not able to recover Sharjeel’s mobile phones during raids and a team will be sent to Bihar to look for them. His social media profiles are being scanned to identify his associates. Sources said during interrogation, Sharjeel first claimed that his mobile phone was in his room at JNU, but when police didn’t find it there, he claimed that it was at a friend’s house in Bihar.

Sharjeel mentioned three associates, one of them a classmate, who were aiding him in research for his speech. Efforts are being made to track them. Sources said he told police that he started raising his voice after he felt that the policies of the government were purposely being framed against his community. He was aware that he might get arrested for sedition, but still went ahead with his speeches.

The video of the speech has been sent for forensic analysis. His voice samples are also being analysed and they will be matched with the video. He is also being questioned about the role of his friends who helped him evade police.

Title: Cut off from Haridwar, urns with ashes of Hindus piling up in Pakistan
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Pakistan’s Hindus have the option to perform the rites at Sadh Belo, an island on the Indus river. But people ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Urns containing the ashes of deceased members of Hindu families in Pakistan are piling up in temples and crematoriums there as the community awaits restoration of train and bus links with India to perform the final rite of passage — immersion of the ashes in the Ganga.

“The majority of Hindus in Pakistan prefer to perform the last rites of their deceased family members in Haridwar. Now, ashes of the deceased are being preserved in urns and kept in temples, special rooms in crematoriums and, in some cases, even at home,” provincial assembly member Diwan Chand Chawla told TOI over phone from Sukkur in Sindh province on Thursday.

All transport routes between India and Pakistan have been shut since August last year, when bilateral ties snapped in the wake of Parliament nullifying Articles 370 and 35A that used to guarantee special status to Jammu & Kashmir.

Chawla, a former functionary of the Muttahida Qaumi Movement , urged the Indian and Pakistani governments to arrange a special train to the Attari-Wagah international border so that scores of Pakistani Hindus are able to take the ashes of their deceased family members to Haridwar for the final rites.

Pakistan’s Hindu community has the option of performing the last rites at Sadh Belo, an island on the Indus river with a cluster of temples and a gurdwara.

“However, people prefer to visit Haridwar. They would rather wait for the resumption of rail and road communication than hurriedly immerse the ashes somewhere else. A special train would do for now,” Chawla said.

Hindu families that can afford higher travel costs use private transport to first reach Lahore or Wagah rail station, from where they take taxis till the international border. After crossing the border on foot, they hire taxis till the nearest town they have visas for and then proceed to Haridwar.

“This journey is long and expensive,” Chawla said. “Only a few give it a shot.”

In the past, Hindus who couldn’t afford to travel to India would hand over the ashes of their loved ones to religious organisations, including the Hindu Cremation Ground Association in Karachi , to take the urns to Haridwar and perform the last rites on their behalf.

Title: Teacher, pupil’s mom held for anti-CAA play in Bidar school
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

Title: Two-month-old abducted in Agra rescued from Navi Mumbai
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

NAVI MUMBAI: Less than a week after a 40-year-old woman abducted a two-and-a-half-month-old infant from Agra and brought her here, the APMC police helped their Uttar Pradesh counterparts crack the case and apprehend the accused. The woman, who was arrested from Kopri village of APMC node on Wednesday, had struck a deal with a childless couple in Navi Mumbai who were to pay Rs60,000 for the baby girl.

Senior inspector Satish Nikam of APMC police station said, "The infant's father had brought her to Abu Lala Dargah in Agra on January 25 in search of a cure for her ailment. The accused met him outside the dargah and claimed she would get the child treated at a mosque and took him there. The woman took the child inside the mosque, but when she did not return for long, the infant's father searched for her and later registered a kidnapping case."

Nikam said the Agra police got a tip off that the kidnapper had come to Navi Mumbai. "We traced her to a house in Kopri village and rescued the infant, who was with her, on Wednesday. The woman confessed she had kidnapped the infant to sell her to a childless couple in Kopri village."

Police said the accused and the childless woman's mother were from the same native place in Agra. The accused, who the childless couple had not met, lied to the couple over the phone that she was pregnant, and that they could adopt the baby. She demanded Rs 60,000 for hospital expenses.

Title: Guv lashes out at cop, TMC fumes
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Kolkata: Trinamool on Thursday reacted sharply to governor Jagdeep Dhankhar’s public admonition of Barrackpore police commissioner Manoj Verma and his statements on the state’s “deteriorating law and order”. TMC said “(the) governor is behaving like a cadre of a specific political party”.

Dhankhar, who had gone to pay tribute at Barrackpore Gandhighat on Gandhi’s death anniversary, singled out Verma to say some “senior police personnel in uniform in front row kept on casually and freely reading newspapers”. “How can this indecorous act be done by men in uniform?” he said, asking Verma to probe the matter.

State power minister Sobhandeb Chattopadhyay, also present at Gandhighat, said he along with the state home secretary had greeted the governor with folded hands but he did not reciprocate.

Title: Roadblock over arrests in Jalangi Murshidabad
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Behrampore: Nabajagaran Manch — comprising supporters of anti-Trinamool and anti-BJP groups —– blocked Sagarpara-Sheikhpara state highway and Dhanirampur-Bhaduriapara roads at Sahebnagar in Murshidabad’s Jalangi on Thursday morning with bodies of the two persons killed in Wednesday’s violence.

This followed the arre-sts of Kanak Sheikh, Rafiqul Islam and Abul Kalam Basar. “Two from our side died. But they arrested three of our supporters,” Manch leader Gulam Rahman Biswas said.

“We demand the arrest of Tahiruddin Mondal, the main accused.” Tahiruddin, TMC’s Jalangi block president, however, said: “What happened on Wednesday was nothing but a conspiracy to kill me.”

The blockade was lifted after senior police officers intervened.

Anarul Biswas (62) — the imam of a local mosque — and Salauddin Sheikh (17) were killed as violence raged during an anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act bandh. Trouble broke out between bandh enforcers from Manch and alleged TMC supporters. Though both sides oppose CAA, TMC opposed the bandh on the ground that a shutdown was unnecessary on Saraswati Puja.

Murshidabad SP Ajit Singh Yadav said: “Two FIRs have been lodged over Wednesday’s violence. We have arrested three, including two named in an FIR. Raids are on to nab more suspects.”

Title: Extortion and blackmail: Five more complaints against biz scion duo
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Five more women came forward to lodge complaints of extortion and blackmail against the two young Kolkata-based business family scions on Thursday, bringing the total number of complaints to a staggering 187.

Aditya Aggarwal and Anish Loharuka were arrested on Wednesday for allegedly extorting money from women after threatening to make public intimate moments captured with them on video. Kailash Yadav , a cook employed by Anish, was also arrested for involvement in the case that spanned several years.

Aggarwal’s family owns an ethnic-wear retail chain with a nationwide presence; Loharuka’s family owns multiple hotels in the city.

Two of the women — now married — have said they were still minors when they had a relationship with one of the accused, around six years ago, and had no idea they were being filmed.

The cops have got the statement of one complainant recorded before a magistrate. The statements of two others are in the process of being recorded. Only one of the complainants has confirmed that she had partly paid the extortion amount.

TOI called and texted both families but received no response, like Wednesday.

The police said the accused used advanced technology to run the extortion racket in a way that masked the actual number that they were using to call the victims. “They were using a virtual SIM, which is one of the best ways to hide your number,” explained an officer. “With this trick, you will get a virtual number whenever someone calls you, which is not registered to any person.” This, he said, was the reason it took some time to crack the actual number they were using.

“The evidence against the accused is only getting stronger,” another investigator said. “The total number of women whose intimate videos have been recovered has gone up to 187 now. We can now confirm that both Aditya and Anish figure in at least some of the videos that we have recovered. We are sending the hard disk to forensic experts for deeper analysis.”

Police sources said the accused even exchanged the videos among themselves and maintained a bank. “Anish’s cook, Kailash Yadav, was roped in because they did not wish to reveal their identity while making the extortion threats,” the officer added.

On Wednesday, a member of the latter’s family had told TOI that Anish was being “framed”. Joint commissioner of police (crime) Murlidhar Sharma refused to comment any further.

“The interrogation of the two prime accused revealed that they would befriend women and call them to different locations, where it seems, cameras were already set up to film their intimate moments. They developed a data bank of these videos and began to extort money around a year ago. In one case, they decided to extort Rs 5 lakh from a girl by convincing Yadav to call her up. The victim initially paid up. But then they demanded Rs 10 lakh more, prompting her to approach the cyber cell,” an official involved in the investigation said.

Title: TMC backs AAP for Delhi elections
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

KOLKATA: Trinamool Congress has endorsed Aam Aadmi Party for the Delhi polls, with Rajya Sabha MP Derek O’Brien urging people to vote for chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and all AAP candidates.

Posting a video of Rajendra Nagar constituency in Central Delhi , Derek said: “What they promised, they have delivered. The candidate is Ragh-av Chadha, he is a boy from here, very enthusiastic. One of the youngest bright minds I have seen in Delhi. Vote for AAP, vote for Raghav Chadha . May Aam Aadmi Party do very, very well.” CM Mamata Banerjee enjoys a very good personal rapport with Kejriwal.

Senior BJP leader Kailash Vijayvargiya said: “TMC is fast losing ground in Bengal and is extending support to AAP in Delhi, where it doesn’t have any existence. The less we speak on such issues, the better.”

Title: Did not fund anti-CAA protests, PFI refutes charges
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Popular Front of India has issued a statement refuting allegations that it has financed the protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

The organisation has alleged that “groups with vested interests have always been trying to raise different types of allegations against the organisation, and it is not going to cease with this allegation. They will continue with new allegations as long as the organisation continues its fight for justice.”

In a statement, M Mohamed Ali Jinnah , the general secretary of Popular Front of India, rejected allegations that the organisation is behind the violence and that investigations had revealed that about Rs 120 crore had been spent to carry out riots.

“Popular Front is not behind, but is part of the protests against CAA wherever it has presence,” the organisation said in response to the allegations. “Popular Front members and associates have never indulged in any sort of violence anywhere and it has never funded protesters anywhere with any amount of money. Let the ‘investigators’ produce substantiating evidence to support their allegations,” the statement said.

“The media reports quoting the Enforcement Directorate have dragged the name of an NGO working in the field of village development into the financial dealing of Popular Front without any evidence. A few reputed Supreme Court lawyers like Kapil Sibal , Dushyant Dave and Indira Jaising were also alleged to have received money from PFI to instigate anti-CAA protests,” the statement read.

“Popular Front outrightly denies all such allegations levelled with the intention of maligning the organisation and also the other individuals and organisations,” the statement further added.

Title: Nirbhaya case: Hangman from Meerut reaches Tihar, dummy hanging today
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Pawan Jallad

NEW DELHI: Pawan Jallad , the hangman from Meerut jail who is scheduled to hang the four convicts in the Nirbhaya case , reached Delhi on Thursday evening.

Before leaving the Meerut jail premises, Jallad said ‘Jai Hind’ to fellow staffers. The hanging is schedule to be held on Saturday morning. A dummy practice will be carried out on Friday to check the ropes and the weight of the convicts.

Jallad will be paid Rs 15,000 per execution.

Wearing beige pants, maroon shirt and a black jacket, a clean shaven Jallad arrived at Tihar. A team of three officials from Tihar had gone to Meerut to bring him to Delhi.

Meanwhile, Tihar Jail authorities are exploring the option of hanging the four convicts one by one as there is no provision in the jail manual mandating hanging of co-convicts together. Sources said legal opinion is being taken on this.

Title: Sena’s Sharjeel stand may create rifts in Maharashtra government
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

MUMBAI: Saamna, the Shiv Sena mouthpiece, on Thursday tore into anti-citizenship law protester Sharjeel Imam’s “inflammatory and anti-national” statement and supported the government’s crackdown on him, raising fears of discord in the government it runs along with NCP and Congress.

In Sena’s rough and ready style, Saamna said Imam’s hands should be chopped off and hung up on the 22km highway — the ‘chicken’s neck’ — that links the Northeast with the rest of India. JNU student Imam was arrested on Tuesday for sedition and other charges.

Calling on the Centre to crush the “pest” of separatism, it wondered if there was a well-planned plot to “poison” the minds of students. “Imam is an IITMumbai alumni... This is a conspiracy to plant separatism (in the mind of the educated people) and take them on the path of extremism,” said the Saamna editorial. “The conspiracy is to perpetuate Hindu-Muslim disharmony and a prolonged civil war... Urban Naxalism is very much on. Add to this, the extremism of intellectuals which is being fanned by politicians,” it added.

This stand can bring Sena into direct conflict with Congress, which has been pro-active in the anti-CAA, anti-NRC protests across the country, and NCP, which claims the Elgar Parishad case was foisted on intellectuals and activists and wants it quashed.

Urging the Centre not to indulge in a political game, Saamna endorsed Amit Shah ’s statement that Imam’s ‘chicken neck’ remark was more dangerous than Kanhaiyya Kumar ’s ‘freedom’ utterances and that Imam’s next seven generations will not succeed in cutting the Northeast from the country.

Title: Scrap tweaked citizenship law, Chhattisgarh cabinet tells PM
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Chhattisgarh CM Bhupesh Baghel (File photo)

RAIPUR: The Chhattisgarh cabinet on Thursday urged PM Modi to scrap the controversial Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), saying that the law is discriminatory and against the spirit of the Constitution .

“On the one hand, this Act appears to be discriminatory towards illegal immigrants based on their religious beliefs, contradictory to Article 14 of Indian Constitution, and on the other, the Act has no provision for people from neighbouring countries such as Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Nepal, and Bhutan living in India,” reads CM Bhupesh Baghel ’s letter to PM Modi.

“Chhattisgarh is basically a state of people belonging to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and OBCs, and most of these people are poor, illiterate and ill equipped, which will make it extremely difficult for them to complete the formalities under this Act,” Baghel said. “ CAA appears to be damaging the core spirit of the Constitution — secularism,” he said.

Title: ‘Indira tried to throttle democracy’
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

NEW DELHI: NCP’s Jitendra Awhad has said that Indira Gandhi tried to “throttle” democracy by imposing Emergency , prompting ally Congress to warn of a “befitting reply” if its ministers were insulted. Awhad later claimed that he was quoted “out of context”.

“Indira Gandhi tried to throttle democracy by imposing Emergency. That time nobody spoke against it openly. But opposition started from Ahmedabad and Patna (with students’ agitations ), and Indira Gandhi was defeated due to the power of people,” he said. “Whenever a Hitler is born, he is afraid of intellectuals and students as they are rebels,” the minister said.

Title: Bombay HC returns son born in Pune to Egyptian
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The custody of an infant was restored to his Egyptian father by the Bombay high court on Thursday from his grandmother and aunt who have been caring for him since his Indian mother died two months after giving birth in Pune.

The court observed the 11-month-old had been in "improper detention" since last September and directed the police not to take any coercive steps against the Egyptian and his family when they are in India.

A bench of Justices S S Shinde and N B Suryawanshi said the child "cannot be deprived of his father's love for no valid reason". However, noting the care he had received in Pune and in view of the Supreme Court ruling that affection from both sets of parents is vital, they granted the two women visitation rights and video-conferencing access.

The father's lawyers, Navroz Seervai and Subir Kumar, argued that only provisions of the special marriage Act would apply when it came to custody of the baby since the couple was married under that law in Myanmar in 2014. The Hindu woman had met the Muslim man when he was working with a multinational in India in 2007 and they had fallen in love.

But his in-laws' counsel Sonal (who goes by one name) argued "vehemently", as the HC noted, that since the father is a Muslim, the child would be Muslim too, and hence Muslim personal laws would apply. Under these laws, the maternal grandmother can retain custody of a child.

The HC said it was neither commenting on nor deciding on applicability of personal law, but merely on restoration of custody to the child's natural guardian. "It would be harsh to brand him by a particular religion since he is of very tender age and not capable of forming or expressing his wish," said the HC, leaving it open for the maternal family to approach a family court to decide on their legal rights for custody of the child.

The Egyptian father had approached the HC for a writ of habeas corpus (an order to produce in court someone who is unlawfully detained). Seervai pointed out that it was a "settled law that writ of habeas corpus lies to restore the custody of a minor from a person who is not his legal guardian".

The HC observed there was "improper detention'' of the child by the maternal aunt and hence the father's plea is maintainable. Reacting to the in-laws' claim that change in custody would "not be in the best interest of the child", the court held that "the ultimate future of child" would lie with the father as his "only surviving parent and natural guardian". The Egyptian had neither abandoned nor neglected the child, was well educated and capable of taking care of his son, the HC said.

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: Tamil Nadu steps up screening protocol, orders blood tests for all travellers from China
Content:
This story is from January 31, 2020

Tamil Nadu steps up screening protocol, orders blood tests for all travellers from China

Director of public health K Kolandaswamy on Thursday said the screening protocol, recommended by the Union hea... Read More

Director of public health K Kolandaswamy on Thursday said the screening protocol, recommended by the Union health ministry, will begin by Friday morning.



The samples will be dispatched for further tests to King Institute of Preventive Medicine in Guindy.

Patients arriving from other regions of China would continue to be kept on domiciliary quarantine for at least 28 days after routine screening at the airport. All patients arriving from south-east Asian countries will be screened as per the new protocol, he said.

In the past one week, nearly 78 patients, including 10 Chinese citizens, arriving from China have been moved to home quarantines. A health inspector and a village health nurse visit them every day. “They will be asked to shift to a hospital if they show influenza-like symptoms. Till date, we haven’t seen anyone with such symptoms,” he said. Patients on quarantine include students, businessmen and employees of manufacturing and corporate firms in China, Kolandaswamy said.

The novel coronavirus, which was first detected in Wuhan, is now spreading to other parts of the globe. Kerala confirmed India’s first case of coronavirus on Thursday. A woman who studies in Wuhan tested positive for the virus that has till now killed 170 people and is spreading fast. As the number of cases is going up across the globe, the World Health Organisation and Centre for Disease Control, US, are monitoring the situation closely.

In Tamil Nadu, the health department has set aside a special unit with ten beds at the Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital. “Additionally, we have beds in Tambaram GH as it is closer to the airport,” said health secretary Beela Rajesh.

The department, she said, received reagents used in diagnosis from the Centre on Thursday. “We don’t have to send samples to Pune anymore,” she said.

“As of now, there is no vaccine for coronavirus but personal hygiene goes a long way in prevention,” said former city health officer Dr P Kuganandam.

In the wake of India’s first positive case ,the state has stepped up healthcare vigilance in border districts such as Coimbatore and Nagercoil.

Passengers arriving from Wuhan at Chennai and other airports in Tamil Nadu are now required to provide blood samples for coronavirus screening with immediate effect. Additionally, they will be put on compulsory home quarantine for at least 28 days.Director of public health K Kolandaswamy on Thursday said the screening protocol, recommended by the Union health ministry, will begin by Friday morning.The samples will be dispatched for further tests to King Institute of Preventive Medicine in Guindy.Patients arriving from other regions of China would continue to be kept on domiciliary quarantine for at least 28 days after routine screening at the airport.
